description:
Bravissimo!! I cannot get enough of this place.  One, if not at the very top, of my most favorite Italian restaurants in the city. Seriously, their focaccia would make my Nonna proud. I find every reason to go there - anniversary with my girlfriend, birthday, Saturday night out.  

The pizze is fantastic, especially the Funghi, - thin and a wonderful crust. As a vegetarian, I find that they accommodate variety well.  They are masters at dishes with mushrooms. The servers know their wines and never go wrong on the pairings.  The space is wonderful, touched with beautiful wooden tables, clean decor, and an amazing bar. And placed in the hip location of the Dog Patch, it provides a vibrant environment. Reservations are necessary, as it can get busy. 

Salute! Piccino!
author: John C.

description:
Oh man, where do I even begin? This place came as a recommendation from a trusted foodie, and every single dish that we tried was amazing. 

We came here on a Saturday night with a reservation (made earlier that same day), and the entire dining experience was wonderful. The space is beautiful, and there were a lot of couples as well as larger groups of friends dining. 

We ordered three dishes total, and honestly, I would recommend each and every one of them. The octopus is really tasty and if I had to pick a favorite, it may be the octopus. The funghi pizza is a safe choice for a larger group, and of course, it is delicious as well. Finally, the pork shoulder pasta and shishito was out of this world. Each time a new dish came out, we were prepared to be disappointed. We anticipated that the next dish would not be as good as the previous dish, and we were wrong time and time again.  

1) octopus, marble potato, smoked paprika, lemon aioli, cilantro 
2) funghi: roasted mushroom, stracchino, shaved garlic pizza
3) chiocciole, pork shoulder, shishito and gypsy pepper, horseradish 

There's also free parking which is an amazing plus. We ordered three dishes and the total bill came out to around $80. It is definitely on the pricier end of things (although really not that bad for the quality of the food AND every dish was a hit). Perfect for date night ;)
author: Teresa C.

description:
My friends and I ended up coming here for brunch, there wasn't too much of a wait when we came and there were plenty of seats, but I heard it can get crowded. They serve sightglass coffee here as well, if you like that!

We shared a basket of pastries, which was served with bread and marmalade and they were decent, but nothing too amazing or out of the ordinary.

I ended up ordering the guanciale hash and it was just okay. The guanciale tasted like bits of really fatty bacon or pancetta (or pretty much just the fat), mixed into the potatoes, squash and corn. It tasted fine, but it was a bit rich at times, and at other times it felt kind of boring

I ended up sharing the tiramisu for dessert and it was a bit of a disappointment. The cake parts tasted really dry, and were kind of hard and not as moist and pleasant as I am used to. The dessert overall looked pretty but didn't really taste that great.

Overall an okay spot, but nothing all that special.
author: Tyler T.

description: Came here for dinner with a girl friend and had a great time! I love their pizza. The crust is super thin and it was just the right size for me to crush the entire pizza on my own. I also love that I could add an egg topping to my pizza. Solid food, great ambiance. Recommended!
author: Christina N.

description: I'm usually not a big fan of thin crust pizzas but this place did it right! What I dislike the most about thin crusts is that they usually come out soggy to the point where the pizza is falling apart before it reaches your mouth. The pizza at piccino had a crunchy and chewy crust that stayed dry and not drenched in oil or sauce! We got the sausage and margarita pizza and they were devoured. We also ordered the boiled egg with pork dish. The spot has a really nice and inviting atmosphere with outdoor seating!
author: Sui N.

description: Started out with the lies antipasti that had fresh goat cheese (creamy) Meyer lemon compote and deflect noir dates. Very refreshing. Pork and beef polpette crushed tomatoes accompanied with Parmesan. And aglio verde pizza. All these items were new to my taste pallets. So I can't really compliment on there ratings. All we're good and the atmosphere was soft and non cluttered
author: John B.

description: Great place. Located in dogpatch.  Nice open space. Super nice staff. Magnificent cauliflower salad appetizer. Sausage pasta with breadcrumbs and fennel was devine. Marguerita pizza was good enough--although, it's certainly not the best I've had.  Probably wouldn't come here for pizza. Dessert was great. Wish I could remember what it was called. Kind of a butterscotch pudding with some crunch. All in all a very positive dining experience. Reasonably priced.  I will be back.
author: Tommy F.

description:
Solid Italian place in the city. Good service, solid food. My only complaint is that it's often cold in the restaurant on a regular chilly San Francisco. So dress warmly here when you come. 

None of the dishes were mind blowing but solid. 

Chicken mousse - pretty large portion. Wished that they had a smaller version of this to not overeat in the beginning of the dinner

Hamachi jalapeño - this is probably the best dish of the night. Light and flavorful. 

Salsaccia pizza - pretty good but very much front loaded on meat/sausage. This pizza could be balanced a bit more a bit more onion / broccoli rabe

Cortorni of wax and Romano beans with corn - this has more corn than beans. I love Romano beans so didn't dislike this dish but the beans were overbooked. 

SKIP:
Chocolate cake with gelato - this is more of a chocolate fondant in French style. Not as decadent as it's French equivalent. A bit too dense, sweet, and drier than I have had in the past.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Piccino is a cute little restaurant tucked away in a charming part of the Potrero Hill/Dogpath neighborhoods. Upon entry you'll notice the clean decor and it's symbiotic with the food they are serving. In fact, the restaurant has a nice European feel and I really appreciated it. 

To start, I split the chicken liver pate with a friend of mine and we both enjoyed it very much. Delicate and well seasoned with larger grains of salt made for a great starter. The trout caught my eye and decided to get that as my lunch main. It was seared with skin on and medium rare...perfect. It's accompaniment of shaved fruits and veggies was a bit muddled by the cream dressing but, was enjoyable nonetheless. 

All in all, it was a solid 4 star experience. Friendly staff, clean eating and in a part of town I don't frequent often so a really nice surprise.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
We made a reservation on Opentable, not sure what the normal wait time is. I've read reviews saying they are not very friendly, and sadly I feel the same way, the foods are okay, but 50% I'd be people who served us seem not in a good mood.

We ordered the Bianca pizza and the pastry basket. The basket has a muffin, a skinny croissant and a coconut flavored pastry that I like the best but sadly don't know what it's called... the Bianca piazza was okay, but we regretted not having ordered their pasta instead...

The service is not that satisfying, the lady obviously forgot we had a togo box for the leftover pizza, and I waited for a while after signing the check..
author: Xuaner Z.

description:
My husband and I live in the area and finally decided to try this place out.  Unfortunately we came at an odd hour where we weren't really hungry and just wanted a snack. We decided to have some wine and coffee and share the Octopus pizza. The crust was flavorful and there were hints of peppers throughout the pizza which was nice. 
The customer service and decor was really nice as well. We sat at the kitchen bar area and was able to view our pizza being made in the oven. Can't wait to come back for dinner or brunch. Very convenient that they are on Open Table as well. I would recommend reservations since it seems like they fill up very quickly and is a popular restaurant spot in the Dogpatch.
author: Cicely T.

description:
I can't come here and not order the salsiccia pizza!!! Other things I like are the pork and beef polpette with egg, Arnold Palmer, and sightglass iced coffee.

Their pizza is so perfectly thin and the toppings are just the right amount so that it is delicious.
author: Andrea T.

description:
The restaurant is like something out of a quaint furniture store ad, with glowing candles and cute chairs surrounding long wooden tables. Open kitchen kept things interesting. Nabbed a seat at the bar facing a clothing shop, which was sort of odd, but a talking point I suppose. 

The eggplant and pita was much better than expected-- the pita had just the right amount of chew and was perfect with the smoky eggplant dip. Allllmost felt worth the $9. 3.75/5

The margherita pizza, while nothing to write home about, had really flavorful tomato sauce. I wish the cheese had been a bit more melted and hot, and the pie could have benefited from a couple more basil strips. Overall, a solid 3.75/5

I'd be back if I were in the neighborhood!
author: Nicole H.

description:
Italian food can be a hit or miss, especially in SF (they're mostly misses), but Piccino is excellent! 

They have two pastas: one with meat (sausage) and one without. Both are really really good. 

Their pizzas are excellent as well, I've tried the asparagi, the funghi, and the blanca. The funghi one is by one of the best tasting pizzas I've ever had, and I don't normally like pizza at all. Most mushroom pizzas are made with those cheap cremini mushrooms, but not the funghi here, this one is made with better, more expensive mushrooms. The asparagi is the most expensive and unique one, but the taste was just OK; I would pass on this. The blanca one is good, but very garlicky. The best thing about these pizzas is that the crust is super thin. The worst thing is that there may be too much crust ends. 

Overall, an excellent Italian place, if you get the pastas or the funghi pizza. Prices are also OK.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The ingredients are so fresh and the Pinot Noir is perfect!

The waitress gave me great recommendations and service is excellent.
author: Julie L.

description:
All this talk about how good their pizza it made me crave their pizza.

I was told that it would be a great saucy thin crust pizza with quality toppings.

Um, first off it was thin but that's where it went downhill. I felt like it didn't have enough sauce, and the crust itself wasn't that tasty, in fact I just ate the dough with the toppings only and left the crust there in a pile.

The chicken liver pate was good with excellent crunchy bread and the focaccia was also very good.

But unless I'm coming here for bread, I don't think I'll be back for their pricey average tasting pizza.

I would have ordered pasta but even the waitress said everyone orders the pizza, so maybe I chose wrong.

Parking is difficult at best, so I'm not sure if it's worth the trek down here.
author: Jack R.

description:
Piccino is like a person who is both beautiful inside and out! Meaning the food, service and interior design all created a perfect experience. It was a Sunday late lunch around 2pm and my friend and I were able to get a table within a few minutes. I started off with a lemon shandy ($7), which was ok; tart and light in flavor. My friend's Luna Rosa ($12) was refreshing though! I should have ordered that instead. 

The radish, avocado salad was unbelievable, so good. Tonnato sauce really brought the salad together in flavor and texture. The crispy garlic was also nice but a bit too hard on the teeth. The funghi pizza with anchovy spread ($15) was light, mushroomy goodness. 

Service was nice, attentive and not overbearing. Interior was bright and beautiful.
author: Thomas L.

description: The burrata dish was good but the pastas were very mediocre (and expensive). Service was poor - hovering when you didn't need them, slow when you did. It was uncomfortably noisy. And to top it all off, it was really expensive. A small dinner for two with no alcohol and no dessert: $100.
author: Just R.

description: We were celebrating our friend's birthday here. The appetizers and entrances taste didn't disappoint us. The restaurant is well-decorated and has these beautiful glass windows. We enjoy our dinner there. BTW, it's not hard to find parking.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
A modern and trendy spot that unfortunately falls short where it really matters.

Setting:
We had outdoor seating which was nice on a nice warm day and had nice service.

Food:
I had the duck hash and tried the focaccia bread. The focaccia bread was fine. It's baked vegan which is nice for those who have those values, but unfortunately the texture was just strange and not for me. 

The duck hash was strange. It was overly peppered and just had a mix of taste that didn't really stand out. The duck had little to no effect when I was really excited to taste such a hash.
author: Vinh T.

description:
Salsiccia - pizza with housemade sausage, red onion, and mozzarella. The sausage was delicious! I enjoyed this pizza and also loved that they brought out chili flakes with it for you to sprinkle on if you need it.
Soft scramble - I really dislike overcooked scrambled eggs but this place really knows what they're doing. It was so soft and just ever so slightly runny making it a perfect scramble. Seasoned with salt and pepper sprinkled on top. The veggies on the side (asparagus and avocados) had a lemony taste to them which I thought was great and added a nice kick to the otherwise plain plate.
Overall, it wasn't anything too special for me and I didn't leave thinking I'd be back, which is why it's 4 stars and not 5. Nothing really wrong with the food, but also nothing having me craving more.
author: Jeana Y.

description: I was so excited about this place because its right around the corner from where I live. I'm all about quantity not quality, so when I received my small plate of cold sketti shells I was extremely disappointed.
author: Jorge P.

description:
***NOTE: This review is for the Piccino cafe that is near the restaurant***

Located in the trendy Dogpatch area, Piccino has both a full-service restaurant and a small cafe around the corner.  I would comment on my dinner at Piccino (which I thought was very good), but it was so many years ago that my thoughts are moot.  However, I do think the cafe is a nice space if you are looking for pastries/cakes and a caffeine fix.

The cafe is narrow, so I don't think it would be an ideal space for doing work or sitting for long periods at time.  At times, I've felt that the service was a bit curt, but it wasn't annoying enough for me to not return.  However, the chocolate marzipan bundt cake that I had was amazing, and I've enjoyed their espresso-based drinks.  I would recommend checking it out.
author: Keith H.

description:
We were actually waiting for a table across the way when my friends decided to come to Piccino for a pre-brunch drink and snack. They got here around 12:45pm, but I didn't join our table for four until a little after 1pm on Friday, November 10th.

*house made focaccia bread, olive oil ($3)
*burrata, roasted early girl tomato, hazelnut basil pesto, crostini ($17)
*luna rosa: cocchi americano rosa, margerum amaro, prosecco ($12) x2
*harmonic on the tiles ipa: mango, guave blueberry notes ($7)
*NV Sommariva Prosecco di Conegliano-Valdobbiadene Superiore (Glera), Veneto, Italy ($10 glass) x3

I basically just drank two glasses of prosecco and had a bite of the burrata. The cheese was good. Nice and creamy. The focaccia seemed standard. I actually ate it with the burrata versus the costini as I love my bread a little softer and with a lot of olive oil or butter. Our water was sweet. Even though I felt kind of bad that we only had drinks and snacks. At least I ordered two glasses of bubbly?

Nice place to kill some time before brunch / lunch. If I'm ever back in the neighborhood, I may drop by for an actual meal. Their pizzas did look tasty!
author: Elena N.

description:
Great lunch spot. I love how this place has remained terrific. It really anchors the dog patch hood. 

Tasty. Good service. 

Warm feeling in the place.
author: Why N.

description:
Came here with a couple friends for dinner. Located in the Dogpatch area, this joint is known for serving up Italian appetizers, dishes, pizza, and the like. We ended up ordering the following: funghi pizza, pork & beef polpette/crushed tomato/parmesan (meatballs), strozzapreti/squash/currant/pine nut/midnight moon gouda pasta, and chiocciole/fennel sausage/braised kale/parmesan/chili pasta. 

Ambiance: The restaurant is pretty nice with both indoor & outdoor seating available. Indoors was well furnished & kept and the outdoor seating was just as great considering the warm mild weather that defines SF during the fall months (warmest months of the year in this area).

Now onto the food! The funghi pizza was interesting. Personally, I'm a big fan of 'shrooms in general and this was indeed no expection (they're done well). The crust was thin but retained enough moisture that such was pleasant to eat without feeling like you were just eating pizza crust that felt too dry. Shaved garlic gave the pizza a little zest though there were so few pieces of such on it that its impact was minimal at best. 

Pork & beef polpette/crushed tomato/parmesan (meatballs): Favorite dish out of the bunch. Crushed tomato was juicy/soft and complemented well with the parmesan. The meatballs themselves came out quite tender/soft/yummy/full of flavor. Would definitely recommend this dish to others!

The two pasta dishes were alright. For the strozzapreti/squash/currant/pine nut/midnight moon gouda pasta, I found such to taste just like pasta despite the squash added into the pasta & appreciated the mildness of flavor. For the chiocciole/fennel sausage/braised kale/parmesan/chili pasta, probably the best part was the sausage, which was cooked to perfection. The chili added a minimal kick though I found this one to be a bit too salty for my own personal taste.

All in all, a decent Italian restaurant to consider although I'm personally quite neutral about Italian cuisine since I've had it so many times in the past. If you go early enough, would recommend finishing off with dessert at Mr. & Mrs. Miscalleaneous (my favorite ice cream scoop shop in SF) nearby!
author: Jack M.

description:
No. I wonder where they get there mozzarella from cus that's exactly where dominoes gets it. I got the only pizza with meat,  the one with the 'house sausage' and it was pretty bad. The red onions used were flat and didn't have any zing to it, and the dough tasted like thin crust pizza hut. I would've been happier paying much less at a pizza chain. I can say it's one of the worst pizza I've had at an Italian restaurant. The 2 stars are for the food,  nothing else really matters to me. The meat was OK,  although it did feel like Walmart ground beef sauted, which Id say is decent but nothing to shout about. 

I won't take stars out for the service but I feel it can be improved. The waiter/waitress had a hard time remembering and telling what the specials were. I don't blame them, as it was noisy and had 7 ingredients each. Do the practical thing people, just print it out.
author: Mackie M.

description:
We went here for a late lunch. Staff is friendly. Ordered the focaccia with oil, margherita pizza and the funghi pizza. If you are a hardcore mushroom fan like me then you will appreciate this funghi pizza. Apparently this pizza is made with 14 different types of mushrooms!!! We also loved the margherita pizza. The sauce was fresh and very well balanced between sweet and tangy. The focaccia with herbs was delicious and extremely fresh. I highly recommend all 3 of these items. 

Also they have their own roaster next door so if you appreciate good coffee you should def check it out. My husband got the chai which was a bit too sweet for my taste. I ordered a regular latte which was delicious! Enjoy! :)
author: Nidhi P.

description: Yum! Can't believe it took me so long to experience Piccino. A really nice dining experience. Came on a weekday about an hour before closing, pretty decent service. We got the burrata, the octopus, and the sausage pizza with sardines.  Everything was so delicious! Really recommend the burrata! The octopus was super tender and perfectly cooked. The sardines were a bit salty on our pizza- but that is to be expected. Love thin pizza! Would definitely return to try other items on the menu!
author: Vivian D.

description: My wife and I stopped in here after visiting the Recchuiti Chocolate Lab just down the street. Wife said she wasn't hungry so we got two side plates and a pizza. I got a fabulous yellow fin tuna dish with basil seeds and some kind of citrus dressing. Wife got a radish dish with something like hummus & avocado. See photos. Why impressed me was each bite was not only delicious but also delightfully different from anything I had tried before. I forgot to mention the focaccia, which is made right there & served warm with superb olive oil. Slurp! The pizza was also stellar and made with a variety of mushrooms. I finished off with a butterscotch bundino, kind of like custard only better, plus a Gibraltar coffee drink. I generally don't like milk mixed wit coffee, but I was intrigued - 2 shots of espresso with just a wee bit of steamed milk. I enjoyed both! The service was excellent and welcoming. We will be back.
author: Tom M.

description: I just got to this place and I'm impressed. Friendly staff, open kitchen serving BEAUTIFULLY crafted food. I can see the entire kitchen from my counter seat. The chef greater me & suggested the soup. Absolutely will come again.
author: Liz F.

description:
I've been on an Italian kick lately. Who needs more carbs? Apparently me. With so many Italian restaurants in the Bay Area, I can't believe I've waited this long to visit this popular one. After my delicious dinner there, I'm really kicking myself for not going sooner. It's truly a neighborhood gem. 

Piccino is located on Minnesota Street in the Dogpatch area of San Francisco. I actually really love this area of the city. It's not heavily crowded and my favorite ice cream shop, Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous is just a few blocks away! Parking is fairly easy on the streets. There's plenty of non-metered spaces everywhere. 

As one walks up to the yellow outer façade, one can already feel the casual hipster feel of this restaurant. Small tables of two line the side of the building, giving off a cozy and friendly vibe. The interior consists of an open dining room with a high ceiling which is filled with large orbes as lighting. There's also a bar area which looks into their open kitchen where all the chefs work together in harmony. This seems like the perfect place for a casual date or a group get together. We ordered our food and received them within a few minutes. Our server was nice and patient. They serve Sightglass Coffee too! That's definitely a plus in my book. Each item we ordered was really good, with the exception of the dessert. If it wasn't for that, this would be a five star review. 

Seared Octopus : This was a wonderful surprise! I didn't know octopus could taste this amazing. It wasn't rubbery or overdone. The exterior had a crispness while the interior was soft. The fingerling potatoes added another texture also. I would definitely order this again. 

Salsiccia : I took a chance on this as I really like a good Sicilian style pizza. It came out just as I imagined; crunchy thin crust with a good amount of their house made sausage spread evenly all over each slice. (That's one of my pet peeves. I need to have every ingredient spread evenly on each slice. : ))

Grapefruit Float : Yes, it does say on the menu that it's Candied Grapefruit ice cream, but I really couldn't taste any of it. To me, it was just like plain Vanilla ice cream sitting in soda water. It wasn't worth the $8 price.
author: Julie W.

description:
Damn good funghi pizza. Instead of sauce, they use a mushroom spread. 
 I don't know what they did to bring that much mushroom umami, but dang it is good.   Don't share. Everyone should order one.  :)
author: S F.

description:
Great lunch here today! I've been to Aina, Serpentine and Just for You without knowing that Piccino was in the neighborhood. The space is gorgeous and airy/bright and the bright yellow exterior is pretty iconic.

We had the best server who gave great suggestions for food and wine. We tried a grüner and the rosé. The rosé was a bit pricey for the glass but was very refreshing. To start, we had the tomato salad with cucumber yogurt and croutons. We then moved onto a charred eggplant pasta with pesto sauce and corn pizza. The pizza was delicious and I really liked the salad. The pasta missed the mark. Came out a little lower temperature wise than I wanted and there was barely any eggplant in the dish. The pesto and tomato sauce mixture also made for an odd muddy color. Execution just wasn't as finessed as the rest of the dishes.

Despite the pasta, this place really did impress and I'll definitely be back!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
2 stars because of the great aesthetic inside. Really airy with lots of natural lighting and flowers. Other than that it was meh. 

My friend and I had a reservation for brunch at 11:15 AM today but got seated early. We ordered steamed mussels and a fungi pizza to share. The mussels came out first as an appetizer and were really good! Really flavorful broth with bits of chorizo and caramelized onions, along with 2 crostini to mop up the soup. 

Then the meal dropped off: we must have waited 25-30 min after the mussels for the pizza to come. We must have been the first or second party to order but somehow our pizza came after tens of other pizzas came out. I REALLY wanted to like the pizza but I just didn't. The crust was nice and thin and there were tons of mushrooms on it, but the type of mushrooms they used were just...bad. They had a really overpowering, pungent foot flavor? I'm not sure how to describe it but my friend and I had to scrape off all the mushrooms and douse it in leftover broth from the mussels to be able to stomach it. It caught us incredibly off guard because we both LOVE mushrooms usually and we were pretty disappointed because I know they're known for pizzas. 

Overall, it was okay and a little expensive, but nicely decorated. I wouldn't come again.
author: Melissa H.

description:
No reservations on a Friday night? Yah, poor planning, but it ended up being a pretty short wait and they brought us drinks so it was all good. The restaurant was pretty beautiful inside in an artistically modern way. 

I'm in the habit of ordering food I either don't normally make but would
like to knock off, or food that I think would be too complicated or time consuming to make at home.

So we ordered asparagus and egg pizza, strozzapreti,  meatballs, and focaccia. 
First, we drooled and smelled everything. Weird? Maybe, but the food was gorgeous and smelled heavenly. It deserved to be savored even before the first bite.

Next we tasted...and then inhaled it all.
I thought we'd need to order more but it was actually the perfect amount; we were full but didn't need expando pants or anything to remain comfortable. I will be making all of those dishes at home. I especially loved the pizza and arugula pesto on the pasta, and all of them should be fairly easy to make.

For dessert we had strawberry zeppole (aka St. Joseph's Cake, even though I think St Joseph's Day is in March?) These are like beignets...and I've never met a beignet I didn't love. Yum! And no, I'm not even going to try to knock that off. Daughter who is way more into duplication of difficult foods has plans.
:)

The service was great....we had a darling and classy waitress with a ready smile. Toward the end of our meal she sat a large party next to us at our shared table. The other party clearly didn't want us there (death looks/scooting their chairs into us, elbowing even though there was actually a ton of room) which made the last few minutes of an otherwise excellent meal uncomfortable. 

I don't blame the restaurant for that, but just think it deserves a mention in case you are someone who doesn't want to share tables ( if you are not okay sharing please don't! There are options here! You don't have to share if you're willing to wait a bit longer. Please don't ruin someone else's meal;  that's just mean!!)

With the exception of the last ten minutes of our meal, it was all very very good. We will be back. This is my kind of restaurant.
author: El B.

description:
Much delayed review of Piccino. Everything was fantastic, from food to service and many unique items to try here. 

Met up with a girlfriend here and we shared:
- Squash pizza - killer pesto base. I really want to try making this at home. 
- Squid ink pasta with crab - spot on flavor profile, balanced by the pungency of the squid ink and the sweetness of the crab
- Octopus - a bit stingy on portion size though
author: Mary F.

description: Oh my god. Like, oh my god. I'm not religious but holy Heavenly Father hallow be thy name this restaurant is incredible. I ordered the chiocciole with pork, and it was without a doubt the best pasta I have ever had. For the price, which is modest for San Fran, it was a truly incredible dish. The atmosphere was great: lots of light and easy music. The service was the kind you'd find in a much more expensive restaurant. I'm speechless from here; just visit and enjoy. You won't regret it.
author: Michael B.

description:
Guy at counter service with ponytail is really rude. My takeout order took forever! Should of called it in two hours in advance. Don't recommend. There's better places to spend your money.

Update - I thought I would try them again and this time it was a big guy with wrinkled clothes who came out to say they forgot to start the order and would be a while without an apology. This place is terrible.
author: Mike R.

description:
Whole: So glad I'd made a reservation for our annual SF trip! Not to mention the airy, earthy interior, the simple, natural combinations of ingredients reflected the beauty of delicacy. I can taste the urge of extracting the humble ingredients to their greatest performance. In addition, the service is utterly pleasant. Our server is very attentive and nice, assuring us to have a wonderful dining experience.

Food: My family order several dishes to share, from appetisers to desserts. First, the salad and the soup coordinate with the seasonal ingredients, like pears and nutmeg, warming up our appetite for the coming goodness. For the entrees, we ordered two pasta and one pizza. Both the pasta are the most outstanding ones I've tried! The al dente noodles and the refreshing sauce dance on one's taste buds. For the pizza, I'm a fan of their thin, crispy crust. Topped with the fresh ingredients and stringy cheese, the pizza conjure a graceful magic in my mouth. Fo desserts, we had the roasted pear, an elevated version of apple crisp, and brown butter hazelnut cake. I am pretty surprised to see how the pears plays out in the classic apple crisp. Yet, this dessert is on the sweet side, while the cake gives milky and creamy texture. Both desserts mark a perfect ending of our meals.
author: Jui Han Y.

description:
Delightful spot with street parking, diagonal to Aina. Piccino is neat. It is popular for a reason. It's seasoned and affordable. 

My girlfriends and I came here for brunch because we do this often. And each time we try to find some other place to eat just so that we can vary our dining lives. Not all of them are winners but this one is.

I like the idea of shared plate. Pizza is always a good way to finish a big meal, but the salads are amazing and should be good to start. We had a bottle of Piseco, not bad. People tend to do family style here which makes it more fun as we got to share a lot of dishes. 

We ordered two desserts both were good and not too heavy.

This is not the most expensive place on earth. With all that goodies, we paid a fraction of what we usually would pay. Three hours of quality girls time to catch up on the latest and greatest PTA related drama and dissing women we don't know. There is a sense of cattiness that still persists even as we entered the middle age. But hey who's counting? Blame on the good food and wine.

This is one of the best places we've been to for girls brunch out. A perfect mid day spent with my perfectly flawed best of the best girlfriends. Thanks for making our brunch so memorable.
author: Victoria E.

description:
What a lovely place for an intimate dinner with a partner. The ambiance and service here are top-notch.

We started with coffee (it was a long day) and an aperitif, both great. They brew Sightglass here and have some nice drinks besides just house coffee. 

The cheese plate was paired with some delicious bread (which they kept coming, yay) and oh, oops, we love cheese so we did the burrata, too-- which was the perfect mix of flavors. I could have eaten more of that as an entire meal.

Also got the chicken and the margherita pizza, which were both-- shocker-- to die for. I have no complaints about the environment they've created here. Really is a great place to feel cozy and full, but still chic. ;)
author: Aidan S.

description:
Very fancy and tasty Italian food, though you pay for it.

The cheese plate appetizer had a very tasty cheese and some fresh, warm, amazing zucchini bread, with a strawberry rhubarb jam that I could have just eaten straight. The portion was a bit small.

We also had the homemade sausage pizza which was decent-sized, and the homemade sausage was very tasty, a bit on the underdone side (which I liked) and had a great flavor and a bit of a spicy kick. The other pizza toppings were raw red onion and some cheese, all on a pretty thin and crispy crust. So overall the pizza was only OK and a bit boring, the sausage was great and it was at least a reasonable size.

We also split the strozzapreti pasta dish that was sweet, savory, creamy, and extremely unique. It was a bit small, but really flavorful and tasty and different than pretty most other pasta dishes I've ever had.

For dessert we had the butterscotch budino which was light, fluffy, creamy, sweet (but not too sweet), and the perfect light and tasty dessert after a big meal

The wine selection was large and reasonably priced.

The ambiance was nice and the waitstaff were friendly and attentive. While the food was unique and mostly very flavorful, I wasn't blown away (and would definitely not get a pizza again) and the price was a bit high.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Wait - Reservation for brunch.

Value - $15 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium sized. 

Seared Octopus - This is a must order. The octopus is cooked perfectly with a nice char on the outside with a buttery finish on the inside. The flavor of the octopus is complimented well by the refreshing medley of vegetables and potatoes. 

Burrata - I'm not a huge fan of their version of burrata. I prefer burrata with tomatoes and served on grilled toast. Piccino's version looks and tastes more like a salad. Albeit a tasty and refreshing salad. 

Bianca - By far the best pizza of the meal. This thin crust pizza is really cheesy and each of the different types of cheeses can be tasted. The shaved garlic is a nice touch adding a bit of kick to each bite. 

Funghi - I wish the topping on this pizza was placed on the Bianca. The funghi pizza lacks the cheesy flavor which I believe should be the core component of every pizza. Nevertheless, the mushroom flavor is prominent and quite tasty. 

Figura - We were adventurous and wanted to try fig on a pizza. The combination of the blue cheese and fig is great but maybe not so much on a pizza.

Apricot Shrub - The perfect refreshing drink for a hot day. The drink tastes like it's made from fresh apricots and it's not overly sweet. 


"Less is More" seems to be the core concept of Piccino. They take this idea to create refreshingly simple and light dishes. Each dish is very well executed with a perfect balance of heavy and light elements. However I do think some dishes, such as the Funghi pizza, may have been stripped too much. I do wish I had a chance to try their pasta to see how they applied the "less is more" concept.

Piccino's interior is much like their food - light and refreshing. The interior is a well designed modern space with lots natural light throughout. The wood furniture adds a nice touch of warmth and makes the whole space feel very Scandinavian (hygge). On a good day, Piccino offers outside seating if you choose to dine al fresco. The whole experience feels very coherent as both the interior space and the food are one and the same. 

What I enjoy most about Piccino's is that you'll leave feeling full but not in a food coma.
author: Julian L.

description:
What a find!  Killer breakfast/brunch/lunch spot for weekends that is uncrowded, ungreasy and unbelievably good. 

Think of a great dinner spot with an inspired menu of delicious dishes made from first-rate fresh healthy ingredients, new but not whacked-out combinations and preparations...then apply those ideas to brunch and you're getting the Piccino picture. 

The space is light and airy and the seats are comfy for lingering. The coffee is excellent. The service is so helpful and friendly. You can sit inside or outside in the sunshine. They serve wine and bubbles too. 

I had the soft scramble and the cheese plate with zucchini bread, and both were excellent. Preparation was flawless. 

And, Dogpatch?...who knew it could be so comforting!!
author: Lanny B.

description:
I'm usually disappointed with the taste and pricing of Italian restaurants but I wasn't with Piccino. Although this place is definitely on the pricier side, I thought it was worth it. The venue is very large with a lot of seating so we were able to get a table for dinner even without a reservation on a Saturday evening. I like it when places aren't terribly full and when there is a lot of natural light. The staff here all very friendly and welcoming, which improved our dining experience for sure.

We started off with some bread with olive oil dip. It was delicious but I wish the portion were bigger! It just left me wanting more but it also wasn't very special. The main entrees were definitely the much more unique. We ordered a shell pasta dish with sausage and different vegetables and a white pizza. The pizza was so tasty and delicious. Although I hate paying a lot for fancy artisan pizzas, this one was so good that I felt it was worth it. The egg in the middle was cooked to perfection and was a nice addition to the pizza. I mostly enjoyed the shell pasta dish. The flavor was so powerful and rich but just kept you wanting more. I don't even know the flavor but it was so unique and unlike anything I've ever tasted!
author: Catherine S.

description:
Wow Great experience here!!! The owners truly are amazing and gave my dad a memorable birthday! Food is amazing and a great spot for brunch. I Came here with a group of 10. Service was on point! 

We ordered the 2 mushroom pizzas, sausage pizza, and the margherita pizza to share for the table and then I ordered the baked egg for my entree.The ingredients were so fresh and of high quality. You could taste it! 

Mushroom pizza 5 stars: not usually a fan of just meatless pizzas but this one was amazing. Many different types of mushrooms on it with some fresh mozzarella. I love thin crust pizzas and these were defintely some of the best in the city. Very light pizzas. mmm soo good!

Sausage 5 stars: also very fresh ingredients and I believe homemade sausage. Very flavorful and would definitely order this again. 

Margherita 4.5 stars: only giving it 4.5 because the other two were so good! this would be a 5 though if comparing it to other Margherita pizzas in the city. Definitely just as good as Tony's famous margherita pizza.  

I will most definitely be coming here again. The management is amazing and you can tell they really care about people! If you have not yet come check this place out!
author: Mel S.

description:
Waaaaaay overpriced.
Went here for brunch and got a baked egg for ~ $18.
After waiting for along time, I received a tiny little bowl of food, which basically consisted of just some tomato sauce over an egg.  

Super disappointing, since the interior of the restaurant is so nice.
Won't be coming here again.
author: Micah D.

description: It was a very nice location. I wish there were more pasta options but the food was excellent. Nice way to spice up the DogPatch
author: Danny P.

description:
This is a really nice place for lunch or dinner for 1 or 10. There is nice bar seating around the kitchen and large community tables for larger parties! It's a really nice, warm, well lite space! We had a 6 olock reservation and the Restaurant  was completely full but the middle of our dinner but wasn't too noisy or loud. We didn't have to yell to talk to one another. 

I love that there is a daily menu. There are lots of great options and there is something for everything. We went for more vegetables. We have two salads, a pasta and fish. Everything was really tasty, fresh and light! The puntarelle salad we had was nice and it was finished with shaved tuna heart on top but it was a bit over dressed! The beets weren't that special but tasted good. The entrees however were excellent! Strozzapreti which was a sauce of squash and pine nut and I'm not sure what else topped with cheese and it was amazing!!! Lots of depth of flavor and flavors that went so well together. It was cozy and delicious yet elegant. Then we had the sea bass which was perfectly cooked and paired with chick peas and sun chokes and citrus. Great flavor profiles there too! 
The service was excellent as well! Our server was great!! Looking forward to going back again or dinner and brunch!
author: Andrea W.

description:
EVENT: It's Easter weekend and we have some special guest visiting from SoCal! That's right! My FAM-BAM is here!!!! Time to EAT! Located in such a cute little yellow house-like place! Where's the entrance? Finally found it on the other side! Love the atmosphere - the indoor seating with so much light! And, and.. the outdoor... so perfect for summertime! Def will come back just to check out the outdoor seating area! 5 stars!

SERVICE: WONDERFUL... again... WONDERFUL SERVICE! BEST I HAD! Forgot server girl's name... but WONDERFUL! Soooo helpful with picking dishes, wine, and such excellent recommendation! Ask your server she/he knows it best! I LOVE HER! 5 stars!

HERE'S WHAT WE GOT:
(1) Octopus, $19: seared perfectly served with potatoes! Sauce was like BAM! Citrus flavors!
(2) Chiocciole, $22: it's a pasta dish, kale, some minced up sausage, and a tint of spice!
(3) Pork & Beef Polpette, $18: such fresh meatballs in tomato sauce and parmesan! SO GOOD!
(3) Funghi Pizza, $17: MY FAVSSSS!!!! SO much mushrooms... sooooooooooo much mushrooms in a thin crust! 

DRINKS:
Had a glass of lovely wine, $15 - server helped me pick it out... and wow! She knows best!
Lemon Shandy, $7 - house made lemonade with some beer! MMmm! 

*MUST GET: FUNGHI PIZZA!

**OVERALL: service excellent and food excellent!!! 5 stars and beyond!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
This is a nice place with friends and also with a significant other because it is so homey but also nicely decorated for a romantic feel. Also has seating outside of their cute yellow building. Great for warm nights.

I love their pastas. One of the best in SF. It does make me sad that their menu's change because I would fall in love with a dish and know that it would not be there again the next time I came. Many that I introduced Piccino to have agreed that their pasta dishes is well balanced in flavor, unique and wonderfully made. I always order at least 2 of their pasta dishes!

The funghi pizza is amazing. The sauce is really just a mushroom based puree. Topped it with sausage and chili flakes, and it was perfect. The thin crust held great and went well all together. If you love mushrooms, you have to get this! 

Dessert! That butterscotch is the best that I have had. Not too sweet and has a crunchy top... so the texture and the taste really made it enjoyable.

Lastly, I love the service. So attentive and sweet. Really one of my favorite places for dinner.
author: Anna T.

description:
The basket of pastries are amazing and very fresh. Got the mushroom pizza which was also amazing. ( in photos) Unfortunately it was early in the afternoon and I didn't get a Chance to try any of the wine so I just got the beer that they had on tap, which was also great. The portion sizes were decent ; the pizza was 12 inches and decently sized for two people who weren't super hungry. 

The decor and service was great as well -- my girlfriend loved the clean decor. No complaints there and based on what I saw, the restaurant is actually also very friendly for families and for intimate dates.
author: Calvin C.

description:
This is my absolute favorite neighborhood spot. It's yellow wood siding, it's amazing restaurant, and adjacent cafe and bakery, really bring character and  charm to a lovely neighborhood. I've only lived here two months but I know good food and I can highly recommend a few highlights: the octopus, the burrata, their lemon tart dessert, and their wine selection. 

FAVORITE PICK: The octopus dish. Octopus isn't everyone's go-to pick, but this one is incredibly tender and slightly crispy from what tastes like a combination of a brine soak and wood-grill char. It's over a bed of paprika cream sauce and fingerling potatoes, and shaved veggies. AMAZING
author: Paris T.

description: Outstanding food from this great restaurant. Worth visiting for breakfast, brunch, lunch, of dinner. The cafe opens early and has excellent ever-changing pastries as well as great coffee and tea. The pizzas are the thing to get in the restaurant, but they have an ever changing assortment of specials and fresh or seasonal ingredients.
author: James T.

description: This place is nice.  The food is really good. We had the funghi pizza and nettle pasta were pretty good. The zeppole was just okay.  They had local beer and I had the lemon shandy that was watery. I agree with the rest of the helpers that the portions were surprisingly stingy. My husband and I looked at each other bc it looked like a half order or a side - definitely not an entree size (even my Chopped standards ;)).  Service is nice but a little hectic.  You have to be proactive to order but attentive towards the end of the meal (surprise surprise).
author: Chris L.

description:
Such a good restaurant! My husband and I loved everything from the beginning to the end. The service was excellent. The food was delicious and really tasty. Great selection of wine. 
Love this place! I highly recommend it!
author: Ornella G.

description:
Drool worthy Italian food in the Dogpatch area. Went here on a Saturday night around 630 and it  was already packed. Had to wait a little for a seat which was fine (recommend getting reso here in advanced if coming on weekend). The vibe is cozy and homey and staff are all attentive and friendly. 

To start we had the focaccia which was super lightweight and flavorful. High recommend. The olives, burrata and eggplant were also all excellent. 

For mains I had one of their pizzas. It was a great classic Italian pizza with crunch thing crust and plenty of cheese. My partner had one of their pastas and it was also delish and perfectly al dente. For dessert, I highly recommend the chocolate tart with sea salt.
author: Grace A.

description: Prix fix for 9 of us was so  delicious and fresh every item we got was fab and well worth the cost the burrata  was so soft and creamy.  The two different pastas, one with fennel sausage and other with arugula pesto delicious, two pizzas margarita and asparagus with egg were perfectly crispy and filled with yum.  So much food and Great service too!
author: Wendy M.

description: Absolutely loved this food. It was so so good. Such great flavor and good portions! I am trying to eat a little bit smaller portions but I was still super full after eating the burrata appetizer/salad, the pork shoulder pasta dish (primi), the chicken and veggies dish (secondi) and a dessert (Tiramisu!). Our waitress was super professional and attentive (not too attentive either). I had an absolute great time.
author: Jessica L.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city for freshly made pasta! So good!

The pizza is also good, but you really can't skip their pasta. Sometimes they have a pasta dish with crab in it. SO GOOD. Get it.

Good selection of wines and bubbles too!

Be sure to make a reservation. This place gets packed and kind of loud.
author: Jaching H.

description:
I was here once for lunch many months ago and liked it alot - recently went for dinner and still like it alot.
It's a bit noisy when full but we're old folks so more annoyed by loud places than we used to be - oh well.
We shared a few things - all were good:
Roasted mushroom and garlic pizza - yum
Chicory salad
Polenta with herbs
Good service, nice environment.
a winner for sure!
author: Tina O.

description:
Never again. Tons of great Italian restaurants in the city without resorting to this one. The cheapest portions you can find. Never in my life have I been shocked by how cheap portions were. Usually I love small bites to try a bunch of other things. Their chocolate tart came out and my mouth dropped. It's the kind of slice that a skinny girl takes because "she's on a diet" and it's this ridiculous sliver of the actual slice. The waiter said it was because real Valrhona chocolate is used. A bag of Valrhona 100% chocolate baking power costs the same as the tart. Don't give me that bullshit.  

Here are some actual good Italian recommendations in the city: a mano, beretta, ristorante Milano, acquerello, spqr. Skip this place.
author: Belle B.

description:
A super cute, instagram-worthy brunch spot in the city without the ridiculous wait. The wait was only about 10 minutes for my party of 4 on a Saturday at around 11am. The decor is modern and sleek with a warm, homey feel. Our waitress was attentive and very personable. Now onto the yums!

~ Bianca pizza ($14; 4/5): this was a simple cheese pizza with great flavors. I love how crispy and thin the pizza crusts here are. The pizzas themselves are not super saucy. This pizza was basically just olive oil and cheese. It seemed more like a garlic cheese stick than a pizza to me but it still tasted delicious. We added an egg for an addtional $2. I didn't think it was worth it because the egg was just on the middle slice and didn't and any flavors to the pizza. 
~ Funghi pizza with added sausage ($17; 5/5): YUM! So many flavors and textures on this one. The added sausage gave that extra oomph to the flavorful funghi. When they say funghi, it's FUNGHI so if you are on the fence with mushrooms, I would not recommend. Like I said before, these pizzas aren't really saucy so you get to enjoy the toppings more!
~ Baked egg ($17; 3/5): this dish was okay to me. Nothing special and definitely not worth $17. It was basically an egg baked onto a tomato meat sauce. The dish just tasted like averge spaghetti sauce to me. The egg (which was supposed to be the star of the dish) did not shine through, 

Overall, the menu isn't that big so I wont be back to try other dishes but I would definitely come back for the pizza,
author: Annie N.

description:
My love for Piccino, the restaurant, has grown over the years.  Their seasonal and funghi pizzas are amazing for the generous and delicious toppings, and their desserts are the best.

I also love that it is family owned and operated.
author: Grasshopper R.

description: Friendly service, *very* good food.  One of our favorite Italian restaurants in the city.
author: Jose G.

description:
Came to the coffee shop while waiting for a table at aina across the street. My boyfriend and his father like this place for their coffee, but we didn't order coffee this time. Instead, we got an iced chai and a lemonade. For what we got, both were overpriced. The iced chai could stand to be a little sweeter, but otherwise a fine chai. The lemonade was SO SOUR. I generally enjoy sour things, but even I was having trouble keeping my face from puckering when drinking this. Definitely gets your salivary glands going if that's what you're looking for. If not, definitely stay away from lemonade here.

Definitely not the best I've had from a café, but also not the worst. However, for a café in San Francisco, where the competition is so high, I expected better.
author: Melinda W.

description: We came here on a Sunday noon, so they served us brunch menu and we didn't get a chance to try the pasta. We ordered two pizzas (Salsiccia and Ginger) and they were delicious! I personally like the Ginger pizza more, but the Salsiccia pizza was good too. They give loads of meat in that one! Sad that we couldn't try the pasta, but will definitely come back during lunch or dinner to try again!
author: Lily K.

description: Still a solid place for coffee . Parking can be a challenge although be patient it is worth it.
author: Manny G.

description: Incredible restaurant with true food!  A variety of foods n nice interiors ... we ate an assortment of foods
author: My Y.

description:
Honest people. Awesome food

Service sometimes slow but always worth it

Beautiful lighting and great atmosphere
author: Bored I.

description:
It's one of those places in the Dogpatch that people should definitely keep in their list of essentials. Definitely a place that has some nice exquisite food with a great coffee shop for the everyday goer. 

I would say it's a great place to grab some nice food that works well for a date or even just nice spot to grab a quick cappuccino. 

Mentionable Items:
1. Great coffee - Done in front of you
2. Focaccia bread - Bread that is crisp on the outside, but so fluffy on the inside. Dipped in Olive oil it makes it flavorful and consistent
3. Fregola Sarda - Good seafood taste a has a nice broth 

Overall a great place to grab some great food.
author: Frank O.

description:
Came by last night 2/28 for dinner, did not have a reservation. I thought I write this review to point to management that your hostess is the face of your restaurant and represents your restaurant. To leave my name, my number with your "face of your restaurant" on a not busy night and then having her give me a blank stare upon our return in 18 minutes time as she had explained (wait is 15-20min) , asking the same dumb questions if we have a reservation, telling my party it's another 20 minutes wait, blaming the tables for not leaving as if I'm complaining , I do not have patience for that type of BS service and sincerely wanted to walk out if not for my friend who's too lazy to search another place. Dogpatch is up and coming. Think I'll stick around in Hayes Valley where hostesses are actually young and bright even under the most busy circumstances. 

Btw your other servers are wonderful, this extra star is for them. Food is lacking in flavor, pizza was great. Would i come back? Not with her at the door. My first impression is already ruined.
author: Catalina C.

description: I've been meaning to try this place for the longest time but I'm rarely in that neighborhood. I decided to go this past Saturday with my mother, man was that a great decision. We didn't have reservations so we walked in and put ourselves in he waiting list. The hostess said it would probably be 30-45 mins which I thought was reasonable. We decided to go to the coffee shop which is also part of the same building and restaurant, ordered two chai tea lattes and sat. I think it was only like 25 mins when they called me that our table was ready, we rushed back excited and hungry. They actually sat us on the bar looking table with the tall but rather comfortable stools, my mother in the other hand didn't like that much because she's very short and feels funny sitting on big tall chairs...but she made it work and said towards the end that they were actually rather comfy. We had some amazing wine that our very knowledgeable server suggested while we enjoyed the view of people making amazing looking plates and enjoying themselves while doing it. It's a wonderful thing to see ppl love what they do. Our food was every bit of amazing, my mother was happy and that's all I could ever ask for. Those meatballs were superb! I can't wait to go back!
author: Patricia H.

description: Pretty much the best mushroom pizza on the planet.  My Lyft driver told me about this restaurant.  Show up early or make a reservation.
author: Christine D.

description: What an amazing experience, the things that chef can do with a chicken is nothing less than magical. the service is quick, and the food is delicious, l can't wait to return with friends.
author: tony n.

description:
My group ended up here for brunch after not being able to get a table at Aina or Serpentine. Hands down the best item we ordered was the basket of warm pastries. It came with 3 items, each fresh from the oven and melt in your mouth delicious! The seasonal plum jam was good enough to enjoy on its own without one of the vessels it was served with.

We also ordered the scramble and a pizza which were only ok--perhaps a bit overpriced.

Overall, the atmosphere in and around (near other poppin brunch places) the restaurant was perfect for a lovely Sunday brunch!
author: Dennis C.

description:
Walked in at 5:20 on a Sunday starving for some quasi healthy comfort food after a long day of shooting- I was not disappointed. After asking my very helpful waiter his recommendation he steered me towards a pasta which I honestly do not remember how to spell the name of but consisted of house made sausage, braised kale, breadcrumbs, and dill. Excuse my language but this plate was a god damn masterpiece- textually flawless, plate-licking delicious, flavors well balanced with some heat, perhaps a bit on the heavier side but hey it's pasta and we all know that's the goal. After trying my pasta, I placed a to go order for one of their pizzas to warm up later- I have no doubt they'll nail that too. 
A weird thing about me: Since i was a child I've always somewhat judged restaurants based on their lemonades. This lemonade is in my top 3 of all time, and trust me- I've had a lot of lemonade. 
Yes this place is bourgeoisie SF at its peak but you knew what you were getting into when you walked in the door. Smile and enjoy it! 

OVERALL: priced fairly for size and how spectacularly delicious everything is and I will DEFINITELY be returning
author: Nicole S.

description:
Food is insanely good. Service is... a little odd. 

Be sure to make a reservation - we didn't have one, so we got stuck in this weird mandatory waiting situation. There were multiple available tables that were fully prepped, but we were forced to sit and stare at them for 15 minutes before being allowed to sit at one. I swear to god, nothing was done to ANY of the empty tables during that period. It was totally insane. Felt very much like pretentious bullshit to me...

Thankfully, once we were allowed out of the waiting area, service was fast, and the food was next-level - honestly some of the best I've ever had in San Francisco... Which is probably how they've been getting away with that stupid waiting policy.
author: Rae A.

description:
Such a cute spot! Located in Dogpatch its pretty far from everything, but the great thing about this is that they have a parking lot right in front of the spot. 

I came here for brunch after making reservations on OpenTable and we actually got here way earlier than expected/our reservation, but they accommodated us and let us sit down earlier. It has such a cute ambiance that's very open with natural lighting, simple/modern design, and friendly service. We got a table near the window so it was great to people watch while we were enjoying our food and the sunlight. 

We ended up getting the basket of warm pastries with seasonal jam/butter and the bianca pizza to share. The basket of warm pastries was delicious! They had about 4 various breads to try ranging from savory to sweet and paired with their jam it was heaven. You could tell they were fresh out of the oven and really thought about the flavors they paired within it. I know they sold some of them at their coffee shop as well but for the most part they did not because I wanted to buy some in bulk to take home. The pizza was also scrumptious as well! As a fan of thin crust they really out did themselves. The bottom was nice and toasted just how I like it and topped with just enough ingredients without being overwhelming. How can you go wrong with parmesan, garlic, and chili oil!? They even bring you pepper flakes that you can add on top which was awesome. 

Will definitely be coming back to enjoy this place again! 

Head over to the coffee shop after to enjoy some of their homemade chai as well. YUMM.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Located in the dogpatch, if you plan on driving over, the parking spots are very limited. I usually come here for dinner, but the brunch is decent. This is a review for their dinner.

Bread does not come with the meal and the focaccia bread appetizer ($6) is quite pricey. There aren't that many pieces. I would skip this.

Entrees
Piccino's pastas are good though as the other reviews say, the portion sizes are small. I could easily eat that and their pizza by myself. The pastas are around (~$20) and I very much enjoyed the cavatelli ($21). Is it the best pasta for the price? Yes, if you don't eat a lot; if you are a voracious eater, order the pizza ($15-$25). I recommend the funghi pizza; I love the balance of the mushrooms.

Desserts!!!!!!
This place is definitely worth checking out just for the desserts.
I've tried everything on their dessert menu. The best thing that I have eaten here is the Budino ($11). The portion looks small but it's filled to the brim with this butterscotch and light cream. I was skeptical with butterscotch because it tends to be overwhelmingly sweet; however, this custard dish was perfectly balanced: crunchy, creamy, sweet, and a hint of salty. The chocolate tart and pound cake (~$12) were okay; they aren't bad but not worth it in my opinion. Their tiramisu ($12) felt a bit dry. On another note, they change the desserts every few months; there was a plum cake a few months ago that was pretty amazing as well.

If you get anything at Piccino, get the Budino. 

The only reason I took off a star was because the price was much higher for the portion size that I expected. If you are in the area, I'd recommend checking it out at least once. Maybe you'll get hooked on the desserts; that's what's got me coming back here.
author: Margaret H.

description:
Absolutely loved our dinner experience at Piccino. The Hostess, Lucy, made sure we were well taken care of and checked in with us after we were seated to make sure all was well. Our server, Kate, was amazing as well.
Best part was the food - the burrata plate with green beans, the arugula pesto pasta, the Bianca pizza, and the meatballs were all unbelievable!
We are a lot :)
Definitely a must try if you are in SF!
author: Hovik A.

description:
Seriously, you're gonna charge me $3 for 2 pieces of foccacia bread?  I wasn't cool with that...  Doesn't polpette require some bread to scoop up the sauce and to eat along with the meatballs?  The tomato sauce was bland and was more like chopped tomatoes.  

All the portions are small and the prices are pretty expensive considering.  The pesto pasta was good but didn't have the WOW factor that I was expecting judging from the presentation.  The pasta was topped with edible micro flowers.  Very fancy and again, it was a small portion. 

The biggest disappointment though was the verdure crude which hardly made any sense to me.  There were some mini radishes, pickled beets, and baby carrots that were ontop of a smear of beet hummus.  Multi-grain crackers were included, but honestly it was messy and hard to share.  It would have been much better if the hummus was separate.

Pizza bianchi was good.  We got it with the egg and the center piece was the best part.

The wine by the glass and canned beer or on tap is very limited.

Obviously a disappointing experience.  Don't think I will be back.
author: Seung Eun C.

description: Love this spot for lunch when I visit my mom in the City. Great salads and pizza and wine list is perfect! Love the interior and decor and the service is always outstanding. Going there again this week!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I came here for brunch on a Saturday with a reservation. It's a beautiful restaurant, lots of natural lighting, and a lot of wood decor which lends well to a brunch mood. The waitress was very nice and attentive. Things started out well...

I ordered a $4 orange juice, and when it came it was one of the smallest glasses of orange juice I had ever had. It was nice in that it wasn't too tart, but if I had known there would be no refill of that tiny glass there is no way I would have ordered it. Moving on:

I had / shared the salsiccia: their pizza with the housemade sausage. Very good. Light, flavorful, fresh. I really enjoyed it. The crust was a little soggy though.

The softshell crab: It was decent. I've had better softshell crab that was a little better seasoned and a lot cheaper. I'm not sure I would splurge on this again.

The zeppole (French beignets): I'm a sucker for desserts, so I really enjoyed this. A little pricey, but the beignets were very good. Fried perfectly and just the right amount of sugar. The caramel sauce with pine nuts complemented it well, and I enjoyed this the most.

Overall, a nice place to go with solid quality food - but in regards to price, I don't think it's worth it unless you're willing to splurge.
author: Michelle L.

description: The food and service are absolutely amazing. We have enjoyed every amazing bit and beverage. The only negative is how loud it gets in the dining area. Some soft seating or other sound attenuation would be greatly welcomed.
author: Sara A.

description:
Matt B, Server 3249, blonde beard bowlcut, your moodiness and sass are uncalled for and unwelcome. You would be more effective and more liked without the rude commentary. Don't worry, you still got your 20%. 

Backstory: We have reservations for 4. We come in and are sat in minutes. Wonderful. We sit for a few minutes. A gentleman says hello and brings us sparkling water. Great. Matty B comes over and asks if we want drinks. Already has an attitude about something. As we put in our orders he makes faces in response to our orders. My pregnant wife (33 weeks) simply asks for a Diet Coke. Matty Bowlcut laughs out loud and smugly responds "we dont serve coca cola products here". The tone he uses was condescending enough for the whole table to be quiet. All of ours mouths drop open and we all look at each other. My wife quickly orders one of their other sugar sparking drinks and moves on. 

Honestly, the meal was great. The food was perfect.  Pizza was great. Salmon was well cooked. Olives were delicious. 

Matty B left us without water refills for all of the meal until I asked a food runner to provide a refill. 

It's too bad that the only thing I will remember about this place is this emotional server's rudeness. And his bowlcut.

Sidenote: my wife thinks I should thank Matty B because of the amount of entertainment provided by his antics.
author: Rocky N.

description: Decided to stop by for a quick bite before my eye appointment and quickly ordered the scramble.  Looked great and the zucchini was cooked very nice but the eggs themselves were very salty.  I was biting into big chunks of sea salt or something.  The mimosa was one of the best I've ever had.  I'd come back and give this place another try with another entree.
author: Nyla K.

description: Food was ok, but almost all employees made us feel like we were intruding. No smiles the whole time.
author: Dustin S.

description:
BF, our two dogs, and I came here for a late brunch.

Pros:
-easy street parking
-no wait around 1:30pm on a Saturday for brunch (inside was 75% full, outside was 50% full)
-dog friendly: the waiter brought a big water bowl for our dogs
-food! I had the soft scrambled eggs, fried Brussel sprouts, potatoes, and I think tempeh. So so so so delicious. BF had the bianca (cheese + garlic) thin crust pizza and also really enjoyed it

Cons:
-service was so inconsistent/lacking!! I appreciated the waiter who brought drinks and water for our dog, but that's where the service ended. Our food was dropped off, nobody followed up, and we were pretty much neglected/forgotten. I had no clue who our server even was (some girl came up and took our order w/o introduction, and I don't think I ever saw her again), so just tried to flag down the nearest person to ask for the check. 

The food is easily 3.5-4 stars, and I would've rounded up bc they're dog friendly, but I'm so turned off by the nearly non-existent service. Maybe indoor diners will have better luck.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Delicious food! Their pasta was perfectly cooked and the food was beautifully presented. 

Also lone that this place is outside the chaos of downtown San Francisco.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Love love love !
Great place , great ambiance! Loved the vegetarian options - smoked mozzarella pizza , bittersweet chocolate tart, zucchini bread with 3 cheese !
author: Chetana K.

description:
A solid choice for brunch, lunch, or dinner. My favorites include the salsiccia (house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion) pizza, the polenta, as well as the pork and beef polpette. Everything goes down well with one of their quality wines. 

The overall atmosphere is airy, comfortable, and modern, with a large bar wrapping around an open-air kitchen, and lots of tables large and small. Service is also friendly. A perfect venue for a good meal, no matter what time of day or occasion.
author: Vincent L.

description: Great food and service, always friendly . I had the soft scrambled w delish roasted veggies and salsa Verdes. Be sure to ask for extra salsa Verde. Husband had duck hash and started w pate, I had a few bites of both. Everything was great. My husband had the tiramisu and gave it a high 8.75 out of 10 which tells you he thought it was great since he's a dessert snob. It was hells freezing outside (we were w our dogs) but they brought us blankets. Dog friendly!
author: Ottis M.

description:
Delicious place to dine! 

We started with a delicious rose (great wine menu) and ordered the 1) asparagus, pine nut, espelette, slow cooked egg, pecorino and the 2) baby lettuce, shallot, radish, herbs, red wine vinaigrette. Both were good but the asparagus is an excellent "primi" choice.

For meals, we chose: 1) chiocciole, fennel sausage, braised kale, parmesan, chili, 2) margherita: tomato, mozzarella, oregano and 3) and another pasta dish. All were incredible. Everything tastes delicious. 

This restaurant is nestled in the Dogpatch and is a great place for a well designed meal with great flavor and presentation.
author: Tara B.

description: Delicious funghi pizza.   Really solid.  It has this mushroom purée sauce instead of a white sauce, very strong premium mushroom flavor.
author: Sean F.

description:
Great pasta and pizza! Had the strozzapreti and funghi pizza - the pasta was al dente and had a very fresh flavor. I'm used to heavy, overly-rich Italian food, so this was a nice change. The pizza was solid - loved the thin crust, but a bit indifferent on the toppings themselves. Could've used some salt to bring out the earthy flavor of the mushrooms. I'd come again in if I were in the area, but try a different pizza.

Came here for an early dinner on Saturday (around 5pm) - parking was starting to build up. All the tables were reserved, but we snagged a seat at the cool/awkward (depends on how you look at it) bar area in the back that has a glass window into the boutique next door. By the time we left around 7, you could see the streets were packed. Come early!
author: Larissa M.

description:
I come to the cafe in the mornings for the lattes at a reasonable price, but MAINLY for the housemade granola and yogurt. It's so good and I can't get enough of it, even though it's $6. Just do it and make your morning better!

During the day and at night, I love the ambiance in the restaurant as it's clean and classy without coming off as too fancy. The food is great. The first time I came here was for lunch and I got a bowl of beef meatballs. It was a bit pricey but so delicious! The second time I came here was for dinner (great date night spot!) and I got the ricotta gnudi with wild mushrooms and also had some of the salsiccia pizza. Everything was so on point, writing this review I'm salivating and wondering the next time I'll be able to eat here!
author: Jenny L.

description:
*Been here many many times over the years and it's a pleasant experience every time. Consistency!

*One of my go-to restaurants for larger parties, for bringing out of town guests to when they have children with them 

*One of my go-to restaurants that have a good chance of reservations available pretty last minute because it's a pretty big restaurant in SF

*Some menu items change from time to time so you won't get bored

*Some menu items are always there so you can satisfy that craving when you need to

*Children friendly food items available: they can modify their pizzas and pastas to make it simpler such as leaving out basil, etc. 

*Currently, they offer Florentine Mondays of 21 day aged 34oz Oliver's Butchery T-bone

*Pizzas and pastas are always good for dinner 

*Bread/pastry basket with coffee is always nice with brunch/lunch

*Good service, even when we bring kids who are loud, fight, and chase around the table... :[  (we didn't know the kids would be so hyper... They're Not our kids!)
author: Iris H.

description:
Obviously, the pizza is the main event but the service is topnotch. Our server was not only very attentive, he was funny and cute too. (Oops did I just say that?! Yes I did). 

First: Strozzapreti
Second: Funghi pizza with egg
Drinks: a glass of Bubbly and/or Rose

Everyone near our table were eyeing our Strozzapreti and copying our move by ordering the same. It was a good choice, indeed. Funghi pizza was thin crusted and savory. Both entrees are served in big portions that would be enough for two parties. 

Happy eating and enjoy the finer things in life y'all. :)
author: Trish P.

description:
Such a great spot. Easy (compared to other parts of the city) parking. 
Funghi pizza is delicious - I even ate the crust, which I never do. 
Pasta was bomb - large macaroni style with bread crumbs, housemade sausage, kale, a little bit of spice, and parmesan. 
Grilled octopus with potatoes was amazing. It came out nice and hot, with delicious red sauce on the side. 
Service is friendly and attentive. Interior is spacious, and well done. There is a a few tables outside for when you feel like dining al fresco.
author: Veronica L.

description: Great neighborhood Italian restaurant - my wife and I came here weekly when we lived in the Dogpatch. The pastas are always excellent and they have a great wine selection. It's also relatively easy to get a last minute or walk-in reservation on the weekends.
author: Brandon G.

description:
Atmosphere: awesome and fun and spacious
Price: great
Service: awesome
Lovely and friendly
author: Mary N.

description:
When SF Chronicle restaurant critic, Michael Bauer, removed Piccino from his annual list of the Bay Area's top 100 restaurants recently, his stated reason for doing so was that the menu - which had remained steady and solid - hadn't kept up to that of the competition.  Unlike other places that got axed from the list, he had no qualms about the solid goodness of the food to which he'd repeatedly awarded 3 solid stars (different rating system than yelp) in 2011 and again in 2013.  

This is akin to those times when a longtime, solid employee is suddenly dinged on a performance review for not keeping up with the latest trend to which I'd like to say:  who cares?  Good is good.

Piccino is quite good.

I think we're beyond the point that we need to describe the Dogpatch area and how perfectly this restaurant fits into the neighborhood.  This is the place I'd live at were I a financially successful neighbor.  It's the place I'd take dates to and later, once settled, it'd become "our" place.  It feels simultaneously upscale and casual and though it's Italian, it's not old-school-red-sauce-Italian.  It's modern and whatever anyone else might be doing on their menu, Piccino's menu is successful in its own right.  Reading through it then eating through it, words like "fresh", "flavorful", and "lightly handled" come to mind.  The food isn't heavy but it's perfectly executed and terribly satisfying.  

A "primi" of cucumber, stone fruit, radish, mint, parsley, and sumac ($14) was delicate in flavor but a gorgeous mix of tastes and textures that I'd not have come up with on my own.  Is that not why we dine out in the first place?

Then there's those things that I surely could make at home, but not with such artful finesse:  A pasta dish, Chiocciole (with fennel sausage, braised kale, parmesan, breadcrumbs, & chili; $22) was satisfying, with a spicy bite, and though I'd probably have liked more I think Piccino knows how large a portion ought to be.  

Not on the regular menu - but if it is you must hunt it down and devour it - Ricotta Gnudi is something I've never seen or sampled elsewhere (take that Michael Bauer).  Pillows of ricotta cheese are somehow prepared like gnocchi and, hell, I don't have a clue how this is made.  I just know that Piccino's version had me longing to find this on menus all over town.  Should you find it on Piccino's ever-changing menu don't miss it.  

Desserts?  Service?  Check and check.  All is good here and I'd welcome a return visit.   

Piccino might no longer be on Michael Bauer's list but don't let that stop you from visiting.  On my list?  It's quite high.
author: Tracey A.

description: Fantastic Italian Food. Service was good. Food was quick and savory. Dessert was ridiculous.
author: Alex G.

description: Great fresh ingrediants, especially the veggies. Beautiful airy atmosphere that is great for late lunches. Great wines by the glass selection, but a bit pricey. Our go-to meal when we visit Dogpatch.
author: Laura D.

description:
Just moved into the neighborhood via Avalon Dogpatch  - open late & super great service. Loved the Pinot / Burgandy by the glass & octopus. Underwhelmed by the sea bass (might be overlooked a tad), should have gotten the lamb ;) love the dim lighting & view of the cooking
Nonetheless, I'll be back!

Came back & highly recommend their burrata with pesto (amazing sauce) & shell pasta with sausage (rich but light, amazing texture), arancini (rice balls) has amazing green sauce. Their zeppoles for dessert are delish! 

Reason for 4 stars is the cost
author: Caroline L.

description:
