A spendy place, to be sure. A very light lunch indeed with small plate of Italian doughnuts ( dainty and less than 10 oz), and a small European portion of farro and beans, 2 cocktails:$55. I was starving after the meal. No joke

We asked to wait for an outdoor table, and when texted, was told our counter seats were ready. Um-- misstep! I asked for lemon slices in my water, friend asked for sparkling water. Neither did we receive, at all.

I personally felt our drinks to be watered down. Wasn't my favorite. Think I'll continue sticking to this place for my coffee needs.
author: Jana C.

description:
Piccinos is a wonderful gem found in the Dog Patch. If I wrote out just how amazing this place was I would take up pages and pages so I will refrain from doing so. I'll just do a quick breakdown: 

Location: easy parking, lots of surrounding places to walk around too.

Atmosphere: lovely, relaxed, friendly, crisp, simple, clean. 

Seating: ranges from small to big tables, counter seating overlooking the kitchen and outside seats. 

Food: here is where they simply outdo themselves. The menu changes weekly and is always full of local fresh ingredients. I've been here (way too) many times and love that I can try something new every time. Be sure to try their Luna Rosa drink, and pizze with an egg on top. *see my pictures for the things I've had so far*

Staff: always polite and kind, informed of the meals being served and the drinks as well. 

Overall: FIVE STARS (and if there were more I'd give them those too)
author: Angela D.

description: Went here Saturday am for coffee.  Coffee is really good. I got two 12 ounces for $6....tastes great. Cute little spot in dog patch. Soooooo wanted the desserts but I'm On my way to my trainer so naw!
author: Jill P.

description: Everything here is delicious! Cozy restaurant and I love the decor. Service during lunch time could be a bit slow...but food is fresh and great, no complaints!
author: Lana B.

description:
Tips:
1.) for a light main dish, get the fregole sarde The broth is OMG soooo good, manila clams done right.
2.) for dessert, the zeppole is quite a surprise, being just a donut hole. What made it my favorite in the entire dinner was the vanilla bean cream with huckleberry that goes with it.
3.) and if you want a not-so-sweet but amazingly delicious dessert, get the matcha cake. The caramelized orange and the citrus caramel sauce on the cake is the bomb!
author: Kia M.

description: We found a fabulous new "favorite" restaurant!  Piccino was a delight.  We shared chiccolo with pork shoulder, shishito pepper, combo Di toro & horseradish and glasses of red wine and followed with gelato & ice cream and chocolate cake.  Sitting up on the high stools we were able to watch the competent kitchen staff, and  seasonable, fresh ingredients.
author: Sharon F.

description:
YUMM - Definitely a fan and will come back! Piccino is located in the dogpatch area so it's kinda hidden but not really. I love the setting and interior inside the restaurant. It could be a great date spot too! 

The food tasted amazing and the service was great. Super friendly and helped me on deciding what to order as well. Wine selection is great -- especially their rose wine. The pasta is definitely homemade and everything here is pretty much fresh. Whatever you get - you wont be disapointed. 

What I recommend: 
- salad: garden greens, shallot, watermelon radish, herbs, red wine vinaigrette 
- pasta: creste di gallo, lamb ragù, pangrattato, pecorino sardo, oregano 
- pasta: e linguine, pancetta, asparagus, egg yolk, parmesan 
- pizza: aglio verde: green garlic, potato, rosemary, garlic confit, stracchino
author: Jenn L.

description: I've had two experiences with Piccino and both have been really subpar. The atmosphere of the restaurant got me really excited and I've had people strongly recommend it. For our first experience, the food was decent but the pizza was inedibly salty. Our second experience, the hostess was SO rude even before we opened our mouths, our waiter forgot to bring us our appetizers, never apologized and we waited for an very long time for even bread, while diners around us were served way before us. We eventually had to tell the manager who did comp us a few items but overall super disappointed in the experience. I won't be returning.
author: Danielle T.

description: I love this restaurant so much!! Always recommend when people ask what restaurant to go to! Their menu is phenomenal, but seasonal so don't get too attached to something on it! Odds are it won't be there next time. But this is what makes the restaurant so great!! I love to sit at the counter that overlooks the kitchen. The vibe of this restaurant is so nice. Great for a intimate dinner or just hosting an out of town guest. So pretty on the inside, and so adorable on the outside. 10/10 recommend
author: Summer ..

description:
Fungi pizza!!!!!!!! Bomb dot com!!!

Octopus dish was so small it should be renamed potatoes with sides of microscopic octopus bits.

Great wine list. Lovely interior.
author: Janice L.

description: Not bad. Sort of industrial, literature and art styles. Several chocolate, bread, tea stories around. Good to look around.
author: Xin L.

description: I have to agree with other reviewers, the funghi pizza is to die for. I've now been here a few times and every time have had a really delicious meal and fantastic service. The only downside is parking - always difficult so makes the experience a bit less relaxing. That said, i'll be back.
author: Karen O.

description:
Piccino is amazing. I highly, highly recommend it.

My friend and I had no clue what we were eating half the time, and that made it all the more memorable. One of my nicknames is "Picky Nicky," and although some of the food looks like it descended from Mars, it's delicious. Some of the items we ordered included the bruschetta (cue aliens), citrus salad, red wine, and cappuccinos to cap it off.

The ambiance is wonderful - equally-suited to a hot date or a night out with friends. It's really lovely in there. My one and only ding would be the prices. They are HIGH. That said, it's worth it to squirrel away and splurge on a meal here.

A solid 4 stars for Piccino, as rated by one finicky eater.
author: Nic Z.

description: I used to love Piccino. I went yesterday and was disappointed to hear they have a new chef. The food was still good, but not as good as I remember it being in the past. Our waitress was also a bit cold. Friendlier staff would've probably made the experience more pleasant.
author: Silva Y.

description:
We stopped by here for a late lunch, took a stroll around the neighbor, and came back for dinner. Yes, it was THAT good. 

Currently, Piccino is my top pick for Italian pizza in SF. Everything was flavorful - from the crust, to the sausage, to the cheese. Lunch menu is a bit limited (to pizzas, more or less).

We ordered the burrata, squid ink pasta, and salmon to share between two for dinner. I'm still craving their pastas today...

Looking forward to dining with Piccino again. I know it won't be long!
author: Elaine T.

description:
This space is so nice & comfortable.  I can't quite put my finger on why, but I felt like I was having dinner at my friend's house.  This quality really sets Piccino apart from a zillion other restaurants in SF.  

The dishes are dreamily aromatic.  The sausage pizza was 100 times fresh & tasty, but I was disappointed w the crust.  I understand that the outside edges can be deceiving; they were appropriately crispy, but the rest of the pie was soft.  Thin crust should be firm throughout, yes?

But, the lasagna?  No misses here.  Fabulous.  The best lasagna I've had in SF.  Lighter than Italian Homemade, Marcella's Lasagneria, & Alimento (all outstanding in their own right).  The sauce was fantastic & the texture of this lasagna was absolutely pillowy, light perfection.  

Don't skip dessert here.  They bake/make all desserts in house, in addition to cookies & pastry fare that they sell at their tiny cafe next door.  We ordered the apple walnut cake.  A touch of spice, moist, & served warm w fresh whipped cream.  It was a perfect winter dessert.  

We stopped at the cafe after dinner, & got a bunch of goodies to take home.  After trying the lemon cookies, & the oatmeal raisin, & the chocolate chip, & the fig newtons, & the chocolate marzipan cake, I can say that the fig newtons & the chocolate cake are exceptional.  I also appreciated the chocolate chip cookies being adult chocolate chip cookies; less sugar, more flavor.

The staff were all great.  Hostess, waiter, bussers.  Our waiter was informative, personable, & never rushed us.  This space is modern, but uber warm & cozy.  The sunlight it gets is positively gorgeous, & the lighting at night is soft & soothing.  You can't go wrong.

The gem of dogpatch.

4 & 1/2 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Came here for late lunch. It was quiet and was able to find street parking. Normally this place is pretty busy....
Had nice cheese plate and mushroom pizza. Loved them both.
Cheese plate came with zucchini bread which was yummy. 
It could be hard to park but if you time it, not a big deal.
author: Akiko I.

description: Hostess was surprisingly unfriendly when my daughter and I stopped by on Mother's Day. My daughter was beyond excited to take me out for brunch, but didn't feel welcome. :( lovely place and the menu looked great, but we went elsewhere
author: Friea B.

description:
Came here for brunch on sat at 12:30am, easy to make reservations day of and really yummy food! 

Also can try their pastries and coffee from their coffee shop next door if you have to wait.

Must haves: fungi pizza & zeppole! 

Avoid: sauage

The mushroom (fungi) pizza was amazing! Unlike usual mushroom pizza theirs had finely chopped mushrooms and two diff types of mushrooms on top. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water.

The zeppole(donut holes) was a great starter to have. Perfectly fried, not too sweet and they give you just enough vanilla cream with huckleberry. Really opens up your appetite before the pizza comes. 

We also got the sausage which was the most expensive thing on the brunch menu. Really disappointing. First the portion was just one sausage. Second it was super dry. Lastly, the taste wasn't super special or good. I'd just avoid this $24 dish. 

Will be back to try the pizza with an egg on top next time!
author: Rohenne L.

description:
Was pleasantly surprised at the hipster interior decor (gorgeous wood) AND delicious food. We came here for valentine's. Sadly there were no specials, but at least they had fried brussel sprouts (makes everything better ofc). I would come here again just to order the brussel sprouts for $10.

We ordered piccino bread, winter citrus salad, and the pork loin roast. The piccino bread was meh-- it's just bread and olive oil, pretty bland imo. We wanted to balance out the salad though, which was bomb. The fruits they added were a great touch to the slightly bitter greens. This dish was very refreshing and all the flavors meshed tog. We asked for no goat cheese and it still tasted good. The dish looked very simple but the flavors tasted complicated. As for the pork loin.. MmMmm. The meat was tender and the fat just melted in your mouth. The crispy skin was the "cherry on top." Oh, and brussel sprouts just made the meal 100x better. We would have had dessert here too, but we were too full. Maybe next time, when we come again for the brussel sprouts!
author: Connie L.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend after he played softball one night and this place was actually a good choice. Though it is a bit far out from everything there's plenty of parking. 

Clams and mussels: 4/5: this was listed as an entree but it was so tiny that it was more appetizer size. There was only a handful of clams and mussels but the sauce made it tasty! It was spicy and tangy and just went so well with the bread accompanied with it. Would have liked it better if it was a bigger portion!

Farm egg pizza: 4/5: comparing this to pizzetta 211 just isn't fair cause it's definitely not the same. There was just one egg and it was slightly runny. The prosciutto and potato were decent on it but the potato wasn't as melt in your mouth good as I thought it would be. Overall it was decent!

Sausage pizza: 4/5: this pizza was actually the highlight! The amount of sausage was good, it was a bit spicy so it have a little kick. The sauce and onions paired so well! We kinda wished we had ordered another one of these!

Overall, a cute and modern Italian place. Would definitely come back here again in the future of I'm in the area! 

Total for 2: $70
author: Stella J.

description:
Chic, fresh, inventive brunch spot.

Restaurant exterior is the most smile inducing yellow. The interior was bright and airy, classy yet casual. I absolutely adore the open kitchen design (the little kid in me still loves watching the chefs at work). We came here after church service and grabbed the last two available seats at the bar. The wait for a table was about an hour, which speaks to their popularity.

They have a seasonal menu and I'd definitely recommend going off-course and choosing something you don't normally see! They use amazingly fresh ingredients and everything we tried was beautifully delicious. One of our dishes had watermelon radishes on it, how cute! And where else can you get a pizza topped with snap peas and pea tendrils? That's right. While you muse over that, I'm already making another reservation.
author: Deanna C.

description: Tasty food in tiny portions. Haven't been here for some time but not much has changed. The space is nice, the food is quite good (try the burrata) but the portions are small, making it an overpriced dinner. If only they would be a bit more generous and not starve the guests.
author: M K.

description:
Pizza was good even though the crust was a little bland. The vegetarian pasta and salad were super yummy, but the portions were small for the price (19 dollars for the pasta before tip and tax). This dampened the enjoyment somewhat. 

In general it is a very nice restaurant that has a neighborly feel to it. It's just a little pricy, even by SF standards, and that is why we might not return anytime soon.
author: Stefanie R.

description:
Great bunch spot! Perfect for large groups since the place is very big and they take reservations! 

The pizzas here are incredible (make sure to add an egg on them). My two favorites are the stone fruit pizza and the classic margherita.
author: Tanay J.

description:
Beautiful restaurant. Located on a corner a few blocks from Caltrain. Great wine selection. We ended up with a beautiful bottle of cab franc. We started with homemade focaccia and a cheese plate. So far so good. 

For my entree I ordered the gnocchi. What I received on my plate were 3 lumps of mashed potatoes. I was extremely disappointed by the texture and flavor. Maybe this is an innovative approach to gnocchi but I wish the server or menu had provided more information if traditional gnocchi was not to be expected. My friend had ordered the same and we were both pretty disappointed. It seems like dishes here are a bit of a hit or miss. Everyone around us who had ordered flatbread pizzas seemed to really be enjoying their meal. For the price I definitely expected higher quality food.
author: Yin H.

description: My most favorite coffee shop in the world. Though it's just a hole in the wall their lattes, cappuccinos etc are consistently great and pasties are habit forming. Only trouble is they let my coffee goddess Gail to take a vacation instead of having her work all shifts. She helps make this place as awesome as I think it is.  With her I don't need to explain my order, it's automatic:). At this time almond latte kids temperature and ginger scone is happiness
author: Sergio K.

description:
This review is primarily for the coffee bar.

This is right near the 22nd Caltrain station and just a short walk away. I really love all the little bites I've gotten here especially the biscotti and cookies, but, and it's a little but, the price for the size you get isn't what I would call 'to sell.'

One smaller cookie is around $2, which sounds okay until you think that mini cupcakes, which have frosting and a wrapper and sprinkles are usually $2.50/$3. But the cookies taste divine, and are incredibly fresh so they're priced just at the tail end of me agreeing to pay it. Just a scosche more and I'd be like $3! That cookie better be dipped in gold!

I'm apparently very discerning. But I digress, the service here is spectacular. Not only is Piccino about the only store close to Caltrain where they do not mind if you use their restroom, the service is always incredibly friendly and warm at the coffee bar. It really makes me want to return.

Even if I'm paying $2 for a delicious cookie about the size of a silver dollar.
author: Meg T.

description: I went in for some afternoon tea and the quality of the food was absolutely amazing. The tea was soothing and nice (recommend the ruby black tea) and the dessert (tiramisu and lemon tart) were a blast. Overall, the price was decent and the service was nice.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This review is for the little cafe attached to Piccino. Just walked in this evening and was treated with terrible service. 

The barista was incredibly rude to my friend. Gave us super stank looks and terrible vibes. She went out of her way to be snotty when she asked us if we wanted our sandwich for here or togo. We asked to have it for here and she plopped the sandwich that was still in the pastry bag onto a fancy plate and nudged it to us. 

What was the point of that entire snotty interaction then if you're just gonna plop a sandwich on a plate, in the pastry bag and all?! 

Never going here again.
author: Jerrie F.

description:
This restaurant is a gem in the Dogpatch. I rarely go to the Dogpatch and I was shocked to find this restaurant in this new and developing neighborhood. This restaurant looks like a house (yellow) with the similar architecture and very high ceilings. If you have to wait for a while they have a small little bar right next to the front entrance to wine taste while you wait.

For appetizers I would start with the Brie dish, which was very soft, tender, and perfectly cooked. For the main course the pizzas are the way to go I would recommend a very unique cauliflower pizza that blew my socks off.

Overall, I thought the ambiance was amazing, very homie atmosphere, and it feels like you're dining in your living room (in a good way). Get your moccasins and pajamas ready for this unique dining experience.
author: Kunal T.

description:
My restaurant master recommended this place.  
He was absolutely right! 
I tried many Italian in SF bay area, but this is one of the best! 
Their chioccole with fennel sausage, braised kale and chile was excellent!  
Boiled right pasta with little scorched sausage make very nice touch in a month!
author: Hiro M.

description: My friend suggested this place to go to for us to hang out and catch up, and I love Italian food so I thought I would give this place a try. My friend made a reservation for 2 on a Thursday at 12, and we arrived 15 minutes early since I thought parking would be an issue (there's a lot of spaces nearby and no meter parking!!). The restaurant has an upscale hipster feel to it, which is pretty common in this area. We were immediately seated and the server was attentive in giving us water and making suggestions. The restaurant wasn't initially that busy, but later on in our meal, the place was getting packed. My friend and I decided to share the bianca pizza and the salsiccia pizza. The food wait time wasn't long, and both pizzas were delicious, though I preferred the salsiccia pizza. My friend said this pizza was her favorite pizza (EVER!!!) and I had to agree that this pizza was really good. There was a nice hint of spice from the sausage, and all the flavors really melded together. The bianca pizza was so-so, and it was mainly a cheese pizza. The service was great and attentive, and the food was great. Overall, I would definitely come back here!
author: Lisa C.

description:
I prefer non oily thin crust pizza. They served almost perfect pizza my favorite especially veggies and mushrooms. Their open kitchen looks clean and very functional because I didn't wait time to serve my dishes.
This restaurant is the best of my favorite Italian.
author: Atsumu M.

description:
Dogpatch does it again. The new and growing Bayshore region of San Francisco will surprise you. Thought surrounded by warehouses and gentrified urban developments, the area has drops of delectable surprises. Piccino is one of those. 

Customer Experience: The hostess, Jody if I remember correctly, took our reservation for 2 though I called 2 hours in advance. She seated us at the chef's counter and quickly got the waiter to take our order as she knew we were in a bit of a time crunch. 

Interior: Trendy, open air, communal feel, and not pretentiously hipster in any way. The lights are dimmed to 60% opacity: perfect lighting to still be able to see your friends/loved ones you're eating with, but also just enough to get that intimate feel. 

primi: melon salad + avocado. An incredibly simple Californian dish, and tossed with just the right amount of vinaigrette. The serving portion was however a bit underwhelming. 
paste: strozzapreti with pork ragù. Get it when it's still on the menu. Just do it. 
pizze: funghi with stracchino. Funghi wasn't too strong, and the garlic paired incredibly with the stracchino cheese. You know its a properly made artisanal pizza when the cheese to topping to marinara portion is up to par.
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
Excellent food, gracious wait staff, casual atmosphere, delightful experience.
Definitely worth checking out if you're in the mood for awesome pizza (I recommend the Zucca pizza).
author: Natalie K.

description: It's very spacious and I love how easy to find street parking in the neighborhood! Came here for dinner with a girl friend. I had the tomato soup and rockfish as main course - both were fantastic. Didn't like our server (the one with short hair and piercing) that much, she always "checked in" with a fake smile and disrupted our chat. It almost made me think that she did it on purpose. Otherwise, love this place!
author: Shaz L.

description:
This review is for the coffee area.
The place has a restaurant and a coffee area.

The coffee was delicious.
I added only one sugar since it was so good and smooth.

I had the biscotti, yum
the chocolate cookie with sea salt, yum
and the cinnamon roll, yum.

My son and I came out very happy.
The guy was ultra-helpful too and gave my son a cup of milk,

Too bad my local coffee joints are nothing like this one.
author: Saar H.

description:
Better than ok, not as great as wow.

Came for brunch with my girlfriends - we wanted to try out a new place and the reviews here raved about what a "gem" it was. So we took a punt...

Firstly don't come here if you're strapped for cash, or hungry. Don't get me wrong, the food is indeed incredible, I just could have done with a whole lot more of it. The $21 I paid for one scrambled egg and an artistically arranged sliver of trout seemed like little much, and left me wishing I had ordered one of the amazing smelling  (and much larger) pizzas that kept getting carried past me.

Secondly - the chairs. Whilst we were told this is something they get a lot of complaints about, and that they'll be getting new ones soon, I couldn't help but feel like an adult sitting on a child's chair with my knees up around my ears. Granted, I'm not short (5 foot 10...) but even my 'normal' sized (5 foot 6) friend was having problems knowing where to put her excess leg...

Thirdly and lastly, we were unfortunate to be landed with probably most awkward of the waiting staff they have, who not only took an age to take our order, but then rather oddly hung around our table with a wide-eyed, half crazed look for the remainder of our meal.

Definitely an experience! But probably not one I'm going to repeat.
author: Jemma B.

description: Had a delicious el fresco Sunday brunch. The menu is seasonal and flavorful with a great selection of flatbread pizzas, and appetizers. We got the soft egg scramble with veggies and the zucca pizza, both were delicious, the zucca pizza was out of this world! Complete with squash blossoms and chilli oil and we added sardines for an extra kick. Extremely flavorful and just enough of a portion to make you feel full but not heavy. Service was excellent.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Swung by here after a yelp elite event nearby. We didn't have reservations, but were able to get seated at the bar pretty quickly. We walked by the coffee shop side, and was really confused, but turns out the entrance is around the corner.

We ordered pizza, the meatballs, a salad, and dessert! We did start with the bread and olive oil for $3. Skip it.

The salad had peaches and was a very refreshing salad. Very light and fruity.
The (sausage) pizza was also very good. Thin crust, very balanced flavours, and just all-in-all delicious.
The pork and beef meatballs were just okay. The sauce was okay, but this dish didn't really stand out.
The dessert was essentially homemade donut holes with a dipping sauce. I enjoyed this dish much more than I thought I would. 

The server was very friendly and attentive. We were able to strike conversation with the kitchen staff and they were also very friendly and informative. Seems like they enjoy what they do, and they kind of talked about their approach to the menu. Very enlightening and very cool.

I recommend this place, and i'll be back for the mushroom pizza!
author: Kaje Y.

description:
A hidden gem. Can't miss the location in the bright yellow building on Minnesota street.

Best Mushroom pizza on the planet followed by the sausage pizza and my wife's favorite fig pizza. Oh, forgot the Margherita pizza. Pasta was also amazing. 

Glad we went with a large group so we could have a flavor from many different dishes including the octopus and soft shell crab, both a must try.

Place is always bustling but any wait time is worth it. Restaurant is a decent size but tables are not crowded together like other busy places.

Service from the floor staff was excellent. Interaction with the hostess was very pleasant. 

Puccini really knows how to provide customers with a wonderful dining experience.
author: David S.

description: This review is for the coffee shop. We think it's the best coffee in San Francisco and the pastries are also delicious! (Made daily.) It's not a sit down and hang out coffee spot but there are lots of places to sit and enjoy your coffee in the area.
author: Urban S.

description:
*** In Short ***

Casually upscale Italian with tasty, albeit pricy, food.

*** In Depth ***

Despite living in the neighborhood, I've only been to Piccino twice. Now, that's not without trying: there've certainly been more occasions than that, when I've tried to have brunch here. Unfortunately, Piccino's popularity is not particular conducive to walk-ins or last minute reservation attempts, so some upfront planning is highly recommended.

And it's easy to see why this is the case: the restaurant itself is comfortable and inviting, but definitely nicer and somewhat upscale. This is reflected in both the food on the menu, but especially in the prices: when you're paying close to $20 for an entree with the likes of some scrambled eggs and sauteed veggies, you know you're probably paying for a lot more than just the food itself, as tasty as it is.

Because of this, Piccino will unlikely ever be one of my top choices for brunch in my neighborhood, as your money will go a lot further at other nearby eateries, but if you're looking for something a bit more atmospheric (say, for a date), or something a bit simpler and fresher, they're well worth considering.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Another spacious restaurant with both seating and maneuvering shouldn't pose a problem. The restaurant entrance is elevated onto a second floor, but there are both stairs and a long winding ramp to the right of them to get you there.

Bathroom - Still haven't tried them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I give a 4 stars because of the followings:
1- the food portion is fairly small and not worth the price
2-There is a charge to refill your coffee which is absurd for these type of restaurants.
3-Overall pricey, food wasn't a wow. You can find less expensive brunch places in the city with similar or even better food quality.

However, the waiter was nice and helpful. The ambience is good. Good place if you want to go on a date but definitely not suitable if you are hungry and looking for a traditional brunch place.
author: Alex M.

description: Lunch today with a friend. Started by sharing the soft crab salad special and a burrata with arugula appetizer. Followed with the asparagus and chili pizza. Ended with cappuccino. $47 each including tip. All the food was good, tasty, well-presented, arrived in a timely way but not too fast. Service overall was good. The only downside of the place is parking is horrible.
author: Michelle C.

description:
What a find...nestled at the corner of this neighbourhood. Ambiance is excellent with large bright windows and simple, elegant decor. There is outdoor seating which is glorious on a beautiful sunny day. We made sure to have a reservation for this place as it was quite.packed when we got here. Service was very warm and pleasant. 
We started with some bread, the white bean soup and octopus. The white bean soup was herbalicious and the foccacia was nice. However the octopus was the highlight among the starters. Beautifully cooked with a nice roasted aroma, it was a good way to start the meal. We then followed with the popette and trout. The popette was tender and full of flavour. Drenched in a thick tomato sauce -it complements it perfectly. Plus the serving was large. The trout we had was cooked to perfection. All in all we had a good time here and would definitely come back if ever we are in town
author: Keets Y.

description: Decided to check this place out. Was not disappointed. All were a hit. From salad to pasta to pizza. Drinks were also pretty good. Definitely coming back.
author: John Z.

description:
My favorite color is yellow. The restaurant exterior is yellow. I love yellow.

I glance at this place while passing by and I knew I would be in for a treat.  Started off with a simple margherita smother in freshly tomato sauce, mozzarella, and topped with basil. My secondi is the slow poached halibut in basil-ginger broth, garnished artichokes, potatoes, and a little bit of lime. Finally, dessert of zeppole with side sauce of vanilla bean crema, meyer lemon curd, and huckleberry all in one. 

A simple place, serving simple foods, with happy simple friends. I hope you give this place a try. Cheers! 

The simple things in life.
author: Owie N.

description:
It started with a wonderful glass of strawberry mint non-alcoholic drink. Extremely refreshing, set me in a great mood for the rest of the meal. 

We shared the burratta as starter, a perfect mix with peas and beans, plus mint and allium oil. It is probably one of my fav. burrata dish! 

Wholesome Italian meals, we had brazino, prosciutto pizza, fregola sarda, and chiocciole.

Brazino skin was beautifully seared. Fregola was cooked with clams, a very brothy, well balanced dish. Pizza was decorated with kumquat, which gave a freshness, balanced with the prosciutto. My chiocciole was amazing! It was al dente. The mix with braised kales and fennel sausages was nicely distributed, every bite had all the ingredients. The flavor was subtle, but complex. It is the most meaty dish among the 4, yet it was not heavy. 

Dessert-we shared strawberry crostata with basil leaf ice cream from mr. and mrs. miscellaneous.... This is where the one star went missing.. The pastry was a bit too healthy, pretty dense and quite blend. Basil ice cream itself is nice, interesting flavour, but with crostata almost making it savory.... 

Overall, loved every part of the meal until the dessert. Will definitely go back again!
author: Anonymous L.

description:
Highly recommend a visit if you are in the area. 
- A very San Francisco Ambiance
- Quaint dining room with what feels like ample seating
- Plenty of bar spots 
- MUST try is the brussel sprouts 
- If you get the Pizza be sure to throw an egg on the top
author: Roz B.

description: This place was a blast. The only real downside to this was that the portion were quite small. Their pasta and pizza are very flavorful too. If you like Italian food, I highly suggest try this place out!
author: Justin L.

description:
One of our go-to places for Italian food. This weekend, I tried the corn ravioli and it was most definitely the best ravioli of my life - it literally tasted like summer! The pasta was perfectly cooked, the corn filling was so creamy that I didn't miss cheese, the roasted corn kernels added a nice crunch, and the cherry tomatoes provided a sweet juiciness that complemented the dish perfectly. The padron peppers were a nice touch that added another flavor profile but the ravioli would have been fine without it as well. Not mentioned on the menu, but it's topped with basil leaves and thin garlic slices, which really bring the dish together given that the sauce is just a thin, clear sauce (note to vegetarians: it normally has chicken broth so make sure to ask for the vegetarian iteration). Our favorite pizza is the bianca but we also enjoy the funghi and zucca (seasonal squash blossom pizza). 

Piccino also has great dessert options. We were excited to learn that they serve Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous ice cream. Their current offering is the sweet cream flavor, which melts in your mouth and tastes like butter. We loved it so much that we had to order a second scoop after polishing off the first in a matter of minutes!
author: Janjri V.

description: An absolute favorite. Their menu changes a lot so you'll see there's a date on the menu each time you go there. I always bring guests from outside the city here, although it is a little bit far from the downtown area it is totally worth it. The pizza is amazing, I usually get the funghi Pizza with the egg and anchovies on the top. The processor amazing too, my fav is the spaghetti. If it's still the same the donuts are great for dessert!
author: Kevin L.

description:
We came here for brunch after finding out that it's an almost 2 hour wait at 'Aina across the street. We were promptly seated and we decided to split the pastry basket and the baked eggs. 

There were three small pastries and they were all warm. There was a small bread roll, a small (financier sized) banana bread and a small scone. See the theme here? Everything were small and the basket was $10. The pastries were good, but nothing special. I can make this at home. 

The baked eggs came next. It was an egg baked in a lamb stew. It came with two small toasted rounds of baguette. We asked for extra baguette and they waiter didn't bring it until the end (plus they charged us $1 per small piece). 

This place is so overrated. The food was very average and waaaay overpriced. Maybe dinner was better, but I get the sense that this restaurant is way more focused on where the ingredients came from than the actual taste of the food. I hate this trend in SF where everything is about which farm the produce came from and the menu is so blah. The food is simply unsatisfying and feels like one of those glass boxes that the flippers churn out throughout the city.
author: Alice W.

description:
The cafe was a disappointment, especially compared to how great the restaurant was!

My Housemade Chai ($3.75/$4.50) tasted watered down. There was a tiny kick of spice, but it barely amounted to anything. 2.5 stars.

My boyfriend's Latte ($4) had a roasted flavor, but it seemed to have too much cream that dampened its flavor. I'm not a huge coffee drinker though, and my boyfriend did like it. 3.5 stars.
author: Ziyan C.

description: The Italian food is here is very good sometimes dry but not too bad. The staff is great and it's very clean only thing would be they need to improve the quality of their coffee
author: Janiele M.

description:
This place is great. The food is always top notch.

Wonderful pizza. The pizza's are perfectly sized to fill two people up without making you feel overstuffed.

The salad's are always delicious. The kitchen takes a lot of care with selecting the produce and arranging the salads and it comes through. Always fresh, seasonal and delicious.

The polpette are a great entree if you are trying not too go too heavy on carbs (actually possible here unlike most Italian restaurants)

Good wine list and great coffee as well.
author: Daniel O.

description:
Hey, are you standing in line for Aina? Don't wanna wait two hours? Piccino's got you! That may or may not have been how me and mine came across this lil gem. Let's not dwell on this and instead acknowledge how good this place is! We indulged in both their coffee, tea, and Italian food.
 
For noms, we had two pizzas: one with sage and egg and the other, a basic margarita. If you love Italian style pizza, this place will not disappoint. It was good enough to wipe the disappointment off my face when we got turned away from another restaurant... for whatever reasons... it's ok it's not important for this review. Also, the donuts are YUM.
 
Piccino finds a nice balance between casual and high end dining, while staying kind to your wallet. OMG their coffee! They have a barista on the side who makes killer coffee! Like if you're in line for Aina and waiting two hours, go grab coffee from Piccino! But I digress, the food is good, real good.

YUMMER SCORE:    Food-8    Service - 8    Expereince  -  9
author: Ryan M.

description:
Piccino's is a beautiful place for a date. I'd say it's on the top of the list for restaurants in terms of atmosphere and ambiance. It's modern, slightly industrial, super bright and beautiful. I just loved looking at the architecture and light fixtures. Aside from how nice it is to have wine and enjoy great conversation, I'd say the pizza was okay. 

We arrived earlier in the evening on a Saturday and decided to have some drinks before ordering. Service was really pushy; they didn't like that we took so long to order our meals. She came about 4-5 times to ask if we were ready to order. You can tell they're working hard to turn over.

We started with the bread and olive oil. That was a waste of the few dollars on the bill.

We went for two pizzas - the Pizza Bianca which I enjoyed. The cheese was salty, dough nice and chewy. Loved the combo of shaved garlic and chili oil, although it wasn't spicy at all. It still had a really satisfying flavor. The second one we ordered was the salciccia. I was little disappointed in this, but it was our fault for overlooking that it didn't have tomato sauce. The sausage was plain and overall I enjoyed the bianca way better.

Also, my partner and I drove all the way to Dogpatch from the northern part of the city one night and they stop taking new customers at 9pm sharp. Is this normal in SF? It was really frustrating. 

Bottom line: boring pizza, beautiful place to impress someone, a little pricey. Service is okay.
author: Priti K.

description: good food, but some portions were tending toward the skimpy. pizza was good size as was salad, but the octopus was just 8-10 little nuggets. sea bass was wonderful but again, pretty small. roasted brussel sprouts worth a look. service was knowledgeable and accommodating.
author: Jon W.

description:
Been here a couple times and it looks like they've made minor changes to menu in between those visits.  It's tough for me to justifying paying so much for Italian food but I've never walked away from Piccino feeling unsatisfied or swindled.  Last time we went, ordered some spinach or arugula based wood fire pizza with added anchovies on it, which gave it that salty goodness to it.  The pork and beef polpette is so tasty that I wish we ordered an additional one for myself. Also, had the tagliatelle dish with pork bits in it which was a delicious something I know I could never make at home.

The food is so good that I didn't pay much attention to the decor.  Could be a romantic date place if you don't mind sitting so close to others.  Service is good but something in the eyes of the waitresses I've had there tell me they hate their jobs.  I'll say great job anyways.
author: Bailey N.

description:
Note: this is review for the coffee only.

My friend and I stumbled upon this place while waiting for a table for Plow and decided to go in for some coffee and snack a little since we were starving. The 12-hour cold brew was amazing! It's syrup-y and chocolatey and full of flavor! We also had the vegetarian slider which tasted a little odd... and also the savory scone, which was delicious. It's definitely a cute place to stop by for some coffee and treats!
author: Janet H.

description:
Such good pizza!! They have a good amount of vegetarian options and a fantastic selection of wines. 

We had the pizza with potatoes in it and it was delicious!! We split one pizza and a foccacia bread and it.was the perfect meal. Such a cute and comfy place to catch up and relax! I'm definitely going back!
author: Akshaya V.

description:
This place is probably fantastic during their regular hours. My 3 friends and I walked in at 3:05PM and were promptly told by the staff that their brunch menu ends at 3, and we could order off their "snack" menu. We were hungry and there was nothing else close by, so we got a table (right by the drafty exit door) to order. 

Our server felt the need to tell us again that "if only" we had come in 5 minute earlier we could have ordered off that full menu. Thanks. That's what we wanted anyway...I don't see any reason why the server would tease a hungry group of people about this. 

Now, the food we did get was very good. I had the bread and olive oil and the cheese plate and I enjoyed both. I had to wave over our server multiple times to get our waters refilled.

When it came time to settle our bill, we had 1 card and the rest cash. He asked if we wanted our change back, we said yes, and he kept it anyway saying it was "only a few dollars". Hard to calculate a tip when we didn't have the full amount, and I thought it odd that he'd ask if we wanted our change if he was just going to keep it. It was going to be his gratuity anyway, and it made me wonder if he was thinking we were going to not tip him do he was trying a pre-emptive strike to get some cash in his pocket?

It looked like a cute place but I doubt I'll be back after this experience. SF has such great restaurants with superb service I don't really want to frequent someplace with subpar service.
author: Cristina B.

description: Very refreshing dishes and great find in dogpatch! Decor is very adorable here and the two dishes we got were delicious. We ordered the Piccino radish salad (with snap peas, garlic aioli, garlic chips, sesame seeds and other crunchy goodness) and the trout with cauliflower and broccoli. Recommend getting the sightglass coffee they have as well.
author: Vivien H.

description:
I'll be straight up - I have a hard time liking Italian restaurants. I'm just never impressed, so I've probably given a low star rating, but, Italian Restaurants... I can usually make the same thing they did at home (and more of it).

What I liked:

The Space.  Great space.  Light, airy, comfortable, friendly.  They also had outdoor seating which I could totally get into.  And hey, the dogpatch is kinda cool these days.   

The service - very nice wait person and very helpful, although it did get pretty busy at the end and it seemed like the host/busers weren't really on top of it.

The bechemel sauce.  It was nice.  good flavor and consistency for sure.

The wine I chose - it was nice - and even though it was by the glass they let me taste first.

What was meh:

The food - I got the lasagna and it was good, but like I said, I could have made it at home....

What I was less impressed with:

The size of the pour of my wine

The size of the portions themselves in relation to the price

The amount of milk in my cappuccino.  

The fact our food didn't come out at the same time.

overall, I probably won't go back.  

Italian. When will I find somewhere that WOWS me?
author: Sarah C.

description: Just had a delightful day in Dogpatch today and found this restaurant. The owner was so helpful while we waited a short while for our table; she had a brochure guide of the area and was helpful in planning the rest of our day. We sat at the bar, had the Sancerre which was highly recommended by the hostess-it was perfect for a warm day in SF. Then we had the pleasure of watching the food prep by the amazing chefs. We had the grilled octopus and a meatball, egg, and kale dish. If you are a chef, which my husband is, it was a real treat to watch the food prep and the dance with the cooks. Enjoyed the food very much and ambience. Next time we'll get the pizza! We then visited the wind store called Dig next door which is owned by the owner's husband, had a delightful visit and bought a unique French wine (they carry special varietals from Europe. A great place to eat!!
author: Madeline S.

description: Great service and great food. Octopus starter is delicious. Pizzas are perfect and dessert was scrumptious. I tried a bit of the chocolate torte with dark chocolate and salt. Also tried a Benitez style donut hole with peach cream. The menu is creative and fresh...good pastas too.  I highly recommend this gem.
author: Erin S.

description:
Golly Moses, has it really been 7-1/2 years since my first and last visit to Piccino? Back then, it was on the adjacent corner of 22nd Street and Tennessee where the Lab is now (...which by the way, sounds like quite an intriguing concept). It was a tiny cafe space where I recall that Jamie W. and I sat on a tiny table out on the sidewalk to split a pizza and a pasta dish. We had no idea they moved to the big yellow house on the other corner at Minnesota in an enclave with a women's clothing store and a wine shop right across from the new playground (photo: http://bit.ly/1BXoSx4). Such a nice space, very open, very Californian with a counter surrounding an open kitchen and large communal tables in the middle (photo: http://bit.ly/15sb4wc).

It's become quite a dining destination in Dogpatch, which is why another couple had suggested it for a dinner meet-up. You can still sit outside, but it was butt-cold that evening so fuggedaboutit. We were seated on a banquette next to a metal divider that made maneuvering out of it tricky. The server was the model of self-control expressing her enthusiasm for the dishes in a very measured fashion. I decided to start with the $14 Winter Citrus Salad with Fennel, Dandelion, Aged Goat Cheese and a Sherry Vinaigrette, which was a refreshing mix dominated by grapefruit slices though somewhat overpriced for the portion which was inexplicably scooted to one side of the plate as if it was on its way to the floor (photo: http://bit.ly/1B53lxa).

Somebody was in a hurry. One of my dining companions and I ordered the same entree, a special that night, the $27 Roasted Riverdog Farm Chicken Breast, sliced in four pieces, sitting atop a Parmesan Risotto mixed with more Grapefruit, Warmed Radicchio and a Green Garlic Salsa Verde (photo: http://bit.ly/1CoL9To). That was an inventive dish, savory and succulent for white meat with the sweetness of the grapefruit providing a welcome balance. Jamie decided on the more reasonably priced $18 Pappardelle Bolognese with Oregano, which definitely had a meaty, earthy sauce you would expect but a bit hamstrung by the limpness of the pasta noodles (photo: http://bit.ly/15zndQl). No paisan was harmed in the making of that dish.

Even Lidia Bastianich would have crinkled her ample forehead at such a wet texture. Our other dining companion went back to basics and ordered the $17 Funghi Pizze with Roasted Mushroom, Stracchino and Shaved Garlic (photo: http://bit.ly/1tbeE9d). I have to say the pizza is still the most satisfying item in their repertoire - crunchy, thin crust with flavorful toppings that don't overwhelm. She also ordered the $8 side of Sauteed Greens with Chili and Garlic. Simple goodness. Jamie had a side of his own, the $8 Fried Brussel Sprouts with Charred Leeks and Garum Vinaigrette, but he looked like he barely got any since the busman was hovering incessantly grabbing dishes as if the five-second rule applied to his job.

It was a major ding if you ask me. Our other complaint was the $3 surcharge for a shared bread roll which calculated to sixty-cents a slice. Not a dining phenomenon unique to Piccino, but I hate it as it's worse than not getting the complimentary water glass. Dessert pacified us as we shared three of them, and there was no grapefruit to be found. There was the old-fashioned $10 Peppermint Stix Ice Cream with Shortbread, Marshmallow and Dark Chocolate (photo: http://bit.ly/1urO9aW), which I thought was akin to a parlor treat sundae without the gloopiness of a sauce. Then there was the $9 Spiced Ginger Bread Pudding with Salted Caramel, Streusel and Crema (photo: http://bit.ly/1GOBx8Q).

That was a no-brain winner since it was a variation of the spiced ginger cake classic at Chow. Lastly, there was the $8 Zeppole with Vanilla Bean Crema, Meyer Lemon Curd and Huckleberry - five donut spheres, very lightly fried and powdered with fine sugar. They cleverly made the curd and crema look like a fried egg on the side (photo: http://bit.ly/1xPNu4t). Rounding out the meal was a $6 bottle of a 2013 De Forville Barbera d'Alba, which had a deep cherry flavor with a silky finish (photo: http://bit.ly/1EFGFqT). Piccino feels all grown up now like it's ready for its first prom worried it has to go to third base with its customers. I've got unnerving news for you, Piccino... I expect a homer.  

FOOD - 4 stars...delicious neo-Italian fare with a few flaws, nothing irreparable though...pizza still heads the menu
AMBIANCE - 4 stars....welcoming open space is a major improvement over the corner cafe they had years ago
SERVICE - 3 stars...needs work, we didn't feel that special...and where did those Brussel sprout go?
TOTAL - 4 stars...Dogpatch dining went up another notch in a big yellow house
author: Ed U.

description:
The espresso is good here but the woman who brewed it made it terribly, so it was really bitter. I asked her to remake it and it was just as bad. The few sips of it I had left a unpleasant feeling in my mouth that I dumped it the first chance I got. 

Two stars because the ice cream was delicious.
author: Iris L.

description:
Can't say, just becomes my top 3 in SF. 
Amazing and perfect food, just can't stand for it.
I like tomato salad with avocado, capper, tiny greens and very fresh dressing;
The tomato sauce meatball, has herb mixed with the meat and very tasty;
The pasta, with parmesan cheese and meat, is one of my favorite and top 3 pasta so far.
Desert I love the Asian pear tartar with ginger ice cream and pomegranate, just creative and yummy.
Restaurant is cozy and comfy, love the decorations and furniture, service is nice, 
Love here so much so much!!!!
author: Olivia J.

description: I've never been blown away by Piccino but I've always been happy enough. We had a large group lunch here and it was pretty easy to get everyone situated and served family-style, although we had a bit of difficulty with one person's unusual dietary restrictions. Another smaller dinner really highlighted the neighborhood friendly vibe while maintaining an intimate setting. But, in both cases, the food was just fine without being particularly memorable.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I hadn't been in awhile however the other day, we decided to pop in for brunch since I was able to score us a last minute reservation from Open Table while in the area. 

They've since redecorated and I immediately noticed their pizzas looked a lot better than I remember. However we stuck to our guns and decided to stick with the brunch fare we were eyeing on their online menu before we arrived. 

We ordered: 

Zeppole - it was fine. vanilla bean and curd. prob could have skipped it however for light bites and coffee, it would have sufficed. 

Egg scramble - creamy eggs served with Brussels sprouts. Good flavors from the garlic anchovy aioli. 

Croissant French Toast - strawberries, creme fraiche and hazelnut. Hit the spot for what I was craving that day and perfect portions for splitting with the hubs. 

Coffee - my husband likes their coffee bar (he's been a fan ever since we lived in SoMa on Townsend Street) and we stop by occasionally when we find ourselves in this part of town so he ordered a cup. 

Service was extremely rushed for a restaurant that wasn't particularly busy that day/time. I didn't enjoy that. We were seated and the server came by to take our orders for everything - drinks, starters and meal less than five minutes of being seated. We weren't really ready to decide on our mains (I thought she would have started off taking drinks and starters first since she came by so quickly) but she waited so we can decide on the spot. Food arrived in no time but dishes were being cleared off practically as soon as the last morsels were consumed. It was a bit uncomfortable (and not to mention quite annoying) and I think we were in and out of the restaurant in about 35 minutes of being seated. 

Overall I did enjoy their menu but word to Piccino - as a diner the rushing bit is really off-putting.
author: Esther A.

description: We had a reservation at 8:30 pm to celebrate a birthday. We got there right on time and they told us they were getting our table ready. Yet, they made us wait standing in the entrance for 40 minutes! Though food was good, we were very unsatisfied with the way they made us wait despite our birthday dinner reservation and failed to make it up to us.
author: Cansu C.

description:
My Aunts, mom and me went here on the way to the theater about a week ago.  We were greeted and seated appropriately.  Although, our server was odd.  She had this faux attitude that seemed to belong in Los Angeles.  I kind of wanted to tell her to return to the mid west and practice her perception of kindness on her people.  The food was A-OK.  Nothing too amazing.  I heard great things about it, but did not get a SF feel.  I grew-up in the Bay Area, and this place represents the ugly that SF has turned into.  Pinky up and nose in the air.  

I am not sure where the down to earth peeps have fled to, but I am sad that places like this are indicative of what this town now stands for...
author: Juliet M.

description:
I'm usually not a big coffee fan, but the cappucino was definitely something I'll come back again for. It's always tough when you ask a bakery what's good, since everything is, but the coffee cake definitely did not disappoint! Plus the clutch location in the dogpatch makes it easy access to my current workplace.

The attached Italian restaurant looked beautiful inside and is definitely something I'll have to try out in the future!
author: Brian G.

description: The staff is extremely helpful and even kid friendly. I went for Saturday night early dinner with my toddler. They provided a Phil and Ted clip-on high chair for my toddler to eat at the bar (facing the chefs) along with paper and crayons, and they offered to make a kids pasta (spaghetti with butter). Instead I ordered two pastas (small portions). The desserts are also wonderful here. The food is great but it seems pricey (if you're not ordering pizza) because the portions are quite small.
author: Meredith G.

description:
Great atmosphere, service and food, 
As Yelp puts it.. for 5 stars.. Piccino's as good as it gets!

I had dinner here twice in 2 weeks I loved the.. 

octopus salad 
the cod entree 
spaghetti w uni and crab 
meatballs 
apple tart
author: Nancie T.

description:
Nice service and staff. I can't figure quite why of the thousands of reviews here, none of the negative's are about the food. Makes me sad not to have anything in common with so many people. The food sucks, OK??

 This is the first time in my pretty long life that someone actually screwed up pizza. Not even Pizza Hut can do that for you. But I guess all things must happen. And I even tried two different ones. The tomato pizza had a ridiculously thin and soggy crust with just as thin a cheese topping. I literally could not taste the cheese it was so thin and bland. Both pizzas had no salt and tasted weird. It just sucks when you make an exception to eat junk food without the instant gratification. 

To sum it up: this is not a place for a foodie.
author: R S.

description: Good food.   Terribly slow service.   50 minutes and still waiting for food.  And the restaurant isn't busy.    Really disappointed
author: Amy H.

description: Was there recently with my company having a business dinner. The staff at Piccino is amazing. The roasted chicken was incredible. Tried their Arnold Palmer. It's the best one I ever had.
author: Jon N.

description:
Cool vibe and excellent service. It was packed on a rainy Friday night. 

Loved the pork and beef polpettes (we needed 2 orders) and the white pizza. 

I like that they do carafes of wine as options if you wanna try a couple different ones. 

Their prices have gone up a decent chunk since the last time I visited, and I'd no longer call it a value. Now it's typical city pricing.
author: Brenda C.

description: I will for sure be back! They have a fantastic menu with options for all types of eaters. I had the sausage pasta dish(forgot the name). We also had the burrata appetizer and pea salad to start. Everyone should try this place.
author: Gabriela H.

description:
I came here after reading Cherylynn N.'s review, she is my fave yelper to date! So go read her reviews if your feeling down, since they never fail to make me laugh and are informative as well. 

Dinner for 2 on a weekend night, my friend and I ended up sitting at the bar since we didn't want to sit at the communal table. 
Easy parking right in front of the restaurant! 

I love the interior of this restaurant, wooden rustic tables, purse hooks, chairs, pumpkins for fall. I almost always will choose to sit at the bar if I have a choice, because I love watching the process of how they make the food.  The kitchen here is very clean and sparkly. 

We ordered the funghi pizza, polpette ( meatballs), goat cheese and nectarine compote appetizer, and the chocolate cremeux for dessert. 

I love mushrooms so I knew we had to order this pizza, every bite had mushroom in it, and since the crust was the perfect density and size it absorbed all the delicious mushroom and cheese flavor.  I wish they gave more nectarine compote with the appetizer because I ended up with alot of extra goat cheese and not enough crackers or compote. 

The polpette was so tender, and fell apart in my mouth, I usually don't like meatballs, but I saw several people had ordered them so decided to try them as well, I was not disappointed. 

The chocolate cremeux was the perfect way to top off our meal, not too sweet, and a fantastic chocolate crust on the bottom.  My friend's iced coffee was one of the best iced coffees I've ever had, it had a strong, robust, coffee flavor, with the tiniest hint of bitterness.  They took time to make this coffee instead of just pouring hot coffee over ice, which I know many places do and which disgusts me because than the coffee becomes all watery and gross. 

You must come here if you are ever in the Dogpatch area and are the slightest bit hungry, it would be a waste not to.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: I came for dinner with friends and greatly enjoyed the ambiance. I found the wine list selection to be quite nice. The burrata was very fresh. Also recommend the polpette, which was delicious!
author: Gaëlle S.

description:
Came to this place based on the high ratings it got on Yelp. I want to think that most of those reviews are for the brunch or something like that because dinner was very disappointing. 

Let's start with the good part: the decoration is very nice. The waitress was nice. That's it. No wait, there's more. You can actually use Apple Pay with opentable to pay for your bill which is convenient. 

Pizza was relatively small and dough was not very good. To be honest the pizza tasted like a pre-made frozen pizza from the supermarket. We had the margherita and the funghi. They looked very nice in the pictures but live it was a whole different story. 

The service was also super super slow, even when there was hardly anyone there the waitress spent most of the time talking with the other employees instead of taking care of the customers. 

For dessert we had the little donut balls. Nice but also not worth the price. 

Might try it once more for brunch. Maybe that's the forte of this place. Certainly never again for dinner and never again for pizza.
author: Nuno S.

description: Piccino is always a solid bet. W/O a reservation during lunch hours, there can always be a bit of a wait, but it's worth it. My favorite pasta dish, their linguine, asparagus, pancetta, egg yolk, parmesan. Top-notch!
author: Nick S.

description: Great spot in Dogpatch. Good Italian inspired food. Unique wine list, friendly staff. Love the open kitchen concept. However it's a bit loud.
author: leslie m.

description: Do not waste your time and go here. Arrogant and rude baristas. Very, very, very limited food selection. The coffee they served me was cold. Their hot chocolate had nothing chocolatey about it, it was bitter and tasted awful. Complete waste of money.
author: Vinoo M.

description: Came here for brunch and was blown away by the Bianca pizza. Came back for dinner. I would recommend avoiding their wine "cocktails" which taste like cough syrup, but their wines are delicious. Ordered the brussels sprouts, which were terrific, and the funghi pizza with added sausage. Their pizza is definitely great, but for me the funghi pizza was overrated, heaped with tough, stringy pieces of mushroom that take forever to chew. We had an amazing waitress who knew a ton about wine and was incredibly nice, which pushed them up to four stars.
author: Young J.

description: Amazing restaurant with complex taste concoctions. I had the octopus and the layered flavor over the grilled octopus was fantastic. The pizza my colleague shared was also extremely tasty.
author: Tim M.

description:
This place was nicer than I expected.  We walked in and there was an open kitchen set up, it was actually really cool!  We sat at the bar and had dinner there.  It was a weeknight and we had to wait about 30 minutes, but we were able to walk around the neighborhood and passed the time quickly at Dogpatch Saloon.  

Food was top notch!  I loved everything.  Dinner was:

Bread and olive oil-  creamy olive oil, yumz.
Spaghetti-  some people are reluctant to get spaghetti because they think it's basic, but don't let that deter you, this was wonderfully crafted and really deicious!
Funghi pizza- mushroom pizza...my 2nd favorite type of pizza  this was good, but a little bit too fancy for my pizza prefs 
Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous nutella ice cream for dessert- local ice cream, so good.  

This place was great, I definitely recommend it.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Visited for dinner with my friends.  We shared the sausage pizza as an appetizer. I had the butternut squash carrot soup and the pork chop for my main.

I thought the sausage on the pizza was OK, as the taste didn't really stand out. The crust was good though, but I  didn't really care for the center parts becoming soggy quickly.  I really enjoyed the butternut squash soup.  You could taste the ginger and lemongrass inside. This added a unique surprising flavor.

The pork chop was an OK dish.   Our server said that it's cooked medium, but my piece was "well".   The moisture from the butter beans did help in eating the pork chop.  

For my dessert, we shared the apple date cake, chocolate mousse, goat cheese custard, and pear tarte.   From all four, the apple date cake stood out the best. The spices in the cake made the cake very pronounced to the other desserts flavors.    My second favorite was the goat cheese custard, only because I like goat cheese. 

Our server was great and the staff welcoming.  I think I would rather come here for brunch than dinner.
author: Marck N.

description:
The 7x7 list that I'm trying to finish is sometimes exhausting, but honestly, the places I get taken to by the list are places I've never known about before that have some amazing food. 

I ordered a few things there that sounded interesting.  I got the aqua fresca (strawberry basil) with some prosecco. Super refreshing with the macerated strawberries and if you read my reviews, you know I love me prosecco! 

I then ordered the baked egg since it had polpette in it. Polpette is a meatball so the egg was on top with the meat and some vegetables (kale and onions) as well. It was a great dish with a bit of bread. It was one of those dishes that didn't look filling, but by the end of it I was definitely full and didn't want anymore food.  

Overall, the food was delicious, drink was good. I will say that the service was a bit slow, but nothing too horrible.  Just wave a waiter down if you're having troubles.  

Protip: there was no wait for brunch! Very rare for a great brunch place in the City.
author: Nina Y.

description: If you want the luxury of drinking a $100 bottle of wine with over priced pizza, pasta and salad, this is the place for you!  The food is fresh and it has an open kitchen, but the staff is snarky, arrogant and down right rude.  This place is for hipsters and yupsters and I would not recommend it if you have friends from out of town that you want to take out to dinner. The people who serve here give San Francisco dining a very bad taste in your mouth. As an event planner, I do not recommend this restaurant for large parties as well.
author: Tre T.

description: This is my "go to" in the neighborhood.  The food is delicious and the service is always attentive.  I also feels as if the host is always genuinely trying to find me a spot when I arrive without a reservation.  My favorites are the polpette (meatballs) and the funghi pizza.
author: bill l.

description:
I went here for brunch this past weekend.  The waitress was really patient with us as my group were having a fun conversation that distracted us from the menu.  When we did finally order, our food came out promptly.

I ordered the french toast, which came with an oat crumble, apples, and almonds.  I thought the portion size was just right, but I wish it was less in price.  The french toast was one slice of bread at $14.

The atmosphere is relaxing, almost cabana style (sorry, I'm not well-versed in interior decorating).  It's a pretty laid-back vibe.  If you're here for brunch and are hungry, I would order a pizza or two of their brunch items.
author: Vira P.

description: Slow service. Food was average for the price. Open kitchen is not well run. Waiters unresponsive. Deceitful names in the menu for a regular pasta or humus plate. Long wait times. Not coming back.
author: Javier F.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco. The food is always fresh and interesting and pretty and surprising. No pretense. Staff is friendly. Restaurant is warm. I've had nearly the entire dinner menu at this point and have yet to be disappointed.
author: Nicholas V.

description: I love this location, it is perfect! I always look forward to sitting down and enjoying the seasonal menu they offer here. The menu is always changing! The food quality has never been bad, and the servers and hosts are very knowledgeable of the menu and are very helpful. I always have a great time either coming to Piccino alone, or with my family.
author: Tim V.

description: Healthy food and deserts! Little bit a pricey but overall great and good place for dating, romantic place in the evening.
author: Firuz N.

description:
I don't really know how to rate this restaurant! 

        I really love their food: pasta, pizza, beer, and also their service. We even was talking about our next visiting, then something happened: 
        I was sitting at the bar with an open kitchen, and I saw the stuff was making food. But she didn't wash her hands after she sneezing n covering with her hands. Then she just keep making a salad @@ (poor customers, hope they will be fine)
        The worst thing happened next, my friend saw the same stuff came out from restroom, and did a "2sec" hand washing, then back to work. @@ 

Ok ... I just want here to be better, becuz I really want to visit again... It should be the most important part of the employee training.
author: Chou t.

description:
Quick Hits:
Saturday SF brunch with no wait. Reservations also accepted. Enough said.

Located in the "up and coming" (aren't all areas up and coming in the bay?) Dogpatch -- this place is a fairly solid option for brunch.

What we got:
- Watermelon Agua Fresca + Prosecco: Win on all accounts. If you're into sweet, semi alcoholic goodness, this is the way to go.
- Hibiscus Sparkler: Another signature drink and another winner
- Tuna Crudo: Albacore tuna + tuna something, surrounded with crostini's and veggies. Definitely good. Definitely not enough crostini's. Beware: 2 extra crostini pieces will run you $2. Absurd. Portion carefully
- Baked Egg: Just the right amount of goodness in the baked egg. Everyone's already written about it, so give it a try!

Waiter sat us down and immediately asked if we'd like to start off with a fresh basket of bread and pastries. Warning: $10 for said basket, so beware. Otherwise, waitstaff was really attentive and accommodating!
author: Andrew C.

description:
I recently went to Piccino for brunch. I was running late to meet a couple friends and they decided to put an order in for me. I asked them to order the soft scrambled eggs with mushrooms, snap peas, and meyer lemon ricotta. The eggs were beautifully cooked as were the mushroom and peas. It was topped up with delicate greens in a very light vinaigrette. I also had a couple glasses of mimosa (It was the weekend anyway... or as the Brits and French say... "the week-end." Sounds more luxurious when you break up the word.) Anyway, the three of us also shared an order of zeppole with vanilla bean crema, Meyer lemon curd, and huckleberries. The order was for four of these doughnut-like confections. They are dusted with sugar and taste absolutely magical. 

Now, because I arrived late, I couldn't be a full judge of service. Overall, it seemed alright. I did notice, however, that our server only addressed one of us at the table every time she came around. That was a little awkward when my friend and I would look at her, but she would only look at our other friend when it came to ordering or other questions. The ambiance: lovely. I love the "modern rustic" (yes, a paradox!) feel of Piccino. It is open, airy, and has plenty of windows for light. The crowd: yuppies in the "emerging" neighborhood of Dogpatch... mostly 30-somethings... some folks chatting about politics, the others gossiping or talking about travel plans. You get the picture.

This is a darling place. Since my good friends live around the corner, I look forward to visiting again!
author: James Z.

description:
Came by Piccino Coffe bar after brunch at Serpentine down the street. Dogpatch is an up and coming area of SF that is still quite industrial today.

Experience here was decent. Apparently they use Blue bottle coffee? Service was friendly by the staff and the mocha was perfectly crafted. ...not too sweet...just the way that I like it ! There was also plenty of foam! :)

~$4.75 for a mocha.
author: Derek S.

description: I just had the most amazing evening at Piccino! I went for a late dinner with a friend. We're both vegan and enjoyed the eggplant caponata and shishito peppers - both already vegan and amazing! They also made the mushroom pizza vegan for us, which was wonderful. Our host was so nice and our server Kate was a doll. She had such a sweet disposition and surprised us with some chocolate spice vegan cookies from the cafe because we had to wait a few extra minutes for our table. We were so touched by the gesture, she truly made it a memorable dining experience. I can't wait to go back!
author: Nicole K.

description:
Dinner and the City.

After all the eating (so many restaurants so little time) and shopping (so many stores not so much money) during our week long trip, I was thankful my brother chose a place that was casual and nearby his apartment.  

SETTING:  The restaurant is simply decorated, yet exudes elegance and warmth.  Welcoming atmosphere and open area.  Loved the wood furnishings.  

NOTE:  Street parking readily available.

FOOD:
1.  Marinated Olives:  Decent portion.  Enough for the table to share, but could easily be for just 1 individual.

2.  Baby Lettuces:  Simple salad.  It was ok.  We meant to share this among the 3 of us, but this is definitely a portion for just 1 person; possibly 2 could share this dish.

3.  Salsiccia Pizza: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion.  My favorite pizza that we ordered.  Actually, my mom and brother loved it too.  It was gone before we knew it and we were still hungry.  Simple yet tremendously satisfying.

4.  Margherita Pizza:  tomato, mozzarella, fresh oregano.  With our hunger not yet satisfied, so we decided to order this 2nd pizza.  For me, it was just okay.  I preferred the Salsiccia Pizza quite honestly.  

Since my mom and I had to wake up early the next morning, we decided to forgo dessert altogether.  The 3 of us enjoyed our drinks, laughed, talked, and just enjoyed the company of one another before calling it a night.

SERVICE:  Very attentive and satisfactory.  Our server was friendly and patiently answered all our questions concerning the menu and drink selections.  He always made sure to check on us throughout our meal, and we appreciated he let us take our time before departing the restaurant.

BOTTOM LINE:  A simple yet appetizing last meal in San Francisco.
author: Michael C.

description: Have to give them fives stars because not only is the food so fresh, delicious & creative, but the staff is warm and unpretentious. We had the grilled octopus for a starter along with the radish salad . Just as tasty as in Italy. Two pizzas, the fungi one & the sausage. Both light and crispy. We had a bottle of Sicilian wine, perfectly described by our waiter. Very happy.
author: Mary D.

description:
The OYA pizza is probably the most delicious pizza I've ever had! Not to mention the most beautiful pizza I've ever seen! 
Three of us ordered and shared 2 different amazing salads, 3 entrées and 2 desserts. Everything as well as all of our service the minute we walked in the door was very enjoyable. 
Made a Rez through open table. 
I look forward to my fourth return visit!
author: Adla N.

description:
Just say yes.  Everything is delicious (from the salsicca pizza to the lamb ragu).  I love the casual rustic space, welcoming vibe, and that they have a solid selection of half bottles of wine available.  

Piccino is perfect for date night, that catch up session with your friend, or when family is visiting from out of town.  The volume in the restaurant is just right (you can actually hear the people at the table); the servers are knowledgeable and attentive; and the food is divine. 

Need I say more.  Make a reservation. It's worth it.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Mmmm the ricotta gnudi is a must!! Never tried or heard of Gnudi until today. They're tender, gnocchi-like pasta dumplings with a creamy ricotta filling. Deceptively light and shined with the simple creamy pesto sauce, mushrooms and snap peas. 

Cute, corner, yellow building, next door to their bakery (they used to only be a Lil bakery that sold baked goods and pizza..oh they serve SIGHT GLASS coffee and yummy FIVE MOUNTAIN TEA)

Oh funghi pizza with an egg was ahhmazing..

Great service..super cute spot! :)
author: Chanel H.

description: Yummy baked goods.  LOVE the ginger scones!
author: Laura P.

description: It might be fair to say that Piccino's has the best pizza in San Francisco. It's certainly most excellent; so good that you never have to order beyond the margherita. It's like a Kipling poem. The dough is thin, yet not too thin. The crust is crispy, yet also soft; dusted with cornmeal, but not too much. The tomato sauce is fresh, yet also cooked ... If you're into minimal, modern presentation that has a gentle contemporary feel and also blends with a reserved earthy warmth, you'll love this place. Simple and good. Some people shy away from the restaurant's popularity. Try eating off hours. The food's great whenever you decide to come.
author: Anna L.

description: Came here coincidentally during the Dog Patch Block Party.  Really nice restaurant to have brunch outside on a nice day and enjoy the foot traffic. The food is very fresh as it is all farm to fresh.  They also have a cute coffee and pick up to go area that I might try next time.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Great small coffee place next to their restaurant.  We've ordeted white tea, Americans and macaroons.  All of the items were fresh and delish!
author: Maryanna K.

description:
If there's one type of restaurants that I'm not fond of, it's neighborhood restaurants. I can't tell you how many of these so-called "neighborhood gems" that's I've been to that were a bust (e.g. Park Chow, Frascati, Garibaldi, Le P'tit Laurent, Hillside Supper Club etc). Gem my ass. More like a diamond ring you get from a gumball machine. 

Unlike any other neighborhood restaurants I've been to, Piccino is a triple threat: solid food, awesome service, and charming ambiance. All the components that make-up a 5 star restaurant.

This past Sunday, my friends and I (party of six) came to Piccino for brunch with reservations. They just have a lunch menu (no breakfast items) which was just fine by me because thanks to Anthony Bourdain, I will never look at bacteria-loving hollandaise sauce the same way again.

We shared the following apps and desserts but ordered our own entrees (pizzas). Based on our sampling of the menu, you really can't go wrong with any of their dishes as they execute top-notch ingredients very well. 

* ~ * F O O D * ~ *
*Kenne tomales creamery aged goat cheese, carrot cake, orange oil, black pepper ($10) - 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1a0E49j
Insanely delicious, this app was like eating an elevated and savory carrot cake. So ridiculously good, we ordered two orders. 

*Burrata, beets, crispy polenta, watercress, red wine vinegar ($14) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/18btVpt
Milky burrata, fresh beets, and deliciously creamy fried polenta? The healthy way to get in your fried foods and cheese without an ounce of guilt!

*Funghi: roasted mushrooms, stracchino, shaved garlic ($17 + $2 egg) - 3.5 STARS 
http://bit.ly/1idQf7J
If you love mushrooms then you will love the funghi pizza. Mushroom tapenade (in lieu of marinara sauce) layered atop a flavorful crust then topped with whole mushrooms and stracchino cheese. A bit too mushroomy for me and I couldn't taste the cheese but add an egg. Boom--brunch food!
