*Mr. NSS' Salsiccia: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion ($16) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1a9nkPg
I liked the salsiccia over my funghi pizza because you can actually taste and feel the texture of the ooey gooey cheese in your mouth. Loved the robust sausage and I liked that the crust stayed a lot more crisp than the funghi pizza. 

*Zeppole, vanilla bean crema, huckleberry marmellata ($7) - 4.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1a9nqGB

*Goat cheese custard, berries, black pepper tuile, pumpkin seed ($8) - 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1fVd0QV

*Passito rosso poached figs, mascarpone mousse, hazelnuts, coco nib ($12) - 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/1bf1qKL

*Apple tarte tatin, creme fraiche, pomegranate ($8) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/Hhrcof

Although I'm not a dessert person, I almost always order dessert when dining out in order to get a true sampling of the menu. We shared 4 desserts and by far, the fav among our group was the goat cheese custard which was a savory sweet deliciousness in a jar. Our 2nd fav was the zeppole which were fried to order and so light. The vanilla crema added just the right amount of creamy sweetness. I liked the buttery flakey crust of the apple tarte tatin but I think a scoop of vanilla ice cream would have made it even better to give it that lovely temperature contrast. The least fav was my pick of the poached figs and mascarpone mousse. The accompanying cake was dry and overall, the dessert lacked flavor. I guess that's what I get for trying to pick the healthiest dessert. 

* ~  * S E R V I C E * ~ *
Just as solid as the food was the service. The staff was very friendly and casual yet professional and attentive. Although we had a larger party, service didn't suffer as they do with many restaurants. Food service was timely as well. 

* ~ * A M B I A N C E / D E C O R * ~ *
I absolutely adore Piccino's ambiance. After having an ear-bleeding brunch at Central Kitchen the previous week, it was such a relief to have brunch/lunch in relaxed ambiance without having to shout across the table. 

Industrial chic meets Napa wine country, Piccino's space is very open with tons of light coming through and natural wood furnishings. The funky buddha's hand adorning the tables was really cool! I'm a sucker for open kitchens and Piccino is no exception; loved their large open kitchen. Highly recommended for a first date!

* ~ * P A R K I N G * ~ *
Plenty of free, non-metered parking because Piccino is located in a desolate part of Dogpatch. Chocolate Lab is down the block and Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous is just a block away.  

Piccino in Italian means "little" but there's nothing "little" about this restaurant. I mean, I don't think they call them "Italian Stallions" for nothing right? Umm, not that I was looking... 

#MindForeverInTheGutter
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Potrero Hill never disappoints with food as I think I have found one of my new favorite restaurants in SF! This cute little Italian restaurant is the essence of what I love about places in the burbs - very unassuming from the outside, but so well decorated and welcoming on the inside. Definitely suitable for a date night or in my case, a nice b-day dinner with one of my closest girlfriends!

My friend and I did classic Asian, family-style dining, splitting 1 app and 2 entrees, while successfully butchering the pronunciation of everything we ordered. But hey, that's how you know you're at an authentic place, right? 

We started off with the fig toast (a dish I'm guessing is only seasonal), and it was the perfect start to the meal - light, but flavorful. I'm usually one to save sweets for dessert at the end, but I'd been craving fig toast for quite some time now and it was well worth the wait! For entrees, we ordered the pork beef polpette and the strozzapreti which was just the right balance of meat, vegetables, and carbs. The polpette (essentially meatballs) was soo tender and well seasoned! I really like that these meatballs were substantial, but not too heavy and it was just the right amount for sharing. The strozzapreti also hit the spot and gave our meal the tangy but earthy taste from the pesto sauce. If you're a vegetarian, I'd highly recommend this one!

I will definitely be back here to try their pizzas and desserts!
author: Betty W.

description:
I have always had a fantastic meal at Piccino.  On my most recent visit I had a meal of the best combination of starters, pizzas and pastas.

I had a super fresh and carefully prepared Verdure Crude with Baba Ghanoush, the Garden Salad is well prepared with the freshest of ingredients.  The Cucumber Salad has stone fruit (peaches), radish, mint, parsley and sumac was outstanding.  The Strozzapreti, nettle pesto and mushroom was absolutely beautiful and fulfilling.  The Chiocciole and fennel sausage is not to be missed--the fennel sausage has a bit of heat spice.    I had a small slice of the Margherita, Aglio and Bianca.  The pizza's are nicely thin with very high quality ingredients.  Each dish I had was completely satisfying.

Piccino has a nice and well edited wine list.  A very good experience each time I dine here and look forward to going back.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Always a good meal with good service.  Usually a wait.  Not sure if they take reservations now.  Great unusual salads.
author: Howard S.

description: Was okay. We had 4 pizzas. None were great. The zucchini blossom one was super oily. The margrehita was fine. The sausage was fine. Wine list was expensive. A few more Cali wines would be a welcome addition. Service was slow. Don't really see a reason to return.
author: Gail S.

description:
For those who know me well, you know I'm a simple guy. I love high quality things but they don't have to be fancy nor expensive. 

Enter Piccino. 

Coming late in the day, I really didn't notice the bright yellow building which added to the character of the place. Inside was a hip atmosphere complete with an exhibition kitchen and a coffee bar.

Water and margherita pizza was all I had, and yes I was satisfied. Did I mention I am simple?
author: Ron L.

description:
Unexpectedly nice find in the Dogpatch, but not sure what all the buzz is about... 

Came here during dinner on a Sunday night around 5:30pm - no tables until... 8:30pm, so we set at a side bar.  I don't mind - I got a better view on their open kitchen - my "partner in crime" is already not thrilled and wants a more comfortable chair.  But we stay, since the pizza looks good, the awesome smell from the kitchen is intriguing and we are hungry. 

The server/ waiter shows up and sparingly greets us. "What you want to drink"? we have not had a chance to look at the menu - we don't know - he is unhappy and it shows - he just leaves.  OK, I guess, next opportunity we get to order - we'd better be ready! He comes back and I dare to ask about any specials - big mistake... 

Well, we place the order from their great selection of seasonal dishes - burrata on heirloom polenta, brussel sprouts, a salad (I noted I wanted dressing on the side - and all the souses came on the side - I like this!) - and a pizza to share. 

All ingredients were very fresh and high quality.  Burrata was good, polenta not so much. Brussel sprouts were just amazing - I would have licked the bowl if I could. 

Now, what we came here for - their pizza.  The first one we ordered - well, we are picky, but it just wasn't good enough for us to eat it.  However, our fault, should have read the menu better (not that we could ask our server any questions, since, well, he is important). We ordered another pizza - Margarita this time.  This was much better, but still not even close to my expectations.  The crust was blunt and the sauce really lacked favor. Again, ingredients are good, but may be add some more.. spices.  

Either way, didn't feel like staying for dessert (partially because we got completely abandoned by our waiter). 

Also, they didn't offer to take another pizza off the bill (well, we didn't ask since it is our fault, but... they could have offered), had to hunt people down to get my hot tea, getting the bill was a challenge.  

I always conclude my review with a question - ever again? well, may be for this one - if we ever move to the neighborhood and don't want to drive. Definitely not putting on my "destination restaurants" list.
author: Marianna K.

description:
Cute space. Love how it's bright inside from all the natural sunlight. Haven't tried their coffee bar but the pastas were delish. 

Fresh and tasty, not too heavy and overwhelming - even when you're hungover!
author: Susy C.

description:
I've been to Piccino many time now, with their old chef, with Ravi Kapur as a guest chef and with the new regime. I've always had a great meal. Ive even dined by myself, made some single serving friends next to me, while owner Sher Rogat was just on the other side. This new space is always crowded and I've had to endure some waits. However it was always worth it. With the ever changing menu, it keeps you from being bored, though there are some staples that I feel I want each time I return. 

*Starters:

Marinated Olives

Pickled Vegetables

House Made Sesame

poppy and nigella seeded crackers

Farro Verde, Cauliflower, Grapes, Pine Nuts

Burrata, Heirloom Polenta, Watercress, Sea Salt 

Tagliatelle, broccoli di ciccio, onion soffritto, calabrian chili, ricotta salata 

Pork and beef polpette, crushed tomatoes, parmesan 

*Mains:

Chicken breast

Pork Loin

Artic Char

*Pizzas:

salsiccia: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion

bianca: parmesan, pecorino,mozzarella, shaved garlic, chili oil 

Those are just some of the things I've loved while eating here. There are few other things, and desserts that are slipping my mind and are also excellent. Service is also always stellar and if Hana is still there, you should try and sit at her area, but everyone else is great too. I'd say one of the marquee restaurants of the Dogpatch. If you like SF influenced Italian fare, then this is a must try.
author: Kim N.

description:
Came for a late brunch/lunch on a saturday.
The baked brioche French Toast was not bad. The bread wasn't moist or eggy which is what I prefer. 
The pizza was pretty to look at, especially with the added egg on top (+$2).
salsiccia: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion 
The pizza sauce was bland and the overall pizza flavor was very muted. The crust was good though.
author: Heejin L.

description: Great Neapolitan style pizza, nice small plates, very pleasant service.
author: Ilya K.

description: I loved the octopus and burrata dishes. The focaccia was not great, but it was served with a great mild olive oil. The sausage pizza was alright - next time I'd like to try the mushroom and shaved garlic pizza. Sitting on the counter and watching the open kitchen was a nice treat.
author: Amin S.

description:
New favorite Italian place in SF. I haven't been to another place that does pizza and pasta nearly as well (and authentically!) 

I highly recommend the strozzapretti. The nettle pesto and midnight moon gouda made such a creamy combination, making this by far my favorite dish. 

I am not usually impressed by pizza but after browsing photos and previous reviews, my friend and I ordered the salsiccia. The pizza itself was thin-crust, which made the flavor from house-made sausage and red onion all the more distinct. The portion was generous enough for two girls who had just walked in from intense workouts! 

I love the fact that they have daily, seasonal menus, so I'll definitely be back to try more of their primi and contorni. I noticed the pork/beef poulette on the neighboring table and the marinara (crushed tomato) looked delicious. I'll be trying that next time.

All in all, if you're in the Dogpatch neighborhood, do not miss out! Even though the prices were a bit high, the service and quality of food makes this restaurant one of my newfound favorites.
author: Kristi L.

description:
Polpette good
Octopus was really good
Strozzapreti above average
Galette dessert really good
Service was great
Silver bud tea was good
Only negative is small portion sizes
author: Jones T.

description:
Consistently fantastic the food, servers & atmosphere!
I've had brunch & lunch here & both are great! Their pizzas are awesome if you like crispy crunch crust & amazing toppings!
author: Ashley G.

description:
Finally had a chance to come after having bookmarked it for a couple of years. And it was worth the wait.

People who know me know that I don't like to share. I enjoy family style if the situation presents itself. Fortunately the four of us were able to share at lunch here. 

The portion sizes weren't huge but large enough where you could have more than a spoonful or a fork full.  Just enough to please the palate, and to satisfy the tummy.

Given another visit and choosing not to share, I'd go with a pasta dish or the very thin crust funghi pizza. We had two pasta dishes - the  pappardelle and the fusilli. 

The spicy meatball dish went well with the pizza.  We also shared a salad and two desserts - zeppole (like beignets) and the poppy seed angel food cake.  

Service was attentive.  Plates changed frequently.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Highly recommend the restaurant.  We come there often and the food is consistently good, made from fresh ingredients, and the service is attentive.  
Would have given it 5 stars if not for the bad service at attached little cafe/bakery.  There we waited for quite a while to get attention from one of 3! people behind the tiny counter.  But they had other more important tasks to focus on and matters to discuss.   Finally we left.  Luckily there are other great bakeries in the area.
author: shaul t.

description:
A group of us girls dined here for brunch recently. At 11am when the restaurant opened, there was a steady line out the door - good thing we had reservations!

The space is open, airy, and much more roomy than it looks like from the outside - it can also accommodate large parties (there was a 10+ person baby shower table just behind us).

Now, first things first - if you're a breakfast food type of eater at brunch (like me) - this may not be the most ideal place for you. There were precisely two egg options on the menu, and no traditional breakfast items like pancakes, french toast, etc.

If you're open to eating pizza for breakfast - you will love Piccino. The wide variety of thin crust pizzas (you can opt to put an egg on top), looked delicious.

Our table started out with basket of warm pastries, which was delicious! Mixed with a scone, popover, and bread - definitely a great "breakfast" item. We were also eyeing the zeppole, but the server kindly informed us they were not able to make that dish that day.

For my main entree, I chose to go with one of the egg dishes - namely, the soft scrambled egg with brassicas and a horseradish cream fraiche. The dish was very refined, and the sauce definitely played a major role in flavor. 

I do have to say that for the $16 price tag, the portion size was a bit small. Had it come with a slice of toast or complimenting item, that might've alleviated my portion size distress.

Overall, everyone at the table enjoyed their dishes. Others also felt the portions were a bit limited. The server also mentioned that the pizzas were "mini" and made for one, and then proceeded to upsell an additional salad - definitely unecessary. The pizza is more than adequate for two people.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Made reservations for 11:30am on a Saturday which was a perfect time before the traffic jam began. 

Great atmosphere and very hipster decor. Don't get the entrances confused - there's an entrance for the bakery then a side entrance to their dining. Love restaurants with open kitchens! I feel better about eating the food that comes out.

The menu is light and pricey. I honestly could not pronounce most of the things on the menu! A gentle question of "have you've been here before?" would've been nice with a little explanation of the items on their menu.  

Love love their asparagus with avocado (pictured). Their Saliccia and Funghi pizza was delicious - more so the Saliccia because if the homemade sausage. The egg, however, did not add any special texture or taste to it. Although their egg was perfectly cooked (yay!!), it was a waste to add it to the pizza. 

Parking is street parking which becomes more challenging to find throughout the day.
author: Jenna T.

description:
This is my "Go-to" Italian restaurant.  All ingredients are super-fresh (they must come from Farmer's market !).  Everything is super-delicious, and Hanna is our favorite waitress. 
This is a Gem of San Francisco.  Highly recommended !!
author: Y. Keith T.

description: The food here was spectacular it was actually light and really really flavorful and also the atmosphere is fantastic and the woman that waited on us was wonderful great customer service a must eat!
author: Teri D.

description: Stepped her a late night coffee and dessert after an event at UCSF Mission Bay.   No tables, so sat at the bar which was fine.  Ordered the French press and a stone fruit galette.  Both were great, service fantastic, prices typical.  Easy parking on the street.  Would come back for real food someday.
author: Steve G.

description: always good food, always good service. This is one of my favorite places to eat in SF.
author: David N.

description: Super disappointing experience at Piccino. I made a reservation through Open Table for 5 ppl at 9 pm. In the reservation, I noted that it was a birthday so the restaurant would be aware it was a special night. Our group arrived 15 minutes early and after checking in with the host, I was told the table was ready and they were just setting it for us. 10 minutes later, we checked in again to see if it was set and we were told that despite our table being ready, the waitress had been overwhelmed with orders so they were 'giving her a rest and spacing out the orders'. Ookay. The host also somewhat smugly asked us what time it was at this point, it was 8:57. She then said they would try to seat us 'as close to 9 pm as possible'. Considering it was noted as a birthday dinner (and our group waited til most restaurants' closing times to eat because 9 pm was Piccino's earliest reservation available), this was incredibly disappointing. Our group waited outside until 10 minutes past 9 and then decided to leave and find another spot for the birthday dinner. Piccino did call at 9:15 but we were already gone and quite honestly fed up with the attitude and false promises.
author: Katie C.

description:
Piccino is a Dogpatch sensation. If you haven't eaten here, you haven't experienced good food. The simplest of the food or drink thats made here is out of the world. I have had latte, plum muffin, coffee cake, knoci, margarita pizza, fungi pizza, pasta, olive side order just to name a few and was blown away by the quality and taste of food. I know some of the employees by name now and would like to mention them here because talking to them make the food even more pleasurable.

Carlos : Carlos is a very open-hearted and happy person.

Katie and the guy in beard (can't recall his name) : Katie is the sweetest barista. When I order coffee, I make sure Katie (or the guy in the Beard makes it) serves it because they make it with love !

Anette : Anette is one of the workers inside the restaurant. She was very knowledgeable about the menu and helped answer all our questions. She was very courteous and well spoken too.

5/5 stars to my favorite italian restaurant in San Francisco Bay Area.
author: Piyush H.

description:
I found the hostess' snootiness to be irksome, & the wait time for our dishes interminable; unexpectedly, the meal took up a considerable chunk of our Sunday afternoon, however, our waitress' joyful energy was the bright spot in this servicing issue. 

My brunch partner enjoyed the sauce & the sweet, caramelized carrots in his pork hash. Shredded pork looked juicy, but the first bite proved looks can be deceiving. 

We shared the yelp-highlighted Funghi pizza, which was abundant in a variety of mushrooms & had perfect amounts of cresenza cheese & roasted garlic. Crust is paper-thin, more like a cracker than doughy pizza crust. It's simply amazing. Five stars. 

I couldn't decide between a cuppa celery root soup (with lemon cream & crispy leeks) and granola w/ milk, honey, kiwi slices, & pomegranate seeds, so I ordered both (fear not for my waistline, I didn't actually finish both!) Again, each dish was phenomenal. 4.5 stars. 

Four overall stars in spite of 2-star service because delicious food rules all, & Piccino serves delicious food, albeit rather slowly.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Piccino, I love you! I wish I lived closer so I could come more often! I had lunch today and it was wonderful. 

The ambiance is lovely. I didn't know if I wanted to sit inside or outside since both options are so nice. We ended up sitting inside which was great. Our waiter was very friendly and gave some great recommendations. 

We ordered the baby lettuce salad, funghi pizza with no cheese and added arugula, and the bianca pizza. The salad was kind of disappointing. I mean it was good, but it was VERY small. For $9 you get a tiny portion of fresh tasting lettuce with a sprinkle of pecans and a few slivers of radish. I wouldn't order it again. The pizza on the other hand was delicious! I don't eat dairy, so I asked the waiter if I could hold the cheese and add a vegetable. She suggested arugula which was such a good idea! The arugula was lightly dressed and the mushrooms on the pizza were like nothing I'd ever had before. This pizza was perfect and they should add it to the menu! I didn't have any of the bianca pizza since I don't eat dairy, but I was told it was very good. 

I would definitely come back to Piccino just for the funghi pizza! There were many other options on the menu that sounded delicious. The staff was great and I look forward to my next meal there!
author: Rachel S.

description: Amazing food and even better service! We'll definitely be back. Try the pizzas or the imported beers, absolutely incredible!
author: Steve W.

description: I went back to this restaurant for the second time last week after a great first experience some months ago and they did not disappoint. We had a tight schedule and not much time to eat in so I called ahead to ask if they thought it would be reasonable to get fed within the hour. The host was gracious and said she'd reserve a table for us so that it'd be ready on arrival. In an effort to accommodate us, they got food to the table quickly - with no compromise to great service or food. I am particularly in love with their funghi pizza but everything was spot on. Feels like a hidden SF gem.
author: Dee M.

description:
We decided to snack here while waiting for another place (yeah, excessive) so tried the cinnamon brioche and Banner Dark coffee. The brioche was like a dry cinnamon roll, not worth the SF price tag. The coffee, though, was very tasty, with hints of chocolate. 

Overall I may stop by again for the coffee and hold off on the baked goods.
author: Jerico M.

description:
In Italian it's, Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo.  In English it's The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly.  That's how I would describe Piccino.  

There's things I really like about Piccino but there were other things about them that I didn't like and even loathe.  So I'll break it down from the top:

The Good:  

I liked the ikea-esque decor.  It's bright, it's clean looking with the light colored wood framing and tables.  The noise level is moderate among the wine drinking aficionados, hipsters, and treehugging crowd that comes here and despite the tight space between tables I felt like we had a nice measure of privacy.  

Also as far as the food was concerned.  The two things that stood out was the Funghi and Bianca Pizzas.  Funghi pizza was full of delicious mushrooms, stracchino, and shaved garlic, it was packed with flavor.  Bianca consists of three cheeses, it was great with the thin crust used.

The Bad:

After having the wonderful Funghi and Bianca you'd assume all the pizzas made here are equal but this wasn't the case.  We also ordered the Margherita pizza which was bland and boring.  Also to my surprise the salsicca pizza with pepperoni added was not good.  I already felt like a manly man like myself shouldn't be eating crust so thin so I tried to compensate and turn the salsicca into a meat-lovers pizza but some how it back fired. 

Along with the not-so-good pizzas was the two desserts ordered.  We ordered a chocolate mousse style cake which just didn't taste good.  The cinnamon apple cake with ice cream was ok if you gotta have dessert which I didn't. 

The Ugly:

The service was poor.  Our waitress serviced our table with mild neglect.  She came around very seldom and when we had questions or we ordered she was unfriendly and very short with us.  Her forced smile made it look like her face was going to crack.  I tried to play it off since we were having good conversation with our company but inside I was irritated with her.    

So if you go to Piccino, expect to get a little (Blondie aka Funghi, Bianca) as Good,  a little (Angel Eyes aka Magherita, desserts) as Bad, and (Tuco aka MY WAITRESS) as Ugly.
author: Michael L.

description: Had a four course meal. Salad was fine, nothing special. Some vege was not cut well making it difficult to share. Grilled whole fish was excellent. Mushroom pizza I can't get enough. Margarita pizza was light and just right. Good drink selection including hot loose leave teas. Didn't care much about the donut, just a personal preference.
author: Daveen L.

description: Not kid-friendly and would not recommend this restaurant due to poor customer service.  Booked a reservation for 5 adults and 3 small toddlers under 2, was told to add my credit card when making the reservation, forgot to call back the next day.  That week got a call from Piccino confirming my reservation as they obviously had my phone number stored to have called me back.  They didn't ask for my credit card info so assumed the reservation was good to go as the person on the phone was like see you then.  When we finally get to the reservation weeks later, the reservation was no where to be found.  May have been a miscommunication but the front desk person there was extremely rude about it and had no sense of customer service.  The other families I was with also thought she was super rude and her tone was uncalled for.  She could have handled it better and could brush up on some customer service training from management with dealing with issues like this.  The restaurant looked empty too, and had many empty seats available.  Her tone was extremely rude especially with having all the kids around us and then having to hear her rude tone.  Very unhappy about the whole experience, the other families were even at awe at how rude she was to us.  We ended up going to the brunch place across the street called Just For You Cafe, much more of a pleasant experience and more kid-friendly with high chairs.  I have been to Piccino before and the food is just alright from what I remember but after the experience with the lady who was supposed to check us in for our reservation, we all agreed to never come back even if it's close to MyGym where we were coming from.  The other families even told me they have no intention of even getting coffee or pastries there anymore.  Lost business from many families from MyGym!  Would not recommend this restaurant to anyone even if they didn't have kids!
author: Kathleen R.

description:
What a great locals spot for us!  

We went for dinner last halloween and recently went back for lunch - everything is delicious and the restaurant itself is so warm and cozy .. just overall 5 stars.  Relaxed feel with delicious homey food.

Favorites:
-bianca (white) pizza
- Salsiccia pizza 
- pork and beef polpette - the sauce is AMAZING, you will lick the plate dry

For brunch they have a polpette served with an egg on top - the meat was served in a dish in a more "patty" like style with the egg on top  - this was even more phenomenal than the dinner course that's just the meatballs in the sauce.

So happy we gave this place another try after we had the funghi pizza years ago at their old location.  It's a bit funky and not your usual mushroom pizza.. but everything really is great at this local gem!
author: Melody T.

description:
My friend made a reservation for five of us at Piccino - I was really excited to try it! We all arrived around 5 minutes on either side of our reservation for 7pm. However, we weren't seated until 7:15pm. When I went to talk to the host at 7:10pm about a table, he told me to give our server some time. Wow, okay? We made a reservation for 7pm, but we should give our server some time? I also told him it was my friend's birthday, which he failed to relay to our server.

Then we ended up at a shared table seated next to an extremely obnoxious child who couldn't stop moving or making strange noises. So much for reservations.

Throughout the meal, we had to ask for our bottle of water to be refilled. This happened at least five times. It was never taken or refilled without our asking. We also poured our own water the entire time, minus the first glass. Our server was often nowhere to be found, and I had to ask other servers and the host to help us instead. Even then, the hosts and servers were often conversing instead of attending to guests or tables.

We had to tell another server that it was my friend's birthday, which she was able to relay to the kitchen. The wine list also boasts expensive wines - there were no reasonably priced ones. The average glass cost $14-15. The $50 bottle we ordered was only okay.

The only saving grace was the food. The pasta I had was great, well seasoned and well made. The portions are pretty small though, so keep that in mind when ordering!

Weirdly, in the middle of dusk, they placed a candle on our table. But it was about an hour later around 8:30pm that they abruptly turned down the lights... and turned them back on again.

With the awful service, strange ambiance, and shared tables, I won't be going back. The food is good, but isn't worth it.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I've been to this place probably about 4-5 times and have always had a good experience.  The food was good, but never anything amazing, and since now I live in the hood it's a great place to drop by.  We used to eat here after open houses and finally can now call this hood home. 

That being said, I came here with a girlfriend for dinner.  They were about 20 minutes late to seat us, no apology.  It took about 10 minutes to get water.

The server came by to tell us about the specials and when we asked her about the fish, she said "it's delicious, but I've never had it".  What a strange thing to say about a dish, and btw, she hasn't had any of the other dishes, and didn't know anything about the wine.  She asked another one of the servers to come over to help, and this girl didn't know anything either, so I tasted about 4 wines before picking one that btw, wasn't great but I just got tired.  The food was delivered by someone else, the waitress was never around when we needed her, and didn't pick up on any cues about us not being thrilled with the food or service.

The food: 
The squash soups we had were good, but lacked some spice and flavor, they were kinda flat.  We had to ask for pepper.
The fish was good, but not anything great. 
The gnocchi were awful. First, they were whole wheat, then they were sitting in vinegar based sauce that was watery, acidic and just not appetizing.  The portion was also very small, would have been nice to know that ahead of time. 

Just for fun we asked about desserts, but ended up skipping. Yes the waitress hasn't tried any of those either.

On her way to the bathroom my friend found the manager and told her about our experience.  Instead of an apology or maybe covering part of the tab, she said that the staff was not well trained.  Well I think that's her fault, not ours.  Again, complete fail to do anything about our comments.

I don't think I have ever done this, but neither one of us tipped.
author: Inga W.

description:
The beef polpette, aka meatballs, were truly the best meatballs I've ever had in my life. At $16 for a small bowl, it was a bit pricy.

However, if you ever miss your caltrain at 22nd st, and feel down. Here's a good place to go to grab a drink or splurge on meatballs!
author: Alfonso C.

description:
This place is so cute and so so convenient.  I love how it is right by the Cal Trains station.  The neighborhood is not yet over developed and that gives Piccino a warm inviting feel.  

This place is good for lunch or small group dinners.  You have to be careful how to order though, to you'll need up disappointed.  Some of the items are ridiculously portioned or have no business being on a menu in the first place.  I once ordered an endive salad that was three pieces of lettuce, five pistachios, and some honey drizzle.  Stick to the pizzas and you'll be okay.
author: Jessica H.

description: A favorite local pizza pasta place. Thin crust and fresh mushrooms. Refreshing shanty (beer and lemonade) Warm donuts always a winner.
author: Theresa L.

description: Butternut squash soup - UMMM, YUM!!  Loved the little walnuts that were like little surprises in every bite - pleasantly not crunchy, soaking all the yummy goodness of the soup.
author: Alyssaaa S.

description: Always good food. Easy booking online and never an issue for brunch which makes this our brunch spot of choice of late. Food is crazy fresh and seasonal (love the spring peas on the menu -- in the soups, salads and even on pizza!), but is on the expensive side. Casual ambiance, most Sundays full of kids and locals, and being a block away from Mr. & Mrs. Misc doesn't hurt.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I came here last week and had a great dinner date with my girlfriend. We were greeted by a friendly hostess and seated in the corner which was pretty cozy overlooking the entire restaurant.

We started off with the butternut squash soup which was pretty good - the grapes and hazelnuts were a nice touch. I had the Salsiccia Pizza which was excellent - the sausage was tasty and onions were sweet which, combined with the mozzarella, was perfect. My girlfriend had the Margherita pizza which tasted fine, but it was nothing special.

Decor was modern, yet relaxing and we never felt rushed by any of the staff who were all pleasant and attentive. I could tell this place has a higher attention to detail than most other places (food presentation, candle placement, utensils etc.) I came in wearing a t-shirt and felt a bit under dressed. Parking was a breeze.
author: Josh L.

description: Mainly liked the sleek and modern ambiance. The brunch was HELLA overpriced. $26 bucks for my dish. And it wasn't that tasty - needed salt. I need to go back for dinner to really judge... and I will.
author: Andrew K.

description: Terrific restaurant with a relaxed service feel, no one tried to rush us out of our table, even though we arrived earlier than reservation.  Terrific and freshly made menu of delicious selections from original pasta recipes to pizzas, appetizers, entres and desserts. Good wine list. Great place for your group or just a party of 2!!!
author: Lorin S.

description: 5 stars for the restaurant decor, ambiance and the thin-crust mushroom pizza with tons of garlic!
author: Judy H.

description: Utterly outstanding (as always). I've been coming to Piccino for almost four years and they never cease to amaze. The menu changes weekly, based on in-season and available ingredients, but there are always a few staples. The funghi pizza is the best pizza in the Bay Area, but the other pizzas never fail... however, the Polpette is to-die-for; like, it would be my Death Row meal. Amazing.
author: Brendan G.

description: Fabulous Italian.  Had a tagliatelle with sausage that was out of this world.  Heartily Foodbag recommended.
author: Foodbag B.

description:
Great Italian food! The place is very unassuming as it is in an area of the city called the dogpatch. The restaurant feels very trendy and upscale. Everything we had tasted amazing and as fresh as can be. Great place to bring a date or even a family with kids. 

The cheese plates are soo good. They use a lot of kumquat and rhubarb which add a unique tanginess to the dishes they serve. The fresh herbs such as smoked sage really help make their dishes pop. The deserts are also out of control, they use the tangy fruits in them as well and have really done a good job at balancing those flavors; the sweet, tangy and savory all come together nicely.

This is a really good place for vegetarians, they have many options and its all so fresh and tasty. Would definitely come back again!
author: Albert E.

description:
Thanks to Cherylynn N., Piccino has become my FAVORITE place for gourmet pizza!

Came here with the boyfriend on a Saturday afternoon right around lunchtime, and to our surprise- there was no wait to get a table. Easy parking, and no wait to be seated, SCORE!

W O O D  O N  W O O D  O N  W O O D (like: racks on racks on racks)
The ambiance, and decor was very SF and I loved it! Wooden tables, wooden flooring, wooden legs on chairs, wood everywhere (that's what she said)!! It was just beautiful, and felt very inviting (hehehehe....)!

P I Z Z A
Based on the highlights, the boyfriend and I ordered the Salsiccia- house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion. It was good, but the Melanzana- eggplant, marinated bell pepper, goat cheese, chili was even better. Yes, I said it. The pizza with the vegetables was better than the one with the meat! It was bursting with flavor, and was the type of pizza where you wished never ended. Yeah, it was that good! :) 

C O N C L U S I O N
Easy parking, no wait, awesome service, and oh so delicious pizza, what's not to like about Piccino! So, the next time you're craving gourmet pizza, get your butt to Piccino and order the Melanzana. My mouth is salivating just thinking about how delicious that pizza was, dammit! =P I'll be back for you, pizza!
author: Heather C.

description:
Twice in one day? It must be pretty good.

When searching for wine bars open in the middle of the day in the Dogpatch, options are kinda slim. Piccino's kitchen closes between 3-5 pm but you are able to sit outside and enjoy a drink, along with a few small bites on the limited menu.

A carafe of rosé and a delicious goat cheese/strawberry compote/zucchini bread small plate later, my gal pal and I were ready for real food! And more wine. 

We wandered down to Smokestack for a drink, then tried to visit Yield, but their kitchen staff wasn't ready yet.

Back to Piccino. This time for dinner and a bottle of Italian red. We left full of pizza and slightly purple mouthed, but very satisfied.

It's a bit pricey, but quality more than makes up for it. Great date night spot or for an early evening meal.
author: Abby S.

description:
Seriously can't wait to try this place again!  I loved the decor and classy yet casual ambiance. My server was super sweet and very knowledgeable about the menu. The menu is not too big which for me says they focus on doing a few things perfectly instead of too many things just mediocre. 

Started with the butternut squash soup. Warm rich thick and creamy. Loved the hazel nuts and olive oil. Really awesome flavor.  

I ordered the pasta. Perfect portion with amazingly rich flavor. Noodles were not over cooked at all. Garlic and shaved cheese. I cannot complain. 

Dessert was good. I had the cookie ice cream sandwhich. The ice cream was interesting and the sweetness was subtle. 

Beautiful presentation for all dishes. Planning on having a brunch there with my girls! I really want to try their mushroom pizza! It looks delish!
author: Krystal T.

description:
Recently discovered this little gem in the Dogpatch and I've already been here three times since. The interior is beautiful. It's a relatively small place so the seating can be a little packed on the edges but the food was divine!

And the service was incredible as well.
author: Tania S.

description:
I really enjoy coming here with friends or just grabbing a pizza to go. As someone who is from the east coast, it's been hard to find the pizza place out here in the bay area. This is one I can eat anytime. I always enjoy bianca, funghi and salsiccia pizzas in addition to the chestnut gnuchi as entrees.  I've had the pickled vegetables with hummus, which isn't my favorite, but the vegetables are good. Always leaves room for dessert. The zepoles are delicious, yummy fried dough covered in sugar with lemon curd and berry compote. PLUS they serve sightglass coffee there.

Only salads and pizzas are on the take out menu. Definitely make a reservation on OpenTable unless it's just 2 of you. Most of time at the right hour, you can grab a bar seat and be mesmerized by the kitchen staff.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I've had Piccino bookmarked for quite sometime.  Finally decided to try their brunch spur of the moment this past Saturday.  I easily found last minute reservations on Opentable as well.  We decided on sharing the Funghi Pizza with an egg ($17 + 2) and the milk braised pork ($18).  

The pork came out first and it was tender, but not too soft, as it still stayed together pretty well.  The pork had a little bit of sweetness to it from the milk and I loved the herbs and the light sauce with potatoes and peas finishing off the dish.  I think it could have used a little more flavor but I appreciate that this dish was light, as it sounded heavy when reading it on the menu. When our pizza was presented to us we noticed that the egg was missing.  Our waitress offered to have it remade or to fry an egg separately and put it on top.  I asked her what she thought was better..but then she offered to have us hold on to the pizza in front of us while the other one with the egg was remade.  I loved the fresh mushrooms and garlic, but the pizza with the egg was so much better as it added more flavor to the pizza which it needed.  The egg yolk was perfect and oozed out when pierced and gave the pizza a more creamy flavor.  The pizza was thin but didn't get soggy and had the perfect crunch and no burnt parts at all.  We would say it's the best Italian style pizza we've had so far.  

Our waitress was so sweet and we loved the minimalist decor of the restaurant.  And of course are pizza was pretty amazing and the pork was satisfying as well.  We can't wait to come back to try Piccino's dinner menu.  Piccino is a solid 4 for now and a gem in the Dogpatch.
author: Cat C.

description: Piccino serves an excellent dinner menu, and service is friendly, swift and top grade.  My favorite dish is the chiocciole with fennel sausage, braised kale, parmesan, chili.  This dish is fantastic, a chorus of flavors coming together in a dish that is surprisingly light.  I get it every time.
author: Crista B.

description: Quaint coffee/beer/wine shop in dog patch. Great cappuccino and place to hang out, if you can grab a spot at single table. Definitely worth the visit.
author: Shaun J.

description:
Came here for a birthday lunch - wife + son (4). It was *okay* but didn't blow my socks off and I'm struggling to put my finger on why.

Location is great - good parking (Black Friday so plenty of space) and a park across the road for my son to play in after a meal. 

Son had french toast - loved it. Apples on the side were yummy - just the right texture.

Wife had scrambled eggs + dungeness crab. She said it was enjoyable.

I had a baked eggs + polpette. It was fine. Nothing amazing, nothing terrible.

It all just felt a tad pretentious for what it is - a good solid cafe with enjoyable food. The waiter was pleasant but seemed a bit put off by our lack of drink ordering (wine list being relatively extensive). I also found it a bit odd that he "presumed" we didn't want dessert and brought us our bill.  

Would I go again? No. Love the area but a bit of a dime a dozen cafe with the quality of the service.
author: Cameron O.

description:
Super quick review coming up! *rings bell*

Food: 4/5
Overall very tasty! 
- Burrata was very tasty, perfect blend of eggplant, tomato, and salty finish. 
- Watermelon salad was super interesting a refreshing!
- Pasta was perfectly cooked although one tasted a little more curryish than I would prefer at an Italian style restaurant. 
- Pizza was good but nothing special (Salsiccia, excuse the spelling)
- the tiny donut desert was really tasty! 

Ambiance: 4/5
Nice! Basic, clean, well designed. Tables aren't stacked up on each other as much as other SF places. Parking isn't a nightmare either (mini celebratory dance) 

Service: 2/5
What on earth. Come on "Jeriel"...not friendly, no updates when things were slow...nothing. I know the assistant servers are supposed to bring things like bread and water, etc but as the lead server, you are supposed to make sure it arrives in a timely fashion. If the coffee takes 7 min to do, then maybe place the order for desert to coincide? Things like that are important. Also, she checked on her other tables more than ours, skipping us often. No, it's not a misguided "feeling" that I had, I actually counted because I was wondering if it was just me. 

I'm a nice person...I just want some nice service when I go out. Pretty please?

Price: 2.5/5
Pretty expensive for quite small portions but the food is pretty good. I have mixed feelings on this one: sometimes small portions are okay but the food has to be epic. Pizza is big enough for a hungry one (or in my case, just me hehe).
author: Adrian M.

description: Don't miss this Dogpatch treasure. We enjoyed a specialty pizza with fresh tomatoes and kalamata olives as well as a fennel and browned-sausage pasta.  Both we pretty-much perfect with tons of flavor. Special note on the pizza... I put a high emphasis on the crust and how the pizza is baked...the pizza and crust were absolutely perfect... Just the right amount of dough and clearly cooked in the right oven at the perfect temperature. The only thing that would have made our experience better would be to offer a wider selection of wines by the glass at the $10-$13 price range.  We wanted to try several different wines but paying $15-$20 per glass was cost prohibitive for us.  That said, the sommelier was awesome and we chatted for at least five minutes as though we were the only customers in the restaurant.  Very impressive, appreciated, and just so enjoyable to learn more about his perspective on craft beer and wine. Finally, and although we thought we were in the mood for a romantic dinner, we sat at the community table and thoroughly enjoyed it.  So there ya go.
author: Scott M.

description: Favorite new place in the city. Terrific food (except the pizza), and great service. Can't wait to go back.
author: Nancy R.

description:
We had pizzas, salad, brussels sprouts, and ginger bread pudding.   Everything  was really good.  It's a cool space, and it was nice to see them preparing the food.

I hope to go back soon.
author: Michael E.

description:
There is two places named Piccino. One is a small bakery and a coffeshop with only one table, other one is a restaurant with many tables. Unfortunetly we entered into the coffeshop and it was awful. Barista was so rude. She didn't like me and she gave me bad coffee. I think she is lesbian and there is nothing wrong about it but she hated me because I am a man, she gave me hate look. By the way this place is a self service place. Don't wait any service at all. You also need to pay tip, which is ridicilous, do we pay tip at starbucks?
Anyways, don't go to cafe. Restaurany may be good, no comment.
author: Burak S.

description:
Ok. Really good pizza. Really a little bit overpriced. $17 for a pizza that served one person (could feed 1.5 people if they're not as hungry). My husband loved the pizza. He kept saying, "This pizza is really good," between each bite. 

I couldn't get a pizza because they weren't gluten-free. But I did taste the mushrooms that my daughter didn't want and it really was good. 

$7 for a polenta with walnuts and raisins. A well-balanced sweet and savory dish. $6 for pickled vegetables that went well with the pizza that I couldn't eat, but I imagine it would balance out the greasiness quite well. 

All-in-all $30 to feed two people sort-of. If I was hungrier I probably would've wanted a little more food.
author: Wendy H.

description:
This place is... complicated.

It's a pretty good place to take a date, because the ambiance is great, the service is exceptional (what do you expect?) and they have those fancy oval sinks that make you feel like you're at a high class hotel... mmmmm....

BUT I think this place really shines as a first stop on a nice night out.  You have to look for the cheap eats, but they're there... 

Get a margherita w/ anchovies, split a salad and a carafe of wine... you can sit at the bar and still get out under $50.  

I had to google how to spell margherita.  I'm still copying and pasting it.  

Keep it classy SF!
author: Daniel K.

description:
Great breakfast/brunch, even greater pizza! I came here today for brunch and to also try their funghi pizza, it is amazing ! Please do yourself a favor and get one!

Ordered the pulled pork hash, funghi and Salsiccia pizza - all very tasty. I'm a huge sucker for artisan pizza, always the best tasting ones :)

The best part about this place is, tons of parking and no wait - always a plus.
author: Colleen L.

description:
This is really a 4.5 star rating.

Really good Italian dishes in a fun room. Food was well executed but nothing super creative. Definitely a fun place to take a group and split a bunch of things.

Don't miss:
Amari Selection
Lamb ragout
author: Tom B.

description:
i like this place for one reason - THERE'S NO WAIT FOR BRUNCH. yes, you heard that right, NO WAIT for brunch.

this is such a rarity in san francisco, it deserves recognition. 

now onto the food:

delicious! i want to come back here to try their other dishes. but i ordered a whole pizza, with an egg, all to myself. i couldn't finish it, but it was so good! when i paid for my meal, i accidentally left my doggy bag on the table. i've been regretting it ever since.

i want to come back here for dinner (which i hear is more of a wait)
author: Andy H.

description:
Had brunch here with the bf and got a table easily without reservations on a Saturday.  Note, we arrived at 11:00AM and didn't have any trouble with party either.  We came here a few years ago before the remodeled and became bigger.

I tried the baked brioche french toast, almond oat crumble, roasted stone fruit while my bf got the housemade pork sausage, pistachios, slow cooked egg, squash, & potatoes.  His dish had small portions aka very portion controlled, but I liked the sausage - slightly spicy.  My french toast in sum was SWEET, I didn't mind it, but the sugar just hits you, good texture with the almond oats.

I'd come back to try their pizzas.  This place seems like a good place for brunch for a group.
author: Joycelyn L.

description: So many delicious dishes, though a couple of misses. Loved loved the tagliatelle in a light creamy sauce with sweet and spicy notes (mint, fig, chili). The funghi pizza is for mushroom lovers! A puréed mushroom sauce with mushrooms and just a hint if cheese (wish there was more cheese actually, but still tasty). The meatballs were also very tasty but slightly overcooked on the outside - but the flavorful chunky tomato sauce made you forget about the burnt edges. I wasn't a huge fan of the picked vegetables. The waiter had praised the tomato salad but there were only about 4 tomato slices. Disappointing. Desserts were decent - ice cream sandwich and a deconstructed peach cobbler. We ordered all of that for 5 people. Didn't leave stuffed so you get a sense of the small portions. Very beautiful restaurant and delightful service.
author: Sara C.

description:
this was the fourth time dining at piccino. i don't know what it is but i always expect it to be better than what it is. this time we had olives, foccacia, octopus, pizza, two pasta dishes, matcha cake, tarte tatine and two glasses of prosecco. we did a byob.

the great thing about pizza when you eat out is that it comes to the table right out of the oven, super hot, crust perfect. you know, you can't wait to eat it so you scorch the roof of your mouth. well this wasn't that because  it  was, you know, kind of... tepid.

the great thing about pasta when you eat out is that it comes to the table steaming hot out of the kitchen, when all the ingredients are combined at peak flavor. you know, you can't wait to eat it so you have to blow on it a little to cool it off. well this wasn't that because  it was, you know, kind of... tepid. in fact it was a congealed mess.

this goes to show you a restaurant is only as good as its weakest link. piccino either needs more food runners, faster food runners, something, because what they have now ain't working. too bad.

this place is also hella loud. especially when there's a table of six twenty something "chicks" at the adjacent table, shrieking while they celebrate someone's birthday.

i don't think there will be a fifth visit...
author: Sanil S.

description:
This restaurant is the epitome of the "neighborhood gem," and this gem is also a brilliant canary yellow (the cut, I'm not quite sure of); hard to miss it.  On the inside the high ceilings, many windows allowing plenty of natural light to come through along with the light maple wood colored decor all make this place feel warm and inviting.

Ordered the baked semolina gnocchi with parmesan broth and basil pesto along with the pancetta pizza topped off with an egg.  The gnocchi dish was delicious but was much different from any gnocchi I've ever had as this one was just one large piece and resembled something akin to polenta as opposed to the little dumplings I think most of us are used to.  Flavors of the pancetta pizza worked well and I enjoyed it.

The portions here aren't massive but you'll feel comfortable when you leave.
author: Erich D.

description:
So I used to say that Tony's Pizza was my favorite pizza establishment in SF and after visiting Piccino on Friday, I am singing a new tune!  The white pizza here was UNREAL delicious.  We had the sheet's milk cheese appetizer which I highly recommend, the salad and the white pizza with arugula. Oh and the affogato ice cream. I am already looking forward to my next meal here.  

One downside: the service was not memorable.
author: Maggie P.

description:
Very cool space, very good food!

We ordered: 
- spaghetti, roasted broccoli, walnut spinach pesto, parmesan. The pasta was incredibly fresh, and very gracefully executed. I ate most of the dish, despite being full after just a couple of bites. 
- chestnut ricotta gnudi, wild mushroom, brodo, mostarda. I could eat the rich and creamy ricotta gnudi all day. It came with a heavily seasoned array of mushrooms, which nicely complemented the mild ricotta. 
- bianca pizza: parmesan, pecorino, mozzarella, shaved garlic, chili oil. Didn't try this, but it was gone pretty quickly :)
- funghi pizza: roasted mushroom, stracchino, shaved garlic. Wow. Sometimes you order a topping and get 2 pieces of the topping on the whole pizza. This wasn't that. The pizza was generously covered with mushrooms, and even had a spread that coated the pie evenly so you didn't miss a single bite. 

Great spot, I'd be happy to go back.
author: Dimple B.

description:
I have not eaten at the new location as I'm sure the menu has changed a bit as well, but the Piccino I remember is now being turned into a Rechutti Chocolate Bar.  Interesting.


Piccino serves up some delicious bites, and having been here for the morning lunch meals, their dishes hit the spot.  The food is reminiscent of a typical cafe somewhere foreign.  The food is dainty and yet refined enough for the flavors to kick in at the right moment.  You get what you pay for and this is no ma' and pa' diner. This is an "upscale" restaurant for the elite easy-goers who want a break away from the madness that is SF.

Grab a seat and get adventurous with  robiola tre latti, hen of the woods mushroom and caramelized onion bruschetta to start your palate off right.  The chilled asparagus was a great Primi and you can't go wrong with any of their Pizzes.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Go - if you want a "foodie experience" - don't go if you are actually hungry or just want to eat. 

My Italian is good enough to order food in restaurants in Italy - I had to look up the dumplings they serve on GOOG -specialty- arrived very designed and too minty. My friend told me that ricotta is very filling- so k should be ok. The waiter screwed up big time on the food for our kids - the owner apologized nicely and took it off the bill. She told us they like kids. ?? 

Overall overpriced designer-food. Somehow on the other end of the - admittedly pretty disgusting - huge plates of pasta at places like Bucca di Beppo.
author: Flo B.

description: I thought the pizza here was pretty good. We all split the sausage pizza. it was thin crust and oven baked. My main consisted of the pork chop. It was on the bone but they deboned it and put the bone on the side for you to gnaw on. I thought it was pretty delicious.
author: Kenson K.

description:
Okay, so we had planned a lunch a couple of months ago at The House, which got 86'd when G's mom in NM needed attention and  rescheduled for today.  I guess she'd been too busy to reserve it for today and just yesterday asked me to.  Ring...ring...ring...  Do we need a reservation for today?  Yes, you would need one if we had a table...   1:15 is the earliest I could fit you in.   Well that won't work.  After considering several options,  I know nothing about any of them ptions named.  I'm trying to be better about not trying to control things so..."Pick whatever you like."  We end up at Piccino, and I loved it.

Service:  I didn't catch our servers name, but he had a tattoo of Lake Superior on his inner arm.  He was wonderful - very helpful, volunteering a taste of any wine before we committed even to a glass, and telling us his favorites, which turned out to be exactly what we had already thought we would order, BINGO

We shared two apps.

pickled vegetables:  I loved the brine and the veg.  Carrots, radishes, rhutabaga, and brussel sprouts.  They'd been cured to just the right texture and my only regret was that we ordered several things and would otherwise have focused more on this dish

buratta with arugula and polenta:  This was sublimely rich and a tutorial in appreciating subtle, yet extraordinary ingredients.  The "cracked open" buratta sat on top of lightly dressed arugula on top of exquisite (an adjective I rarely invoke for carbs) polenta that was creamy and luxurious on the inside, but crisply fried on the outside.

I had the fried oyster sandwich with lemon aioli and frisee on a brioche type bun.  Each element was well executed, but I would have preferred larger, more pungent oysters, less frisee, and a more sturdy bun.  The brioche was a good concept, but disintegrated during the eating

G. had the funghi pizza, which she said from the get was quite possibly the best pizza she'd ever had.  I (the not very fond of pizza oddball) also liked it.  I didn't have much (if any) cheese, so lacked the "gloppiness" I sometimes find off-putting, and used a base on top of the perfect crust of duxelles, lending an intense mushroom note, which is my favorite flavor in life.

G. wanted to get the goat cheese custard dessert, so I got the affogato over date ice cream, just so she wouldn't feel like she was eating alone.  Mine was a cut above, because of the lovely date flavor of the ice cream.  Hers was exquisite.  Despite the fact I usually turn down all but the lightest goat cheese, due to some early bad experiences with caproic acid in organic chemistry labs, this was transcendent.

Food:  37/40
Service:  19/20
Intang/atm:  18/20
value (I didn't pay wich always makes the value better!):  17/20
Overall:  91/100= A-= 5 stars (barely, but them I'm a hard grader)
author: Diane B.

description: Had brunch and I loved it! The area is very cute and away from the hustle of the city. We had the mushroom pizza, scramble, and basket of baked goods. They were all delicious. Very good, light meal.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
This was pretty great food. Even has good coffee. 

Funghi Pizza: 9/10 taste. About right for a single person. 
Goat cheese cake: delicious as well 9/10
author: Spencer C.

description:
Excellent food
Excellent service
Excellent consistency 

I've been coming to Piccino for the past two years and have been debating whether to leave a review because I don't want this secret to be out. I'm admitting it, it's one of my favourite restaurants in SF, and that doesn't come lightly, my inner Italian would never forgive me for it.

I love its humble name, as I like translating Piccino as "itty bitty", yet nothing about this place is small. Friendly osteria feel with a more refined decor, offering a very well-thought-out menu filled with classics. The food is always delicious and service is just impeccable, they seriously have some of the best wait staff under one roof that I've ever seen.

I've brought picky eaters, as well as vegetarian friends, and everyone loved it just the same. Come with a friend or two and try a little bit of everything. Add a perfectly thin crusted pizza to whatever you're ordering and don't say no to dessert. Two hours will go by before you notice, and you'll already be thinking of what to order next time.
author: Jade T.

description: Fantastic meal of Polpette, Acorn Squash and a unique pasta with homemade sausage. Great wine list, fantastic vibe, very friendly staff for us as we had no,reservation and a 9 year old in tow. Will be back for sure.
author: Matt H.

description: Found this place on yelp and it is exactly as good as the reviews say it is!! The lady at the register was extreme nice and accommodating.
author: James D.

description: Great ambiance, great food & great service! I love the set-up of the chefs table around their open kitchen, those are definitely my favorite seats in the house. Great for a date night or dinner with family and friends. Highly recommended!
author: Kristen G.

description:
As always, it is a treat to dine out with my middle brother and my sister in law. We always order a variety of things which gives us a much clearer picture of what a place can do. 

For Piccino, we ordered...

Antipasti
Robiola tre latti, hen of the woods mushroom and caramelized onion bruschetta ($11)

Primi
Chilled asparagus, hard cooked egg, pickled mustard seed vinaigrette and breadcrumbs ($12)
Pork and beef polpette, crushed tomatoes and parmesan ($15)

Pizza
Margherita: tomato, mozzarella and fresh oregano ($10)
Pancetta tomato, broccoli shoots, meyer lemon, garlic confit and romana ($18)

Dessert
Zeppole: cardamon cream and candied orange peel ($7)
Lavender ricotta cheesecake, burnt honey and kumquats ($7)

Pros

Robiola tre latti (cheese) was amazing, paired well with everything on the plate
Asparagus was cooked well and seasoned properly
Pork and beef polpette (meatball) was packed with flavor!
Margherita was simple and fresh
Zeppole (Italian donut holes) were super fluffy, just the right level of sweetness, amazing 
Pizza crust had a great bite to, almost tasted like Italy, but something was missing...can't place my finger on it 

Cons

Margherita pizza could have used more cheese!!!
Polpette, texture was on the softer side 
Pancetta pizza was overloaded, lemon was powering but amazing in small bites, overall, my least favorite dish of the night
Lavender ricotta cheesecake, first time trying it, didn't love it, didn't hate it. The ricotta imparted a strange texture but I did enjoy the brunt honey!

Service was good but the expediter was pushing out food faster than she should have

Overall Thoughts

A little taste of Italy in Dogpatch, might not be the real deal but strives to come close
author: Eddie W.

description:
It is time to update my review. Been back to Piccino a few more times--most recently for lunch with colleagues. The menu was full of Summer dishes and everything looked great!
We shared the melon and cucumber caprese salad--was refreshing and delicious. 
My squid with black rice was AMAZING. The squid was perfectly cooked, and the black rice was flavorful without being too rich. 

My colleagues had the mushroom pizza and the peach and prosciutto pizza. They both looked good and there was enough for leftovers. 

This place just gets better over time.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Came here on a busy Saturday lunch.  The restaurant is very SF - feels local-y, is bright and exudes tons of character.  Service was very good and fast (40 minutes from being seated to paying the check) - we had a reservation (no wait at all).

The restaurant was filled with people of all stripes including a lot of well-behaved kids.  

As with most SF restaurants, everything was local, organic, sustainable, artisan, etc. etc...  But like Portland, SF dining scene is almost becoming a joke in its "preciousness".

But despite the conscientiousness of the food sourcing, the food was meh...  Good, solid but nothing special.

We had the salad with little romaine lettuce (some cute little "gem") - too sour, too lemon-y.  But the true disappointment was the pizza. We had come specifically for the pie and we were decidedly disappointed. The thin crust was thin but a bit cardboard-y (not enough of the chew). We ordered three: 1) margherita, 2) sausage, and 3) potato. The sauce and the cheese on the margherita was flavorless (needed salt, spices), 2) the sausage pizza was slightly better, but again the sauce was just unremarkable and 3) the potato was interesting, but didn't wow me.

There are far better pizza places in and around SF - If you go to Piccino for the pizza you will be disappointed. If you go for the ambience and service, you will be satisfied.

It was also expensive especially for this part of town.
author: Madison W.

description:
The best white pizzas i've ever had. Amazing aged cheese and the variation in each bit was great. The red pepper and fried egg on top also helped to make the pizza a lot better. 
We also ordered the pizza with meat and was the exact same as mine except a very small amount if toppings sprinkled on top. It was $20 and needed a lot moe toppings for that amount. 
The French waiter was a complete tool and although I understand not all people there are like him, he is a reason why I don't want to come back.
I've had more gourmet/eloquent pizzas in other cities that had the same feel, but weren't so ridiculously expensive.
author: Danielle O.

description: One of my favorite casual-and-hip places.  I have been a couple of times, now.  Super good food, nice wine list, excellent service.  Last night three of us shared primi- burrata with some lovely beans, seared octopus, plus fresh and tasty focaccia - and we each had a pasta dish.  All were excellent, cooked perfectly and so good. The vegetarian pasta was off the menu - a pesto made of pistachios and walnuts, with a little lemon zest in there oh wow it was fabulous (that was my dish). I tasted the others: Chiocciole with sausage, parmesan, and a little heat in a creamy sauce was delicious, as was the fregola sarda with seafood and chorizo.  We then indulged in sharing 3 desserts and they were all excellent.  The first time I went there I snacked at the bar overlooking the kitchen, which is great fun, too.
author: Laura H.

description: We go to Piccino about once every 2 weeks, and it's delightful every time. It's a relaxed yet sophisticated atmosphere, and the food and drink never disappoints. We always enjoy the pastas, the octopus, the focaccia, the delicious desserts, and the great drinks.
author: Davey M.

description:
We had malagousia zafeieakis,erbaluce castaldi,malagousia zafeirakis ,luwa and Financier.It is a nice hole in the wall restaurant in dogpatch area in SF.We went for desserts and it was brimming with people even at the bar.

The server Karine was really helpful.She patiently and enthusiastically,answered all our questions related to menu items.

Will come here again for dinner.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Piccino is now a big restaurant, no longer a corner cafe.  Their pizzas & pastas are amazing.  Produce from Mariquita Farms, best lettuce I've ever had.  I think they deserve a Michelin star.
author: Janet S.

description:
Overpriced mediocre Italian food. Should have $$$. They do try to be fancy but in the 3 years since I have been here it feels as amateur now as it was then. 6 gnudi (pasta wrapped ricotta) with a bunch of pea pods thrown on top in a tasteless green sauce for $18, cheapest entree on the menu, roasted chicken for $30.

Positive notes, nice outdoor seating, and good wine.
author: Matt F.

description:
WHERE MY COFFEE ADDICTION COMES TO FIND SOLACE (and free Wifi!)

THE SIT-REP  (Situation Report)

I actually found this little gem nestled in a sweet neighborhood at the end of Minnesota Street several months back when I was wandering through the streets of San Francisco's "Dogpatch" hood to find some free WiFi.  As wondrous luck would have it, I found Piccino - and my now favorite Bay Area Barista CAITLIN - at the same time.  

THE FARE

Caitlin delivers up the most amazing Cappuccino that I've ever had this side of Seattle (Cafe Argento in Capitol Hill) and her delicious, artistic "ambrosia" puts me into a time warp that takes me back to my college days back in Washington State.  

There are also so many delicious little dessert items - baked on site - to have along with specialty coffees, including croissants, cupcakes and other pastries.  I had a carrot cake cupcake here that was mouth-watering and disappeared all too soon.  On other occasions, I've also had the personal cheese and pepperoni pizzas that they freshly prepare and bake here.  

GROUND COFFEE

Piccino also does a vibrant business with their own roasted coffees.  When I'm at the coffee bar with my laptop, it seems just as many people come in to the coffee bar to buy bags of coffee as do buy the specialty coffee drinks.

THE LOWDOWN

Piccino's delicious Cappuccino and Mocha's are just $3, as are many of the desserts.  The pizzas were around $10.  You can't go wrong with selections here and this has become one of my favorite post-work mid-evening stops when I find myself working in the Bay Area and staying in town for an evening of fun clubbing later on at night.
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
Since I was in the neighborhood I decided to check out Piccino Coffee Bar in the Dogpatch.  It's a small closet just to make coffee, not much seating either.

I got a Cappuccino after asking if they do Latte Art.  Yes, they do.  My cap was $3.50, charged it.

It looked fine, coffee a bit strong, so I added sugar to make it less so.

Piccino the Restaurant is next door.  I hope to try it one day.
author: Ann L.

description:
Best cappuccino I've had in this city, by far. The foam is always thick in a way I've never had it anywhere else. I go out of my way to come here.
The staff is super friendly, the pastries look delicious and are always changing, and the vibe is polished but still super relaxed.
Try the cinnamon bun! It's sweet without being sickeningly so, and it feels light because there's no crazy glaze on top.
author: Laura S.

description:
9 months later, we thought we'd try again.

Late afternoon, 4 or 5 tables of people only. They're conducting loud waiter training inside. We sit at the bar but the chef is right there prepping, so we move outside to be able to talk.

10 minutes after we get here the wine list arrives. We ask for a food menu and none is forthcoming. We ask again, menus arrive after a long wait. 10 minutes later, still no-one, nothing.

Our water glass was broken so we shared water from the unchipped glass. We left.
author: Nick C.

description:
Piccino is one of our favorite spots for a casual brunch or dinner.  The woodsy, streamlined interior complements the fresh and rustic cuisine.  The simple, yet sophisticated menu, which features fresh local ingredients that are skillfully prepared and artfully combined.  The cooking style is "farm-to-table" and minimalist with pristine presentation (I think Boulette's Larder is an apt comparison).  While the modest portions will not overwhelm you, I think the menu anticipates you will order a couple of courses.  (Our party of two adults and a toddler is usually satiated with two starters and two entrees.) 

The thin crust pizzas are tasty, particularly the margherita, funghi, and salsiccia -- but some may find the pizza too thin for the price (ranging from $12-$20).  Also, please note the pizza is thinner than the traditional New York style thin crust pizza.  The market soup, little gem salads, and polpette (meatballs) are also reliably delicious, but, as previously noted, do not come in large portions.  The pastas are also fresh and delicious, such as the tagliatelle with maitake mushrooms and escarole we had recently.  

To top it off, Piccino's service is friendly and responsive, and the setting is very kid-friendly.
author: Chris T.

description: Oh how i love everything about this place. From the beautifully designed restaurant to the small plates to the pizzas to the smartly put together wine list. The brussel sprouts are a must.  I love the mushroom pizza.  And the zeppole with lemon curd.  Hit that for sure.
author: Kamael S.

description: Super delicious thin crust pizza, well dressed salads, refined pork belly with Brussel sprouts and beans and excellent desserts. Top notch service, very attentive and timely, super chill atmosphere.
author: Andrew P.

description:
I called Piccino on Wednesday 2/17/16 in the afternoon to make a reservation for my girlfriend's bday party for 12 people for Saturday 2/20/16.
I talked to the person in charge that night, and she said it was hard, but she could accommodate my party at +/- 8:45PM - 9PM.
5 minutes ago, today 2/19/16, I received a call from the "manager" - I guess - and she tells me they cannot accommodate my party.
With not a bit of regret or shame, she tells me there is nothing they can do. Period. She even lectured me I should not be calling so late on a Wednesday for a reservation on Saturday. What a nerve! (after they took my reservation).
They made the mistake, they took the reservation, they took my card to hold it, AND NOW, ON THE LAST MINUTE, I need to start looking for another place because they cannot inform their people what to do or say.
It is hard to find a place for large parties, and I stopped looking once they informed me I was set for Saturday night.
EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING and incredible to believe the person who called me just now does not give a damn about my event. I can't believe this.
I liked this place until now. I NEVER write reviews, but this is infuriating.
author: Javier C.

description:
Had a great dinner here, with a lot of different dishes at a reasonable price. Between 2 people, we got 3 beers, 1 pasta, 2 pizzas, and 2 desserts (yes, we were hungry!) for $100 including tip and tax. I'd definitely recommend this to other people and am looking forward to coming back again and again (for both brunch and dinner). Pizza is one of my favorite foods, and this ranks up high in my list amongst Del Popolo, Flour and Water, Zero Zero. 

The space is really great - light, airy, high ceilings and lots of natural sunlight if you come early enough. 

Main Dishes:

Fusilli with Lamb Sugo ($16) - I really enjoyed this pasta dish. I don't normally like lamb (it's usually too gamey for my taste), but this was done really well. The pasta was cooked perfectly, and the right amount of flavors combined for a perfect dish. Loved the addition of the pistachios for an extra crunch and I know it's a good pasta dish when I can't easily recreate it at home.

Estate Pizza ($18) - Mozzarella di bufala, squash, corn, cherry tomatoes, arugula - Delicious thin crust pizza, and one of the best on their menu. All the ingredients were really fresh and light. I loved that the crust was not soggy in the middle. The crust is definitely more crispy, and it is less sourdough-y and less chewy than Flour and Water.

Funghi Pizza ($18) - Instead of a layer of tomato sauce, imagine a layer of roasted mushroom puree. It's definitely different from any other mushroom pizza I've had, and delicious. I preferred the Estate pizza to this, but still enjoyed this. There were thin slices of garlic on top, so if you're on a first date, it's probably best to avoid this.

Desserts:

Zeppole ($7) - Little fluffy donut pillows, sprinkled with sugar. They were piping hot and soft. It comes with 5 or 6 pieces. I would get this again.

Affogato ($7) - Another dessert I'd definitely get again. The espresso paired perfectly with the palm sugar ice cream. We polished this off and were left wanting more.

All in all, a solid meal in beautiful space, with great service, for a reasonable price. Make sure to get at least a pizza, a pasta and a dessert!
author: Christina L.

description:
Awesome Italian pizza spot in Dogpatch. Beautifully furnished and designed, the place has a warm and intimate atmosphere (yet modern).

I recommend the margarita and funghi pizza. The gem salad is great as is the tomato/burrata combination. Service is friendly and fast too.
author: Victor W.

description:
No juice and chai was just alright. 

I was bopping around Instagram one day and saw that Piccino was serving fresh juice every week day morning. I love going to the Dogpatch and I absolutely love juice so I thought I would swing by before work during the week. When I showed up and asked about the juice the baristas looked at me as if I were crazy. Then I decided I just wanted a chai and to be honest it was just sweet like a chai you would get at Starbucks. Sad day it was indeed. Guess I will just have to go somewhere else to get my juice then *sigh*
author: Jacqueline C.

description: I've been here many times, at least once every 2 months, and it has the most unfriendly host and wait staff in the city. I have no idea what's going on but they are a combination of unfriendly, unenthusiastic, unaccomodating and indifferent. Your food is great, please match it with the right human interaction. It makes me feel weird dining there...
author: Lo F.

description:
It's actually a 4.5 stars.  

We came in looking for brunch but it turns out they don't serve brunch.  It was a nice space and we didn't want to get in the line at Just for You so we decided to stay.   We were glad we did! 

I ordered the salsiccia pizza with onions, and added mushrooms and an egg at the server's suggestion.  It was delicious!  One of the best thin crust pizzas I've had.  So much better than the salsiccia pizza at Pizzeria Delfina, which had very few toppings and wasn't half as tasty.   I took half home and enjoyed it for dinner.  

My friend ordered the panini with fried green tomatoes and crescenza, which came with a small side salad with early girl tomatoes, and she loved it.
