We sat the counter and basically drooled over all the food getting prepared in front of us, including the ricotta torte (which apparently is only sold at the Piccino coffee bar around the corner), the quiche, and the olive oil cake which was layers of cake with raspberries, strawberries, and a lot of cream lathered around it.   The cooks were all very friendly and happy to answer the dozen questions we asked about what they were making.  

They serve Sightglass Coffee, which was very good, as well as Mr & Mrs Miscellaneous ice cream.  

The space is really nice, airy, and gets a lot of light, plus there are some outside tables.  

Definitely putting this on the list to come back for dinner.
author: Vivian W.

description:
One of the best coffee bars in SF, Piccino is a tiny, busy stall like space with simple, modern, industrial looking decor. They use Sightglass organic coffee beans to make excellent drinks and the baked goods are made in house. The pastry selection isn't large but everything I've had has been delicious. I've seen cinnamon rolls, brioche, slices of cake, tarts, chocolate chip cookies, scones, granola, etc. 

The lattes ($3.50) always come with nice foam art and are made with skill. They're rich and creamy even when made with nonfat milk.

* Ricotta tart: moist, savory, thyme scented, reminded me of a denser quiche, really good but I wish it hadn't been so cold

They sell Sightglass coffee beans and cycling gear. If you see a crowd, many are probably waiting for drinks. It may take a little longer to get your drink but it will be worth the wait.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The food was good, but too pricy for what you get. The ambient is nice, small place with nice setting for good conversation. Portions rather on the small side. For main I recommend the gnocchi, for dessert the apple date cake. Ok for one time visit, not a regular favorite.
Charged $6 for group reservation via OpenTable.
author: V A.

description: Slow service, overpriced, not well managed or run. Kitchen staff visibly distraught. Inattentive and unresponsive staff. Waited for 25 minutes to get seated when there were plenty of open tables. Small portions and served our appetizer at the same time as our main course.
author: Kyle D.

description:
I was really excited to try this place because of the stellar reviews on Yelp, but unfortunately, I was underwhelmed.

Service was great; quick, attentive, etc. No complaints on that front. And the space was super cute. 

The food itself, however, was mediocre at best. Thin-crust pizza wasn't anything to write home about; we ordered three pizzas: margherita, funghi, and a third one that's no longer on the menu (so I can't reference back to it). 

The margherita was very plain, even though we ordered it with burrata instead of the usual mozzarella. The funghi...I normally LOVE mushrooms on my pizza, but Piccino's style was a bit odd--it seems they pureed the mushrooms and used that as a topping, which made for a strange texture. The third pizza, we didn't even finish because it wasn't good, and the three of us left pretty much half of the third pizza on the plate. 

Very disappointing overall, sadly.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
They love their bitter and citrus here so if that is your flavor profile, then this is a fantastic spot for you. 

Had the very photogenic funghi pizza (the savory paste on it is lovely but the thin crispy crust is one of the best things ever), the aged goat cheese (much more aged and funky than expected but surprisingly delicious - especially with the bitter grapefruit compote on the side), and I think the tagliatelle with these bits of fried pork belly. Everything was spectacular.

Service was very attentive. They also brought out generous samples of wines when we couldn't decide. I think we ended up with a carafe of chardonnay but can't remember its name.

Also sitting at the bar is a lot more fun than the table. You get to watch the chefs prepare all the dishes which I quite enjoy.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
We were in the neighborhood and wanted something quick to eat and we saw Piccino Coffee Bar open.  We had dinner at the restaurant before and had an excellent meal so knew this place wouldn't disappoint.  My wife ordered the Sightglass coffee which she loves and we got some little snacks like cinnamon roll (which was great) and the ham sandwich.

Good spot for a quick pick me up.
author: Blake B.

description: Came here for brunch on a Sat. Service was ok. They have a lot of pizza options, not necessarily brunch options. Pizzas were good.
author: Faiz S.

description:
Food was good, but the service was worse than that of fast food chains. I would never go back, and agree with other Yelpers that this place doesn't even deserve a single star. 

It took nearly 40 minutes before our soup was served, and it was a Tuesday afternoon after 1pm. Our server did not know the meaning of customer service. She only stopped by the table twice: once after we were seated for 10 minutes with heads turned trying to flag down a person to order; the second time inquiring if we finished our food (this is when we were still actively eating our pizza with 2 slices still on the table!). Never once did anyone came by to give a status update on our food order. We waited 40 minutes for squash soup, and then wasted another 30 minutes for meatball and pizza. Stay away from Piccino unless you have plenty of time to kill and don't mind waiting on the lazy and clueless server.
author: Jessica K.

description:
I still dream of the first bite of the funghi pizza, that thin and crispy pizza crust goodness that melted in my mouth.  Oh how I long for another slice.   Piccino, I salute you and your culinary expertise.  

This was a great place for my girlfriend and I to catch up.  Good thing we made reservations or else we might have been wandering around trying to find a place to eat.  No way would we have been able to get it on this busy Tuesday night.  That's right, packed with people waiting on a Tuesday.  It's that good!

There wasn't a single item that touched our table that wasn't amazingly good to eat.  We had a summer bean salad, a housemade pappardelle with chicken, and their sauteed greens.  You can tell they really pick choice and fresh ingredients for their daily menus.  To finish, we also had a coconut panna cotta with berries.  Each dish was amazingly simple, yet bursting with memorable flavors.

Try to sit at the counter where you can see the food masterpieces being assembled.  You may have to wait a bit longer for your food, but it is well worth the wait.  Service on this visit was courteous and tactful.  I could tell they wanted to move us along to ordering, but the server was very good at noting that we were there to catch up with each other so our meal was paced out pretty well.  She was also very knowledgable with the wine list, which is a plus for a novice wine drinker like myself.  Only hiccup was that they wanted to seat us by the door next to a corner table that had people already seated when the room was not at all filled yet, but were good at allowing us to sit more in the middle of the room at our request.  

Remember - make a reservation and order at least one pizza.  You'll thank me later!
author: Maria S.

description:
Cute place in Dogpatch. It has an industrial California look.. open, light, airy. We had reservations for a Friday night but were late 45 minutes due to Giants' preseason game traffic. But they held on to our table! After letting them know we were running late, of course.
Very impressive wine list! Although they were out of the Bordeaux I wanted, which was Ok because the server recommended something similar which I liked. 

For food, we ordered:
- pork and beef polpette, basically meatballs which were so light and delicious. The tomatoes were very fresh. 
- Funghi pizza which was also good but not as good as the reviews may indicate
- Bianca pizza with egg.. this was definitely delicious! Yum. Good advice by the server to eat it fast or it turns chewy.

That's all we had because we ate some snacks beforehand d'oh. But it was good! If you're in the area, I'd recommend going. We took MUNI T from downtown and it's very convenient location at the 20th/3rd street stop, just 5 minutes walk to Minnesota St.
author: Vol T.

description:
Everything on the menu is delicious, however watch the hostess like a hawk! 

While my husband was following up with the hostess, he watched her arbitrarily cross our name  off the waitlist even though we were never located more than an earshot away. She did the same thing to a group ahead of us. After she corrected the issue, she went ahead and sat a different 2-person party ahead of us for no apparent reason. None of this appeared to be done with malice, just utter incompetence.

Additionally the hostess was grossly unrealistic with seating times, telling groups "a few minutes" for wait time when several groups ahead had been waiting for 40 min+. 

Normally I'm sympathetic to the pressures of this role, however this was the worst experience I ever had with a hostess. 

Food and service are great once you sit down... if you ever get the chance.
author: Lindsey W.

description:
Friendly. Small space. One shared table. 
Had a refressing iced tea.
author: Amy O.

description:
Absolutely charming. Simple and beautiful decor. Good service. Great food. Perfect crowd. My only qualm = the chairs, they are too low for the tables (the community table at least). 
We started with simple 'ol olives , you must order them!! I buy fancy olives often, eat them regularly when I go out but these olives are different. The olive oil was devine(at least that's my guess for the beautiful flavor). The chicories and fig salad was good, followed by an off menu chickpea dish that was full of flavor and perfect. The tagliatelle was one of my favorite dishes for tge evening, could have a nice big plate of that alone and would've been happy. The funghi pizza was good but a bit too salty for me, however I like a traditional margherita pizzas. We had a bottle of the Lamuri, unusual peppery finish, it was great. Perfect evening, can't wait to return.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: This was my third time for lunch at Piccino. I had the funghi pizza and my boss got the bianca with an egg. I love their pizzas. Thin and crispy. For my funghi pizza they spread like a type of mushroom tapenade as opposed to "sauce". Absolutely delicious.
author: Viyada S.

description:
15.01.31          2 visit
                        1st at new location

Not sure if I am correct ...
They used to on a corner where "LAB" located.

Pretty nice place.
Located off the side corner and side street.
I made a mistake on thinking ...
    Polpette was Pappardelle


Fungi pizza 
  is good
  The topping total covered the pie except the edge
  Good strong flavor ... 
    never could loose on mushroom pizza

Meatball polpette
   gotta remember ... it is not pappardelle (pasta)
   Pretty good
   Beef and pork mixture
   Nice seared crust outside
        Nice touch ... different ... seared part
        Adds more flavor and texture
   All meat only dish only with sauce
   roughly 2/3 to 1 lb of meat (wild estimate)
      I am pushing for 1lb of meat

We preferred the outside seating.
  Mild temp
  No wind
  Noisy inside
  Clear skies
  Hardly any cars
       located on a dead end street
       away from main 3rd Street
author: S.K. Y.

description: I love this place. It really IS Dogpatch. It's hipSter and yuppie but I love it. My Moto loves it and best of all its near Recchiutt Chocolate and RickShaw Bags! The kitchen is totally open and you can't work in this kitchen unless you're OCD/germophobe....which is great for me. The salad was small, but tasty and tasteful. The soup is plentiful and about equal to what I make, which is good. The Sunday Menu could use a little more pizzazz than panini and pizza. It's a very airy sweet little place
author: Kevin F.

description:
Worst experience ever.

My friend & I had a reservation as she just moved to Dog Patch and wanted to check out the restaurant. BIG MISTAKE.

The waitress came by after 10 or so minutes to offer us water...finally. Then, we asked for her recommendations. She told us that one entrée was just delicious... And then told us she's never had it before. That was just the beginning.

My friend asked for a particular varietal of wine recommendation. The waitress brought over another waitress to help figure this out. I suggested maybe you could let my friend taste some wines? They were like okay... And they brought over two wines, however they only had one glass. I gave them my wine glass so my friend could taste the wine. Again this is just the beginning.

Dinner started and we both had soup to start. My friend didn't like her soup and I was looking for flavor, so wanted pepper. We had to ask the wait staff to help us get some pepper. This is just ridiculous service.

For some reason we weren't getting the message about how terrible the food and the service were. It came time for dessert. We're at Italian restaurant so we figured the dessert has to be good. There was this item on the menu called pink squirrel... And we were curious to what is a pink squirrel. Shouldn't they just call it strawberry or something what is pink squirrel? We asked the waitress and once again her ability to describe the food was sub optimal. She said it was "some vodka infused dessert".

At this point I have never gone out to seek the manager at a restaurant but this was too awful. After telling the manager of this lovely story, she seemed to be much more concerned with who it was on the team as opposed to customer service; she was also not listening that her staff had never tried the food so how can they serve it or recommend it well?! We both left clearly no tip. The manager didn't even say goodbye or sorry about the service. Wow. 

AVOID THIS PLACE LIKE THE PLAGUE.

We only can hope a better place comes to Dogpatch soon to replace this one.

Ciao.
author: Sharon M.

description:
I am a Graduate student whose campus is near this restaurant, with very few other restaurants to choose from in the area.  I have tried to patronize this business several times in the last year, and every time I order food, they have been extremely rude, non customer-service oriented, and unpleasant.  They hardly ever answer the phone to place to-go orders, are extremely difficult when you want condiments for your pizza, and refuse to assist you with a smile.  

I ordered a pizza to go - and they took my order and then hung up on me without so much as a "goodbye". They said 15-20 mins - so I came back in 20 minutes and it seemed as though my pizza had been sitting there for 10 mins because it was cold by the time I walked ONE block back to campus...

As the other reviews state - SERVICE IS HORRIBLE HERE!!  Unless you are DESPERATE for food - I would not recommend them or their service!

If you want REAL Italian food in the Dogpatch, go to Marcella's on the corner of 22nd and Tennessee.
They have EXCELLENT SERVICE and real Italian food - homemade pastas, etc.  The owner and his son are from Italy and treat you with sincere compassion and gratefulness for being a customer. I have NEVER been disappointed!
author: Chrystal M.

description: Delicious - I enjoyed everything I ate here and I am a major foodie! Yum, yum, yum! I will be back.
author: Meredith L.

description: Be aware of the extra costs that are added on to your bill at this restaurant - and how they add up.  One is asked "Water, sparkling or still?" - you are paying for the sparkling.  If any ONE at the table gets bread - you pay extra for the bread.  If you modify any of the dishes such as the pizza and ask for a generous helping of an ingredient already on the pizza - you pay additional.  There is a San Francisco health surcharge of 4% - 5% - again an add on.  If you are a party of 6 or more - a 20% gratuity is added on.  My husband, not knowing and taking all of this into consideration left an additional 15% on top of everything.  I was stunned at the amount of our total bill.  Be forewarned.
author: Kristina G.

description: I do like how they have different things on their menu, the location and the place itself is awesome! I just always have an ok time here. To me there is nothing that stands out. Service is ok. Food is ok. I would not take kids here, their menu is...minimal. I dont know if there is a kids menu, but a margarita pizza is the only thing i get there.
author: Kim V.

description: Amazing pasta dishes. Great vegetarian options. Solid wine list. Great service. Pizza is excellent. Great location. The cafe is awesome coffee and espresso and scones. Love this place!
author: sean s.

description: We did family-style and not one dish disappointed, from the piccino bread and winter salad to the ragu, moroccan spiced chicken and polpette.  Simply awesome.  Thank you chef and awesome wait staff!
author: Paul M.

description:
What a charming, cozy, sophisticated cafe. Dogpatch isn't where most of us would think of heading for a delightful, airy, setting straight out of Umbria, but turn onto a hidden, dead-end block of Minnesota Street and there it is.

My wife and I met our daughter there for dinner the other night and sat at the counter surrounding the open kitchen. We started off sharing an amazing mushroom pizza. Each of us had a salad then a pasta for dinner all of which were as fresh as could be, and showcased bright flavors. There is nothing that I can say that is too extravagant for the quality of this simple Italian perfection.

My only caveat, and it's not enough to ding a star from the rating, but a caution, is that hostess station is very friendly, but kind of chaotic. We ended up sitting about an hour after was estimated, and then we finally sat due to us keeping an eye on the situation. The upside is that they have a nice wine list to sample while you wait. 

But, go. It's more than worth the trek to Dogpatch.
author: Rick H.

description:
YESSS!  My kinda place.  Fabulous food and even better service.

It's a friendly, open, welcoming, bustling, neighborhood kind of place. We entered Piccino to a warm greeting, immediate seating at the bar, and a lovely atmosphere filled with positive vibes.

First up - special wines are posted on the chalk board near the bar.  Our som's recommendations were great.

Next - food.  Lots of small bites for my party of two.
  *The Buratta with polenta is DIVINE.  A must-try.
  *Golden beet salad will make you love beets (in case you don't already).
  *funghi pizza.  Very good - interesting flavors.  I would say that Beretta's might be 
   better.  A little tip for your pizza aficionados out there.

Next - dessert.  chocolate hazelnut torte.  It's my sh*z.

Finally - Dessert wine!  Um, this came on the house and honestly, I have no idea what we had.  But it was dang good so thank you :)

The only misstep is that they forgot to give us our doggie bag (yes, I do take food with me. Just don't have the heart to waste).  The server was googling over my friend the whole time, so I guess his mind was just somewhere else..

Other than that, the pleasure was all mine.
author: Angella S.

description:
I just went there tonight for the first time with my son - I'm trying to become a more diligent yelper.
My son is 3, by the way, and tonight was Saturday night, and it was just he and I.  Not exactly what a hip Dogpatch restaurant wants to see walking through the door.
However! The hostess greeted us very nicely.  I think we came in at 6:45 PM, so the dinner crowd was pretty much in full swing if not on the cusp.  When she asked if we had a res and I said no, she said we could sit at the bar area facing the store they are attached to.  For a hot second I thought we were being relegated to no-man's land because "it's-a-mom-with-small-child" and I got momentarily pissed (good thing I have a bangin' poker face), but I Zen-ed out on that feeling because I totally got that it was Saturday night and they literally have NO idea if my kid is chill or not.  So no problem.  The hostess totally decided to take it to the net, however, without any prompting, and brought some folded blankets so my son, George, wasn't eye-level with the bar by sitting on top of them.  Well played, my good hostess.
The server arrived pretty quickly and, as we are simple folk with simple needs, we got our crackers lickity split, as well as my vino (praise!).  The crackers they have as an appetizer are really worth ordering - large, maybe 6 inches long and 3 inches wide, they have a remarkably Zaatar flavor to them and just the right punch of sea salt.  My son and I loved them.  
Our pizza came out in due course, meaning like 8 minutes - perfect.  We got a simple margarita and my son, George, seriously should have been on camera when he bit into the slice: "This is GOOD pizza, mommy!" with his little elf voice and face.  I actually DID try to have him do it again on camera, but he's very Greta Garbo - you better catch him the first time.   I did take a picture, though, so I'll add it here.  
Also, George was being so freakin' good, that I got like 800 smiles from both staff and patrons.  A nice feeling for all, and indicative of the place attracting a good crowd. 
We got our check right when I asked, no prob.   
Also, the decor is very nice - not pretentious, not overly DIY or trying too hard or whatever.  Really classy and modern. They also have the added blessing of being on a corner, so there are many windows.  
I will definitely go back, probably without George, so I can have a date night and order whatever.  But I'd like to take him again as well, as he really enjoyed it, which made me enjoy it all the more.  I remember when Dogpatch didn't have a damn thing, and now it's this bustling neighborhood growing with fun stuff.  Piccino is a great addition to the growth and I hope it sticks around!
author: Lila G.

description: My husband and I used to frequent this restaurant often in 2007-2008 when they first opened and were a small operation with an amazing pizza and coffee counter. At that time, we were graduate students at UCSF and mission bay plus the Dogpatch neighborhood were beginning to develop. We fell in love with this restaurant and our families flew in from NY, Philadelphia, and LA, we had our (post PhD defence) graduation family celebratory lunch here.  It was perfect and we ordered perfect pizzas and sat outside, a meal we will never forget. We then left San Francisco and returned back East to continue our education and then careers. We returned a couple weeks ago for a double birthday brunch with an old friend. Wow, how things have changed!! First, the restaurant moved down the street one block and now occupies a very large, well lit, and airy elegant space in a yellow painted home adjacent to a fancy clothing store. We were delighted to see that despite their wonderful (congrats!!) expansion and growth, that the warm hospitality, kindness, and great pride in their food has not changed!  Their menu has expanded quite a bit beyond their superlative pizza to include tender meats and pastas and a host of desserts. We ordered lamb ragu pasta, white pizza, meatballs, salad, and all were truly superlative. Their pizza is a must...you won't eat better anywhere. The lamb ragu was also very special. Very flavorful without being gamey and perfectly seasoned on a bed of homemade pasta. They were so kind as I had no idea they had expanded and they were nearly packed when we arrived 15 min early without a reservation and they very kindly held a table for us without reservation. The chef, learning we were fans and patrons from the restaurant's beginning years, so generously brought us a pesto homemade pasta on the house which was so delicious as well as well as did not charge us for two birthday cake slices which were also absolutely delicious, esp the poppyseed cake. This was such a generous and kind gesture, and it made our reunion birthday brunch years later at our favorite San Francisco Italian restaurant so absolutely memorable and truly unforgettable. Thank you, Piccino!!!!
author: Laila D.

description: Really amazing dinner for three last night at Piccino.  Our server, Hana M, was perfect -- she followed our rhythms, offered informative answers to our questions, knew exactly when to stop by our table...really the best server I've ever had.  The steak was well-seasoned and had excellent texture.  The chianti classico (recommended to us) was delicioso!  Just a block from Caltrain.  Will return!
author: Heidi F.

description:
If you are HUNGRY take your money somewhere else! While this place has a few flavorful dishes it's not worth the price tag!! 

Had dinner here with my friends just this past Saturday night.  The moment I looked at the menu I wanted to run as fast as I could but since I was there with one of my girlfriend whom I do not get to see frequently and 4 others, I kept my mouth shut and endured it. 

I ordered the "little gem" salad (Main dish).  The name represents itself well. Little it was. I felt like the restaurant was putting me on a diet! I about LOL when the waiter placed my salad in-front of me and so did 2 of my other friends.  Of course we fought our laughs but it was not funny to say the least.  The salad was tasty but for the price, I'll never order it again. 

3 out of 5 people at our table was disappointed in the food, portions, and price tag. All of their dishes should be considered appetizers and the appetizers should not even be on the menu. 

You would have to order the whole menu to be full so unless you want spend a lot for nothing and no experience take your hard earned money somewhere else. 

I don't mind paying big bucks to have a good tasty meal and not cheap by any means but this was just bad. Nothing special about the location or the decor. Very bland and plain. I will never go back. This place falls in my list of "first time, last time". 

If I'm repeating myself here, it's because this experience is something, I never want to experience again. 

Happy Eating!
author: No H.

description: Cute spot and good food.
author: Sheryl M.

description:
The atmosphere was really strange. Kitchen staff all looked like they hated their lives. Waiters were the same.

The minestrone was a tiny bowl of some barely-salted clear broth with a few pieces of asparagus and orzo.

Definitely wouldn't go back.
author: Brooke K.

description:
Went here for brunch, the food was great, but the service was horrible.  The place was also completely empty, so you would think the service would be more on point, especially for how much they are charging for brunch.  I had to ask the waiter 3 times for red pepper flakes, because they do not have any type of hot sauce, even though they serve brunch - minus 1 star just for that.

Minus another 2 stars for the waiter coming over to the table and taking my champagne class that still had champagne in it - not even asking if I was done, if we needed anything, or wanted another drink.  

This place redeems themselves a little bit since they do take reservations, but still not worth the price and sub-par service.
author: Sichia B.

description: So a little back story first. My girlfriend was invited down to San Francisco from Portland, OR to work. She found a terrific listing on Airbnb to accomodate her stay and was told by her host that there was a great restaurant within walking distance. So, after working a 10 hour shift, she made the trip down to Piccino. She sent me a picture of the place and I thought it looked nice. She was really excited to eat there based off the recommendation she had been given. She went inside. This unfortunately is where the story goes south. She waited in line to order. Instead of taking her order, they helped the customer after her. Then the next after them. And so on. My girlfriend, defeated and realizing that Piccino had no interest in serving her, or had any customer service established etiquette (or common courtesy for that matter), left the restaurant sad and unknowing why she was treated with such disregard and disrespect. For this, I can whole-heartedly say, avoid this place. Or flip a coin. Who knows, maybe they will help you. . . . . Or maybe not
author: Johnathon F.

description:
19-August, Sunday:
Sorelle Bronca Prosecco di Valdobbiadene, (Veneto) Italy is fully refreshing and delightfully extra dry.

I enjoyed the simplicity of each of the pizzas we ordered, each had a flavor profile that was very individual to each of their own. In order of taste preference:

1. Funghi:  roasted mushrooms which a rich concentrated amount of flavor, shaved savory garlic, the stracchino was superbly smooth and was lusciously melted around all the aforementioned ingredients and paired very smoothly with the already strong introductions of flavor.
2. Salsiccia:  the house made sausage was lightly spiced, mozzarella and red onion that was perfected roasted releasing a subtle caramelized flavoring.
3. Margherita:  then finally the very traditional basic tomato, mozzarella and fresh basil. This was nothing short of flavorful, I just had a stronger liking towards the other pizzas when compared to the simplicity of this pizza.

Everything was reasonably priced; the space is open with high ceilings, very well illuminated with tall windows, the staff very personable and attentive. And dare I say it? I think the pizzas here are much better than Del Fina Pizzeria...

I can't wait to come back for dinner.
author: Ty T.

description:
(See pics) Review #1287. Delicious Italian cuisine, all fresh and flavorful. Great local place to enjoy some good food.

The arugula salad with hazelnuts was not just fresh and tasty but was also visually appealing. The squid pasta with tomatoes were perfectly done with properly ripen tomatoes peeled. The dish was simple but the taste was delightful.

Service overall was good.
author: T L.

description:
Some times athletes have good days. And some times even the most talented athletes have not-so-good days. Case in point, Colin Kaepernick's recent performance against the Chicago Bears. The same can be said about certain restaurants. 

So let me preface this review by saying that Piccino is a good restaurant. I know that they have a talented team in the kitchen, and they're a huge boon to the emerging Dogpatch neighborhood. But I have to admit, my dinner experience last night was slightly better than average. And that was a huge surprise. It was like their A-team had the night off, and their B-team was doing the best they could to hold court.

My friends and I ordered a sausage/red onion pizza to share. It was delicious! One of the best pizzas I've had in a while. Next time I dine here, I'm going to order a pizza all for myself. The others can fend for themselves. For our entree, we ordered pasta. And when I say pasta, I mean very simple pasta - spaghetti with tomatoes, olive oil, garlic, and chili pepper flakes. For some reason unbeknownst to me, it took over 30 minutes for our spaghetti to arrive. And when it did finally arrive, the pasta was crunchy. Trust me, I know what al dente is, but this spaghetti was like 2 minutes undercooked. The sauce was fine, but nothing mind-blowing. I guess I could've sent the dish back to the kitchen, but I was so hungry (and the service was so slow), I just decided to suck it up.

Speaking of service, our waitress was a bit on the dour side. No smiles. No welcoming attitude. She really gave off the vibe that she wanted to be somewhere else. And that's kind of a shame, because we were a fun-loving, easy-going, low maintenance table, and her sour disposition kind of ruined our happy buzz. 
In addition to the slow pasta service, I saw a few mishaps on the floor (this, unfortunately, is one of the down sides of having an open kitchen where you can see everything). First off, our pizza was delivered to the wrong table. We then received it a few minutes later, once the mistake was discovered. As I mentioned before, our pasta arrived 30 minutes later and undercooked (and this is a basic spaghetti dish that one could make at home in less than 10 minutes). Our dessert (Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous ice cream with espresso) arrived promptly. However, our decaf macchiatos arrived 10 minutes after the dessert. To her credit, the server admitted that she had accidentally spilled the drinks, hence the reason for the delay. But still, if you're spending $50 per person for dinner at a nice restaurant, you want your meal and coffee to arrive in a timely manner. 

All in all, Piccino is a fine restaurant. There's a lot about the cuisine, ambiance, and clientele that reminds me of Delfina in the Mission (and that's a compliment). I will certainly come back (especially for the pizza). I just hope that their A-team is back on the line.

P.S.
Piccino also has a coffee bar off-shoot (with delicious espresso beverages and pastries). Their 12 hour ice-coffee is a refreshing treat on a hot, summer (or Indian summer) day.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Had a fantastic lunch at Piccino. The place was packed by noon. Service was just attentive enough and really friendly and down to earth. The place looks and smells amazing, and I love the open kitchen. Beer and wine only.

For a nice lunch for 3 of us (cos we were saving room for ice cream from Mr. & Mrs Miscellaneous nearby), we shared:

-Roasted cauliflower with farro, pine nuts and grapes - 5 stars. Nutty, earthy, flavorful, comforting. Quintessential farm to table dish.

-Beef & pork polpette - 4 stars. 5 moist and juicy meatballs. Straightforward and simple.

-ricotta gnudi with mushrooms - 3.5 stars. Nice fall dish. Hearty with a nice ricotta bursting out of the pasta. Accompanied by earthy mushrooms.

-margherita thin crust pizza - 4 stars. I usually don't like thin crust pizza cos I'm a big carb fiend. However, their rendition was delicious! The crust remained crispy and had good flavor. The sauce was sweet and bright. Yum.

Beer and wine (all Italian) only. Look for the bright yellow house on the corner.
author: Catherine N.

description: Outstanding Italian restaurant in the city.  The place itself is really nice and relaxed and plenty of room to breathe.  The food was just so delicious.  I believe their menu changes regularly if not daily but the pasta dish we had with sausage and a delicate sauce was so tasty and the pizza with the sauasage was phenomenal.  They were very patient while I selected a glass of wine and brought me different bottles to taste before committing.  Definitely appreciated that.  We ended the night with the doughnuts and nutella ice cream and MAN that was to die for.  Next up will be trying their brunch.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I love to go here before and after climbing. The drinks are always well made (nice cappuccinos and well-made pour overs). The pastries have been pretty consistently lackluster. Can get really crowded and a little loud, as it's very small (seating at the tables maxes out at ~8)
author: Kate M.

description: Piccino is a coffee bar that reminds me a bit of when Blue Bottle's kiosk first opened. It has that open-air garage type feel with minimal seating. I guess at some point, they switched from Blue Bottle to Sightglass coffee, but no matter. The latte was $4.75 for a modestly large size. The baristas were skilled in creating some of the better latte art I've seen. It was nice to enjoy a beautifully crafted cup of espresso on a sunny Saturday afternoon in the city.
author: Bailey Z.

description: What a wonderful meal! Tonight the Piccino kitchen was as good as it has ever been. The grilled octopus salad was divine. The pasta courses and pork belly were excellent. And the service was excellent--attentive, friendly, timely, welcoming. I had posted a Yelp review after a disappointing experience with both food and service a few months ago (after which I received a call from one of the owners apologizing and vowing to do better), but those problems have been completely eliminated. I am so delighted that one of my long-time favorite restaurants has returned to its superb form. Can't wait to go back!
author: Sheryl F.

description: Beautiful setting. Limited menu but the food was good and service decent.  Great place in this part of town...
author: Cynthia T.

description: Not sur what others see in it.  Pizza sauce taste like jarred tomato sauce.  Pastas odd flavor. I had the sausage with butter vegetable downing out the flavor. Worst of all was the 58 dollar rib eye with the oddest rub have ever experienced.   Salads leafy and not a lot of girth.  It's a menu that just tries to hard.
author: mark d.

description:
Great food!  I had dinner there last weekend and sat at the counter.  It's casual, but great!  You could taste the freshness and quality in all of the dishes.

My friend and I got a half bottle of wine, shared an appetizer, pasta and pizza, and I was beyond satisfied.  We ordered:
- Ribeye Carpaccio
- Funghi Pizza
- Garganelli Pasta

Everything was FANTASTIC! I wonder how/why it took so long for me to discover Piccino!
author: Audrey C.

description:
Came here for the first time for dinner a few days ago with a friend.  The food was excellent, but the service was awful.  The only reason why this isn't a 5 star review is because of the server.  The greeter was a young woman who was wonderful, we had 7:30pm reservations and our table wasn't quite ready, but she was attentive and kept us updated on wait times, so no problems there. 

Our actual waitress was horrible.  She was a tight lipped woman with short hair who didn't smile once.  She didn't even introduce herself, the first words out of her mouth were "do you know what you want?"  We had to flag down the greeter to get some water.   When we had finished our meals, she came over and put the dessert menu on our table without saying a single word and just walked away.  

My friend and I were laughing at just how absurd the entire interaction was the whole night.  I almost wanted to ask her if we offended her or did anything wrong, because it was just so ridiculous.  Every other staff member we talked to was more pleasant than this woman. 

The food was excellent.  I highly recommend the pork ragu - it was seriously the best pasta I've ever had in my life.  We got a salad and roasted tomato soup to start,  great.  We shared the ragu, and I had the pork loin and my friend had trout for entrees, both excellent.  Pork loin a bit pricey for what it was, but was fine.  Dessert was goat cheese tart which was delicious as well. 

Decor was warm and inviting, loved the wood panels.  Open kitchen. 

All in all I'll probably be back, but will be on the look out for that awful server.  If I end up with her again I will seriously request for another waiter/waitress.
author: X X.

description:
We chanced upon it during a stroll through Dogpatch and I'm glad we did. Being just slightly hungry we shared the Strozzapretti with a delectable cream sauce. Highly recommended and I can't wait to try more pasta here. 

BTW I didn't care for the ambience, which is a bit 70's-slash-cafeteria-esque, but the wait staff was friendly and knowledgable.
author: Emily H.

description: Still 3 stars...the food was much better this time.  But two big problems...waitress had this air of smug attitude.  Really unnecessary.  Secondly, my clothes reeked of cooking smell. Many other restaurants have open kitchens but the ventilation system here is clearly inadequate.  Not a place for a date unless you like making out with a chimney afterwards.
author: Eric C.

description: Went with a friend (who just moved to town) for lunch. Incredibly happy we did! We arrived about 15 mins before the lunch crowd and were greeted with smiles. With the warm welcome and lovely decor, our first impressions were spot on for what we were hoping for. The food only made our experience better. We ordered 1. beet arancini, goat cheese crema, fines herbs AND 2. Pizza: datteri: cauliflower, taleggio, date, olive tapenade, arugula, chili (chili flakes in a sweet little wood bowl on the side-perfect because I like spice and my friend, does not). One bite into the beet dish and we both laughed, literally, with delight. The pizze was just as impressive and perfectly paired with the beet dish. The beet dish and pizze, combined were perfect for the two of us to share for lunch, with a slice sent home with my friend. Wonderful food and a lovely, happy atmosphere.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Visited for lunch on a Sunday. 2 stars for food and service, 4 stars for ambiance and friendliness. 
Although we came after 1pm for lunch we got what looked like a brunch menu - and not a good one at that. Most of the menu was pizza with some good looking Italian salad options but few mains. It looked very limited and was not what we expected.
We settled for squash soup (with bread) as a starter and scrambled eggs to share as the main, accompanied by 1 wine and a water. The main came before the starters which we had to ask for. The main was OK. The wine good. The wine came 5 mins before the water.
The starters came with no bread which we also had to ask for. The soup was good except for a thumb sized chunk of ginger in one of them.
Finally we were charged for a juice or something we didn't order or receive.
The service was nice and responsive when we asked for everything but we didn't really want to ask for everything, or get things in the wrong order, or get charged for stuff we didn't order or consume.
The ambiance is very nice. Its a pity they couldn't deliver on everything else.
author: Chris D.

description: The atmosphere is beautiful especially on a warm SF day . We ordered the funghi pizza i love mushrooms so it was great to me , however my husband and kids gave it an ok . The French toast was good and the Carmelized apples made it great . Over all cute place if your in the neighborhood,  but not a must go to.
author: S R.

description:
I live down the street from Piccino, so I'm there fairly often. 

Today I had the garden green salad and the Margharita Pizza.  The salad was perfect, the greens were fresh and the radishes weren't hot.  Not too much dressing and the shallots added a nice touch. 

The Pizza took a little while to get out, there was a back up of some sort, and it was worth waiting for, hot and spicy. 

The service is always great and they pay a lot of attention to details here.
author: Thomas F.

description: Wonderful food, atmosphere, and service. We sat at the bar where they prepare the food. Very enjoyable. Had a great fresh salad and their meatballs. So delicious. You will love it.
author: Patricia B.

description:
What a good night .... there are so many places around the globe that do Pizza, however few do a great one. Well Picconi serve Pizzas that are truly outstanding and I just wish I lived closer. 

We came on the combination of guidance from new acquaintances  and social media it was terrific decision. The two pizzas we had were the Funghi, which includes the mushrooms, stracchio and garlic, and the second was the Salsiccia which is made with home made sausage, mozzarella and red onions. They were in the wow range! The taste, the texture and they looked the part too......

We enjoyed our own Pinot Noir on corkage.....and along with steady service we left thinking if only more Pizza joints could produce them this good!! And very good value for money.
author: Mick A.

description:
This place was very average for me. 

Nothing I disliked, nothing I particularly liked either. 

Prices are normal for an average place in sf I guess... I felt like when I looked at the menu I got the feeling that the restaurant was trying to hold itself up to a higher quality than where it is right now. Don't get me wrong tho, the service/ staff is not pretentious in any way.they were all quite friendly!

The burrata starter was meh....it had "heirloom polenta" how the fuck do you produce heirloom polenta?! Tasted and looked just like regular old polenta. Anywhoo, not bad not awesome, just there. Not worth the price. 2 little squares of polenta with a slice of burrata on top and couple leafy greens...

Mussles - again not worth the price. It looked like it was about 1/4lb. Teeeeeny-tiny portion. Enought for my cat to eat. If I had one. As for as taste it was normal seasonings and the mussels were very tender so points there!

Margherita pizza - not so great. Super duper average if not a little under par for me. I'd try another pizza, some other ones sounded really tasty and interesting.  My date picked this one so I'm a bit biased maybe? 

Coconut financial-  (I think that's how you spell it..)  tiny little thumbelina type portion but it was really tasty and it overly sweet at all. Nothing I'd write home (or post on fb) about.

I want to like this place more but I feel like being in sf you have the luxury of spool many good eats, why settle on mediocre?
author: Ashley Y.

description: It's really too bad I couldn't give you a 4 or even a 5.  You can blame your hostess and wait staff for that.   Came here for lunch last minute because we were tired of waiting for a table at Aina.   My friend has eaten here before and he's got great taste so I knew we would be having a wonderful meal.   The food was delicious!  There was a long wait between our appetizers and our pizza and polpette.   The hostess was walking by so I asked her if she could check on our food.  She looked at me and said "uh no."  I was shocked.  I have never experienced that before.  What do you mean no??  So then I see our waiter and ask him.   He wasn't very friendly either. I know my friend left you all a very undeserving generous tip.   What's up with the staff here??  My friend mentioned that since the restaurant was written up in the new york times years ago that their service has gotten snooty.   You might think you are all that but don't underestimate the power of your crappy service and how it will not make me want to return.  Next time I want a good pizza with good customer service...... I will go instead to All Good Pizza  - a delicious pizza food truck.   Quite honestly the more I think about it....I can get better customer service at Taco Bell or McDonald's.
author: Cortne B.

description: Dropped by the coffee bar side - great service and a very dedicated and attentive staff. The line is long, however it moves pretty fast :).
author: Anh Van P.

description: Stopped by without a reservation but seating was available outside for dinner. Ordered an iced tea, homemade sausage pizza and zeppole for dessert.  Everything was fresh and delicious. Even my iced tea was better than I've had in a long time.  The zeppole are a must have so don't pass on them.  The service was excellent in the beginning but slowed considerably during prime dinner time.  The servers were very friendly and professional.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Reena P.

description: Really enjoyed the wine and food at Piccino. Things are a bit on the pricey side but they're quite worth it. For comfort food with generous portion, try the pork loin.
author: Tabris C.

description: Great Feel in the restaurant.  Baked egg super delish. Catherine was an excellent server and we never needed to ask for a single thing. Solid brunching
author: Thomas B.

description:
Okay this could easily be three stars.  A nice room.  Good service.  But I had the pizza today - the mushroom (funghi) option and did not care for it at all.  It tasted like ground up mushroom puree on a cracker with a couple globs of goat cheese and some slimy additional mushrooms piled here and there.  I did not finish and did not want to take the extra slices home.  Pizza is not the strongest suit of this establishment but what is?  My companion left most of her parpadelle on her plate.

I dunno - I had not been in a while and feel no desire to return soon despite it being close to my office.
author: Nathan D.

description:
Uneven. This is a cute bustling Dogpatch restaurant with potential, airy interior and open kitchen, high ceilings, nicely dressed casual crowd. We popped in on a busy Friday for a quick light bite. It was busy and we opted for immediate outside seating, though it was chilly. 

The dinner menu is short with fancy pizza offerings, pasta, some salads.

A innovative pasta of mint, chili and parsley was well executed.  But was brought out first. 

The starter came out last, a "special" burata and egg plant with toasted bread. The bread was burnt was of immediate concern. This is a classic line manager failing. Burnt toast is easily remedied, throw away, start over. The dish itself was not special. The eggplant over powered the delicate cheese. The entire dish came off as it was a forced special.

That was dinner. 

As it was a quick meal, dim outside lighting and cool, we let the waitress pick a glass of red for the meal. Bad move. Her (or the managements choice) pick was $17 a glass. A nice pour in nice stemware, but sticker shock. Granted a typical glass of wine is easily $11-14, it's was poor form to go upper end. 

The desire to fill the house at all costs, had the front standing room only with patrons waiting creating an airport restaurant scene. Considering my review, not sure this is a place to stand in line for.
author: Chris K.

description:
I had a wonderful brunch on a Sunday afternoon at Piccino.  The atmosphere is casual with a mix of families with children, 20-something couples and even a few lone diners at the bar observing the staff in the open kitchen.

I started with stracciatella soup which is a light, delicate version of egg drop soup.  The salsiccia pizza was delicious with sweet, fresh onions and red pepper flake.

Piccino serves several wines by the glass.  I was impressed with 7 Fuentes from the Canary Islands, very light and tasty.  Perfect for brunch!
author: Lance W.

description: I stopped in to Piccino after working out at my CrossFit gym up on 25th & Cesar Chavez to see my weightlifting training partner, Flying Squirrel (of course that's not her real name, but hey, it sounds cool!).  Flying Squirrel pours coffee here, and having tried some of her cold brew, I was inspired to hang out for awhile, take in the Dogpatch scene, and sip away at my delicious pour over on the fourth of July.  I sat for about 2 hours just people watching and I was seriously impressed with how many regulars stop in here.  The shop's not big, but there's a huge following here.  Flying Squirrel and her crew are almost like local celebrities - everyone knows their name!  I have yet to try Piccino's lunch and dinner service, but I hear it's delicious. I can't wait to come back!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I was really impressed with this place!

I have been here a couple of times now and every dish I've tried was wonderful.  I think the reason this food stands out compared to other italian restaurants is the freshness of the ingredients.  I love almost all italian food and who doesn't?  What Piccino does so well is leave you feeling full and satisfied without overstuffing you.  

The broccoli and almond gremolata is delicious.  It is sort of like a pesto but with big chunks of almonds instead of ground pine nuts and broccoli instead of basil.  It is a great combination of flavors.

The pork and beef polpettes with parmesan are like fancy meatballs.

The salsiccia pizza with sausage and red onion was great but the pizza bianca with parmesan, pecorino, mozzarella with garlic and chili oil was to die for.  I forgot my leftovers at my boyfriend's house and I still haven't forgiven him for eating them!

The desserts we tried were all delightful too.  

Every dish is full of flavor but doesn't leave you with a heavy feeling in your stomach.

We had really friendly service too and all the food came out fresh and hot.  If you sit at the counter, you can even watch the cooks as they prepare your food!
author: Chrissy M.

description:
This place just makes me happy.

Other than a 20 minute wait despite a reservation (granted, it was Friday), and some initial slowness to take our order and get out first dishes, everything just tickled me. The subsequent times, they just killed it in every way possible.

- Burrata with [anything] - awwwsome, I always order the burrata primi
- Polpette meatballs - Uh pork AND beef? Genius. Meatball hall of fame.
- Rib eye tartar - Superior, awesome crackers
- Peach gazpacho - Best soup EVER. Spent the whole night watching them make it to find out the ingredients.
- Stracci pasta - The pasta is just OK, but the mushrooms...oh the mushrooms
- Funghi pizza - Good thin crust, but there's better pizza in town
- Bianca pizza - Good, better than Funghi, but can do better
- Margherita pizza - Solid, similar to Beretta's
- Ice cream sandwich - Solid, not very sweet
- Chocolate brioche & coffee ice cream - Not too sweet or too dense
- Zeppole - Just get this. Don't even think about it.

At ~ $40-50/person (t+t incl), one of the best deals to be found. From the relaxed, clean, open atmosphere, to the open kitchen where you can watch the precision and love they put in, to the attentive and uncannily cheery and friendly staff, to the simple but consistently delicious food - this place is the total package.
author: Snuffles B.

description: This is a cute, quaint spot with great service and delicious food. I enjoyed the atmosphere, but I wasn't too thrilled that the sinks and mirror were outside of the restrooms. There's no privacy if you needed to "touch up." It's small and it's better to make a reservation, but I did enjoy how the bar setting allowed you to see everything be made in front of you. The food was hot and the ingredients were wondrously fresh. I had the garden salad for an appetizer, the linguine with pancetta for main course and zeppoles for dessert. I enjoyed every bite. I wish they were in Monterey, but at least I know of a place to go my next visit.
author: Shanieka J.

description: This place is delightful and is open for lunch at odd hours, which is a plus in my book. I tried the fungi pizza once and I haven't been able to order anything else. It is truly delicious and amazing. They make an intense mushroom pesto-y thing - chopping the mushrooms really fine until it is a paste, and smear it all over the pizza. It has a few flecks of parsley and some oil and that's it. Highly recommended.
author: Ruchi M.

description:
Piccino's is a great weekend brunch place for us. My son loves to go here and get the little basket of freshly baked pastries. It's also right beside a playground which is great for toddlers and young kids.

Go for the pizzas or the baked egg dish and you can't go wrong.
author: Curt B.

description: My experience couldn't have been better. Found the decor stunning with so many beautiful flower arrangements. I wish more restaurants in SF had fresh flowers! I had a mushroom pizza that was delicious. You could easily tell the restaurant places the highest standard for ingredient selection. Everything tasted like it was grown in the backyard - and it practically was as they source all their ingredients from local farms. I also shared the Polpette (meatballs) that had a tomato sauce so fresh and simple. It was perfect. I can't wait to go back and give dinner a try. On Mondays they do Bistecca Fiorentina which I haven't found many places to do over here. So happy Piccino is in SF.
author: Stanley B.

description:
I was into this charming spot a few weeks ago for dinner with a friend.

I've been before but I haven't gotten around writing a review and I think they deserve it.

I had a few courses that were not only tasty but stylishly plated without being fussy. The atmosphere in this place is wonderfully warm and welcoming.

When in the Dogpatch, this is certainly not a place to miss. Lunch or dinner. YUM.
author: Gilbert B.

description:
A cute little coffee bar that's really for takeout service unless you manage to grab one of the two tables there. They serve Sight Glass coffee here, which I don't like as much comparing to the other local coffee roasters, but they have very, very good pastries and food. I could not stop eating the quiche (literally gulped it down!) and the coconut macaroon was very good.

Stoping by for a snack (and maybe an espresso drink) is definitely good if you're in the neighbourhood.
author: Alice C.

description:
Quality food in a relaxed environment  3 of us ordered a bunch of things to share...creating our own mini tasting menu for lunch. The tall ceilings in the dining room makes it feel spacious. Commenting on dishes we had, the menu apparently changes with the availability of ingredients. Everything was either good or great. Parking was easy (always something to note !).

While some reviewers rave about the polpette, I found the sauce to be tasty and fresh, the meat balls somewhat bland = good not great. The house made sesame crackers  - was an unexpected tasty treat, had them with the roasted beet salad (with walnuts) which was very tasty and nice combo of textures. Farmers cheese/artichoke/meyer lemon appetizer/salad concoction was tasty... soft blobs of cheese (I think the nature of this cheese is that it is fresh - as in not aged) tasty while not a Chev're it had that kinda texture. Panini brisket sandwich was very tasty.

Service was attentive and professional (almost more so than I would have expected). I think the bill came to about $ 70 which included tip, felt like it was worth it. Will be back again. .. and want to try one of their pizza's.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Piccino uses sightglass coffee, I believe, and all of their baristas but one are friendly. I may be biased since I'm in the neighborhood, but this is the best almond milk latte or cold brew coffee in SF in my opinion. Their ginger scone is my favorites and the muffins won't disappoint. The only downside is that there is an occasional wait if you're in a hurry to catch Caltrain or something. Overall, they are the gold standard in the art of espresso.
author: Stefan R.

description: Excellent! There is nothing I wouldn't recommend here, and it might be the only restaurant where I would say, if you can afford to not look at the price, do it, just get everything! Sidenote: one  of my biggest pet peeves is when the waitstaff at an expensive restaurant ignores me if I'm not dressed well. I've come to Piccino dressed in ripped jeans and full of chalk (dogpatch is right around the corner and it's almost impossible to clean climbing chalk off your clothes after bouldering), and they never batted an eyelash and I got the most attentive and friendly service ever! I now try to look more presentable when I go, just because I don't want to be rude to them when they're so nice and professional to me, lol! Anyway, this is the sign of a truly good restaurant: when they can afford to give excellent service to everyone. Hope they can keep it up, and I'll be going there for many years to come.
author: I R.

description:
Fancy and cute af decor. You're gonna love the outside dining in good weather, and the lovely modern design and cool chairs inside. 

Basically only get the pizzas and salads because everything else is overpriced and the portions are tiny. I ate here for brunch. Had the pulled pork and squash, and the sausage pizza. Pulled pork was delicious with these small potatoes and squash that are roasted, but the dish was like 6-7 bites and $18. The pizza was a standard 12" and it was good. 

Very well done but nothing too special, also had this hibiscus mimosa. Quality champagne, low sugar, and very very good/flavorful. But $10 for a tiny glass. 

Come here if it's a date and you wanna spend the money. Whole area is cute, attached to a minimalist fashion boutique. Bring a dog, spend a lot of money, and look cute. ( * o_o)
author: Megan L.

description:
We were in the neighborhood and decided to stop by here. There was a 30 min wait and that was fine. 

Mostly the food is delicious , but I do have a bone to pick with them on the food aspect.

We ordered the chicory date salad -- which had exactly one small measly piece of date.We ordered the oya pizza. The pizza was great but I kept wondering where the calabrian chili was. Turned out there were two slices where some of it was reluctantly placed. 

This is what irritated me the most - do not put ingredients on the menu , if you don't want them in the dish.
author: aditi g.

description: Smoked trout salad and the burrata were amazing.  Loved the vibe of the dining room--clean, modern, and comfy.  Desserts were great too (pear satin and apple date cake).
author: Dave K.

description: Would have love to patronize local business but the 2 ladies behind the counter r more interested in talking to each other than to take my order!!!!! What kind of business is this? Do not complain when u go out of business ... Ur attitude toward customers will definitely do that .. There were only 2 guys in front & no one behind ... What's the deal???? I'll take my business elsewhere ... Where the business understands that good customer service goes a long way ! I understand a short few seconds of conversation but to make a customer stand there to wait for when u r ready to work is not acceptable ... Sightglass - take ur coffee elsewhere .. This place do no justice for u!!! Also watch out for the flies on the pastries !
author: Jay S.

description: My review is based on one thing...THE TERRIBLE CHEAP PLASTIC CHAIRS!! We didn't stay because the chairs are so ridiculous. Even my 5'11" boyfriend looked like a midget at the table!! What is up?? Has no one ever complained about the chairs. And, my back hurt after 5 minutes of sitting in them, straining to reach the table. Are you kidding?
author: a. r.

description: Piccino is my favorite resto in Dogpatch, great Italian food, open kitchen, friendly service, nice ambiance and they have a smaller cafe next door. Their appetizers, pasta and pizzas are great!
author: Ennie L.

description: This is another one of those hidden gems of dog patch. It was a warm evening and a glass (couple actually) of prosecco with house made grapefruit juice was perfect. We had a few different things at our table and everyone loved their food as I did my papperdelle with generous portion of pancetta . We did try a bunch of desserts and the beignet type fried dough was just amazing. We will be back for sure. I would dock one  star though just because it was a little hard to get the waiters attention but since it was super busy, it's understandable.
author: Malika S.

description: Everything on the small menu is fresh and lovingly prepared. I had the pizza bianca with an egg--a new experience that I hope to repeat often.
author: Jane S.

description:
Yes, it's true. I'm a New Yorker in Northern California... otherwise known as "WHERE CAN I FIND A DECENT SLICE???" 

I'm so sorry to disappoint, but this just isn't the place. While the ambiance is lovely - hardwood floor, dim lighting, packed bar - the food is sub-par. For all the talk of "amazing pizza," I was expecting a menu boasting creative creations. But there aren't any. And while I appreciate the effort, good pizza isn't good simply because the crust is thin (and it's really thin). The tomato sauce honestly tasted like ketchup. Both my friend and I - another NY transplant - were severely disappointed. Yes, the dishes are presented and prepared with style, but that doesn't make the pizza taste better either.

I also think Piccino, due to their unwarranted and insane popularity, need to hire more staff. Our poor waitress was running herself ragged trying to take orders and fill water glasses.
author: Ray J.

description:
A coffee bar that's essentially run out of a garage, behind the actual restaurant?  Yeah, that's not quite what I had expected, but who cares when the coffee is good, right?

Since there wasn't anyone around when my friend and I arrived, I was pretty happy we were able to just walk right up and order (especially after reading some of these reviews about the wait and the lines).  I thought about ordering their regular drip coffee, but decided to get something a little different and went with the Americano instead.  The guy working the counter did a pretty good job of crafting my drink, and I liked the robust flavor.  Not quite to the level of Philz for me, but still pretty darn solid.  Of course, it helps when you've got Sightglass coffee to work with.  Not to take anything away from Piccino (since you still need to know how to make the drinks), but it helps when you have something good to start with.

There are a few tables around for those that want to grab a seat, but it's really more of a grab-and-go kind of spot.  After all, when it's all said and done...it's still the size of a garage.
author: Mike L.

description:
The shop is really small.

I had a short dry cappuccino. It wasn't anything special, but it was good. 

The girl who was working was nice. 

I had coffeecake, which was yummy, moist, and better-than-average. 

I'd come back if I was in the area, maybe.
author: Alex F.

description:
If nothing else, the Dogpatch is perhaps the neighborhood in San Francisco most easily accessible from the south.  Piccino has easy freeway access, and also plentiful street parking close by.

Saturday dinner was a popular affair, but our reservation was honored exactly when we arrived - though maybe not so much for diners arriving for later seatings, who crowded the entrance for much of our meal, occasionally propping the door open and allowing a chill wind to blast past the bar.  They had a neat child seat for our one year old which hung directly off the end of the table.

The wine list is heavy on European options, with a few Californian selections thrown in seemingly at random. They offer many wines by the glass and caraffe, and our sever seemed to have opinions on the list, though they may or may not have been borne out by the bottle we ended up choosing.

Goat cheese and date cake starter came with a wonderful meyer lemon compote - well balanced and delicious.  Smoked trout mantecato was a small glass jar of mild-flavored fish salad, which went well with the crostini and strawberry salad.  The cured sardine had excellent flavors and a very appealing plating - definitely recommended.

Despite it being early on at Saturday service, they were out of the pappardelle with rabbit sugo and perhaps a few other items.  The milk-braised pork with english pea ragu was hearty, though the legumes ranged from sweet and light to somewhat bitter and starchy.  The funghi pizza, with thin and crisp crust, was well-flavored as advertised, though missing the egg we had ordered on it.  Pizzas are almost personal-sized, maybe good to share between two people depending on your appetite.

Like many of the plates, desserts were small portions.  Of particular note, the passion fruit crema was strongly flavored, perhaps too strongly for its accompaniments, but good.

Overall, service was friendly and relatively fast, giving us plenty of time for a leisurely meal despite the crowds of aspiring diners in the front.  While this is definitely not the place you want to be if you are in the habit of complaining about small plates for rather high prices, the food is uniformly well executed and delicious.
author: Albert H.

description:
While the food here is great, the service has really gone downhill lately. On the 19th, we had a group of 6 for weekend brunch. 

The restaurant was out of multiple dishes, and our server could have cared less about checking on us. 

Although the restaurant was half empty, it took 15 minutes for us to be greeted, and another 15 to get water. The food service was slow, and after lunch it 20 minutes for the waiter to come by to ask is we wanted after meal drinks/coffee.

The final straw: an automatic 20% gratuity for the bad service as we were a group of 6.

Sigh.
author: Sarah K.

description:
A nice modern neighborhood California Italian restaurant in the hipster San Francisco Dogpatch neighborhood. Pizza is good. Worth eating at if you are nearby, not worthy if you need to drive more than 15 minutes. Service is better than the past. Menu changes a lot. Barbacco is better for pasta.

Picks:
Winter citrus salad, fennel, dandelion, aged goat cheese, sherry vinaigrette ($14) decent, bitter greens, fruity accent.

Salsiccia pizza: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion ($17) soft center, nice crust, slight twang to sausage.

OK:
Piccino bread, olive oil ($3) was just ok. Buy some Acme and don't charge. Olive Oil tasted of quality.

Pans:
Strozzapreti, roasted brassicas, garlic crema, aged goats cheese, chili ($15) sour sauce made this weird. Overdone veggies.

Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Very Good
Service - Good
Value - Good

Would we come back - Maybe
author: Ellen H.

description: Great food for brunch. Service was great...yogurt granola was great...surprised they charged almost $4 for coffee.  And u had to lay for refills...ridiculous.  Tried it once but wouldn't go back for this reason.
author: Ara L.

description:
Best Americano in San Francisco.  You pay the premium price but the beans and processes used at Piccino Cafe beat out the competition (yes, I am talking Blue Bottle).

They have some great breakfast snacks: the Ricotta Torta, the Savory Turnover or the Quiche.  If you have a sweet-tooth go for a ginger snap.
author: Grant L.

description:
Back in July, as I was prepping to begin a 2 month-long vegan dietary lifestyle, I looked up the "internet" for best pizza places in San Francisco...
Piccino's was high up in the list and surely it did live up to that ranking!
The pizza was really well made, right from the crust, which wasn't all  doughy or too thick, it was the right amount of thickness, well baked, not too chewy.
We shared a couple of pizzas between the 5 of us and some antipasti..
The toppings on the pizza were fresh, went really well with each other.
The pizza wasn't too cheesy, not too saucy either.
They have a good selection of wines. I dont remember what red wines my friend ordered but know this... the two bottles were long finished before we finished our meals.
author: Kinjal S.

description:
Cute (female) baristas.

Good mochas.

Tasty sweet pastries (not a savory fan).


The line does get outrageously long at times.
author: Evan W.

description:
My friend and I came here the other day after we found out that the place that we wanted to go to was closed for the holidays-:( There aren't that many restaurants around the area within walking distance, so we decided to eat at this place since her brother told her that it's a good place. It's just OK at best. They mostly serve thin crust pizzas and salads there. 

We shared the pickled vegetables which weren't that great. We also shared one of the salads with some tangerines in it. It was just OK too. The pizza was OK at best. It was a bit pricey at $16 I think, but at least we got a good sized portion which was great since I was hungry. The service is fairly attentive. They don't open for dinner until 5p.m so we did have to wait a few minutes since we were there around 4:45. This place is 5 minutes away from CalTrain.
author: Butterfly A.

description:
Hi Piccino,
We had a table for ten dining at your restaurant tonight.  Hannah was darling and we loved the wine selections she chose for us.  I worked out the menu with Sher in advance however was appalled when they only brought two small plates of salads each for ten diners!  Each salad portion was for one, not five.  I didn't partake as there simple was not enough to go around.  The gnocchi were also delightful but only enough for a few people, not a party of ten.
It was kind of embarrassing to have to ask for more.
All in all we had a terrific time, but taking clients to dinner and having to ask them if their paltry two to three leaves of greens was enough for them was not comfortable.  We paid for a prix fix dinner to accommodate a larger party, I suggest family size dinner actually be served on platters, not a small salad plate.
Grazie
author: Cindy T.

description: one of my favorite places in the city. charming staff and unbelievably good cuisine.
author: Tatum T.

description: Frankly, for a $70 brunch for two persons, even in this artificially foodie-frantic era, I found the service and fare lacking. Yes, the dishes were carefully prepared and decorated (if you're into that), but over-salted. For a brunch menu, all items were about $20+ and that did not include  basic table bread.  Upon request, the home-backed focciaca arrived with smooth (likely artisanal-crafted) butter, but ruined by a layer-topping of salt. The coffee was warm, not hot, and disappointingly bitter.  Coffee refills are $4 per cup - for brunch, really?  The baked (single) egg on greens, pork sausage and beef polpette was tasty but over-salted. Perhaps most satisfying was my companion's single service pizza topped with ricotta, stone fruit and arugula $18 (plus $2 extra for an egg); but even that left us uninspired and unimpressed.
author: Tim Y.

description:
Tuscan-style dishes with a light California touch abound at Piccino. 

With its rough wood floors, natural wood counter and tables, upbeat, but not too loud, music, and otherwise minimalist decor, the dining room at Piccino makes it clear that it's all about the food. If diners were left with any doubt of the importance owners Sher Rogat and Margherita Stewart Sagan place on the cuisine, the open kitchen where patrons can watch their dishes being carefully prepared quickly dispels them. 

The menu features classic, seasonally driven thin-crust pizzas and polpette (Tuscan-style pork and beef meatballs), salads, soups, and house-made pastas, as well as contorni (vegetable sides), and entrees of meat, fish, or poultry.

The mixed chiccodia (chicory) in an achiovy-rich, Cesar-like dressing was a fresh, light starter. Unfortunately, the thin house-made crisps tucked in the salad became a little soggy from an over application of dressing.  Bucking the wood-fired oven trend, the pizzas are cooked in a standard pizza oven. The thin crust is almost cracker-like--not chewy, but not too dry. The delicate crust is perfectly cooked--lightly browned (not burned) on the edges and not soggy in the center--a combination I have not experienced since a glorious lunch at Bond 45 in New York.

The wine list focuses on Italian producers with a sprinkling of California standouts. With a substantial number of wines by the glass as well as by the bottle--from a fruity Prosecco to a hearty Alianico from Pietracupa--diners will have no trouble finding an appropriate choice to complement each dish. 

For dessert, be sure to try the light but satisfying zeppole (St. Joseph's Day cake, also called sfinge) with cardamom cream and candied orange peel. 

One minor fly in the soup, however:  while it is de rigueur in many restaurants to provide complementary filtered still or sparkling water, Piccino still chooses to pad the bill by charging $2 for this most basic part of the dining experience. (Minus one star.)

Simple and beautiful, Piccino is a Dogpatch standout.
author: CJ G.

description: Popped in for a seriously late lunch with my momma to this cute restaurant. Without a reservation, the only spot was at the chef's counter which was so much fun! Bianca and margherita pizzas with beer, then zepolis with Meyer lemon and huckleberries! Super great service, and the executive chef was so nice! Thanks guys!
author: Larissa R.

description: 4-stars would be an insult to Piccino. This place is one of the most consistently excellent spots in SF. Have never had a meal there that I didn't like. Great wine list, fantastic staff.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Solid, imaginative food every time. 

Warm, friendly, helpful hostess. Lovely, knowledgable server.

Props to the chef when, confronted with a server who had a customer allergic to dairy, shallots AND garlic, went through every menu item to pick out what was possible and what they could modify.

Didn't need to see the sous chef go into the walk-in and furiously scratch his hair for a full minute in the window before putting his ball cap back on his head, but I'm sure his hair was clean and deep conditioned.

The coconut financier is fucking perfect.  Suggested by the server, it would have been my 3rd choice, but I trusted her word and she was right.
author: Ant C.

description:
Better atmosphere than food.

We came here on a rainy friday for a friend's birthday dinner.
Our party of 6 ordered two pizzas, two salads, meatballs, and pasta dishes to share.

Their crust is thin, stiff and cracker-like and their pizzas were under-dressed. Bad topping to crust ratio. The tagliatelle was over salted.  Their burrata salad was the best thing we ate, it was incredibly fresh and the bed of greens is was on was decent. 

Their waitstaff is friendly and quick with the drink refills.
It's a shame that the food isn't better, cause this place would be awesome if that were the case.
author: Amy L.

description:
5 out of 5 stars all the way.  Wow.  Just wow.

Ambiance:  This place is as sleek as it is warm and inviting.  We found this place, low and behold, after it was featured in the Sunday San Francisco Chronicle Food and Wine section.  It was listed as one of the top restaurants of 2011 to visit.  So we went, and notwithstanding the fact that it seemed far out of the way and in an area that was seemingly sparsely populated, it was really, really amazing.  

TIP:  If you can, sit at the bar -- even though the tables are of a good size and can probably accomodate a fairly sized group, I suggest that if you are with only one to two other people, that you sit at the bar.  The reason being -- you get to watch the chefs.  My friend and I ate, laughed, enjoyed some wine, but more than anything we both kept commenting on how enjoyable it was to watch the chefs.  This is because of the 90degree angle that the bar forms around the open kitchen.  We could see everyone working, such that it was similar if not better than watching Iron Chef or something not unlike that program.  We watched pizzas being made, desserts plated and other items being prepared.  This really made all the difference for me, so I highly recommend it.

Service:  Top notch.  The hostess was beyond nice, even though we came in without a reservation.  Note to readers:  We came in around 6:30, without a reservation, and we were still able to find a seat at the bar.  There were not, however, any tables available.  Now based on the above, I'm not sure if our visit was similar to everyone else's, such that they were all coming because of the Chronicle article, but let me tell you -- after 20-30 minutes, there was a line out the door.  Accordingly, PLAN ahead.  This place takes reservations, but not from OpenTable.com.  Do yourself a favor and make the reservation.  

The waitress was also very good.  We talked to her about the food, but we also talked to her about the restaurant, how long it had been there, and so on and so forth.  She as both knowledge and efficient, both friendly and professional.

Food:  Oh my gahhhh.  We ordered two things each + shared a dessert.  I had the pork and beef polpette (see my photos).  My friend had the funghi pizza.  Both were amazing, but that pizza... man oh man... that pizza was good.  It was probably against some rule somewhere out there in the universe, but I used the sauce that came with my polpette and put it in the pizza, and I think I saw stars.  The food only got better when the zeppole arrived.  Thing french begneits, because they're essentially the same kind of dessert; the cardamon creme sauce though was simply divine.
