I'm going back just for these.

All in all, a hidden gem that I feel guilty about even reviewing, since it may make making a reservation harder for me!  

OH and by the way -- our entire dinner (two entrees + one dessert + one glass of wine + one ice tea) = around $50.00.  Pretty affordable if you ask me.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Glad we got a reservation on an early Sunday evening, because this place got packed 30 minutes after we were seated. Upon stepping in, I thought the service would be a bit uppity and pretentious, but our server was actually nice and made sure we were okay with everything we needed. Our glasses were always filled.

We asked our server for a recommendation for a starter, and we ended up getting a a small plate of farro with roasted cauliflower - very flavorful! For our main, we ordered the funghi pizza and the bianca pizza with an egg on top. Both pizzas were so good and tasty. The thin-crust was just right. For dessert, we shared the zeppole and hazelnut cocoa nib cake. Was a big fan of the zeppole with the vanilla cream and lemon curd, but not so much of the cake, which was probably the only disappointment for us.

A starter and two pizzas were enough to keep our party of three's stomachs content. The dessert just capped it off. (But if you're really hungry, I'm sure one could finish an entire pizza!)

And for the record, they serve Sightglass Coffee, no longer Blue Bottle.
author: Zell C.

description:
I would say one of my favorite restaurants in san francisco. I remember the first time I went there everything I ate was memorable. What I love about this place is that the food is thoughtful, in the sense that everything that is on the plate is meant to be there. The chefs really know how to play with flavors and deliver a fantastic meal.

You HAVE to get the burratta appetizer. It's the softest cheese I've ever had over this crispy rectangle of polenta, but the combination of the crispy texture of the polenta with the softness of the cheese is unreal. It comes on top of an arugula salad that is drizzled with sea salt and I can't even explain how delicious it is to get a bite with a sea salt gem, a little cheese a little arugula and the crunch of the polenta. I then ordered a pasta that has been the best unconventional pasta I've had. I am a FAN of sauces and of creaminess, so I was a little skeptical when the pasta was just flavored with a little butter. It blew me away how the chef managed to make such a creamy hearty pasta without the use of cream. There were mushrooms and slivers of finely cut parmesan cheese and it was just incredible, no other word to describe it.

The reason I am giving it 4 stars is because the second time I went there, things weren't as memorable. I ordered short ribs that were dry and insipid, and my boyfriend ordered risotto, which was really just barley in a chicken broth, which bugged me because as a restaurant, you can't call a dish something you won't deliver because the customer is going to expect what you are saying it is. We were expecting a creamy risotto and got wet barley. It was a "bad" risotto because it wasn't risotto. Seeing it as the barley plate, it was mediocre barley that needed salt, or some other element to deepen the flavor. I did order the burratta again, which was on point as usual.

The ambiance is great. It's cozy and warm and you feel like you are eating in front of a fireplace even though there is no real fire. I have nothing to complain about the aesthetic.

I do highly recommend this place, and perhaps one has to order the italian dishes (pastas and pizzas) versus the meats and poultry.
author: Adriana A.

description:
Piccino!!  It pains me to do this but your coffee bar kinda sucks.

Being a dogpatch guy, Piccino is (and as long as they are around, always will be) my go to restaurant.  

I am pretty sure I helped fund the purchase of at least 3 new plates thanks to all the times I've eaten there.  :)

That all said, the coffee bar drives me crazy.  

a) It's too small, which is fine but the flow and where to stand is a complete nightmare - put up a sign or a super sweet velvet rope. Mmmmm...Velvet rope.
b) Service is SLOOOOOOWWWWW.  I mean...we're talking slower than blue bottle slow.  And no, in this case, slow does not mean higher quality..the lattes and mochas are decent but not great.  During a weekday morning you're looking at least a 15 min wait for your drink.  To order, you're fine, that part is quick. 
c) The food, as you would expect, is Piccino quality amazing - so that's a plus.

I'm all about the local business success story and Piccino is a framework for how it should be done....start small, be part of the community, expand, grow, thrive. 

I love it.  

What I don't love?  

Their coffee bar.  

In fact...it's dead to me.

Mourning.
author: Archie R.

description:
After a awesome Yelp Event at the nearby Ricksaw Bags Warehouse, we came by Piccino. Piccino is a busy upscale pizza restaurant that sure to please thin-crust pizza lovers. The interior of this restaurant is actually very nice. Everything is reminded us of a very modern and contemporary. Even some might call it a high-classed Ikea styled interior.

There were like 30 reservations that were in front of us. So we were basically waiting for a long time. One of the staff (or manager or owner? Not sure), quite understandably, was super worried about us. It's definitely at not fault of theirs because we didn't had any reservations and we made some last minute plans to eat there. While we were waiting there we might have annoyed a few of the staff, but they definitely took care of us once we were seated.

Because of the long wait, the people at Piccino had hooked us up with some starters including pickled vegetables and marinated olives. I'm not a big olive fan but these marinated olives were pretty nice to snack on. Not overwhelmingly strong as the typical pickled stuff. We also went ahead an bought the Mias Pizza, it was a surprisingly spicy pizza, but I love it.

-----
+ Pro: Great pizza and customer service.
- Con: Busy. Reservations highly recommended.
\( ^,^)/ Overall: Great pizza!
author: James N.

description:
Coffee bar review only; 

Adorable staff with the most authentic smiles I've seen in a long time.

Rustic warm vibe although yes a bit small, actually your quite lucky if you get a seat at the picnic bench, and be prepared to be the envy of all those standing in line.

Wholesaler for local Independently owned and perfectly crafted sightglass coffee. No need for a milk and sugar bar with this cup of coffee. 

Locals must hate letting word of this one get out.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Great food. Great service. Great ambiance. Loved it. 

Our waiter, Peter, was fantastic. He's super knowledgable, funny and attentive. Great experience. 

The goat cheese on date bread app was amazing - I never had such creamy/, light goat cheese.
author: Jim D.

description:
Just absurdly good. 

- Melon Caprese
- Strawberry Bruschetta
- Pan Seared Salmon 
- Frutta Estevia Pizza
- Chocolate Cremeux

They knocked every dish out of the park and I was delighted.
author: Lis C.

description:
Pizza crust stiffens to the texture of a frisbee if you don't gobble it down within the first 8 minutes. The toppings are nothing to write home about. We had three types  of bottled beer, crackers and olives and two pizzas, one with sausage and the other with mushrooms. Interesting idea to process the mushrooms into a tapenade spread. We also had the polpettes. The best items were the tomato and burrata salads on a delicious wedge of creamy hot polenta with an ultra crispy almost caramelized crust, the deep fried kind.

A few words about the service:
Although we had requested a four top as quiet as possible two or more weeks ago, when we arrived we were offered a table for three in the middle of the room. My husband asked if we couldn't be seated at an empty banquette table at the side. The host actually spouted out something about that table being reserved for VIPs. At this point my husband asked to speak to the manager. After a delay, the manager was willing to accommodate us.

A trendy Dogpatch eatery with a side of pretension. Sinks Best of Show on this visit.
author: Claire K.

description: Highly recommend everything on this menu...even the salad :). Great spot for a professional dinner and a full wine menu. If you ate pasta while you were in Italy this is the closest you'll get to it.
author: Malak M.

description: Visited on a Saturday night while in the city. Wehad a carafe of wine, the sausage pizza and the ricotta gnocchi, although both dishes had much fancier names. We were blown away by the taste and simplicity of the food, the politeness of the staff, and the ambiance and decor. Tue next time we are in need of fresh, modern and delicious Italian food & wine, we'll be back in Dog Patch.
author: Joy H.

description:
2nd visit, and another win for Piccino!

I was seated for my noon reservation for 4 promptly.  Service was prompt and attentive, but not intrusive.  

Olives and pickled veggies were a nice start.  My polenta and burrata with EVOO and greens was awesome.  The simply dressed thin crust pizza was awesome, especially with a side of EVOO and amazing anchovies.  My guests loved their pappardelle, meatballs, and peach soup (served cold).  I had a 12 hour cold brew coffee before lunch, which was really great.  The espresso wasn't as impressive; it tasted like they squeezed a lemon into it.

Misteps were minor.  We ordered a second round of two additional dishes which were not brought out together.  Our table bottle of water sat empty for a long time.  The table next to us was placed 18" from our table, and the server didn't see fit to separate them a bit more when I asked.
author: Tony C.

description:
The lattes are delicious and frothy. I had 2 within a 2-hour time span. And they make their own pastries which look sooo delectable and are even tastier than they look. The berry coffee cake is one of the best I've had.

Pastry Update (6/29/12): A long overdue update to the pastry review... The ginger scone is THE BEST GINGER SCONE I HAVE EVER HAD! Flaky, buttery, gingery - it is mouth-wateringly delicious. I even like it better than the coffee cake - Doh! I dare you to find a better ginger scone in this city! 

Terrific neighborhood coffee bar. Love.
author: Veronica H.

description:
Italian but not the italian you are accustomed to. I live this and I have to admit it is one of my go to places and I come here almost every month. They have options for vegetarians and they have the neighborly feel.

If you are looking for pasta and cheesy entrees this is not you place. These folks are eclectic yet modest with everything they do. They have a new menu everyday. Folks living in the city should try this at least once.
author: Surya S.

description:
Piccino is my family's favorite restaurant in the city.  When I ask my kids where they want to go for Sunday lunch, the answer is always Piccino.

We love the new Italian cuisine with the California sensibility.  The food is always delicate and flavorful, presentation refreshing and exquisite.  If I have to have vegetarian dishes for the rest of my life, I would want all the dishes to be like Piccino vegetarian ones.  

The menu is always changing according to seasons, the way it should be.  We also love the pleasant surprises of seeing interesting new item, even new wine selection!  

Since we always go for lunch, our experience with the ambiance is bright with natural light, warm with the the wood floor and furnishings; just simply inviting.

We cannot recommend Piccino enough!
author: Ann L.

description: Complete waste of money. The food is just meh. Completely overpriced and overhyped because it's "trendy." The waiter barely spent more than 5 seconds at our table before storming off before I could even give him my order.
author: Anna K.

description:
Let me sum up your experience here.  First, if you don't have a reservation you will be treated like a second class citizen.  The front of house needs some serious work.  Second, this place takes forever to get food from the kitchen to your table.  I hope you are ready to spend at least 45 minutes waiting for a thin crust pizza even during times that aren't busy.  Who is managing the kitchen?  Apparently no one.  Third, don't even think about bringing kids here.  If you like restaurants that tolerate families then this is the place for you.  The staff should walk over to Serpentine to see how families should be treated. 

Dogpatch is in a great area but the staff thinks they are located in Pacific Heights instead of a few blocks from the 22nd Street Caltrain station.  This place was great but once they moved to their current location and expanded they forgot why they were successful. Maybe the ownership changed recently or they simply don't care anymore. We won't be back and I would encourage anyone to look for alternatives in the area for restaurants that actually like customers.
author: James B.

description:
This place is so good. The menu changes on a regular basis - inspired by fresh, local ingredients. I love the aesthetic of dining room and being able to see into the kitchen. Next time, I'm sitting at the bar so I can just be mesmerized by all the cooking going on in the kitchen.

I love going to new places and trying lots of different things on the menu. Fortunately, I was able to try an amazing selection from the menu on my very first trip.

Our food choices:
burrata, heirloom polenta, arugula, sea salt
fritto misto: butternut squash, broccoli di ciccio, celery root, green garlic
pappardelle, beef and veal bolognese (the newest menu addition)
barley risotto, savoy cabbage, roasted butternut squash, mushroom, ricotta
pizze aglio verde: pancetta, green garlic, rapini, chili topped with an egg (yes an egg!)

Every dish had amazing flavor. My personal favorites were the burrate and the pizze aglio verde with egg. 

The service was tremendous. Plus a wine list that lives up to the claims of being "highly edited". They don't put just any old wine on their list. Their selections are super creative.

Suggest you call to make a reservation or put your name on the list for one of the communal tables. Or, sit at the bar.  That's where you'll find me next time.
author: Wendy P.

description:
My favorite coffee place of all time! I'm a total regular here now, and I keep coming back because their drinks are so good. I usually get a cappuccino or a macchiato, and I'm never disappointed. The drinks are smooth and the perfect balance between milk and coffee. 

The place has a great feel to it, and the staff are really friendly. There's none of the standoffishness or snobiness you can sometimes get from baristas. 

The pastries are made fresh in house and simply delicious. My favorites are the coffee cake (with fruit layered in it) and the cinnamon buns (probably the best ones I've ever had). 

The lines here can get long, so be prepared to wait up to 10 minutes if you get there when it's really busy and there are five people ahead of you. The wait is totally worth it though. 

The place is small, so it's fine to take it "for here" and sit there and drink it, but I wouldn't come here to work or use a laptop. 

Also, you can order any food from the restaurant part here and take it to go.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
The neighborhood and the restaurant are both ultra-cool.  The interior of the restaurant is a knockout.  This establishment is small, to be sure, but I was surprised by its size and its spaciousness.  Reading reviews and descriptions of the restaurant, I expected Piccino to be "tiny," but it's really of moderate size.  We came on a Sunday night and got reservations without trouble by phoning in the day before.  So coming here was pretty easy, and parking on the street was a snap.

The web site for the restaurant was informative and easy to navigate.  Before leaving home, I could see the day's menu and was able to look over the wine list.  Once we arrived, we were greeted warmly by the personnel, who seemed to be enjoying their work and to be proud of Piccino.

On to the food: it was all good.  We ordered a small plate of pickled veggies while waiting for a friend who managed to get lost while walking to the place.  Once he was seated, we ordered two soups ("escarole, tomato and toasted barley soup, parmesan"), two salads ("mixed chicories, white anchovy, garlic crouton and creamy pecorino vinaigrette") and the famous dish of pork and beef polpette, crushed tomatoes and parmesan.  I didn't try the soups, but I loved the salad and ate most of the polpette dish.  (The house encourages family-style service.)  For our main dishes, we ordered three pizzas for the five of us; this is what our server recommended, and the quantity seemed right.  Our pizzas were all vegetarian: the bianca, the funghi and the margherita.  They were all delicious, but I thought that the funghi was the clear winner.

The wine list is interesting.  A big fraction of the wines can be poured at the bar and be ordered by the glass or by the carafe.  I stuck to draft beers, getting the reserve wheat beer from  theTelegraph Brewing Company http://www.telegraphbrewing.com/beer.htm and then a half-order of a second beer whose reference I didn't take down.  (The third draft beer on the menu was from Linden Street, but I avoided it because it was from across the Bay.)

I'm definitely a fan of Piccino.  I hope it won't be too long before we return.
author: Kenneth R.

description: Great food.  Not sure it's worth the wait without a reservation. Had the corn chowder and a few other dishes.  Can't remember the name of them which is usually a sign that they weren't that memorable.  Still worth checking out.
author: Justin P.

description: Really great service, the spaghetti was fantastic (we just got back from Italy...blasphemy to say it was as good - but it was as close as we can remember!), and of course the fungi pizza was a hit. They mince mushrooms into oil and use it as a paste/sauce for the pizza, then layer on lots more mushrooms. Yes+
author: Mihir G.

description:
We had dinner here a few weekends ago, and enjoyed most of the experience. 

We did have to wait a bit for a table, (we ended up in the crappy seats, facing into the clothing store.) Although, they do take reservations, which I'll make next time. 

We had a drink while we waited, and the bartender was really knowledgeable about wine, and a total sweetheart. 

Service wasn't the best once we were seated.Our server was nice and she meant well, but she was forgetful and seemed a bit out of it. Hopefully, with more experience and time open, she'll improve. 

I had read that the portions were on the small side,which was great for us, as we got to try more items. 
We shared: the mais pizza, pork & beef polpette, and warm roasted beets. The menu is seasonally driven, so it does change often. Another thing i really liked about this place. 

The polpette was good, and the simple red sauce was fantastic. The pizza was quite possibly the thinnest i have ever had. I loved the corn, prosciutto, and once again, the sauce was great. I found the peppers to be a little more spicy than i would have liked, but they were easy to pick off. 
The flavors on the pizza worked really well together, and there were the perfect amounts of each. Satisfying, without being too heavy. 

We also shared the chocolate budino, which was the perfect size, and a lovely way to end the meal. 

All in all, we were both pretty happy with the place, and will definitely return.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Unexpected gem!

Came in for an early birthday celebratory dinner last night and was pleasantly surprised.

To start we had the brussel sprouts, the burrata, heirloom polenta, watercress, sea salt salad and the seasonal soup which was a bean type soup.  Both delicious.

Main plates we had (2) pan seared halibut and roasted chicken breast with squash sformato, grapes, baby kale, thyme jus.  All our selections were cooked perfectly, filled with flavor and so well presented.  

Dessert we had the apple tarte tatin, goat cheese custard and the hazelnut-cocoa nib cake.  The flavors of desserts with their accents such as pumpkin seeds to the custard were amazing.  You would never think that a little seed would make the custard that much more desirable. 

All the selections challenge your taste buds and leave them both excited and fulfilled with such delicious flavors.

Great place!
author: Patricia G.

description: This place just keep getting better and better.  It's ok a few people don't enjoy eating here.  Shorter wait for me!  :)  Still dreaming about the meatballs. This is a neighborhood gem.
author: Julia H.

description:
We made our second visit to Piccino last evening (1/9) (first was over a year ago) and our experience was...mixed....
Greeted warmly, seated promptly (we were a party of four), found the staff attentive and friendly w/o being overbearing.
But...my wife observed that
 the pastas three of us ordered as mains, were overcooked
 the Margherita pizza we shared as a starter was cold
 the member of our group who ordered Prosecco got it served to her in a regular white-wine glass.
On the other hand...
 staff let us sit at the table for over two hours, and didn't hustle us out, even though the place was packed and they had customers waiting
 my trout (two filets) was perfectly cooked, and accompanied by unusual sides (steamed spring onions and somehow-cooked radish slices plus delicious greens that I couldn't identify)
 the bottle of Soave we ordered was superb
 the dessert we shared--pear tart tatin--was great.

Will we be back--those three negatives make it unlikely, but we'll see....
author: Bruce C.

description:
I almost feel that I have to give Piccino Coffee Bar 5 stars because they are my main source of caffeine.  Let's just say that I am there so much that I am usually friendly with at least a couple of the baristas and we invited Noah (we still miss you Noah) to our daughter's birthday party.

The good: Personally, I really like Sightglass espresso.  The pastries are excellent, especially the standby ginger scone that has been around since Piccino first opened the coffee bar in the blue building, and the cinnamon bun.  Also, I love the flowers and weird weeds they put in the place.  You can order pizza from Piccino to go and pick it up here.  

The not-so-great:  Variable quality of foam on lattes.  (I cannot believe I just wrote that.  How bougie.  But I prefer the lattes of some baristas to others.) It's not cheap.  The lines are a little out of control some mornings when I don't get in early enough.  Caltrain schmaltrain.  Perhaps because the to-go pizza option became so popular, you can no longer order the special pizzas through the coffee bar and are confined to the standard pizza menu.  Drat.
author: Katina M.

description:
Food is ok - nice sunny interior and fun dogpatch neighborhood. The funghi mushroom pizza was good.  You can add an egg onto anything, including your pizza and that's what I did - runny and yummy.  Forgot what kind of beer I had, but it was good and it came in a cozy Mason jar.  

Only 3 stars because the hostess was rude and anal (I don't expected to be treated like royalty but she should try harder to hide her condescension).  Also, acoustics in the dining room sucks so I had to try harder to hear the person I was sitting next to.
author: Alias A.

description:
I went yesterday to meet up with some friends. Two of us arrived about an hour early, but the waiters did not rush us to order or go away. They let my friend and i chat, poured us some water, and were in general very courteous. 

Friend #3 arrived and we were immediately seated at a communal table, which I didn't mind. The distance between the 2 sides was a bit wide though, and one of us was losing her voice. 

I ordered the beef and pork polpetted, which was tender, juicy, and just the right amount of cooked. Parts of the meatballs were tougher on the outside, and other parts softer and more soup-brewed-like, but in combination it was very delicious. Tomato sauce was very strongly tomato-y, sweet, and salted lightly. I wish it had been less pricey though-- for a pretty small portion it was $15. For dessert, I ordered a pink squirrel ice cream sandwich with dark chocolate bread. Ultimately, the sandwich turned out to be very tasty-- I liked the combination of a light ice cream with light, cracker/cookie dark chocolate bars (what I mean by cracker/cookie is that the bars were not as heavy or sugary as cookies, but resembled crackers more in its lightness). 

My friends ordered peppermint tea for dessert. The strong peppermint overtones were extremely refreshing; I'd definitely order it the next time I come.

My only complaint was that the food is a bit overpriced. But because I loved my culinary experience here, I'm definitely coming back.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Pros:
- relatively easy parking
- good thin crust pizza

CONS :
- terrible service
- they definitely don't have their act together yet. 
- the coffee press could have been better made, they gave too little milk for that much coffee.
- The vibe is a bit too much "mission hipster"/ "too cool to be nice" for me. Maybe try smiling? 

Why I will doc points for service: 
- The waitress was rude and wasn't that friendly from the start. 
- She (curly haired woman) brought out my friend's pizza and then gave me a pizza. Issue was that I ordered an entree plate (not the pizza she delivered me). I just asked what's up and they had messed up my order. My food then came 30 minutes after my friend's food and I was starving. The issue then was that she didn't even comp it or say sorry. She just said "I'll get that in now" without apologizing or being friendly about it.

Overall I had a poor experience which is why I'm not giving this place a good score. :( I really wanted to like it, but alas I didn't like my experience there at all.
author: Hello G.

description:
Loved the mozzarella and the roasted cauliflowers! 
The thin crust was perfect and the sauce too!
author: Sagar J.

description:
Great food. Wine selection is very diverse. They even gave us a second desert on the house. 
Waiters were very efficient (though a bit on the snobby side) 

A great place to go... highly recommend.
author: Gadi P.

description:
Was in the dogpatch area and decided to yelp a place since the Fiancee wanted pizza for dinner which led us here. We sat by the bar with relatively no wait. Personally, I'd say it's the best seat in the house since you get the perfect view of the kitchen making your food.

I'm a big fan of the rustic/modern interior.

Noise level: Good, you can have a normal conversation without having to raise your voice.

What we ordered:
- melon and cucumber caprese, fior di latte, spearmint, basil, sea salt (refreshing)
- pork and beef polpette, crushed tomato, parmesan (Was actually ordering the Beef bavette but gotten this instead - still very good)
- salsiccia: house made sausage, mozzarella, red onion + added an egg (recommended)
author: Jason N.

description: I love this place! I am 10 years old and a really picky eater. They had simple stuff for me and interesting foods for my parents. The desserts are very good too. The service was great! The waiters and waitresses were very friendly, detailed, and attentive. It was casual yet elegant. Please come here and try the best food in the world!
author: Tatum M.

description:
One of the best coffee shops I've been to in San Francisco.  There are tons of high end coffees that charge upwards of $3/cup.  To justify the price, they need to have a unique brew.  Some are good, some are bad.

Piccino offers a normal cup of coffee which is fabulous.  They have great pastries and small sandwiches for a quick bite.  

Nestled in Dog Patch, this is a great little sot.  Their restaurant next door looks fantastic, I need to try it next!
author: Anand A.

description:
Delicious food in a cute restaurant!

We got (for two people):
- padrone peppers (nice and salty but more sour than I would like-- would still order again though)
- burrata, served with toasted bread and extremely sweet and flavorful tomatoes with basil. A nice surprising add to the usual burrata plate and delicious!
- beef and pork polpettes (meatballs). Also good with sauce that's great for dipping with bread but not the best meatballs I've ever had (for example not as good as delfina's!)
- bianca pizza --- sooooo amazing!! One of the best pizzas I've ever had and definitely the best white pizza. The cheeses are delicious without being overpowering. Would come back here just for that pizza!!
- affogato, good and nice way to end the meal but nothing special 

Would recommend getting two appetizers and two main-ish dishes for two people as the portions are a bit small. Came out to about $90 including tax and tip and a glass of wine!
author: Jackie C.

description:
Met for a business meeting.  Great atmosphere to talk during lunch.
Had the half sandwich and soup combo.  Corn soup was amazing - unexpected flavors that were inventive and delicious.  Chicken sandwich was good.  Service was excellent.
author: Helen H.

description:
I truly like everything about this little neighborhood gem we found this wonderful, sunny afternoon in the Dogpatch. 

We shared a simple mixed green and radish salad dressed in a tasty red wine vinaigrette that was delightful.

SWMBO tucked into a wonderful frittata served atop brioche toast so lovely that I ordered a side of same to accompany my soft scramble. The charred squash flavored with mint that accompanied my egg dish was refreshing.

Oh, big happy surprise was the strawberry-rhubarb compote offered in response to my request for preserves to spread on my Brioche toast. One of my top fruit combinations cooked to perfection.

My lovely wife enjoyed a delicate black tea to finish and Piccino did it self proud by serving me a beautifully rich decaf double espresso to close out a very pleasing meal and experience.

The kitchen are doing great things to which I can personally attest. Front of house staff are warm, friendly and accommodating. And the decor is pleasing to this diner's eye.
author: Jay D.

description: This place is ok. The salad we tried had almost no taste at all, sadly. Pizzas were ok but nothing really fabulous. The desserts tho are amazing! Delicious desserts but everything else I could have gone without.
author: Melissa D.

description:
I'm rating the customer service of one particular dark-haired barista here (name unknown). Piccino's serves Sight Glass coffee, I have no problems with the actual drinks and pastries here, everything is up to par with your typical trendy coffee bar standards. The other baristas are efficient and attentive. There is a male barista there who blatantly ignored me when I asked for the price of a veggie drink that they had bottled and displayed. He did not bother putting down his iPhone and proceeded to spend the next minute on his phone, which feels like 5 minutes when you are standing in line waiting for the person behind the counter to acknowledge you and do their job. 

I love their coffee and the restaurant next door is even better but as a former business owner, I believe customer service is key.
author: John V.

description: The squid salad was so good- acidic and salty and creamy all at the same time. Their pizza crust is great; I think that's what carries the pizza. The Bianca was good too, not too cheesy but not bland. The Margherita was a good basic pizza, but probably won't order it again. They gave us a fruit pizza coz they made it instead of a Bianca (it had nectarines, basil, bacon). However, I found a piece of hair in mine. Can't complain because it's free, and because ironically it was my favorite. Will still go back. Good stuff.
author: Rae C.

description:
Wonderful vibe inside. Nice upscale yet casual hipster mix.

Food overpriced with small, but delicious combinations! Very tasty. I wish the portions were bigger. Perhaps pizza is the best way to go here. We ordered the salmon and broccoli rabe -- delicous. Some pasta dish -- wonderful. But we had to ask for bread -- it's a bread upon request restaurant. Whose ever heard of such a thing?! I will admit we very quite full and happy at the end.

Wine list is small and limited but staff is adequately schooled on the wines available.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Came here for lunch on a Saturday because the line at Just for You down the street was too long.  The space is really nice, and we got seated at the counter overlooking the kitchen right away.  It was fun watching the cooking, and the food was very good.  The zeppole were really light and tasty.  The margherita pizza was simple, but the sauce was perfectly flavored.  Will definitely come back here for pizza again sometime.
author: Simon L.

description: I went in for a quick coffee and cinnamon roll.  Though on the expensive side, the coffee was nice and strong like Peets or Ritual.  The cinnamon roll was fresh and not too sweet.  Service was efficient and friendly.  I'll have to take off one star because there was no sleeves available for the coffee (the coffee was extremely hot) and no artificial sweetener.
author: Kai K.

description: I love this place for dinner and now they serve weekend brunch that's just as mouth-wateringly delicious as their pm fare!
author: Sandy G.

description: This place was amazing! These Italians really know what they're doing. I cannot wait to go back. Service was awesome, but the food was to die for!
author: Emily C.

description:
1. Completely overrated food. Margherita pizza looked like the kind of stuff you get at a theme park. Sauce was completely bland. Even my kids complained it was tasteless. The crust also looked like it was rolled - clearly different from every other pizza that was being served. I asked and asked again if there was anything about our pizza that looked strange and server said no. Therefore hard to ask for a new one.

Rest of food was also fairly amateur. There are dozens of better italian places in the city.

2. Not kid friendly, which is highly unusual for a restaurant of this level and price point. Although they give crayons and coloring paper, they don't have standard high chairs or booster seats. The high chairs they have are the kind that screw on the table. Now that might be a management decision because they are actually safer than free-standing high chairs. However, this means that you must be seated at a communal table because the 2- and 4-seated tables can't support such a seat without toppling over. My 4-year daughter was setting on an Eames chair with blankets as her booster seat. Completely absurd.

3. Good service. Service almost felt bad for the way things were run and more than made up for it by being so great.

4. Only one cocktail on the menu. And it tasted like Campari + Aranciata San Pellegrino. Don't mix me something that I can make at home by opening two bottles.

5. Braised green sides were equally tasteless. 

Never going back. Beretta is a 100 times better.
author: M T.

description: Holy mother of beef cheeks! That melt-in-your-mouth meat was sooo delicious! I also enjoyed the buratta with polenta cake this time as well. Bumpin' to 5 stars!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Piccino for dinner and wine, then Chocolate Lab next door for dessert. A match made in heaven! 

Piccino has amazing salads, the heirloom polenta, asparagus with homemade burrata was to die for and our pizza was divine. The pricing was reasonable approx. $15 per person with out drinks, our table service was prompt despite a crowd and the atmosphere is really cute. The tomato sauce on the pizza was very fresh. You can tell who ever cooks here truly loves food.
author: Shannon Z.

description: This place is really cute.  I love the style of this place.  Maybe we went a little overboard, but we had had the sausage pizza with egg, burrata with polenta, the polpette, and beef cheeks.  My favorites were the polpette (meatballs) and the beef cheeks.  Both were incredibly tender and not dried out (an issue I have with meatballs sometime).  The burrata came on arugula and a fried polenta cake, which paired pretty well.  The sausage pizza is very thin, crispy, Californian style pizza.  I personally prefer a somewhat thicker pizza (definas) but Piccino's is quite good.
author: Tiffany C.

description: My favorite restaurant near the Minnesota Street Project. 4 of us and a dog sat outside for lunch even when it was lightly misting and ate Mushroom (grilled oyster mushrooms) and then Margherita pizzas. The food is consistently wonderful and prepared with great care, and the service was lovely even though inside was packed. Will come back again and again.
author: J. J.

description:
Jennifer T on  2/12/2012 hit the nail on the head.. 
First off over priced.. we ordered the little gem salad for 11 dollars. It was a small spear of lettuce. Also got the Garganelli, it was tasty, but oh my ! again a real small portion. Ambiance is nice and for being a large open restaurant its not too loud. For some reason the vibe, as I have noticed over time has become more smug.

The real killer was when we initially sat down I asked the host if it would be ok if I could sit at the end of the table. ( Picinic style table and there were three of us) She said yes," That is the way I prefer to arrange parites of 3, but no matter how I seat people they usually complain". OK ! got it.. dont know if I will be back
author: Andrew T.

description: Had two different pizzas at this place.  We're pretty picky with our pizza and know what we like (and don't like) and this place is SO good!  Great service. The Arnold Palmers had a neat floral hint to them and was also very good.  Would definitely come back if in the neighborhood.
author: Melissa O.

description: Food is good. The zeppole, vanilla bean crema, meyer lemon curd, huckleberry is great. Service is good.
author: Brittany H.

description: For the Dogpatch this place is great. It seems to do modern Italian food with a local Californian twist. We really enjoyed our dinner here at the chef's counter, but came back for lunch and was less impressed. The food was expensive for what you get - there was no ambient music playing - and there weren't many people dining. What was clear... the food was high quality and thoughtfully presented. I say this place is definitely worth the visit - but opt for dinner time with good company to make it special.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I walk up to the counter and I say to the tall "barrista" dude with the dark hair, "cappuccino please".  He says back to me condescendingly "YOU WANT A CAPPUCINO?!"  I say "yeah".  Then he proceeded to make my cup with the care of an 8 year old.  He DUMPS the cream into the cup and then passes it to me.  I take a sip and as expected, it tasted bitter and diluted with milk.  I tell them it tastes terrible and the helpful girl at the register knew right away that it would be terrible and tells me immediately that they will make me another one.  I say ok.  But the dude does the exact same thing to the second cup and yes..it still tasted terrible.  Only slightly less horrible than the previous cup.  The dude says" I can't make a pretty heart for every one!"  I tell him, "it's not how it looks, it's how it tastes.  and it tastes terrible!"  

don't be in the service industry if you cannot be pleasant
don't make coffee if you are not skilled
don't be a jerk

take a lesson from Four Barrel.  they make amazing coffee, not bitter, and they have a smile when they greet you.
author: blue f.

description: Morning bun was like an elephant ear wrapped up, ricotta torte was inventive and savory, tasty baked delicacies and (bonus!) baked dog biscuits.  Downsides: not much seating space and a small selection.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
Would be giving them 5 stars, but they failed the 'p2p' ratio - the price to portion ratio.  Portion sizes were just too small, especially if you plan to share.  I don't mind paying for great food, just make sure your customers aren't leaving hungry at the end of the meal.

The food we ordered was super yummy.  Had the squash linguini and brussel sprouts and both were great,  The salsiccia pizza was a hit with everyone at the table.  

The decor was cool, and I really like the open kitchen thing.  Adds energy to the whole experience.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Such a cute friendly neighborhood restaurant in the midst of good ole Dogpatch. Thank goodness I don't live in the neighborhood because I'd probably be here every evening!

The yellow exterior is warm, cozy and inviting yet the interior is modern and trendy. It's quite hard for a restaurant to simultaneously exude both vibes but Piccino somehow pulls it off irreproachably. I've been here several times with both my family and friends and both the food and service haven't failed to impress one bit. 

This is first and foremost a gourmet pizza spot so keep that in mind when sifting through the menu - I highly recommend at least ordering one pizza for your table. The Funghi pizza is my absolute favorite (influx of truffles with just the right amount of stracchino cheese and a crispy crust) - the flavor is completely overwhelming in a great way. Close seconds are the bianca and salsiccia (sausage) pizzas. 

Also, I'm not usually a vegetable-lover... I was one of those kids who had to be force-fed veggies in the most creative ways yet I simply could not get enough of the asparagus appetizer. It's crunchy, well-cooked and slightly buttery. Oh dear god. 

And finally, if you had to pick only one dessert for some ridiculous reason, order the Zeppole - it's basically an Italian version of beignets and it's creamy, crispy and delicious. 

So if you're in the neighborhood and are craving pizza or a great unpretentious Italian meal, Piccino will hit the right spot. Versatile by nature, it's perfect for dates, nights out with foodie friends, family get-togethers and perhaps even business dinners. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!

P.S. The wine list is quite extensive and descriptive here - I love how they group the wines by boldness and flavor so that even a wine novice can choose exactly what their palette is craving.
author: Priya S.

description:
Tucked in the heavenly neighborhood known as the Dogpatch lies this gem of a restaurant that I have grown to really love. It's open and airy, always seems to have patrons in it when I go and for good reason. The food, the staff, and the environment are excellent.

I've eaten every pizza this place makes and it never disappoints. The restaurant seems to adapt seasonly which makes so many of the items on their menu so good and "new". I've also had just about every salad on the menu and there isn't one I don't like. I've had a pasta dish there and a cheese style plate too and both were very tasty.

Be prepared for a crowd at your typical peaks times as well as weekends. There may also be a bit of a wait to find parking in the area as street parking can be a bit limited. Other than those two bits, this place is a favorite "go-to" spot for me for lunch in the Dogpatch.
author: Gabriel R.

description: This a great neighborhood gem in Dogpatch that my girlfriend stumbled upon online while we were on our way from Brisbane to SF. We stopped for lunch and I enjoyed one of the best lemonades Ive ever had. My girlfriend is a coffee freak and raved about it. We both shared a margarita pizza that was very good. Not best Ive ever had but good. Service is very friendly and prompt. We liked this place so much that we came back for breakfast during our week in San Fran. However, they were not open yet and discovered they have a little cafe next door that is open early. Overall this is a great place to enjoy a good lunch in Dopgpatch or a great cup of coffee. Next time were in the Bay Area we will definitely visit again.
author: Robert F.

description:
I've been eyeing this restaurant for years and was lucky enough to have a friend take me there on Sunday for my birthday. I've spoken to the owners a number of times while wandering around the neighborhood and watched as they renovated the building and moved into a bigger space. They results are lovely! The restaurant is really beautiful. The colors, art, and design is super attractive and makes for a great lunch or early dinner spot when it's full of natural light.

The wine my waiter suggested was delicious and went very well with our dishes. The menu reflects appropriate seasonal choices and healthy options. The brooks cherries, burrata, polenta appetizer was delicious!!! I keep thinking about it! We ordered a zucchini pizza which was a new addition to the menu and it was so tasty! No sauce: just parmesan, olive oil, arugula, and summer squash. Yum!

The only problem was our waiter forgot to pack up the rest of our pizza that we hadn't finished and give us a to-go bag. That was sad but I'll be back!
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Without any expectations my husband & I dined at Piccino. The ambiance is casual yet sophisticated, and the service was impeccable. They have an extensive wine list & our waiter was well versed on all the options. The cabbage & watermelon radish salad was flavorful & crunchy. I had the beef & pork polpete, and my husband had the halibut. We shared the contorni of field greens & butterbeans. All of the food was well prepared, presented & super yummy. We skipped dessert but will certainly be back again! I highly recommend this restaurant :)
author: Lawrence G.

description:
I had a friend that was dropping me off at the 22nd Street CalTrain on a weekend around Noon.   As a thank you, I offered to buy him lunch/brunch.   We wanted to go to the excellent "Just for You" Cafe, but there was a long, winding line down the block to get in; not surprising, but I only had a little over an hour before my train to Santa Clara departed- so that was a no-go.    We looked around the neighborhood and found this place.  It was busy, but a very short line with a short wait (about 8min).  It looked clean, inviting, modern, and had an interesting menu.

So, my buddy ordered the polpette, and I ordered the Italian sausage with lentils, along with a couple of iced teas.    Both of us agreed that the food was excellent; very skillfully done.   The service was brisk, but attentive.  The surroundings were trendy, albeit bordering on precious.  But, my real problem wasn't with any of these things- my problem was with the portion sizes.    My friend received 3 medium-sized meatballs in sauce, nothing more, for $15.   I received one smallish sausage cut up on top of what looked to be a quarter cup of lentils for $16.   Add in two iced teas for about $6 and a very modest, but well flavored meal cost about $42 with tip.   I could have made this entire meal at home for about $10.

I am not proposing that they necessarily have to increase to gargantuan "American Smorgasbord-sized" servings.  In fact, I wish more restaurants would trim down their heaping-plate serving sizes to do their part in reducing our epidemic fat-assery in this country.  BUT, they should contemplate lowering their price point for what most would consider an appetizer-sized portion.   These would have been reasonable at $10 or less per plate.

I feel it necessary to point out that I very rarely gripe about prices at restaurants.   I am, by most accounts, a foodie, and I'm happy to pay $$$ for a meal (I recommend the $85 per person chef's menu at Koo) if I feel it is a unique experience, or a good value for the money.

So, in the end- thanks but no thanks, Piccino; I no longer live in Potrero Hill, so have no reason to go back to this restaurant unless I'm, once again, going to the 22nd Street Caltrain.   I think next time, I'll wait in line at Just for You Cafe and take the next train down...
author: Derek C.

description: Amazing food, small portions, nice atmosphere! Go for brunch. Expect to pay a lot but enjoy every bite.
author: Emily S.

description:
The biggest problem with Piccino Coffee Bar is that it has spoiled me so much and made me a HUGE snob to getting coffee anywhere else. I commute from the 22nd station daily and probably hit up this coffee spot 2-3 a week. Yep, I'm that person waiting at 7am when it first opens up. And I'm not ashamed that one of the regular baristas simply looks at me and says "soy latte?" I don't drink the drip, so I suppose I can't speak for that, but my boyfriend and I both enjoy the espresso drinks immensely (he typically drinks non-fat cappuccinos or americanos). I will admit, Piccinos has officially made me a coffee addict.

On the pastry side! Also amazing. I'm a regular of the prune/plum muffin (I've seen it labeled both ways...although they seem pretty similar to me). The fresh berry coffee cake in the summer was TO DIE for and I can't wait for it to return. The current apple one is good, I'm just not a huge fan of cooked apples in general. If I'm looking for something sweeter, the cinnamon roll always hits the spot. The boyfriend loves the Pumpkin Muffin, but has also enjoyed several of the other pastry and has liked everything he has tried to date. 

I've been teetering about when I will try to Sow juice that they sell in the mornings... I haven't given in yet, but it's bound to happen someday soon. 

And yes, it is a bit pricier than other places--but honestly, it always feels like it's worth every penny. If I really want to save money, I eat my breakfast and make my coffee at home--if not, I go to Piccinos.
author: Morgan R.

description: One of the cute tiny shops on the Dog Patch area of SF. Good strong coffee. I'll def come back when I am in the area.
author: Ben C.

description: Had a delightful dinner here with my husband and brother.  We all had pasta and thought is was great.  What really stood out was the fresh salads we all started with - it was like the chef just picked everything from the ground - it tasted that fresh.
author: Shelby C.

description: Our go to spot in the Dogpatch for nice dinners. Pizzas are always good, service is on point, and a good portion of the menu rotates every couple months. Would recommend the polpette highly, we almost always get them.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Great spot for a simple meal. We started with the little gems salad and got the margherita and salsiccia pizzas. My taste buds detected quality, fresh ingredients in the pizza and they were very happy.  

The pizza dough could have been crispier, but that's just my personal preference. The space was larger than I had imagined and I loved the light on a Sunday afternoon.  Lots of outdoor tables too if you wanted to bring the doggies.
author: Wendy L.

description:
At the risk of seriously dating myself, I can remember a time when the only reason anyone ventured this far down Third Street was the occasional visit to The Ramp. This was absolutely considered the end of the earth by most San Franciscans. 

My, have things changed. Granted it's been 12+ years but we're not gonna talk about that.

Now it's an actual neighborhood called Dogpatch and it's the hottest, hippest destination in town. Piccino is well-positioned as the hub and an absolute must - especially if you're under the spell of the omnipotent wood-fired, Neapolitan-style pizza. With toppings like wild nettle, nectarine, whole milk and mint or roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic there's no end in sight for this enchanting trend.

But pizza is far from the only reason to visit Piccino. I had a creamy, charred corn soup with relish, and a cheddar cauliflower, arugula, farro salad topped with almond gremolata that made me want to cry. Everything about this place is so hip it hurts. 

Starting with this understated-yet-oh-so-perfect centerpiece of onions. And their website, seriously I don't know what's more impressive - their food photos or their commitment to being the hub of this delightfully eclectic neighborhood.

I went for lunch. And while I'm dying to go back for dinner, I can name a few reasons why a noontime visit is the way to roll. The daylight will give you lots of time to explore and take in the flavor of what makes this neighborhood so great. It will also give you time to get over the nervous breakdown that is sure to occur as you attempt to find parking in this neck of the woods.

After lunch, check out neighboring MAC (Modern Appealing Clothing) then pop into the Piccino Coffee Bar next door, fuel up with a cup of Sightglass and head out to Poco Dolce for dessert. I know everybody is doing handcrafted chocolates but they are really doing it right plus it's fun to taste it at the source. Next head off to Wineworks and try your hand at making wine, or just sippin' it or just to check out a cool venue for a private event.

Once you calm down enough to consider getting back into your car, swing by Oliver's Butchery and grab an amazing cut of meat to whip up for dinner. 

Not a bad way to spend the day at the end of the earth if you ask me.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Diamond in the rough, Piccino in San Francisco's Dogpatch district is a definitely a good find. The journey here made me unsure and skeptical. But pulling up to the restaurant was a pleasant and adorable find. Very clean and modern-homey, the restaurant oozes of cream-of-the-cropness. No wonder it was all over the local press for 2011.

Walking in just before 7pm, the restaurant was mildly filled. To my surprise, all the open tables were reserved and my dinning partner and I had to be sat at the bar. This was actually a good time, cause we got a front row seat to their open kitchen. Watching the chefs work was good insight to their legit skills, and incidentally keeping them on top of them game. We ordered a heavenly "Funghi" pizza that was thin, crispy and delicious, plus a meatball dish that was simple to the first impression, but to die for at the first bite. I washed it down with a red wine from their extensive and wide selection and ended with a beignet type dessert that came with a duo or dipping sauces. Sinful for sure. And all of this for an awesomely reasonable price.

I loved it here. Enjoyed everything about it. If this description doesn't make you salivate at the thought, go out and check it for yourself, you won't be sorry.
author: Jon C.

description:
Excellent food. Excellent service.

Came here after reading about this place in an online mag article about places to go in the Dogpatch. Man, was this a gem.  The food here is perfect - good lord the pizza! Plus, they are willing to accommodate to any special needs. A guy is walking around every 10 minutes refilling your water.  You can't ask for more.  Go on a weeknight - plenty of street parking. Also make sure to RSVP to avoid having to wait.
author: Dorothy W.

description:
This is my favorite place in San Francisco. 
Pizza is one of the best in the city with a thin crust. Apetizers are light but delicious in taste, and the terrace makes it one of the most pleasant restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Pascal L.

description: I've not spent much time in the Dogpatch but this is definitely a gem of a brunch spot! The open kitchen and busy staff added to the ambiance. The menu had some unique options and everything we ordered - potato pizza, granola, zepolle, and corn soup - but felt a little overpriced even for SF. That said, our server was an absolute delight and came to our rescue in fixing the only thing that felt out of place...the music. On a beautifully calm, Saturday morning in the very SF feeling restaurant, the speakers were beaming with old school funk music that should really only be reserved for Bar Mitzvahs! All in all, great service and delicious meal and I'd love to come back with a group and sit at one of the long, beautiful wooden tables!
author: Jamie G.

description:
Service 5 stars
Food 4
The pizza is excellent. I would come back it was the best I have experienced in a long time.
Impressed
author: Alison W.

description:
Beautiful, spacious place with a coffee shop attached (serving blue bottle ofcourse). Neighboring is a cute little wine retailer and a clothing shop, reminds me a lot of Hayes Valley. 

It's super busy even on a Wednesday evening, filled most likely with Potrero Hill folks. Make sure you have reservations! Parking was (no surprise here) extremely easy. They have a changing menu, and a pretty extensive wine list.

Food was a bit disappointing. Here's what we got:

BREAD: seemed fresh but just didn't taste very good. The white part was insubstantial and I almost lost a tooth eating the crust. I covered mine in a whipped melted butter because I didn't appreciate the lemony olive oil dipping sauce. 

ARUGULA TOMATO SALAD: prices here are fairly reasonable. But $10 for this tiny plate of arugula and a couple wedges of tomatoes and cucumbers didn't strike my fancy. It was fresh, decent, but not amazing - it tasted very home made. I did like the chunks of pan fried pizza dough.

TALIATELLE w/TOMATO SAUCE: not sure if the pasta was fresh but it didn't have the right texture. It may have been undercooked or not fresh, and the portion was so small I think I might have been able to eat the whole portion in one bite (exaggeration). 

GYPSY PEPPER PANCETTA PIZZA: I thought I would love this pizza - can't go wrong with pancetta right? I don't know if I tasted the meat, there was no cheese, and overall lacked much flavor except tomato sauce (not seasoned well). I don't like the crust here because it is hard, think flatbread, but a little thicker. Also, the pizza is pretty small and too thin in the middle.

SALSICCIA: the homemade sausage was the highlight of the night. Too bad there was so little of it. Keep in mind the sausage is all chopped up.

The damage was $15/person, which isn't bad! A nice place to grab a little bite and drinks with friends, but by far not my favorite pizza place.
author: Jess C.

description:
Pizza!  Pizza!  Pizza!
Their pizza is simply amazing.
Their thin-crust crispy pizza makes me go back there again and again.
It is without a doubt that all the ingredients used in their dishes are high quality and are prepared with a great passion.

I have recommended this place to many of my friends and they all couldn't have agreed more.  The décor is very cute, simple and welcoming.  The waiters/waitresses are always friendly.

I haven't tried many pizzerias in SF, but I feel like I don't have to explore any further for better pizza.
author: Tomomi K.

description: I've only been here for coffee and ginger snaps, but both were tasty :) Really cute location and friendly staff.
author: Eliza D.

description:
I've been frequenting Piccino since it was a tiny hole-in-the-wall. It seems the upgrade in space and atmosphere has come with an increase in attitude. Another reviewer said there's an air of smugness, and that's pretty accurate. I will still continue to come here because it's in the neighborhood and they do have great food, but I always feel like I'm paying too much for what I'm getting. Good luck finding a glass of wine for less than $12. Simply put, this place is overpriced.

Also, a word of advice -- acknowledge your regular customers. I've been seeing the owner of this place several times a week over the years, both at the restaurant and their coffee space, but there's seemingly no appreciation or recognition of a great customer on her part. She could stand to learn a few things from her husband, who runs DIG (the wine store in the building). He is friendly and helpful, and doesn't act like a stranger.
author: K L.

description:
Simply put, the food is better than ever at this parkside hotspot in the dogpatch. We chose to dine outside on this very warm evening, especially since we were accompanied by 2 four legged companions. 

We eschewed appetizers and focused on pasta and entrees. I had the pappardelle with figs and chili. Creamy like an alfredo, with luscious figs, nice combo, lighter than bacon but with the same interest.
The summerbean salad featured newly dug potatoes, yellow beans, arugula and a vinaigrette,very fresh but a bit wan.
My riverdog farms roasted chicken was magnificent, crispy bubbled skin and juicy, richly flavored meat. The chicken was served atop garlic and butter soaked croutons, still soft enough to not shatter when bitten but offering a softer chew. 
A salsiccia pizza of coarse ground sausage, probably river dog's, tasted like it, anchovy, garlic and cheese. The anchovy, which was an addition, enhanced the pork flavor and brightened the pizza.
Wine is pricy, but well selected. Service was ouststanding.
I like piccino because the ingredients are so fine they shine through in the preparations. I can dine with my dogs, a plus, and then work it off on a walk at the local dogpark.
Make reservations unless you want to eat at the bar or outsidel
author: Kelly K.

description:
What a charming place. Very trendy interior decorating, fabulous pizza. Wine by the carafe recommended. Wonderful wait staff. 

Cant wait to come back.
author: Christy D.

description:
Amazing!  And I mean, amazing. Piccino has transformed from a wonderful neighborhood restaurant to a truly special and spectacular place. The care is evident in each dish, the atmosphere, from the open kitchen to the windows to the glassware, and the service.

Go.  Enjoy.  Bon Appetit.
author: Jessica S.

description:
FRESH THIN CRUST PIZZA
(4 stars)

Hidden gem spotted in the Dog Patch neighborhood. Sucker for thin crust pizza!!!!! Tucked and hidden comes a cute, quaint, cozy, little italian cafe that i have fell inlove with. it was so enjoyable, i nearly ate 99% of my pizza pie. And they serve BLUE BOTTLE (oh san franciscan espresso lovers -- you know what i'm talking about!!!!)

- food, light and fresh
- prices, fair
- service, impeccable
- ambiance/space, very small

My friend use to live few buildings down and i've seen this spot but never bothered to try it out because it would always be filled with neighborhood regulars. I have decided to give it a try. this place servers blue bottle coffee so i was tempted to order a cafe latte but i've passed. walked pass the cafe bar and into the restaurant. their menu frequently changes for dinner but their brunch/lunch items usually stay consistent. sandwich vs. pizza. PIZZA!

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

MARGHERITA ($10) - tomato sauce, fresh mozzaralla, oregano. Kept my pizza simple since i'm on the 'healthy regein' and to judge a place by a simple dish. asked the waiter for the size of the pie and it is a 6' but very very thin crush. Definately not greasy!! The pie was served on a flat square wooden 'plate' ontop of parch paper (i think). i nearly ate my entire pie. The crust was so cripsy and delicious and light, the mozzarella was under the tomato sauce, usually its the sauce than the cheese. and there chopped fresh oregano sprinkled ontop of my pizza. mini itty bitty shaped leaves of oregano. i think that made my pizza extra tasty and perfect. LIGHT AND FRESH.

The wait staff was very pleasant. Even ones that were starting their shift when i was mid-way with my pizza. Everyone was just friendly and smiled all the time. Were they smiling at me because i'm a new face? were they smiling at me because i was eating alone? IDK but they were very friendly!!!! love that about a great place such as this spot.

This is an Italian cafe so they serve wine here. People who are drinking the wine know exactly what they want and regulars seem to pour into this place; i could see why, its a hidden cafe and locals from the neighborhood seem to know about this place. If i lived in the neighborhood, i'd totally be a regular too. 

Will I be back? Love to try dinner here or brunch. will be back this week for the cafe bar to get me a cafe latte.


JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Yeah that is right 5 STARS !
Four of us had a greta meal the dishes ranged from very good to great , wine was excellent and the staff was helpful and creative.
my daughter , who is a foodie, picked this place and she was spot on .
The location looked iffy but the entire experience was great .
author: murry z.

description:
Very high-end food and service!! Even the restrooms are high-end! 

If like thin, crispy and tasty pizza (like I do) you'll LOVE this place! 

Nice to see the open kitchen where they prepare the food with so much love, and serve it in the same manner.

I love how everyone gets along at this place!! Wonderful ambience!!
author: Rak P.

description: Amazing food, amazing service, great style and atmosphere. Take a table at the bar which allows you to see the guys preparing the food. Better than any menu.
author: Patric F.

description:
I love Piccino, my husband loves Piccino and my baby loves it. Why 4 stars? Because this past Sunday we came for lunch and had an interesting experience with the hostess.  It was fine that we had to sit outside and said we needed a table for three.  My son was in his carseat asleep.  We waited for our table to be set up, walked outside and amongst a bunch of empty tables, we were given a small table for two with two seats.

I guess my son was supposed to sit on the sidewalk.

When we asked for a larger table (there were at least two empty tables of four), she hesitated and said she could set an extra chair on the small table.  Fine about the chair, but the table wouldn't fit our three pizzas, which we explained. Finally she agreed to give us a larger table.

We enjoyed our pizzas but halfway through lunch a party of five arrived and they needed an extra chair for their child.  Instead of taking the chair that was placed on the small table (which was closer to the table of five and empty), she came to ours and asked for our fourth chair which had my husbands jacket hanging on it.

This was so odd, that I had to write a review. Maybe she just doesn't like babies in carseats or three people sitting at a table for four???
author: Natalie S.

description:
Wife made a reservation for 8/2 at 6:30 for three since we wanted to treat a friend who just came to SF. We just wanted to show her a good time with a nice restaurant in a friendly neighborhood, and we thought Piccino made sense. We really should've paid attention to all those negative reviews here on Yelp for the hostess service before we made the reservation.

We got to Piccino's at 6:25, went in, and there were 8-10 people blocking the doorway area. We waited for about a minute behind those people with no staff acknowledging our presence. So I went around and walked up to the Caucasian hostess who was looking at a computer screen and said hi. She looked up, with a blank and indifferent expression on her face:

"Can I help you?"
"Yes, we have a reservation at 6:30"
"Oh, blah for three?"
"Yes"
"You will be seated shortly"
"Would it be possible for us to sit at that open corner table?"
"That's a table for two, and will be turned in to a five for a later reservation"
"Oh I see, that's ok then"

She then left us with the others in-front of both the front door and the hostess bar, blocking the entry way and the staff grabbing drinks because she left no instruction for us where to wait. One by one, all the people in-front of us were seated, I guess everyone made reservations. After she seated the last couple, I went up to her:

"Excuse me, about when will we be seated? Were we not seated because the last person in our party is not here yet?"
"No, I can seat just you two, but I can't because your table is not ready yet."

She then left again before I could get off another question. At this point my wife is clearly unhappy with the attitude of her service. Not once did she offer an apology for the delayed service or even a smile. She stopped the hostess after she came back, in a firm voice she asked:

"Excuse me, when will our table be ready?"
At this point, the hostess is annoyed and agitated, in a condescending voice she said
"I seat only full parties, you're missing one person. Your table will be ready when the people occupying it leave!"
"Do you have an approximate time for that?"
"No, I don't know. They already paid, I don't know when they will leave. Maybe 10 minutes, maybe 20 minutes!"
"But we have a reservation at 6:30!"
"It's only 6:31, it's only one minute past your reservation!"
"I really don't like your attitude."
"I don't like your attitude either!"
"We have a good friend coming, we just really want to show her a good time. I don't think you're very polite, I don't want her to eat in this type of environment and service"
"Well, you're not very polite either, you yelled at me."
"I didn't yell at you, I'm speaking to you in a firm and calm tone because you're mistreating us. I'm your customer, is this how you treat your customer?"

She shook her head and went back to her computer screen. At this point I just stopped my wife and told her it's not worth it to be upset, let's not eat here anymore. The hostess is the face and the first impression of a restaurant, she already ruined it for Piccino, so it's pointless trying to eat here anymore. 

Luckily we found another good place and salvaged the night out with our friend.
I've worked in the restaurant industry for 5 years and my family runs multiple restaurants, but this is the worst hostess service I've experienced. Here are some of my family secrets I'm willing to share to Piccino when it comes to service.

1) It might be nice to greet all your customers with a smile and an acknowledgement when they first walk in. Why? Friendly service is part of your whole restaurant's dinning experience. Trust me when I say this, I can make all your overpriced, downsized dishes at home with better ingredients and tastes just as good if not better if I wanted to skip the service and atmosphere.
2) It might be nice to set an expectation for how long the customer might wait. For example "I'm sorry for the delay and thank you for being patient. I will try to seat you as soon as possible, you might have to wait for about x-xx amount of minutes because xxx."
3) It might be nice to let people who have reservations to know how long they might have to wait if you can't seat them at the reserved time. Good restaurants get busy, and sometimes there are certain things beyond anyone's control, we all understand that. However, it's the hostess' job to keep customers in the loop about the wait time and apologize. It's arrogant to think an apology is not needed because it's "only one minute".
4) Don't let the customer do your job for you. If customers have to initiate the "greet and smile" for you when they walk in, ask for the wait time, ask about where they will be seated, you have failed as a hostess.
5) Last tip is for our hostess only. If you really hate your job, just quit. It will make your boss happier, your customers happier, and yourself happier.
author: Vince Y.

description:
Blue bottle can only be served by skillful baristas who makes the perfect foam texture, the exact caramel color, and the latte leaf shape, every. single. time.  

Piccino serves great blue bottle coffee.  Look for that purple building and you won't miss it.  I love to alternate between their latte, and mocha, which by the way, is made by REAL melted chocolate bits.  Not too sweet, not too rich, just right.

Baristas are nice and friendly.  I always like to take an extra piece of the buttery thumbprint cookie with me (with strawberry or orange toppings).

That usually starts my day really well :)
author: Carina N.

description:
I loved, loved, loved their mushroom pizza and extra thin crust!!!!!! We were here on a Friday night with no reservation and of course the place was packed. The wait was 30 mins but it was totally worth it! While waiting, we decided to go to Chocolate lab on the corner of the street for desserts and as soon as we were done with our delicious cakes, our table was ready :D 

We ordered some marinated olives, wine and the amazing thin crust mushroom and garlic pizza to share. Everything was exceptional! I seriously think that their pizzas are better than Delphina's or Zero Zero's (if you are a fan of thin crust).

I will definitely be back for more of their awesome pizzas!
author: Vickie Z.

description: I just moved to the neighborhood and kept on hearing about Piccino. I've eaten there 3 times now, and haven't been disappointed once. Their pizzas are the real deal, full of flavor and wood-fired, thin crust. I lived in NYC for 13 years, so I know my pizza. I've tried a few of their salads as well, and a pasta dish. Everything has hit a high note, and I'm pretty happy to have such a great culinary experience within walking distance.
author: K C.

description:
I've eaten here twice now. Very San Francisco/Napa modern, great light and ambiance. Vegetarian friendly, super fresh menu. I've tasted a few salads, a few pizzas, a few drinks, and a few random items like olives and pasta. 

It's about as good as pizza gets. My pasta with mushrooms had a strangely asian flavor - not unpleasant, but unexpected. They let you sugar your own lemonade, which is nice. 

Both times the waiters were incredibly friendly and helpful, but orders were apparently mixed up by the kitchen or the café. Nothing major, and probably just bad luck, but worth noting. 

Great for family brunches or a nice day out.
author: Sophie R.

description: The atmosphere is great. The food is very good. Love the people and the service. A must try. Wine glasses on the table is the norm whether you order it or not.
author: Dee C.

description:
One of my favorite places!

Good food
Pretty decor
Nice service
Fairy easy parking

Can go with your family for a casual dinner, or with your partner for a romantic one.  So perfect.
author: Shine W.

description:
I never knew such a cute place existed so close to where I live! The ambiance was great and service very friendly. They periodically checked up on us to get our orders, see how everything was going, etc. 

We ordered some Moscato, which was great because it was't too sweet or overpowering. We also ordered the margarita pizza, which was your typical margarita but on this really amazing thin crust.

Overall, really cute place with great food. It seemed a little busy when we got there so you may need to make reservations beforehand.
author: Krishna S.

description:
It's been a long time since I've been to Piccino, so long in fact that they have moved to a much larger space and have outdoor seating. Also I had never been here during the day. The price are still a bit high for what you get but are in keeping with the income of the hipster and tech folks that have moved in the neighborhood in the last ten years. 

All the food was tasty, small and very local. Crackers & sweet pickles made in house, pasta made fresh in house and even fruit drinks that are only made on the weekends. The soups were tasty but average.

The brisket panini is good, 13 dollars good? Not so sure about it.

Piccino certainly has the pulse on the way food and the neighborhood is going and their food reflects that.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Went for birthday dinner with my wife and 2 kids on a Tuesday night.  Had to wait for 15 for a table, when we had a reservation.  Restaurant was run by several angry women.  Our server never talked to us, she just took our order.  They made no attempt to bring food out quickly for kids.   Had to ask for bread to soak up the juice from the mussels.  Seems like no one cares..... 

Food was pretty good 3 + stars, had a few pizzas and pastas.   The room/space is really nice, tucked away on a side street.  

The service was so bad, I'll never go back.
author: Jay K.

description:
2013 new year's resolution: polpette: any, all, more !

I was spirited away from my dark office by a dear, kind soul, on a brisk winter's day; destination, Piccino.  We were greeted by the sunny staff and the warm lemony interior, as comforting as a promise of spring.

The squash soup was magical.  The polpettes exquisite.  The broccoli pizza a little ho-hum, but redeemed by the magnificent toothsome crust.  And the pear / lemon tarte, a bit of sunshine renewal.   

A big plus, a wander-gander-worthy neighborhood, with Rickshaw Bags and M A C in close proximity.

(A bigger plus, parking and no meters, but that's just between you and me and non-government types.)
author: Mutant O.

description: great salads and pizza. my favorite dish was the octopus salad.
author: H O.

description: Food is better than average, but service was so bad recently, we walked out. Went in thirsty for a drink in late afternoon. They were serving outside with a few inside. We went to the bar and were the only people there. After ten minutes we could not get anyone to help even though there were 8 people milling around within 15' of us and we tried to get their attention. We walked out. Previously also noticed that they have moved to smaller plates and smaller portions with the same prices. Very disappointing and there are too many other choices to return.
author: Bob F.

description:
I've been here twice - once just for a glass (or was it two?) of wine, and then again for dinner.  Since it's out in Dog Patch, you don't have the hipster crowds that make other restaurants impossible to get into.  I guess the hill over Potrero prevents the fixie riders away.  And you can still find parking, since there's not that much in the area besides the one little strip and Cocomo.

Service is pretty good - I called the day before so they saved some space at one of the "common" tables, even though I felt like we had our own space.  And our server was attentive, and managed our table needs pretty well.

The food wasn't knock-me-out delicious.  The pizza was good, but not amazing - I'd go there again, but they go for minimal cheese, and super thin crust.  I thought the pasta was excellent - not too rich, but more on the subtle side.  I'd get that over the pizza next time.
author: masa s.

description: I've now been to Piccino at least 5-6 times and have always had nothing but delicious, quality food and great service. The ambiance is VERY SF -- I took my old boss from New York there so she could get a true taste of yuppie SF -- lots of light, wood tables, earthy, and elegant. To start you can't go wrong with the farro and brasicas salad, if it's on the menu. The polpette is also very good if you're into something meaty. My favorite, however, is the margarita pizza. The pizza sauce is made with fresh tomatoes, hand-peeled (I asked for the recipe). The crust and cheese are good, but the star is really the sauce. They should bottle and sell the stuff! For dessert you can't skip the bombolini with the HEAVENLY lemon sauce. I hate to spread the word on this little gem, but they deserve the praise.
author: Nicola L.

description:
Pretty close to my house so that is a plus.

I came with two other friends.

We ordred:
Little gem salad... nice fresh and light
Milk pork poached egg and crispy potatos.... good and hearty but not anything I would crave
Parpadelle... nice and light.  I would order this again
Pizza, Margherita & Fungi... i liked the Margherita more than the fungi and really enjoyed the crust.
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: It's hard for me to think of the last time I left a restaurant hungry and didn't even want them to pack up the left overs because I just could not imagine taking another bite of the food. That was Piccino for me. The menu doesn't offer much besides pizzas and I found the pizza pretty bad.
