The crust is thin without much character and the toppings, albeit creative just didn't do it for me. Piccino just reinforces the stereotype of West Coasters not knowing how to make pizza.
author: Stephen S.

description:
What an amazing place! For starters the French wines were perfectly selected for our table to compliment each dish. We started with marinated olives and a little gem salad. They put magic in those oils! Two pizzas although I cannot remember the names had mushrooms and another with multiple cheeses. They were delicious although not as filling as I would have liked. 
The goat cheese dessert is a must and a marcopone dealio was pretty great too!
Picciono could be my new place before the entire world knows about it
author: Sigorney S.

description:
No matter how dreary the morning or how momentous the day, a cup of coffee from Piccino will have you thinking you may just have a chance of making it through the day.

I love walking through the garage door into a sparsely decorated, but adoringly cute space operated by two friendly staff members.  The Blue Bottle coffee drip is bold and is perfectly balanced by any one of their amazing little pastries or sweet bites.  The prosciutto scones are a killer if you prefer savory like I do as are the mushroom phyllo pastries.

The place recently switched over to taking credit cards as well so now you can grab coffee even when you run out of cash!
author: Brian G.

description:
LOVE their pizza! That's the only thing I go there for, so this review is only for pizza and nothing else. We always get - pizza Margherita + Salsiccia (the one with the sausage?)
LOVE IT!!!!
author: Luna R.

description:
6mo - 1yr ago I would've given 5 stars but this place has sadly gone down hill.  

A series of complete entrée misses and pizzas getting smaller and more expensive culminated in a bad group dining experience. 

I had a birthday dinner (my 40th!) with out of town & local family, about 8-10 people.  I thought this would be the perfect place - pizza & salads at the big community table! 

Unfortunately our server was apathetic at best and mostly seemed disappointed in nearly everything we ordered or asked for, even rolling his eyes occasionally.  Pizza and salad were good but the attitude was appalling.  Also, because of the automatic 20% gratuity (large group) I frankly just felt cheated.  Maybe worth 10% because, well, we did eat.
Upon complaining to the hostess, I was told "I'm sorry, we do get stressed out here sometimes".  Really?  Sorry, bad excuse.

My husband and I work near by and used to frequent Piccino for nice, relaxed lunches.  After a series of entrees with little flavor for a lot of money we will not be returning anytime soon - plenty of other very good places to eat in the neighborhood that do hit the mark.
.
It's sad really...Piccino's used to be my go to, to impress out of towners, and now it's simply disappointing.
author: Megan M.

description: I love the space, felt like I was on vacation away from SF. We ordered two pizzas, one sausage with an egg and another with riasted vegetables. We also got a polenta salad. I liked the polenta in the salad, great touch. After having Uva pizza i have become a pizza crust snob. I compare everytjing to Uva. Piccino had good pizza, but not amazing. The toppings made their crust wet and a bit soggy. It was good but not fantastic
author: Karen T.

description:
I really like hanging out at this neighborhood on my weekends. Piccino is unpretentious, fun & cool. Great organic dishes with clean flavors that does not leave you feeling heavy. They offer a great variety of refreshing wines that are easy to pair with their dishes.

My favorites:

To Start- 
arugula, strawberries, pistachios, balsamic, castelmagno, olio nuovo
(Delicious salad)
&
asparagus, burrata, heirloom polenta, watercress, salsa verde
(Like a bruschetta without the bread ;) )

Entree - 
pappardelle, english peas, spring onion, farmer's cheese, walnuts, dill
(Light pasta dish)

Grand Finale-
zeppole, vanilla bean crema, strawberry marmellata 
(Donuts w/ dipping sauce)

Worth the trip up there!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
My colleagues and I came for lunch on a Wednesday. There were nine of us and we had reservations for noon. 

Let me start by saying we arrived on time, just before the tiny place filled up completely. Plus, one of the staff called in sick, so they were shorthanded.

That said, we waited for what seemed like an eternity for any service at all. (Actually, it was about 15 minutes.) We ordered a bottle of wine and three appetizers. We got the wine quickly, but no food. Finally, around 12:30, we asked for some bread. The server brought us four tiny slices of toast. For a table of nine. Lame. At 12:40 p.m., we finally got our appetizers. At 12:50 p.m., we received our pizzas.

Well, the pizza was - in a word - AWESOME. We agreed it was worth the wait. 

Will I return? Definitely not if I'm really hungry or in a hurry.
author: Kim C.

description: Came here with some friends for pizza and were underwhelmed by both the pizza and the apathetic staff. The funghi was awesome, but the others were just average. I haven't been since they had the small cafe, so I did like the "ski chalet" vibe of their new restaurant.
author: Mattheus K.

description: The menu had great choices, but all I wanted was a salad. I ordered the cold salmon appetizer. Here's what I got for $16: 2 small pieces of bread with a little salmon salad spread on it and a small amount of greens on the side. Really? They have the nerve to charge this much for that little creativity and actual food! I will never go there again because this is exactly the kind of restaurant that I hate. It is clear the owners want to squeeze as much money as they can out of the new young and rich crowd with money to burn.
author: Susan G.

description: We always seem to come here for brunch.  Parking is easy.  The walk around the Dogpatch on a sunny day after a tasty brunch is perfection.  I enjoyed the french toast - hearty and not too sweet.  The baked egg and polpette is great and nice that it's served with some toasted bread.  Lastly, we always order the funghi pizza - if you enjoy mushrooms, you have to order this!  Service was prompt and always with a smile.  The decor is modern and the space is open which is great if you have children in the your party.  Last thing you want is your child bothering other patrons in a cramped dining area.
author: Tim L.

description: Great place for lunch.  Love the thin crust pizza.  Salad is amazing and so is the sandwich.  Came here many times and have not been disappointed.   I am not around to try dinner yet.
author: Savvy C.

description:
This place is literally across the street from my friend's house. Everytime I visit him this place is always crackin, there are always people here. I like how there is a take out section for coffee as an option, tucked away on the side of the building. This review will be for the afffogatos and service here. What are affogatos you might ask? Ice cream with a shot of espresso, to create a nice hot cold contrast for a dessert. My original plan had been to try out Mr and Mrs for ice cream, but to my dismay they were closed, and this how I even discovered Piccino had affogatos. The affogato ice cream flavor was a delicious decadent almond toffee flavor. Making conversation with the chef at the bar we were ecstatic to learn that the ice cream was actually from Mr and Mrs. The chef was apathetic that we were not able to try Mr and Mrs for ourselves and was nice enough to let us sample the other Mr and Mrs ice cream flavor they also. This incident alone in being so welcoming and nice left me with a warm feeling in my heart.

It is not only nice to taste something delicious, but to also enjoy the company who serves you. 

I look forward to trying this place out for their normal brunch/lunch menu, as I watched them create pasta from scratch, I was impressed. 
and did i mention this place reminds me of Pottery Barn?
What's not to love?(so far... food review soon to come)
author: Stacey W.

description:
Light rustic Italian...YUM! 

A hidden gem, complete with all the comforts of old-world Italian cooking which makes you wish you'd actually grown up with it!! Definitely my new favorite lunch spot. Very reasonably priced for such unique and freshly made dishes. Art for you palette that doesn't leave you feeling like you have a brick or two in your tummy!
author: Caroll M.

description: Outstanding. Food is always fresh and inventive. Sit at the bar to watch the open kitchen for a real treat. Service is top notch.
author: Annika D.

description:
Business meetings are always better with food. 

My boss and I so happened to be the Dog Patch this afternoon when she suggested Piccino. 

And boy. .. I am glad she did. The front and back of the house was extremely welcoming. I wish I could put the staff in a doggy bag and take them home. (They're that awesome) The food was hmm...good too!  

Any place that carries donuts is A.W.E.S.O.M.E!
author: Nicole R.

description:
Love this place, but...

WHY ARE THEY SO ASS BACKWARDS when it comes to ordering CERTAIN menu items to go? They offer pizzas A, B, and C to go but cannot do a white pizza to go? What's the rationale?
author: Joshua G.

description: Went in at 3pm ish, unfortunately missed the lunch. But what got me was how the server came out...she was a bit terse & rude in her way of saying they're only serving snacks.  Pity, I bookmarked this place to try, but am turned off now. So that's okay, we went to try the coffee as a chance of redemption, but didn't know who was working because employees kept coming in and out but not taking any orders...until a line formed after waiting a few minutes for an iced cup of joe ($3.50, tastes alright).
author: Miss J.

description: Lovely menu - I had a beautiful salad and my friends had pizza and said it was one of the best they've ever had. My kids ordered lemonade and it came tart and sugar-free with a separate simple sugar jar so they could sweeten themselves.  Great service, outdoor seating for brunch.
author: Melissa P.

description: Loved the ambiance.  It's a great space in Dog Patch with open natural light with an open exposed kitchen.  The food was good but not for the price.  I'd go back for one more try, but the vegetarian options were not very imaginative.  Gnocchi was smoky and tasty but not my fav.
author: Jessiqa P.

description:
Went here for lunch, and I gotta say, one of the best place for lunch on the weekend. 

What really stands out at this restaurant is the healthy options that they offer, and I could be wrong -- doubt it -- but believe they make everything there. From the pasta, to the bread, to the dessert. That's probably why I like it so much. The home-cooking style is always a winner for me. I had the pasta, and it was delicious. The pizza was the last course I had, and it was the perfect 'entree' for lunch.

There isn't much of a full-bar there, but they have a bar .... nuf said? Otherwise, they have some beer, but a lot of wine options. It's Italian, what do you expect. The staff was friendly. We sat at the kitchen bar, and we stirred up a conversation with the 'pasta-guy' who made our pasta. Come to think of it, that was kind of weird actually.

The service was good. A little slow all things considering it was around 2:00 p.m., and it wasn't crowded. That's what's preventing me from really giving it he 5th star to be honest. I suppose it didn't matter because we really enjoyed the food. I would recommend this place for anyone in the Dog Patch area in San Francisco.

Happy Eating!
author: Rob B.

description: Mediocre food quality. Apple bee level. Not up to Sanfran quality. Wait staff ok. Nice ambience. But food, get real!
author: Bud E.

description:
The two pizzas my companion and I tried were excellent.  Great thin crisp crust.  My fungi pizza had great mushroom flavor.  Her pizza had locally made sausage crumbled all over it. They were each more than large enough for one person.  With a salad or starter the pizza could be big enough for two.  I had an excellent chocolate ice cream sandwich for dessert - great chocolate ice cream on equally good dark chocolate cookies.  The portion size was large enough for two, but there was no way to take half of it home, of course.  It would be nice if they offered a half size portion.

The service was attentive, the space attractive.  Parking can be difficult, so do allow time.
author: Kristina H.

description: Quite a bit off the beaten path, but a lovely location south of SOMA.  Beer and wine only, while beer selection is limited it is high quality.  Wine list is very good.  Nice ambiance and very suitable for quiet conversation (at least in the early evening hours).  Food is competent.  A bit damning with faint praise, but given the choice, I'd place this joint at 2  1/2 stars.
author: Howard B.

description:
My wife had been to Piccino 7 times--all for dinner. It's our go-to spot in the Dogpatch. It's about time a gave them a review. 

What we love about the Piccino are the portion sizes--they are small (more than good enough) just like European servings, specifically like Italian servings. This means that you can actually try multiple dishes w/o getting way too full. 

The menu changes every quarter or so (seasonally) which is great. Plus the menu is super simple, with a good wine list. We generally always order an antipasti, something from the primi along with soup and just split one of the pizzas.
author: Al G.

description:
Came here for dinner and got, among other things the "tre formaggi agnolotti". It was very bland and tasteless, and for $16 you basically get 6 pieces of ravioli. Way overpriced and tiny servings.

Also got the Salsiccia pizza, which was equally bland and not worth the $16 price tag.
author: Jeff C.

description:
First of all, the parking.  Horrible.  Wear your hiking shoes.  Second of all, the service.  Trendy hornrims girl looked so put out when I refused the wine list and asked for a diet coke.  It's a business lunch at 11:00 on a weekday, Spruce, or whatever your name is.  Sorry, I didn't realize your establishment is too cool to stock plebian drinks like soda or even Pelligrino, I guess I'm the only troglodyte in SF supporting the billion dollar soda industry.  In any case, Ms. Disdainful with the gauche Kanji neck tattoo set the tone of the service.  The place isn't that cool; they are blaring U2 and Sting at top volume.  I settled for the lemonade, which was actually fresh lemons and water that you add your own simple syrup to.  Actually, not a bad idea.  
I must say, after the service and the poor soundtrack I was fully prepared to hate the place and go the 1 or 2 star route, but I honestly can't due to one thing - the food is amazing!  The funghi pizza was incredible, as was my pasta.  Even the coffee ice cream with home made marshmallows was awesome. I'll definitely be back for the food; I'll just get take out so I can double park and also not have to deal with the wait staff.  
Bring your wallet tho - lunch for two (no wine, of course), with two entrees, appetizer, and dessert was over $100 with tax & tip.....
author: Ken P.

description:
Everyone seems to just love Piccino - and I am on that bandwagon. I have been there about four times now, and it is an easy go to place on weekends for brunch/lunch. 

1. Parking - lots of parking in the neighborhood and they have a lot right in front
2. They take reservations - I am way past waiting in line for 60-70 minutes for brunch. This was something I was ok with in my twenties , but no patience for it now. 
3. Gorgeous restaurant - wooden tables, airy atmosphere with open kitchen. Relaxed but friendly place
4. Yummy food! 
Mini-meatballs (polpette)
Pizzas (especially loved the seasonal nettle pizza they had - wonderful!)
Some sort of lovely pork dish with a poached egg
Burratta - fantastic!

Perfect for meeting up with friends, or taking out of town guests. Staff are efficient and knowledgeable, although they are sometimes not the friendliest bunch on the block. They get it done and your waterglass won't run dry.

I am so done with treks across the city for brunch - I'm staying in my neighborhood - Dogpatch, Potrero Hill, Soma, and thankfully, there are some great places that are perfect for the relaxing Sun or Sat lunch with friends or family. This is one of them! Dependable and likable - this is the girl next door restaurant.
author: Connie B.

description:
Winter kills.

Amazing song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FKqkCrY0MF0

Amazing panini: Winter squash, caramelized and pickled onions and chicories with a side of roasted potatoes. Packed with ingredients and flavor. 

Pistachio butter was delivered on the side. Couldn't help myself and almost used all of it.

Not so new anymore space is very well done. Plenty of character in the yellow exterior, lighting accents and wood decor. Bustling and beautiful.

Sandwiches that cost $13 better be amazing. You should definitely take a moment with this one and this place.
author: Jason B.

description: While the food was flavorful (yet small portions), the service was horrendous.  Our waitress' rude and pretentious attitude took away from our dining experience; there are too many other great restaurants in the area to waste your time with bad service.
author: Marie M.

description: One of my favorite spots. Consistently good food, love the ambiance, great service. Been coming here since they opened in the new spot and appreciate the architecture and space design.
author: Sean G.

description: I am very happy to say... This was a fabulous food experience all the way around.  I arrived with great parking karma, seated promptly without reservation, service was very friendly and attentive without being interrupted.  The food was brought out in perfect timing and executed very well.  I ordered their pizze Bianca and pizza funghi which was prepared with a crisp, thin crust and delicately topped with balance and full flavor.  The pork and beef polpette, with crushed tomatoes and Parmesan were tender and delicious!  I enjoyed the intimate setting.  It certainly has a casual, yet romantic ambiance that is alluring to make you want to stay.  Thank you... I will certainly make this my new regular stop in the Dog Patch!
author: Christine R.

description: This restaurant is awesome. The setting is great, very laid back but yet upscale. The food was amazing, service was friendly, and the pricing was reasonable. What more can you ask for out of a delicious weekend Italian dinner. Highly recommend you stop by for a meal if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Scoot S.

description:
Food has somehow gotten better since the move. And its nice to not feel like someones breathing down your neck as you eat. Great dining room. Guessing its gorgeous at night.

Sitting at the bar is a lot of fun. Watch the action unfold in the open kitchen!

Had the Pizza Bianca w/egg really nice flavor & texture and, a very tasty, if not over dressed, broccolini & faro salad with nice chunky roasted almonds. The salad would have been more enjoyable with less olive oil-distracted from the flavor.

menu:
http://www.piccinocafe.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2&Itemid=2
author: Michelle M.

description:
Let's say I can see why people love this place, for the dog patch neighborhood its a great go to restaurant. It's very sleek and trendy and in a adorable location next to a wine store and trendy shop. The Funghi pizza is SO good, crispy and thin and so flavorful. The pasta with octopus sounds weird but is yummy, the octopus is crispy and cooked just right. You should get a reservation first though, otherwise there is not a lot of seating available, and it's cold to sit outside at night.

Only negative is the waiter was  SO slow, he kept stopping to talk to every patron, which is nice, but seriously it made the service a lot slower. Also, when asked for recommendations, he didn't have a lot to say.
author: Anthea L.

description: I came here for dinner with a friend. Even on a Tuesday night, it was pretty full, and it was good that we had gotten reservations. The service was good. Our waitress was very nice and attentive. The food was tasty, but the portions were way too small to justify the high prices. The one dish I was really happy with was the salsiccia pizza. It was reasonably priced and delicious--light and not greasy, and the crust had a perfect amount of crunch. One of the best pizzas I've ever had. The ambiance of the restaurant is classy and intimate. It would be a nice place to treat guests from out of town, but the prices are too high for me to consider coming back here very often.
author: Anna B.

description:
Great place, not even one disappointing dish, great for dates nights AND for an outing with kids. 

We were here twice, once alone and once with the kids, and both dinners were fantastic. Their pizza is superb, not just according to the kids (who, frankly, would probably call Caesar's superb) but according to us grownups. Thin crust, delicious sauce, great cheese, who needs anything else? My son added pepperoni and the result was so good he asked for a second pizza halfway through the first one (teenage boys are a danger to dining budgets everywhere!)

For the grownups, every dish was fantastic. I do have a fondness for their appetizers and next time I plan to order every appetizer on that day's menu instead of an entree. Make sure you try the crackers. 

For dessert, the kids were offered Zepole, which are doughnut holes taken to a new level, served with mascarpone and a mandarin curd (both great.)  A great ending to a great meal.
author: Hagit K.

description: Delicious food, definitely try the gnudi! Great service! Neighborhood favorite.
author: Veronica D.

description: The food at Piccino is delicious. The products are fresh, the meat is amazing, and the pasta original and tasteful ! Piccino has also an amazing wine list, very diverse and with excellent references. The service is great, the waiter was there to share his advice about the wine and thanks to him our "fiorentina" was cooked exactly as we wanted. Although we were one of the last tables, the staff was always very friendly.
author: Celine G.

description: Unfortunately we had to wait 45 minutes for our table, the good thing is that they have a separate coffee bar and it was a beautiful day! When we received the bread, I already knew that it was worth the wait! When I tasted my pizza I knew I would be waiting 45 mins soon! It was amazing!
author: Vincent V.

description:
I've had my eye on Piccino for months, purely on the merit of its ambiance - by day, sunlight pours across light wood tables, among interwoven metal details and by night, bustling movement in the open kitchen offset by candlelight animates the lofty space. The embodiment of modern SF charm.

Wonderful service, with genuinely friendly staff and the impeccable timing of our dishes, each arriving within minutes of the last.  Perfect for a date, group of 2 - 4, or bite to eat @ the bar facing the open kitchen. Probably on the pricey side for a starving group, but the dishes are refreshing & well-composed.

++ | Burratta w/Eggplant |
The giant golden raisins & nepitella really make a difference to bring a sweet & savory balance to the silky cheese.

++ | Funghi Pizza |
Funghi lovers will love this dish; this pizza is largely a mushroom spread on delicate flatbread as opposed to a traditional cheese & toppings pie.

Other dishes: Polpette (meatballs) were juicy and tender, though the sauce wasn't noteworthy. Stracci (pasta) and the beef cheeks are dishes we didn't try that are purported to be amazing.

Dinner for 2 = $55
Dinner w/an extremely liberal allocation for wine = $150
author: Christina J.

description: Exceptional service and great friendly environment to hang out with friends.  The hosts were very welcoming and they took great care in attention to detail.  We ordered verdure crude, house made crackers, carrot and gigante bean hummus for appetizer.  It was a perfect balance of freshness and flavor with just enough filling get your appetite going.  Margherita pizza was a bit too simple but delicious.  Salsiccia pizza was really fresh, with enough of meat but not too heavy.  Coffee at the end was a great finish to an overall solid experience.
author: Eric H.

description:
It was a spontaneous visit on a Friday afternoon for some light snacks and a glass of wine to enwhine the work week, my dining partner and I went to Piccino. We sat at the bar in front of the kitchen where we get to watch all the chefs and cooks in action, it is our favorite spot to sit every time we go to a restaurant. 

We ordered a Funghi Pizza with Stracchino Cheese from Genoa. (Stracchino cheese is a fresh cheese orinated in Genoa Italy that is closely resemble a combination between cream chesee, but lighter in texture and the tanginess of creme fraiche.) Our very thin crust, crispy pizzas arrived and the based was covered with flavorful sauteed ground mushrooms, topped with more piece of mushrooms the stracchino cheese and thinly shaved garlic. There was no sauce of any kind in this pizza and it was the good call by the chef. The aroma of the mushroom was so potent, and the cheese was light and creamy with the thinly sliced garlic flakes that was not at all over powering the rest of the ingredients they shared in that pizza. All in all, the perfect flavor, taste and aroma combination. Bravo! 

Our server, a very friendly French guy from France's Loire Valley recommended a glass of red for my dining companion and a Pinot Blanc from Italy for me and they paired really nicely with our pizza. Good wine list, great food with menu changes daily I believe and that tells me that they only cook with ingredients that are in season. Overall, it was a great afternoon snacks for a post work week. We love the food and services at Piccino. We look forward to returning here for a full dinner soon.  

Date of visit: Sept. 28, 2012
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
This is a great spot to grab lunch on a Saturday afternoon. I came for lunch at Hard Knox, but the place was packed so we ended up coming to Piccino. Good move.

It's a quaint little place with nice rustic touches. The menu had your basic pizzas and the three that we got were good for four guys. The napoletana probably takes the edge over the salsccia, but not everyone likes anchovies so to each his own. For a neighborhood pizza place, their wine list was pretty impressive.

And of course, the coffee is good enough to come for by itself.

Definitely coming back here.
author: Cristofer P.

description: what a great place. we enjoyed our funghi pizza (thin crust and not soggy just the way we like it) as well as the cauliflower and faro salad. unfortunately the brussel sprouts were a little on the salty side. also recommend the mini pork meatballs in tomato sauce. yummy!
author: Helen Y.

description:
This is my second time eating here and every time, I leave with a satisfied stomach. The ingredients taste fresh, the dishes taste  very light. Piccino is one of the places where I can stuff myself and still feel good afterwards. Definitely one of my favorites here in DogPatch. 

*Pizza is delicious, my favorite is the Estate. 

Great service, great food, and I love the interior of the restaurant.
author: Amy W.

description:
The lure of Piccino has caused me to miss my train on more than one occasion. Make sure you have a few extra minutes to wait for your coffee: they grind the beans and brew each cup of Sight Glass individually. 

A great coffee experience takes patience. 

It's not just the coffee that they pay special attention to: the food is fresh and meticulously displayed on sleek wood and frosted glass pedestals. The custom metal and woodwork makes this place feel like an impossibly chic garage that you might use to park your cherry-red vintage pickup!

You'll always meet some fancy dogs while you wait in line (there will almost certainly be a line). 

Try the homemade granola and yogurt!
author: Mrs. E.

description:
Never thought I would put a Potrero restaurant on my list to take visitors, but Piccino is just too good to deny. I never went to this place before the remodel but it is beautiful now. The wood is perfectly contrasted with the blue wall and the lights and metals infuse a very soft and modern environment. We were instantly impressed and VERY happy there was no line at 11:15 on a Sunday. 

The food was 5 stars all around. They had numerous vegetarian options which was great so I could eat many things off the menu. We ended up trying:

Roasted cauliflower, farro and almond gremolata - LOVED LOVED THIS. Simple ingredients that really came together for amazing flavor. High quality olive oil makes a world of a difference!

La tur, hen of the woods mushroom and caramelized onion bruschetta - La tur is the best cheese I think I've ever had. It had the texture of goat chese but a subtle flavor of brie and was amazingly delicious. I kept the cheese and asked for some bread on the side to finish it up.

Celery root soup, spigarello pesto and toasted walnut - very tasty and perfect for a chilly Sunday morning. They were kind enough to split the soup into two different bowls without us asking.

Funghi Pizza: roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic - We got this with an egg on it (were trying to make it a little brunch like) and it was SO delicious. I don't even think the egg is needed. They use a mushroom pesto as the sauce and it is super tasty. The crust was thin and crispy, just how I like it!

Can't wait to come back here and I think we were lucky to get seated right away. The place filled up fast and I believe they take reservations so I would definitely make one before coming in.
author: Raina B.

description: Cutest little coffee shop ever! Dog friendly with homemade doggy goodies. Oh, and homemade pastries and human treats, too! Very friendly staff. Just don't be surprised if there's a line. Latte art to go with a delicious cup of joe!
author: Katherine P.

description: Went here for dinner last night with friends and thoroughly enjoyed the food and ambiance.  The dinner menu here is family style so splitting a few options works really well.  We started off with crackers, pickled vegetables, faro salad and pate.  The pate was very savory without being too heavy.  I liked how it was served in mini jar with crackers so you can dip.  The faro salad was nothing to rave about and the pickled vegetables was just cauliflower and beets.  We also ordered the funghi pizza, the pappardelle pasta, and pork and beef meatballs, all of which were spectacular.  The reason why it's not five stars is we had to wait quite a bit for our table to be ready and feel they should acknowledged it somehow.
author: Tanichka B.

description:
I love this place. I have been for brunch/lunch and for dinner and both are outstanding. 
Things I love:
-innovative pizzas (brunch pizza yesterday was peach, pancetta, arugula and pecorino -- SO good)
-gorgeous interior
-great service
-good wine list
-great iced tea for lunch
-not too loud (perfect for older guests should they be in town)
-easy parking
-great coffee

Whenever we meet people for dinner now we suggest Piccino if there is an open reservation because we know we will get an interesting meal in a lovely restaurant. 

As a sidenote, we went with a 14 week old child and they were super sweet to our party. There are no changing tables or areas where you can turn into one in the bathrooms, but the kid was changed in the car right outside, which is the benefit of easy parking!
author: christine c.

description: Funghi pizza with an egg on top and white wine, yes. Next time I'll try the blanco pizza. Cute restaurant. Great location. Great service and there's a little seating area looking into the clothing store through glass.  Coffee shop attached.
author: Sara K.

description: A regular spot for me and one of my girlfriends, as she lives in the area. The homemade crackers are my favorite to nosh on, and the pizza here is tasty. The salads are also very scrumptious and the perfect amount of flavor and dressing.
author: Taya V.

description: This review is specifically for the cafe. I love it. They have the nicest team ever, they play the best music - and I'm addicted to their ice coffee. Can't live without it, seriously.
author: Too M.

description:
More than a neighborhood place... and a great neighborhood place.

Have never had anything less than great at Piccino.  The sauteed baby carrot contorni are over the top.  Pork and beef polpette (meatballs) will keep you coming back.  Fava falafel so savory and smooth.  Pizza is excellent (must say Tony's still wins a head to head contest) and can be innovative (thin lemon slices on the pancetta pizza).  Excellent dessert choices; I don't usually like dessert.  We tried the zeppole (think donut hole raised to the firmament) with cardamom anglaise and strawberry puree... wow.

Go ahead, just throw a dart at the menu and order it, you will be happy.   Piccino has a great sensibility about produce that shows up in almost every dish - a very welcome distinction that takes great advantage of the bounty of California farming.

Service is excellent... I would use the term "Gastronomy Consultant" for our French born dining tour guide... he staged the order of delights perfectly.

Nice wine list . Corkage is $15 if you have a favorite bottle or two you've been wanting to pair with outstanding Italian treats.   Reservations for sure, it can get busy.  Mangia  bene!!!
author: Bob K.

description:
Pizza with eggs....AMAZING!!!! And blue bottle coffee...how can this place not be a winner! The desserts are tasty too! I'll be back for sure.

Parking is easy and the wait was not bad..but I went here on a Thursday night.
author: Cat K.

description:
The food is delicious and the service is good, it's just rather spendy for the amount of food you receive.

The menu is mainly pizzas with a couple of panini, the polpette and some salads and appetizers. We couldn't make a decision on the main course, so I ordered a salad to start. 
So, the salad was good, but oh so wee.....it was like the lettuce leaves were counted out before being placed on the plate.  The combination of pickles and fried capers with the green leaf? lettuce was surprisingly good and I thought the vegetable soup with bacon and garlic croutons had really good flavor.

The sandwiches we ordered, I personally, liked (one was the brisket and the other the roasted eggplant) although my husband thought the brisket one seemed too heavy or greasy.  I felt satisfied after finishing my sandwich, but left feeling like the $80 lunch bill was a lot of cash to spend on a wee, petite lunch of a couple of sandwiches, soup, salad and a glass o' vino. 
If the prices ever drop, I'd love to return.  The pizzas looked good, too.
author: Julie G.

description:
Dropped by one Sunday afternoon and tried a slice of their orange cake and iced coffee. The orange cake was divine! Not overly sweet and quite moist. I really enjoyed the little slice of candied orange that topped the cake as well. Very cute.

The iced coffee was fixed a bit bitter for my taste, so I had to sweeten it up a bit. Not a big deal. They use Sightglass coffee, which I'm not too sure how I feel about yet. Still a refreshing cup, nevertheless, especially on such a hot day.

Ended up taking home a slice of their pistachio cake... which was good... but it didn't live up to what the orange cake was. There wasn't enough pistachio flavor, as it was overpowered by the dried fruits (if I remember correctly, it was cranberries and maybe peach?). The overall taste came off as a fruitcake instead.

Will stop by again to try out more pastries and sweets!
author: Steph C.

description: The ambiance of this place is great. The food looked good, but I can't comment on how it tasted because we were so turned off by the service that we actually left. The restaurant was not full, but the hostess told us it would be a while until we could be seated. I told her that some people in our party were very, very hungry and asked if we could go ahead and put an order in so that it would be ready when we finally were allowed to sit at one of those already empty tables, and she said "we don't do that here." She couldn't have seemed more apathetic or bored. We had a number of similarly frustrating interactions with her, and at that point, I was so annoyed that we left, despite being famished. The food on other people's tables looked good, but the awful service so rubbed me the wrong way that I do not intend to return, ever.
author: Heather K.

description:
Sight Glass coffe made to perfection. 

Just doesn't get any better than this.
author: Adam Q.

description:
The first time I came here, I was here for lunch on a weekday and seated at the countertop bar. The pizza was tasty, and the service was good albeit it was relatively empty.

Last saturday I went for a Saturday lunch, and while the food was still fresh and tasty, but  the service really put me off. When I asked for a coke, I got a "we don't do soda here". Oh, pardon us for the assumption. After a shared anchovy & chicory salad, our waiter asked if there will be anything else for us before he got the bill. I clarified- "yes, how about our entrees". I also asked for a paper napkin and it went quickly forgotten. There were no attempts to ask us how our food was. The Gnocchi dish was tasty but a rather petite portion. The chicken sandwich was unmemorable but I finished it. 

I'll only return if I can sit at the counter on a weekday during lunch.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Went there last night on a whim with a friend of mine. There was a bit of a line, but it moved quickly and we were able to get seats at the bar facing the brightly lit interior of a women's clothing store next door. Kind of an odd experience to watch women shopping for summer dresses while eating, but fun nonetheless.

My friend and I were deep in conversation for most of the evening and the waiter was very good at being attentitive, yet giving us our space. He finally managed to get us to pay attention to him, and we ordered based on his recommendations: 

To start:
- cabbage, snap peas, watermelon radish, avocado
- farro, mustard greens, roasted brassicas, sea salt almond, horseradish

The salads were pretty good. We both enjoyed the farro and ate most of it before the waiter took it away (again, too busy talking and not paying attention, and he probably didn't want to disturb us, otherwise, the plate would have been clean when he took it) The cabbage salad was a good-sized portion and very tasty.

Entrees:
- slow poached halibut, basil-ginger broth, artichokes, potatoes, lime
- pork and beef polpette, crushed tomato, parmesan

Initially they brought us the wrong entrees, but they corrected their mistake fairly quickly.

The halibut was kind of bad, which was really disappointing because I love slow-poached fish and it's really easy to do well. My halibut smelled fishy (not fresh) and it was overcooked. The basil ginger broth was too subtle for me. Not a lot of flavor. A big miss for them.

The pork and beef polpette was tasty, and seasoned well. 

Dessert:
- date macadamia nut cake, buttermilk caramel, kumquat, crème fraiche

The dessert was tasty but a bit too dense for me. It was kind of like a fancy fruitcake (if you're into that sort of thing)

Atmosphere was pleasant. It was bright and cheery and not too noisy. Staff was friendly but a bit disorganized. If it weren't for the bad fish dish I would have given this place 4 stars. I'll probably go back and try it again.
author: Michael T.

description: Just loved the food here.  We had the trout and it just melted in the mouth.  And the waitstaff were really attentive although they seemed a bit rushed at times.
author: Paul V.

description: Latte is perfectly creamy and awesome.  But the little - no, TINY - tart the size of a quarter costs $2 - and judging from the taste should only cost 75 cents at best.
author: Kristen S.

description: This place is a gem.  I was looking for a cozy Italian restaurant in SF with a low-tourist quotient, and Piccino fits the bill.  I had the butter lettuce with Asian pear salad, and the ingredients made it stand out.  Not in the mood for pasta or pizza, I tried the polpettes, with a light fresh tomato sauce.  Add a couple of glasses of Chianti, and all was right in the world.
author: Jack H.

description: This is a cute neighborhood spot, and we were cute impressed with the pizzas.  The other dishes were delicious as well and I loved the atmosphere.  We all thought that we were in some day spa restaurant rather than in SF.  Nice change of environment.
author: Edgar C.

description: This is for the coffee bar, not the restaurant.  I like hot chocolate, I've been a couple of times in the hopes that each experience will be better than the last.  Unfortunately this hasn't been the case.  It's always luke warm, small, expensive and very, very, very slow getting to the front of the queue.  Finally it sort of sums up the changes to Dog Patch, which is sort of annoying.  I do like the restaurant which I would give four stars.
author: Emma C.

description:
Love the new location (they have been there one year, so not all that new).  

Somehow it didn't get too loud, even when full and with music playing.  It was a warm night and really too bad that the windows didn't open because some fresh air would have been nice and there were flies buzzing around (which bugged the heck out of us) which could have been released.

Service was excellent. Could not have asked for a better waitress than Hana.  The other people who came to the table were cheerful and attentive.  It was a bit much to have someone top off my water glass every few minutes with the carafe that was right on the table.  I appreciate the attention, but I can do that myself and it would be less interuption of the conversation my friend and I were having.

Skip the appetizers.  They are really tiny.  The artichoke was really an artichoke heart cut into four little pieces.  But the pizza was big and the atmosphere fun.

I took the T-line and walked from 20th & Third and felt perfectly safe, so don't let the neighborhood keep you from enjoying this place.

They have outdoor seating.
author: Bay G.

description:
Piccino's is my favorite place in the city to get coffee. Whether offering Blue Bottle coffee as it previously did, or Sightglass coffee, as it does now, what really does it for me is the location. You definitely don't feel like you're still in the city but you're minutes away from great places to stroll.

I appreciate the new cafe more than I did the previous one; there are now places to sit inside. The baked goods are considerably more delectable. The ambiance is much more rustic; I feel like I'm in some off-the-grid Spanish or Italian town when I walk in - somewhat expecting a stray dog to amble by outside or old men to throw around a bocce ball.

If you like everything that comes with great San Francisco coffee but you don't like the laptops and lines - this place gets you in and out so you can begin roaming around the oldest Victorians in San Francisco.
author: Amir S.

description: Pizzas and polpette are always great. The menu is always limited, so you have to be in the mood for the small menu.
author: Jon H.

description:
Hey this place is ALMOST awesome!!  The bartender is a trip... The pizza's are among the best out there.  The fried brussel sprouts although simple were delicious!  And of course the ambiance and feel of the place is wickedly fun and authentically San Francisco.

But WTF maaaaan, we made a reservation!  Seating us an hour after our reservation is not cool.  The hostess asks us, "oh can we get you guys some wine while you wait?"  Well, yeah... thanks!  Well it turns out the wine to keep us entertained was on us, not them!  A lot of places I would not expect to cover a glass of wine in that situation... but a place like Piccino - among the restaurants it competes with and with the prices it charges ... it is the professional thing to do.  A bit of respect lost there (esp when our bill came to ~$50/pp).
author: Kurosh H.

description: Delicious food spot in the Dogpatch! Can't go wrong with a fresh and innovative menu. I love the open kitchen and the overall atmosphere. It's the first place we bring all out of town guests because we know they'll have an amazing food experience!
author: Ula K.

description:
You can't miss the bright yellow building when in search of Piccino, although the entrance can be a bit confusing as there is also a Piccino's coffee bar on one side and a clothing store on the other.  The restaurant inside is bright, modern, and spacious.  I love the wooden panels, table setting, and community tables in the center adorned with festive pomegranates.  There is plenty of seating at this new addition to the Dogpatch neighborhood.

My friend and I met for lunch here and shared the recommended Salsiccia Pizza, with its house made slightly spicy sausage.  The crust was crisp and airy, just how I like my thin crust pizzas.  For the appetizer, we also had a deliciously simple roasted beet, bleu cheese, and what appeared to be baked and crispy kale leaves.  The entire salad was drizzled with balsamic honey and rich in flavor.  

Wonderful restaurant and friendly service without the ridiculous lines like  some other SF pizzerias (for now); I will definitely be back to sample the rest of the menu as it does change seasonally.
author: Pauline L.

description: Beautiful thoughtful food.  Wonderful decor and calming ambience ... a little bit of taking you on an adventure and out of your daily life for a couple hours..   We had a pasta (fig, chili, mint)  pizza, and starter to share.  All were excellent.  The funghi pizza was to die for.  You don't need to go to Italy to experience the best of Italian food.
author: Billy B.

description:
This review makes me sad. You see, my friends love Piccino. All the critics love Piccino. I wanted to love Piccino! Alas, I did not love Piccino.

Much has been written about the new space and I'll just say that I agree with everything that has been said, it is beautiful. Do note that it is extremely loud and at 8pm on a Friday night, the wait was around an hour.

Once seated, we come up with a game plan. We love to share (sharing is caring!) so ordered a number of items.

Pickled veggies: so good, actually the highlight of our meal. Who knew you could pickle a grape? Only gripe - these took over 20 minutes to arrive after ordering. C'mon, we know you're not just pickling them now...what took so long?

Black mission fig, fourme d'ambert, toasted walnut and fennel: these were fine, pretty tasty but the portion size seemed off for $11

Heirloom tomato, lemon cucumber and wild arugula panzanella: the tomatoes were awesome, the bread nice and crunchy, but this dish suffered from being WAY overdressed. I literally had to choke down a couple of bites because it was so vinegary. 

Baked semolina gnocchi, poached egg, zucchini caponata and olive purée: our least favorite dish of the night. I pictured little pillows of perfection on a plate, instead this was one jumbled mess.

Pizza Bianca: loved the crust but the pizza itself didn't come together at all. WAY too much garlic, we joked after that this was glorified garlic bread. 

Chocolate budino, bruléed zabaglione, albion strawberries: our meal ended on a high note, this was a fantastic dessert.

Service was fine though we did have a long wait between ordering and our first dish being brought out. And then they brought the pizza and gnocchi at the same time which made for a tetris like exercise of rearranging our tiny table with all this stuff on it.

Overall, I was quite disappointed in our meal at Piccino. Maybe we ordered wrong? Maybe all the great reviews have them resting on their laurels? Whatever the reason, I doubt I'll be back anytime soon.
author: phil h.

description: Went to Piccino for a day-after-Valentine's dinner & really enjoyed it. I was surprised they charge for the bread & olive oil, though it was delicious & well worth the $3. I had the pappardelle w/ a pork ragu, which was excellent. Rich but delicate. The gf had the bianca pizza. Good but could have used some herbs to vary the flavor, perhaps oregano or basil. She asked for a side of marinara which was great & added to the meal nicely. The star of the show was our side of brussels sprouts. Honestly could have eaten 3 bowls if I hadn't already ordered my entree! The bottle of pinot we split was good & the service was very attentive without being overbearing. We also walked to a bar around the corner for a nightcap & would definitely return!
author: David O.

description:
What is the point of serving artisan coffee if you have people who do not know how to prepare it?

I decided to try a new coffee spot today. I usually go to Sightglass in the SOMA near my home, but ventured off to Piccino's near my studio. 

Like the usual coffee shop in the morning, it was crazy busy. I waited about 20 minutes total to get my cup. I order an Americano and always drink my coffee black. The barista calls out my order and hands it off. I inspected the coffee and it looked pretty peculiar. I thought, "wow, what happened to the crema?!" Rather than looking caramel in color like it should, it was mud black. Hence, like I expected the coffee was bitter and void of complex flavor. Either the barista doesn't know how to pack the espresso properly or the machine needs to be seriously calibrated. 

What else could go wrong? 

The girl working the counter not only handed my card to another customer (it has my picture on it), but gave that person my receipt! Sadly, I had no control over how much tip to leave because the stranger had already filled in some arbitrary amount. Fed up, I signed the receipt, demanded a replacement drip cup and rushed back late to work.   

I've worked many years as a barista in the past and it was odd that the staff appeared to be confused by my comments about the crema. I understand that shops get busy in the morning, but consistency from cup-to-cup is what you expect for paying a premium. 

I do have to give them credit that they didn't contest my disappointment and responded appropriately to my request for an alternative replacement. The drip coffee was mediocre.  

I doubt I'll be returning or recommending this spot to my colleagues.
author: Moises T.

description:
I like this place. It's pretty casual, reasonably quiet, the food is good and the staff is patient and friendly. The margarita pizza's great.

Tip: Takeout's ordered via the coffeeshop. Dial the main Piccino line, then press 16.
author: Susan P.

description: Piccino's cooking, not its incredibly attractive/attitude ridden wait staff, sells itself: Their deconstructed take on gnocchi was sweet, light, and savory, the kind of dish that had me at "poached-egg-on-top."  The true winner though was their margarita pizza, the tomato rich, the basil punchy, and the cheese just the right kind of amount of melty.  If you're expecting a "pizza place" don't come here; rather, show up to Piccino's for a quirky take on country cooking, infused with some Italian simplicity and modern flair.
author: Michael D.

description: Love the food here! I went with a friend there for a quick weekend lunch. We got there at around 12:30 and the restaurant was just getting busy. The space is very simply decorated with clean lines, but feels very comfortable. The broccoli and faro salad was really delicious and the prosciutto panini was outstanding! The bread was perfectly crusted and complements the prosciutto so well. The services were that good. We had to wait for over 20 minutes for the panini. However, when it actually came, it was worthy of the wait.
author: Ally W.

description: Tonight I had the meatballs which were pretty much the best meatballs I've ever had. Everything else I tried was very good too. I had eaten here once before for breakfast but was not super impressed. However after hearing so many people raving about it I decided to give it a go for dinner. My overall impression and opinion is that it is quite delicious but the portions are quite small for the high price...and this is San Francisco--delicious food is not hard to come by here and the portions elsewhere are usually at least enough to fill you up. Don't expect to get enough food here to satisfy your appetite, assuming you bring one, for under 40 bucks.
author: Nathan R.

description: I'm a big fan of the space and the food.  I used to frequent the cafe for their sandwiches, which I don't think they make anymore so now I go to the restaurant occasionally.  I can often find a dinner reservation on open table.  Some of the more memorable items that I've had are the pappardelle with octopus (wish they brought this back. I like it better than the vegetarian options), the burratta with polenta (especially good when cherries were in season) and the farro antipasti. In an attempt to be healthy, I ordered the farro with kale, mint, and pine nuts among other ingredients and savored every bite.  I might actually like farro now for the taste.  It's not 5 stars every time but enough times that I keep going back.  The food is what I go for but parking is fairly easy in the dogpatch and the restaurant gets a lot of light, which are added bonuses.
author: Christina M.

description:
Since I started this draft of my review i have been here a second time.  It may be my new favorite place.  I'd been wanting to try this place out for awhile but for one reason or another i just never got around to it.  I am so glad i did though... My first visit was with a friend visiting and to quote her experience of the meal: "The flavors are dancing in my mouth and they've invited all their friends"--Sandra B.

We shared everything which seemed like the way to go.  First off we had the grilled cauliflower with farro salad.  I was surprised because this dish was cold, but MY GOD.  The flavors...oh the flavors..it's so refreshing and tasty...(i had this my second visit too).

Next up we had the semolina gnocchi with root veggies and dried plum sauce--it also comes with a poached egg.  Really tasty with vibrant flavors.  The gnocchi was large and flat which was different from what i am used to, but loved it nonetheless.

Then we had pizza...it was good, we added an egg.  we had the one with the prosciutto...my second visit i had the pepperoni one with egg...i think i prefer that one better, but both were tasty.  crisp thin crust...yum.

Lastly we had dessert.  we had the zeppole...and the lavender cheesecake.  I preferred the zeppole.

Oh! and we brought our own bottle of wine from Dig. Good experience for which i will return!
author: Lu E.

description: Great food, little expensive but fun ambience. They encourage family style which is always a fun way to eat but it's a little hard because their portions are small. The food is definitely made with care and is very tasteful.
author: Rachel M.

description:
This review is for the cafe since we don't eat at the restaurant anymore. Despite the horrible restaurant service, we've continued going to the cafe because they sold Blue Bottle coffee.  

I'm completely flummoxed as to where Piccino finds their current wait staff.  The restaurant and cafe used to be so efficiently run with personable staff who didn't treat customers like crap.

We ordered a latte and the barista didn't pour enough milk to steam.  The cup she handed us was literally half full and she asks if we're ok with it. NOT! And we've already paid.  Pissed that she has to re-steam more milk, she slammed the steaming pitcher around so hard that milk splattered everywhere.

Seriously?! THIS is customer service?  The one great thing out of this visit - they no longer serve Blue Bottle!  Which means we can write off the cafe now too.
author: M G.

description: Decent food if you are a mouse, a rich mouse. Service was horrible as we were mostly ignored. Drink never arrived. Courses were very poorly timed.  With so many great restaurants in SF, skip this one!
author: Amy G.

description:
The ambiance is great with with the honey wood accents and large inviting tables with beautiful centerpieces. The open kitchen gives most something to look at when you're not admiring the other customers or the space, and the counter is where i'll sit next time to admire a beautiful kitchen with an apparently talented staff. 

If you're going here, go for the Funghi Pizza and the sausage secondi by David Golovin (amazing sausage and excellent lentils). Everything else we had was amazing, but not sure everyone appreciates Baccala (salt cod) fritters... The cauliflower and faro salad was good, and at room temperature it made for a perfect starter. However, everything on the menu was enticing, and i'll have to come back multiple times with different people to give myself an excuse to try everything... i guess one can't go wrong here, from what i've heard, but our server was a great resource and had excellent recommendations. 

Just go... it's delicious!
author: Vittorio L.

description: Amazing food but rather rude service. Ran in at 10:01 and was told a firm no after a waitress walked by and gave me the evil eye. I will definitely go back again, but at 9:59 rather than 10:01 to be absolutely punctual. Also I was running quite fast which means my clock could have been running slower than theirs. Whatever.
author: Erik B.

description: What a gem of a place this is! We stumbled across this place quite by accident when visiting a friend in Dogpatch & now we seek it out. Great pizzas & wine list, and the atmosphere is that of a small bustling cafe. Our favorite spot is sitting at the bar, where we can watch all of the activity in the open prep area. Cool spot. Will be getting my repeat business.
author: Jen S.

description: In no way am I a fine dining expert so I might be a little ignorant and harsh here, but I came out of this place feeling like I just paid 50 dollars for a light snack and a dribble of prosecco. Our server informed us that the restaurant is "family style", so we should order a few dishes and share them between us. We assumed that this meant the dishes would be a bit larger than normal but they were truly only enough for one person, and it would have worked better if we ordered individually. What probably wouldn't have been better was the bill, which was still astronomical despite all the sharing. The little bites of food that I did get were really delicious though, so if you have the money definitely go for it.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
Terrible service--read below for details. 

We went here recently for my girlfriend's birthday. First on the food: Only so so. The crispy polenta with burrata was quite good (though not big enough), and the beef tartar was decent as well. But the pizzas, which I thought would have been their strong suit, were underwhelming.  Unfortunately, while the food was passable, though at times disappointing, the service is what made the experience worse than it should have been. 

Specifically:

1. We had a reservation for 5:45 under the pretense that we needed to be out by 8 before the next reservation. Everyone in our 9 person party new this, though the hostess didn't miss an opportunity to tell every single person in our party as they walked through the door (You know you have to be done by 8, right?).  Even when the birthday girl arrived 20 minutes late after suffering through brutal traffic to get to the restaurant, the welcome message was the same. (Oh good, you're here. You know you have to be gone at 8, right?) 

2. As I mentioned it was my girlfriend's birthday and we brought two cakes as a surprise. When I asked the hostess if she could take the cakes to the back and bring them out after we finished our meal, she grimaced, as if there was something wrong with that, and agreed to our request with reluctance. Note to Piccino: you might talk to your hostess (this was the night of July 31) about her customer service skills!

On top of it all, they charged us a fee of $3 per person for the 9 person table just to cut the cake!!! Charging customers for something they themselves brought for a birthday celebration is not the way to win repeat business. Needless to say, Piccino, I'm not coming back!
author: Devon S.

description:
Went in for dinner late last night.  Lucky for us it wasn't too busy and we were quickly seated at the communal table.  Loved the huge wooden table.  We were at one end and a party of 3 at the other.  Perfect.  The space is warm and inviting with high ceilings and honey wood accents with huge windows all around.  The open kitchen is huge and super clean.  Next time it'd be fun to sit where you watch the kitchen while you eat. Ambiance 4 stars.  

We shared:  
Roasted cauliflower, farro and almond gremolata salad.  Great textures, but flat in flavor I thought.  3 stars
Baccala fritters, castelvetrano olive and Meyer lemon aioli.  Really liked the fritters of salted cod.  4 stars.
For the primi course, a toss up between the semolina gnocchi and the cotechino sausage dish.  Our server told us the sausage is made for the restaurant by David Golovin and is available for a limited time.  The decision made.  It was the clear winner of the night.  The sausage was packed with layers of flavor, moist and really delicious.  It was served over lentils and green chard.  We debated ordering another because it was so good.  Yep, we were being pigs. 5 stars 
Funghi pizza with roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic.  Another winner.  Perfectly crisp crust and flavorful toppings.  Would have liked more garlic and perhaps an egg on top. 4 stars  
Chocolate espresso panna cotta, chestnut, and fresh pomegranate completed the meal with French press coffee.  We liked the blend of chocolate flavor with the pomegranate.  4 stars

The service prompt without being overbearing, always a good point in my book, 4 stars.  I will go back to try other things on the menu.  I'm sure after being named a top pick restaurant for 2011 this place will get really busy in the near future.

Average: 4 stars
author: Kim A.

description: There was nothing terrible about this place but for me I was not special eneough to come back to.  If it was on the corner of my block I would come but not going to make a special trip for this place.
author: ORLA L.

description:
Pickled grapes?  Are you serious?  You know starting off a meal by making something already delicious kind of crazy you're in for a treat.  Piccino did not disappoint.

I wasn't a fan of their old space - cute, but sort of cramped.  However, they really raised the bar with the new location in Dog Patch.  It's chicness is only surpassed by the food (and wine options...more on that in a sec).  I was there with a group of 5, so had the opportunity to try a bunch of different items.  Definitely get the pickled vegetables if they have them (including the aforementioned pickled grapes), and the cauliflower appetizer is a must (I hate nuts and still loved this app).  I can personally attest for the margherita and fungi pizza's - note, the fungi didn't last on the table too long it was that good.  I can also note that the margherita does its pizza job well and tastes excellent cold the next morning.

Some others in my group had the halibut (went over well) and kale (again, I don't normally like kale, but this was fantastic).  We also had the roasted turnips - I didn't love that, but it might be a texture thing and not a flavor issue if you know what I mean.

Anyway, I finished it off with ice cream.  Not sure if they make it themselves, but it was bi-rite worthy.

The staff is super friendly, fun and quite hip - it's a bit hard to tell where the patrons end and the staff starts, that's how comfortable they make you feel.  Oh, about the wine - make sure to ask "Justin" if he's working for a wine pairing recommendation to your meal.  He recommended the Fort Ross Pinot Noir, and it was fan-tas-tic.

Bottom line - eat here now before it starts taking a month to get a reservation.
author: Lane K.

description: One of the best combination in the city of great pizzas+great wines+elegant and fun atmosphere+easy parking. Love this place.
author: Gilad D.

description: Small portions. While delicious, too oily. And surprised to find we got changed for sparkling water. Seemed a bit swindly when they offered water options without a menu present or highlighting any additional charge. And tried to talk me out of a wine taste. Seemed very cheap.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Fantastic, Lovely, Tasty, and Attentive Service....
Fantastic looking restaurant, with it's bar seating and regular tables.
The ingredients used were fresh and wine extremely tasty...  

This place is a must go!
author: Marie S.

description:
It was Piccino time finally! I have been wanting to try this place but it can get very busy and that combined with my lack of planning made for a long wait.

I think it was worth the wait. There was just two of us and we had the choice between the bar or an outside table. I like the bar seating that looks into the food prep area. I think that is so cool! I am not much of a cook so I am completely dazzled by people who make it look so easy and they really finesse the food. Plates were perfectly sauced, berries were methodically yet imperfectly arranged. It was like dinner and a show.

Our server was attentive but not pretentious. Everyone was very nice and the place is very beautiful and meticulous from the food to the restrooms and outdoor areas. OUr food was creative and flavorful without being confusing. (Pizza does not confuse me but we had a fish dish that involved pureed something or other that was delicious) 

Piccino doesn't try too hard. It just does what it does VERY well and I can appreciate that!
It is a bit of a splurge but I will definitely go back- just not as often as I would like to.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Eerily enough, hubs and I headed back to Piccino and split the same exact meal as the last time:  chickory cesar salad, margherita pizza and iced coffee.

However, this time we ate it from the counter top that looked directly into the kitchen.  What a great view!  The chefs danced this intricate dance of plating, juicing, grilling, slicing and dicing.

Bar seating was comfortable and the chefs were friendly and even interacted with with us.

Piccino is a great place for a light italian inspired lunch.
author: Rochelle D.

description:
This is an update to my previously stellar review. 

I was so disappointed by the service today, it was as if the owner and her dominions had a presumption that they were better than everyone else. No, I am not speaking of every staff member because there were some pretty great people helping but it did not smoother the arrogance in the air. 

We had a large party and did our best not to annoy anyone but the owner (I presume the owner because she acted like it) was just not having it. One of the pictures feel about eight inches in back someone and she freaked out, started making some of us feel uncomfortable by telling all of the staff what had happened. She was right next to us discussing the incident to her staff and was not shy about it. That was just not professional, talk crap about us in the back but why in front of us?

Very sorry we caused you such grief but don't make your guest who pay for your salary feel like crap. Very sorry you could not hang up your painting securely, I know some great ways to secure it. Very sorry we chose your establishment. And after all of that, she had to comment while we were leaving which was almost an hour after the incident about how precious her painting meant. Heck, I would have been happy if she would have just billed us instead of making us feel so bad. 

Oh, and the bread incident!!!! BREAD, they actually took the bread from one end of the table to the other to feed all of us. BREAD!!! Just charge us for the bread and give us a lot of it. ARE YOU INSANE? The server even asked us who ordered the bread. Just put the bread down and get us more, very simple.

Besides that, the food was great as always but I for one am very hesitant to spend my money there again. Why, because there are so many great restaurants in San Francisco that would not make twenty plus guest feel like crap over a painting and actually I think it was just a print of a painting. 

Yes, I am extremely mad because I love the food and generally I love the service but I would love it even more if the owner never served me ever again because she really does not understand the food service industry. 

Sorry but I was just saddened because today was a wonderful day ruined by an owner who can not control her emotions. Be professional and get a grip, don't hang things on walls if they mean that much to you or just put on the wall "you touch it, you buy it".
author: Ed N.

description: Great example of a restaurant getting good reviews and letting it go to their heads. In the end a bunch of snots. Never again.
author: Kathleen F.

description: Great food, fantastic service, beautiful setting. Five stars, period.
author: Chris J.

description: Pretty good, but my favorite place in Dog Patch is Cafe La Stazione.
author: William H.

description:
Piccino's incredible drip is what prevents me from hitting 'snooze' in the morning. $2.50 for the best cup of coffee I've had in a while and I feel like I'm stealing. 

No, I take that back. We the people deserve not just good coffee, but great coffee! Am I right folks? *crowd cheers* 

No more overly sweetened, pre-made garbage! Made-to-order is what we deserve, coffee drinkers of America! *crowd cheers*

We will no longer stand for overly sweetened treats! *crowd cheers*

Okay, time to step down from my soapbox. Give their treats a try.  The mushroom-filled whatchamacallit is a favorite.
author: Jaime L.

description:
I live two blocks away and decided to visit for the first time. We had the meatballs, pasta, pizzas and sauteed greens. Unfortunately, the sauteed greens were the best thing. 

The pizza had very little flavor and very little in the way of toppings which is why it had no flavor me thinks! I guess they need to cut corners given this large new location but unfortunately, I don't think the neighborhood will support that kind of product, especially at these prices. Pasta wasn't bad and the meatballs could have been frozen and warmed up. Kind of disappointing all around. 

Our waiter either had no experience waiting tables or quite an attitude. He never once asked how our meal was and....hold on to your hats....couldn't even say thank you when he presented the bill. 

Probably will not be going back here.
author: hercule p.

description:
Great pizzas and fab wine at this dog patch gem - tucked away in a quite street in the dog patch a few blocks from the 3'rd street corridor.

I have been going here since it has opened, and love this place. Food is great, and the service is superb. The only complian that i would have is that as this place has been getting popular - it has been difficult to get a reservations in the last minute..
author: Vivian L.

description:
Came here on a spur of the moment decision on a late Saturday night and were promptly seated.  We chose bar seating so we could see the chefs at work.

Piccino is located in the Dogpatch but away from the action on 3rd street.  Rather, it's tucked away in a hidden cul de sac adjacent to the Muni depot.  Still, the place was pretty happening when we arrived (guess word of mouth travels fast, especially when it's mostly good reviews).

Basic impression is that the menu is creative and the execution top notch.  There are items on the menu that are unique.  For starters we had the roasted cauliflower with  farro and almond gremolata, which while simple, was a tastefully prepared dish.  Temperature wise, we were surprised to find the dish was not hot at all, but this simply added to the freshness of the plate.

The baked gnocchi was a completely unexpected dish (although to be fair, our server gave us a heads up).  Not your typical bite-size gnocchi made from pasta, this "Roman-style" pasta was made from semolina and resembled a large patty of polenta.  This was artfully topped with root vegetable caponata, olive, dried plum and a poached egg on top.  Although entirely vegetarian, the caponata gave the dish a hearty bite and if one didn't realize it, you would think there was meat in it.  Our server actually said it could remind one of an African-inspired dish, which I felt was a perfect description based on my experience.

For pizza, we went with the funghi (roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic).  The crust was perfect - extremely thin but crunchy and not burnt like in other places.  It was not only covered generously covered with mushrooms, there was also a ground mushroom paste that to me resembled an olive tapennade spread - which was a bit too earthy and overpowering for me.  On the flip side, the stracchino, with its stretchy texture and mild taste, could have used a bit more bite.  

Overall, the execution of the dishes was great and I'm eager to come back and try different dishes to compare (e.g. the straightforward margherita pizza, the kale & butternut squash salad).  Also, they ran out of the zeppole (beignets), which looked amazing but we'll just have to wait until next time to try.

Decor is great, very inviting with warm lighting and homey yet roomy feel.


 poached egg, root vegetable caponata, olive and dried plum
author: F. P.

description: A great spot in the dog patch. we made reservations and were seated promptly. our server made some great recommendations for starters and shared plates - I actually cannot remember what we even got from the seasonal menu, but it was delicious. And we also got the bianca pizza which was also great. I also love a place that does wine carafes! We will be back.
author: Kerry F.

description:
I'll keep this review relatively quick and easy: since Piccino has been featured in the SF Chronicle as one of 2011's top 10, its popularity has skyrocketed. Expect a full house and a wait for dinner, I'd advise to make reservations for sure. 

As for the food, I would recommend going family style. Portions are small and best shared around the table.  Primi's weren't all that memorable and a little overpriced for what you get. Fettuccine was a little salty and very small for $18. The Polpettes (meatballs) were pretty tasty but not tasty enough to merit the $14 price tag for five. Semolina gnocchi was probably the best; a delightful blend of savory, tart, and sweet. 

Was hovering on the 3-3.5 star review as the service was slow too, but then the PIZZAS came. Seriously among the BEST pizza I've had in SF. Go for the margherita for sure- simple and really really well done. And the Funghi is outstanding as well. 

Bottom line recommendation? Go for an early lunch, order a pizza and a beer; skip the crowd and don't fret the primi's unless one sounds particularly appealing to you!
author: Chris D.

description:
I've now been to the coffee bar a half dozen times, so I think I have enough of a sample to give a good recommendation.  The coffee is perfectly frothed,  tastes amazing, never overcooked, and beautifully presented.   But the coffee isn't the reason I go out of my way for Piccino's.  You can get good Blue Bottle coffee in a bunch of places around the city.  They have, without question, the best morning sweets of anywhere I've been.  They have this apricot bread that is to die for, the best chocolate chip cookies I've had and these little cinnamon roll clusters that are unlike anything I've had before - like someone just took the center out of a cinnamon roll and stuck them together.   Just recently they added a pistachio torte that is something I've only seen in France and desperately needed over here in the states.  I could go on and on.

Also, to address the wait.  It is a bit slow sometimes, but it is worth waiting for!  Every time I've been waiting I've met some really cool people.  Last time I was in line I stood behind Michael Recchiuti, the guy that makes my favorite chocolate.  And before that it was a guy from twitter with some great stories. Enjoy life, eat sweets, and talk to strangers (but don't take sweets from the strangers).
author: Eric C.

description:
Last night when I was eating at Piccino for the third time this week, I realized that I'd better write a review. 

It's a couple of things that make Piccino my happy place to eat whether with friends or by myself at the counter - it's ridiculous to say, but even with the changing menu I've tried practically everything on the menu at least once. My favorite is probably the salsiccia pizza and the broccoli di ciccio (love the toasted almonds). James and the crew always do such a superb job of recommending good wine that I've really expanded my wine repertoire since I started dining here. 

Being a pizza fanatic, I can only think of two other places that have pizza that rival - possibly Zuni Cafe and Chez Panisse Cafe. Maybe Piccino doesn't have as much variety as Pizzetta 211, but that's fine by me, I'll come here for the great ambience, food, wine, and service any day.  

If you love to geek out and watch them cook, I recommend a seat at the counter. 

Last, but not least, the staff are cool as hell - thank you Holly, Julian, Justin and James for making the restaurant so welcoming!
author: S C.

description:
I can't believe it's taken us a while to get to Piccino - but we're sold! We stopped on a cloudy grey day that thankfully was not too cold in Potrero/ Dogpatch. At around 2:30pm, Just for You was about to close, so we swung by Piccino for a look.  A glance at the menu and the metal-topped tables outside (we had puppy with us) and we decided to stay.  Note that they have overhead heaters only on one side of the establishment.

The brunch menu is small, but it's creative and thoughtfully put together.  There was a glorious white breakfast pizza of pears, bleu cheese and greens, to be topped with an optional egg and bacon; I picked a very hot cazuela of erbette chard, potatoes, lamb sausage and 2 eggs.  Both were perfect brunch dishes, delicious and satisfying.  We finished with a dessert of piping hot zeppoli -- Italian doughnuts stuffed with ricotta and dusted with powdered sugar.  

Service was so friendly and warm - they should write the manual on making customers comfortable... one of our servers noticed a mushroom book that the husband had been carrying around, and we chatted briefly about seasonal foraging.

They're on Twitter and have advertised special events like a whole Pig Roast with Roli Roti, or oysters from Hog Island.  I've yet to make it to one of these parties, but am definitely much more incented to do so. Piccino, we will return soon!
author: Claudine C.

description:
Did not try the Pizza here.. why?  I'm a NY/NJ'er!  No need for me to waste my time here for pizza.  

Although the area could be not your usual downtown scene (couple blocks from downtown), inside has a nice wooden flare to it (reminding me of wine country decor).  Ordered the Cod, Meatballs, gnocci, salads and other veggies for dinner.

Loved the service and recommendations from the waitress (A ginger) and really had a decent experience with the food, service and atmosphere.
