Veggies/meatballs were a bit on the salty side however; no complaints.  Cod was exceptional and loved the broth type sauce it came in.

I would rate this place a solid 4 b/c of the entire experience (food, decor, service and atmosphere)... My ratings are based not soley on food but for the entire experience.

Would I come back for more?  Most def.  For pizza? meh.. I'll be back in the East Coast soon.
author: Jeong K.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets! Their funghi pizza is amazing (I'm a fan) ! 
Layers of goodness- 
Layer 1: A puree of criminis
Layer 2: Whole oyster mushrooms
Layer 3: Shaved garlic

Nothing beats it. Very affordable too. I hope they don't raise their price after they read this.

At this point, I can only write about their pizza, because that was the only thing we had that night. Margherita e Pizza con Funghi. They were really nice. As far as waiting list goes, it took us about 30 minutes to get our table for two. The couple next to us had a dish that was some kind of fat pasta, like a papardelle with pork sugo or something. It looked delish. I'd go for that the next time.
author: Rika P.

description:
for a tues night, piccino was pretty packed.  there is one (?) communal table in the middle where we sat at one end and another party of 3 sat at the other.  

at first the waiter kept checking up on us asking if we were ready to order.  then he left us for a good 15 minutes before coming back.

we started with the beef and pork meatballs and also a salad.  then we shared the sausage pizza, an english peas pizza, and also the bianco cheese pizza with egg.  when our pizzas came i realized we didnt order any with tomato sauce.  the pizzas were ok.  once they cooled though the crust became super tough.  the english peas tasted like they were from frozen ...

also this is TMI but i got the runs after i ate here.
author: claudia y.

description:
I was a big fun of Piccino in their old space! Simple menu for a great little space. 
So I went to the new space last night to try the new and improved Piccino, I felt let down.
The menu has new items which I was really excited to try. I have to say right off gnocchi is potato dumplings, not round polenta cakes! Get a grip chef. The fried green tomatoes were good, but the portion size was really small. I asked for salt, and was given sea salt, I don't mind that but I use sea salt for finishing in the kitchen, not for the table.
There were really no main dishes, which I found strange. If your going to invest all that time and money in a new space, upgrade the the menu and add some main courses.
author: WildBill C.

description:
Food: Small constantly changing menu. Small but simple creative dishes with fresh ingredients. And the pizzas are great if you love thin crust. Had a sparkling red wine, which was pretty cool too.

Ambiance: Beautiful, open and airy restaurant. If there was an Architectural Digest for restaurants, Piccino would be in it.

Service: Good.

Price: A few dollars high for the smaller portion, but well worth it.

Overall: If you live in Dogpatch or are in the area and feel like some pizza, Piccino is well worth the visit.
author: Binh D.

description: The saddest thing about moving from Potrero Hill to Marin was the fact that my frequent walks to dine at one of my favorite restaurants in the country. ended. When asked 'where to eat' in San Francisco, I can't say Piccino's fast enough. Few restaurants can hold their patrons so well: single? Sitting at the bar is a delight. On a date? It's lively but not boisterous; In a big party? Reserve the communal table....which is one of the few of such that I really like. Watching the kitchen staff care-fully & lovingly assemble beautiful meals while seated at the counter, is a treat. The food is off the charts fantastic and consistent. The portions are sane. The creativity and wholesomeness is inspiring.  If you are looking for a cheap meal in a restaurant with wifi, go somewhere else...you will not have good things to say about this place. On the other hand, if you seek an unpretentious meal, served by knowledgeable & engaged staff - without attitude, in an off the beaten path place...you will dig Piccino's!!
author: Gari S.

description: Um; yeah. This place kind of blew my mind. Loved the dishes, loved the vibe. It was super busy so I know that others are all aware that it's fabulous too. Say no more.
author: Kahlia S.

description:
The food was pretty good, but this place needs serious help with hostess.

Pro: early girl tomatoes, funghi, sommelier, beet soup, halibut 

Neutral: meatball. Chocolate cake

Con: tables are not well managed by the hostess. We called 30 min ahead and was told that we shouldn't worry about reservations. It was packed with people waiting for tables and multiple open tables  . The rest of the FOH staff were nice but frazzled because of the hostess.
author: Michael M.

description:
I love the new location.  It's a bit larger than previous (if I remember correctly) and it's comfortable/decorated nicely.  I'm a regular coffee drinker and they serve a mean drip here.  All of their coffee is made with blue bottle beans from oakland and made to order (even each cup of coffee).  

The coffee is superb, the location is great if you live in the neighborhood but the service is a little hit or miss.  

There is no real rhyme or reason to how they do things.  A couple times I would order my coffee and then I'd just kinda stand around waiting.  The person working the espresso machine would be doing his thing and the person who took my order would just kinda turn around and either get my coffee going or tend to someone else's drip.  I'm used to the "order and pay" flow of commerce and here it was "order and stand around... or pay... or wait until the coffee was done then pay... or pay immediately..."  Also, when it gets a little more busy, the queue to pick up drinks is a little haphazard and crowded.

Everyone was friendly though - I think the goal is to just be real casual here - so if that's the case then they've succeeded.  

For those who like the starbucks style drinks with every flavor of syrup under the sun, go somewhere else.  Coffee accompaniments are the basic here, cream, sugar, simple syrup.. That's about it (really a good cup of coffee stands on its own though).
author: Shaun T.

description: The food was incredibly fresh and tasty as always.  Service was unfortunately on the slow side and the server was majorly distracted.  She walked away from the table before we were done ordering at least three times.  The food is a 4.5 but the service was a 2.5
author: Sharon T.

description: Such a good surprise for me that in was two steps away from the Caltrain; perfect when you have 1h to kill at lunch time. The pizzas are great, specially when it's sunny and you can eat outside !
author: Florian P.

description:
Lovely food.. great ambiance.. place is super inviting, very friendly and knowledgeable staff. 

Must try there soups and Pizza... 

Great wine list as wel

Going there again for sure.
author: Avi S.

description: So delicious. I had the green salad, basic but super fresh!! And the parpadelle which was amazingly delicious and so full of flavor!. Even the iced tea was great. Can't wait to come back. Sit outside on a nice day. :)
author: Genevieve S.

description:
This was my first time at Piccino and I can only say that it is a beautiful restaurant.  The place has a welcoming feel, some soul to it.  And its menu kind of reminds me of that of Pizzaiolo in the east bay.  You know, local, sustainable blah blah blah.  But since whatever they do they do well it's OK.

I started with a salad of kale and butternut squash with pomegranate, toasted pecans, and a celery puree.  So, they really do mean what they say about good sourcing.  This was a great salad.  

Pork and beef meatballs with crushed tomatoes and parmesan was very good.  The meatballs were obviously homemade, had real texture, good taste, and a bit of char around the periphery.  Very nicely done.

Finally, a margherita pizza.  Very thin.  Very nice tomato sauce.  Very nice mozzarella.  Very nice. 

I wouldn't want to seem crass. Yet I feel compelled to mention that the price is right here.  A three course meal was about thirty four dollars.  

Everything added up to a nice evening.
author: David D.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here. The service was perfect and the food was awesome. 

I like that the wines are separated by characteristics and not region - it makes it easier on the customer. The pizzas were awesome and I'd say that the apps were just as amazing. Don't forget to make a reservation for dinner. It was pretty busy. 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Alli J.

description: Awesome, awesome, awesome. Had the squid appetizer which was delightful, the Funghi pizza (really good but not as amazing as the Salciccia), and the Salciccia pizza (to die for). Then for dessert had the warm stone fruit, cornbread crumble and creme fraiche ice cream which was also so good. Definitely coming back!!
author: Lizzie S.

description: Parking is pretty easy.  Waitstaff is great.  Food portions are a bit small but tasty.  Ambience and coffee is really good.  Highly recommended for brunch.  Our group of 4 had the sausage pizza, egg bake, smoked salmon scrambled eggs, and cioppino...all really good.  Make sure to the the shanty, beer and lemonade concoction, quite good as well.
author: Adrian B.

description: The zucchini and squash blossom pizza was amazing! Thin, crisp crust, zesty sauce, perfect amount of cheese (not very much) and the zucchini chips and squash blossom added that seasonal freshness I love. We also had the marinated cucumber salad with orange slices and  fried capers which was also very good, I will definatly be back!
author: Vanessa V.

description:
I have to say I really love what Piccino has done to their new space.  Although I'm wondering what they did with all of that awesome reclaimed wood they had stacked outside while they were under construction because everything seems to be brand new inside.  

That set aside, the food was overall OK.  The pricing, not so good. My cauliflower pizza, sans queso (my choice), was $16.  Flour, water, sauce, cauliflower, and a few capers= $16. I just can't make sense of it.  How can people think they can charge so much for such a small food costing item?!  The pizza crust has always been a little too dry and floury.  Slap some olive oil on the crust when it comes out!  Sauce needs some work, too.  I do appreciate the care they take in their produce and did enjoy my well-seasoned salad.

They're still waiting on their wine and beer license so plan to bring a bottle or you'll find yourself next door at their wine shop buying one.
author: Liz B.

description: Sorry to say that after two bad experiences I won't be going back to Piccino. The food is not the problem. It was not great, but it was ok. It's the clueless staff and incompetent, indifferent service that I cannot take. I hate it when the management and staff of an establishment has an attitude that conveys the message that the customer is fortunate to even be there. I won't support that and that's why I will never go to Piccino again. I would recommend people take their business elsewhere if they wish to be treated as if they are appreciated and respected. Maybe this establishment thinks because it got a glowing writeup in Travel + Leisure that they don't need to be gracious or charming with customers? Big mistake. Sooner or later word of mouth will catch up with this pretentious place.
author: john m.

description:
If I were to open a restaurant, I would model it with the Piccino interior. The ambiance is great and the design is modern, classy and quite charming. Hardwood floors, benches, candles, mm, I like! 

The wine selection was delicious, argh, totally forgot which one we picked, but it was around $45 for a bottle. (red) So delicious that we bought two! 

The food however, is just okay. 

The best thing I had (which was really tasty actually) was the gnocchi. The flavors were robust and texture was superb.

What wasn't as good was the pizza (flavors were slightly bland) and the side order of the vegetables was very underwhelming (wasn't even close to my mom's!)

I'd like to try the cafe though, Blue Bottle is a must! 

Overall, a nice place for dinner with friends, but the company and the atmosphere would probably trump the food :)
author: G K.

description:
I think this place might be good for a casual light lunch and a beer or glass of wine.  It has lots of outdoor seating and a nice open air vibe inside the cafe.  

We came for dinner with friends, and I think we expected a bit more complexity and flavor.  We shared two starters - the caprese and the pickled veggies.  Both were presented very nicely, almost too delicately for a chill cafe, but the portions were too small to share.  They were more appropriate for a single person who planned to order an entree, but were not particularly cheap for the size.  The pizzas were okay.  Again, great if you just want a light meal of bread and toppings, but not quite rivaling the chewy crusts and mouthwatering flavors of some other pizza specialists.

A really nice vibe though and very accommodating, chill staff.  We all noted that our wait staff spoke in such a calm, gentle manner that we felt we were about to start a yoga class or massage!
author: Pearl L.

description:
Their pizza is scrumptious, and I particularly love the Funghi. And we all know the coffee is killer. On top of that, I found the customer service to be great, and also it's a nice place to meet a friend. 

Just an fyi, be patient if you place a large order for pick-up; they're a small (but awesome) operation.
author: Sonya Y.

description: Came here for brunch. The funghi pizza was awesome!
author: Motoki B.

description:
Review is for the coffee. Specifically the cold brew. AWESOME. Best cold brew I've had in the Bay Area. I think it's even better than the cold brew I've had in NYC. It has a ton of caffeine though so be warned. :)

Would definitely recommend.
author: Mz S.

description: This place was just OK IMHO... first the good: we have a great and friendly server . Parking was easy.  The dining room is big and it was a nice scene.  That said we were scolded for being late for our 5:45 reservation (maybe 5 or 10 minutes if that)  and were put in probably the worst seats in the house..counter seating facing a clothing store next to the bathrooms...it was fine...but..  the place was never full while we were there and I don't understand why we could not have a table or at least a counter seat not in Siberia. The place was not even busy...food was good.  My complaints are as follows:  1. we were half way through the salad course when the pasta course arrived and they just put it down... I hate that.. bad  restaurant service...It sat there getting cold while we finished the salad.. 2.  Nobody offered to bring new plates for our courses so we had to put pasta on the salad plate and then following courses on same plate.  Maybe that is water saving thing but it bugs me when paying $100 plus for a few courses sitting next to the loo...I thought the pizza was so so..not as much to my liking as Delfina or Flour+Water but maybe it is just a different style.  Other courses were great though.  If I lived in the neighborhood I would come back but not worth a trip otherwise.
author: David B.

description: An outstanding place with great food and the possibility to eat outside ! I loved going there for brunch on a beautiful sunny Sunday. Small portions but for an ok price, and the food is really delicate with a lot of attention to details - plus if you really want to get THAT stuffed, cross the street and check in at just for you. You should try the beignets they're absolutely great!
author: Laure D.

description: Funghi pizza, always the best - a go-to for me.  It's not the cheapest, and it's not the largest, but the quality is worth it.
author: Evelyn M.

description:
What a cool place!  
I walked over while waiting for the 22nd St Caltrain and was very impressed.  It was like a barn where they just rolled the door open and there was a barista making some very cool drinks.
author: George F.

description:
We decided to come here because we wanted to avoid the hectic nature of the mission. I have to say that I was not disappointed at all. It was a Friday night and it was busy, at least with people waiting. Apparently there was a party of 30 people coming in!!!! It kind of sucked, but it seemed like in the time we were waiting, we could have taken 3 of those seats, eaten and left. But I can understand why they wouldn't want to take that chance...

Anyways about the service and food...

Every staff member was exceptionally polite and the wine-tender was really nice and helpful and gave a great suggestion. So if you are unsure about what to get, they have good taste there. 

I ordered the pickled grapes (or the veggies, at least I think that's what its called on the menu). They were awesome! I was afraid they would be too sour, but they were just the right blend of pickled and grape. 

I got the funghi pizza, and this was the most amazing pizza I have EVER had! I nearly forgot to chew at times. It was creamy, crispy, and the had the perfect amount of mushroom texture. I really think this place is better than Delfina.
author: Brandon R.

description: The food here is precious, but equally importantly, the service here is second to none.  I love this place, and will drive all the way across town for a meal here.
author: Stephen B.

description: Great wine selection and helpful server. We had a couple of starters that we good. The pizzas sounded delicious, but they were both too greasy/oily. The crusts were great, but they were too fatty to enjoy.
author: Chris T.

description:
Love the food, don't love the wait. Even with a reservation we still waited about 10 minutes. And without a reservation...goodluck. We showed up here once at around 6 and were quoted a 45 min wait, no thank you! Alas, their pizza is so good and they have a decent beer/wine menu. I might just have to start getting the food to go. 

On an unrelated note- we did have an awkward experience last time we were here. This lady decided to breast feed (no blanket or covering at all, just big boob in your face) right in the middle of the restaurant. I totally understand that the baby was hungry but there were plenty of other places that were less visible to get the job done. everyone felt awkward there was a lot of staring and you could cut the tension with a knife. I feel like someone on the wait staff could have said something, or offered her a more private place.
author: Christina S.

description:
This review was written by my 8-year old son: "I'm going to give this place a sideways thumb. Thumbs down because it took so long but thumbs up because it was so DELICIOUS!"

Indeed, service was slow but the manager apologized because they had to redo one of our pizzas. The pizza was really good, and they have interesting choices including an egg topping. Open kitchen, upscale, very nice decor. Excellent fresh squeezed lemonade and they have very good coffee.
author: Lee S.

description:
Just went here for a celebratory dinner and was extremely impressed with the food.  Well balanced and complex flavors that were neither subtle nor obvious.  A great dinning experience.  

We shared a farmer's cheese antipasto (amazing), falafel balls (amazing), salmon (amazing), and a mushroom pizza (very good).  I literally forgot what I was talking about when I had took my first bite of one dish. My friend had to remind me of my story. 

I really appreciated the kitchen's attention to detail.  Portions were appropriate and so well balanced that while scraping the plate there was still the perfect amount of each ingredient.  A great example of a creative and balanced dish was the salmon.  Perfectly cooked fish with darkly crusted skin and tons of flavor over nectarines, squash and avacado.  In breaking down the components it is all there (fat, salt, acid) but it was much more than its parts.

Well done!
author: B K.

description:
Love the ambiance, great service and delicious food.Easy parking. 
 We went on a weekend for their brunch.No  lunch on weekends.  
Ordered funghi pizza- thin crust and very flavorful. 
Curried farro and roasted cauliflower- YUM!
Quiche dish -I do not remember the name. 

Absolutely love everything about this place. I will definitely go back and try everything on their menu.
author: Chai r.

description: Funghi pizza all the way!  Ask for the fried egg on top. Delish!
author: Kelly M.

description: Beautiful interior, attentive service, delicious thin-crust pizzas. The funghi pizza was my favorite -- though worth noting that despite its lack of meat it was surprisingly greasy. The sausage pizza and the prosciutto pizza actually felt healthier.
author: Gary D.

description:
Really enjoyed a recent dinner at Piccino.  The rare occasion where I had no real criticism of the food, the restaurant or the service.   This is a really well-run establishment.  The open kitchen offers a great view to the service.  The chefs are impresssive - very methodical, very orchestrated, very calm, very precise.

Everything was very good.  I had grilled duck in a blueberry reduction, a margherita pizza, the fennel/strawberry salad, roasted carrots and a dessert.  I will definitely be coming back again soon.  

My only complaint would have been to have a classic Champagne on the menu.  They have processo and a French sparkling wine that needs more sparkle...  The beer from Iceland was off the charts - more bubbles that a glass of champagne. Be sure to try it with your pizza!
author: Ron K.

description: Wonderful!!  My third time here today. Twice for lunch and then brunch today. Every dish is spectacular. For brunch loved the pork sausage and the zeppole for desert. Hibiscus mimosa rounding it out well. Will be back!!
author: Eliette K.

description: Delicious lattes, beautiful espresso and all their pastries are from the restaurant kitchen. Plus the friendliest, most talented baristas. Go!
author: Ali L.

description:
This place used to be the best kept secret in SF.  We used to be able to come here after work on any day of the week and be able to get a seat right away.  Well....I guess they decided to expand and now the secret's out.  Way to go owners....how dare you be successful!

Anyway, awesome pizzas and soups, great staff and I love sitting at the counter watching the head chef work the pass.   The place is just as good as when it was a little hole in the wall.  Although now be sure to get reservations or you'll be waiting about 30 - 45 mins for a seat (and this is on a weekday!)  (*sigh*....i never thought I would say this about piccino!)
author: Tony C.

description: My favorite place to grab a bite.  Flavors and preparations of pizzas and salads never dissapoint.  Love the historic building, the staff - Piccino is a treasure in Dogpatch.
author: BK S.

description: I so want to like this place and continue going here, but the staff is almost universally snotty. Hire nicer people, please!
author: Andrea W.

description:
delicious! shared the soup, a salad and a margarita pizza. soup was so good! pizza was just how i like it, Italian style, thin crust, and simple but super fresh tomato sauce and cheese.

this place also has THE best lemonade in San Francisco. hands down.

I thought the service and the hostess were great. our server was funny and the table next to us loved him too. the people that have left poor reviews about this place are clearly high maintenance and probably miserable everywhere they go.
author: danielle m.

description: Love going here for dinner when everything else seems too complicated.  We have a 6 month-old baby, and it's so easy to sit at the counter, watch the action in the kitchen with the little one in a clip-in high chair.  The food is consistently inventive, fresh, seasonal and great tasting.  Nice creative dishes that aren't pretentious.  Fun talking with Todd and Casey in the kitchen while they work.  Nice interesting wine list as well.
author: Alec L.

description:
Food here is very similar to Zero Zero, however, the prices, portions and taste aren't as favorably comparable.  Pastas and pizzas are fairly unique, appetizers and desserts didn't stand out as hoped.  Wine bar was nice...they had some local wines that weren't too pricey and worth multiple ganders.  

Piccino has the ambiance down (aesthetically modern w/ a plentiful supply of sunflowers), but personally, I don't go to a restaurant to get wooed by the interior set-up.  The food here has the right ideas, but it just doesn't stand out in comparison to its peers.  And the prices you pay for the amount/quality of food you get doesn't quite make you tingle inside.  Not saying this place isn't worth a try, but you probably won't be coming back often.
author: Jeff S.

description:
The food is great, fun atmosphere and cool vibe. I'm thrilled they are in my neighborhood.

I've been four times. Today's service was horrific. We literally did not have  a server. A server never came to our table. I had to hunt down the manager/host to order, get water and get our check. Bizarre. It was not acknowledged in any way.
author: Vicki L.

description:
This bizarely over rated little Italian place just about passes as a solid local restaurant - but the recent hype in the SF press is hard to understand. 

Maybe it's professional reviewers patting themselves on the back for 'discovering' some of the cool things happening in Dogpatch? Or is the state of pizza in the city so bad - that a reasonable thin crust deserves so much applause? Whichever, Piccino does do a good pizza and one or two of the pasta dishes are also passable. Service is spotty at best, and the overall 'feel' is of a restaurant that also believes it's a little better than it actually is. 

Probably a 3.5 rating, but Piccino loses a .5 for the awful service at the ajoining coffee place next door - Baristas who seem to resent being there let alone getting your coffee order quickly or being friendly to anyone.
author: Sam E.

description: Love this place--been here three times for brunch....only street parking which can be dicey. We always have one of the apps and a pastry basket which are always pleasant surprises. Drinks are always on the artisanal side with ingredients not necessarily familiar to us, but never disappointing.  This time we tried the Pork Hash and Chicken salad and have tried the baked eggs, none of which disappointed. Service is always spot on and helpful when this picky eater wants to parse the menu for things she thinks she won't like! Portions are typically on the small side, thus the apps and pastry basket to supplement. A bit pricey for brunch as well is another consideration.
author: Jane V.

description:
I was introduced to this place the other day when my bosses took me out to a surprise birthday lunch. It was a beautiful day and everything we ate hit the spot! Love the ambiance of the area during the day, and I'm also a huge fan of open kitchen designs

We started off with some antipasti to nibble on- the pickled vegetables were gorgeous and the flavors danced in my mouth. I also ate the best marinated olives I've ever had!

Then we had the pork/beef polpette to share, which was the juiciest most succulent meatballs I've ever had. I'd definitely go back for these, the sauce was the perfect sweet/acid combination. 

After that we shared three pizzas between the 4 of us. Loved the thin crust. They did the classic pepperoni really well. The salsiccia (house made sausage, mozzarella and red onion) was creamy and rich, but after those amazing meatballs I had earlier I wish the sausage flavor was a bit more developed; I like my herbs.

I guess the last pizza, the napoletana, was a pretty big disappointment. I love olives, and I love anchovies, but if it wasn't for the sweet sauce on there (this pizza has no cheese) then the anchovies would have taken over the whole dish; it was SO FRIGGIN SALTY!! Definitely the saltiest anchovies I have ever had and it really was kind of unpleasant to finish, it just wasn't balanced and needed some acidic flavor/lemon or something in my opinion - would not recommend it at all.

There's also a tasty beer selection, they were bottled but delightful. I had the alagash white and it went really well with everything I ate.

I'd like to try this spot for dinner sometime!
author: Rachel W.

description:
The first thing I noticed about Piccino is the openness.  The space and decor give the feeling of spaciousness without sparseness, and the effect is open and welcoming.  It's relaxing even when the place is buzzing.

The service was kind of hectic, and the reason this is a 4 star review and not 5 stars.  There was no host station, so you just had to pick out the woman with a clipboard and try to get her attention.  It took a few minutes for her to seat us, but once she did, the wait staff was lovely and attentive.  Only additional complaint there was that it took a really long time to get our pizza.  Of note, the sommelier was great.  I am super excited about food, and people who are excited about food, and our sommelier's enthusiasm about wine was really lovely.

The food was delicious.  Among the standouts were the butter bean and broccoli rabe soup - amazingly savory, with all the beautiful components singing together in perfect harmony.   We had the pizza bianca, which was delightfully garlicky, and the cavolfiore - cauliflower, capers, and the most amazingly titillating pickled chiles.  I love a charred crust myself, but for those who don't, you'll love Piccino's crust.

The dessert was a throwaway, but I couldn't really hold it against them given how happily stuffed I was from everything else.
author: Linda L.

description: Had a delicious margherita pizza for lunch on Saturday afternoon.  The new location is bright and inviting. I'd love to come back for brunch and get some eggs on my pizza.
author: Dan B.

description:
Piccino has become my go-to for an outdoor, afternoon spot glass of weekend wine. 
Decent wines by the glass; you can always score parking and a table after lunch and before dinner. 

i do also like them for dinner  - especially for an early bird meal at the counter. Their food is consisent and made with quality ingredients.  My fave is the white pizza. I've had better Italian but if I am in the hood it's not a bad option.

However, all in all I am partial to their weekend festivities as part of  a Dogpatch "day trip".
author: Carson R.

description: Excellent pizza, salads, fried brussels sprouts. The wine list is so so and a little on the expensive side. The restaurant is noisy and it is hard to hear people on the other side of the table.
author: Scott A.

description:
Absolutely in love with this place.  It won me over before I even ate - the inside is beautiful and open, and I thought it was so cute how they brought out their lemonade (which was SO FRESH and so delish, btw) in mason jars.  I am one of those people who feels like the container the drink is in actually makes it taste better.  Weird.  

Anyways, we got the panzanella, a canellini and kale soup, and the hugely popular funghi pizza.  They were all SO GOOD.  The funghi was the best mushroom pizza I have ever had, and everything just tasted so amazingly fresh. 

Our waitress was so cute and friendly, as well.  Cannot WAIT to come back here.
author: Mandy B.

description:
So delicious!!!

The seared trout was amazing, as was the baked gnocchi.  The trout almost had a smoky flavor, though that might just be me remembering my meal this past weekend! =)  The gnocchi is not your typical pasta, but instead looks more like a pancake.  It's really delicious.

And BYOB.  So worth it!
author: Dorothy K.

description:
First when i came dinner there, there was no hostess and i've waited for a couple of minutes and i have to reach to the bartender because he's right at the bar next to the entrance door. And while i was waiting for my seat, the hostess was around and she was busy with so many people came in with no reservation. While she was surrounded by the crowd of guests that don't have enough seats they have to stand surrounding the bar area. And then I saw the hostess was missing these couple that sneaked in just to get any seat they want, but finally managed to let them know  that they'd have to wait as other guests did. Waiting area could be a lil' bit too small if there are too many people because you know how cold sf sometimes can be outside.
Ambiance is nice, clean & simple. The guests are pretty classy mix. Server she's very helpful. As usual you could ask the server if you've food allergy/vegan/vegetarian.
Food is good here: i had my farinata soup (it's really good!), broccoli pizza (spicy but lovely!), and i also tried the small polenta dish which is yummy!
my partner had the trout and his comment was: i was still hungry even though i just ate the fish, meaning...piccino has lil' pichy pichy tiny portion for such a poachy pouchy pricey food. 
Well, if you're ready for that, come to piccino. I don't mind I just try something new this week and my tummy said she's happy.
author: Ms C.

description:
Rating 3.5 Stars

Gorgeous physical space, great appetizers, smalls plates, wine list and deserts.  The pizza I would give a B/B- (on the generous side).  It's decent pizza just not great.  I think there are other reasons to get excited about this place and pizza is not at the top of the list.  But having said that I will be back and will be happy to bring a group of friends.  (I've recently spent some time in NY and I think the pizza I had and loved there has made me gravitate to particular style of crust flavor profile).  If I could summarize what the dough here is missing, I'd say it's flavor (*dodges thrown tomato*).  The toppings were great on Salciccia, but the dough lacked the finish I was expecting.  The other pizza we had was the Napoletana.  This one exemplifies the lack of balance.  The toppings were far too salty (which says a lot considering I love anchovies, olives and capers (all together).  In addition, the pizza had too much sauce.  I'm a big fan of cheese-less pizzas, but this one was a dud.  In short, I will be back and hope to wowed.
author: Darin E.

description: Came here with friends. Had a gameplan going in of what to have and then tweaked it a bit.  Buratta was excellent, Braised poork very well done but the highlight was the pizza. Specifically the mushroom pizza.  I will drive to Dogpatch for this pizza.  Great neighborhood vibe and I was pleased it was packed on  Thursday. On my short list do go again.
author: C K.

description: A group of 6 of us came here for dinner and tried a few antipastis and sides, a couple primis, 4 pizzas, and a couple desserts.  We loved the pizza!   All the other dishes were overseasoned.  Probably our new favorite place for pizza and would come back for their pizza anytime and skip the other dishes.
author: Irene C.

description:
Tiny coffee shop that is part of the wonderful neighborhood restaurant gem of the same name. The coffee bar serves up Blue Bottle coffee and absolutely delicious pastries and morning breakfast items. I've had muffins that are to die for and recently a focaccia that had apples and cinnamon baked into with a thin glaze over the top that could have been honey, but so far my favorite item by far is the "parmesan-ricotta egg thingys". Yep, that what they called it. It seems as if it were baked in a muffin pan and it's suuuuuuper flavorful, light and fluffy with herbs de provence and olive oil. YUM!!! 

I'm reserving my 5th star for when this location starts serving the New Orleans Iced Coffee and Macau Iced Coffee like some of the other Blue Bottle locations.
author: Jen D.

description:
Mehhh.

First, the good:

1. The space! Looks like the majority of reviewers have commented on the setting, which is modern and airy yet still warm. My friends and I were seated at the bar, and a perk there is that the stools at the bar have backs AND they swivel. Huge plus, in fact.

2. Presentation. The food looks good when it comes out, which -- for me -- suggests it's a passable option for a casual date.

3. Price (for the pizzas). The pizzas are fairly-sized for their $10 to $18 range.

The bad, unfortunately:

1. The food! This was the worst of it, and it was extra disappointing because of the first two plusses listed above. We ordered the corn and prosciutto pizza which sounded delicious based on its description, but it turned out to have hardly any corn... or prosciutto... or flavor other than the incredibly spicy peppers. Our margherita pizza was fine, nothing special. And our tagliatelle pasta was tasty but tiny, which brings me to...

2. Price (for the pasta). A single pasta dish must have contained 4 oz of pasta yet cost the full $14. Absolutely not worth it.

3. No complimentary bread. What kind of Italian restaurant doesn't give complimentary bread??

Three stars because we received above-average service, and I was in a good mood. But otherwise, not up to the hype.
author: Albert L.

description:
Hands down, one of my favorite restaurants in the city, regardless of price point, style of food, location, etc.

The food is bright and clean with well delineated and simple, but deceptively complex layers of flavor.  I'm always into a place whose menu changes with the seasons, but this is the first time that I've eaten at one of those places that really hits it out of the park with highlighting seasonal ingredients.  

I couldn't stop saying "effin delicious!" with every bite of the pizza with mozzarella, peas and pea tendrils.  The pizza looked healthy, but didn't taste "healthy" and was clearly not lacking in the flavor department.  The strawberry, fennel and arugula salad was delicious and the sausage pizza was also wonderfully delicious.

I also love their wine program here as you can clearly see that it is driven by making sure that every wine on the list goes with all the food on the menu.  Also a rarity is the old school, generous pours of wine.  I'm not talking about a 3 oz. glass filled to the rim, but a good quality wine glass filled with 5 oz. of goodness and enough room to swirl, sniff and sip.  They also gave us a couple of sample pours without us even asking.  One sample was simply because we couldn't decide between a couple of the roses and the other was because I ordered one of the more esoteric wines on the menu and they wanted to make sure I wouldn't be put off by the Band-Aid, ointment smell and flavor of the wine (which btw, was an awesome wine - Piedirosso)

Lastly, the service and staff here are fantastic.  Very welcoming, friendly, sincere, conversant, attentive, all of it!
author: Grape C.

description: If sit in the high chairs near kitchen it is entertaining.   Like watching the cooking channel.
author: JoeJet J.

description: Love this place and so do all the peeps I've brought here. Ample parking awesome desserts beautiful fresh modern interiors
author: Shum S.

description: Cute, tiny, busy. Located next to a park where you can sip your cup o' deliciousness or eat a yummy treat.  I tried the yogurt and granola, althoughtexpensive, it tastes great!  And I also tried a ginger scone, sooo good! Latte was nutty and delicious!  A must-visit if you're around the dog patch!
author: Valerie L.

description: I went there for brunch so only tried the heirloom polenta and the beets, both dishes were very delicious.  We sat at the chef's table, and it was super fun to see all the prep work, and see all that all the ingredients used were so incredibly fresh.  Would love to go back for dinner sometime.
author: Mandy C.

description: I love this restaurant. It's proximity to Caltrain has brought me there a few times. The first a friend and I shared delicious, fresh butternut squash soup, a light salad and a margherita pizza. Everything was impeccably simple and exquisite. The second trip had me sharing two fabulous and unique pasta dishes. Good wine list, great service and a rotating menu will keep me coming back here.
author: Emma S.

description: Piccino is one of our favorite go-to restaurants in SF. They consistently offer great food at reasonable prices. Our hands-down two favorite dishes are the "burrata, heirloom polenta, watercress, asparagus, sea salt" (to-die-for!), and their bianca pizza. We keep it simple, and let their exceptional ingredients speak for themselves. I'd highly recommend Piccino to anyone looking for a nice, relaxing dinner without the pretentious nature of many of the cities "best" restaurants.
author: Travis B.

description:
I have really loved this place for years, but I will not go back. The last two times, it has almost been a joke.  Yes, there are some interesting flavors going on. And our waitperson could not have been nicer... BUT --   $12 for 4 - counted them 4 --  little gems leaves and five cut-in-half grapes and some cuke?  And then I had the $13 "Braised Pork and tomato jam" sandwich - just disgusting. It was strips of not too rendered pork belly fat with NO tender sections of the meat - NONE!  We opened up the sandwich after my dining partner and I took a bite finding the three strips of soggy fat and lost my appetite -  can you say value in dogpatch? CHECK PLEASE!!  

Ahhhh ...a general note to you SF chefs out there - can we please LOSE all the pork belly, lamb cheeks, beef cheeks - the trend should be OVER. I know it is VERY VERY  cost effective to use these cuts as they have traditionally gone into all kinds of dog foods, but not at the prices you fine restaurants are charging. And you know what? --  they do NOT taste that damn good either.  Jeez.
author: Richard H.

description:
3.5 stars actually. Recently renovated, open and casual environment to catch up with friends over good wine and pretty good food. After having a glass of wine each and waiting for a while, we chose to eat at the high planked waiting area and the friendly staff happily accommodated us. We ordered the fried green tomatoes for the appetizer. The peeled, breaded, small whole green tomatoes were a good start to the dinner. We then shared the (vegetarian) Cavolfiore pizza amongst the two of us and loved it! The pickled mini whole red-chillies added the perfect amount of sweet-spice to every bite.

I wouldn't mind eating here again!
author: Chinmayi B.

description:
Great food, great service!  The asparagus salad was devine, and our pizza with buffalo mozzarella and English peas was ridiculously good!  It was a little inconvenient that they didn't have their liquor license yet and the wine bar attached to them closed before the restaurant did.  They lost some $$ there, because we would have definitely bought more wine, but I'm sure that will be rectified shortly.

All in all, its a charming location, nice decor, easy parking and great food and service.  We will be back!

***Note to parents.....please take the "not good for kids" rating seriously.  We were told by our friend that made the reservation that it was ok to bring our 17 month old.  Not so.  Not only does the ambience not support a toddler, they don't even have ONE HIGHCHAIR.  We had to hold our squirmy girl the whole dinner, which took away some fun for us.  Totally our own fault, but definitely worth a babysitter for this place!
author: Sara J.

description: Oh my dear lord.  Seriously?  This is amazing! Such a pretty space (moved around the corner from the little shop it once was).  Open, bright, sunny, happy - bringing you thin crusty yummy pizza with your choice of beverage.  It will bring me back to Dogpatch just to eat there again.  Perhaps tomorrow.
author: David S.

description:
Every modern woman of class needs to start a posse of the following:

A knowing hairstylist.
A firm personal trainer.
An impeccable decorator.
~and~
A consistent barista.

while I may still be on the lookout for the first item, the spot for consistent barista goes to... ready for it....Piccino!

Without fail, I go to Piccino after my 3x a week work out with my trainer (who is very firm by the way- both physically and mentally), and without fail, Barista Noah delivers me friendly banters and a cup of drip, delicious and consistent in taste. Nowadays I don't even need to add sugar to my cup, it's that good.

Somethings are better unchanged, Piccino is one of them. Oh... try the savory scone with bacon bits - to die for!
author: Jackie G.

description:
The new Piccino is a great place with a very friendly and positive vibe. I think the pizza has even improved. The starters are delicious. They are still awaiting their alcohol license, but you can buy wine for your meal right there at DIG with no corkage fee.

The convergence of the three businesses in the newly renovated building consisting of Piccino, the fine clothing store MAC, and the new wine store DIG is a wonderful combination.

This is a great new addition to the Dogpatch neighborhood.
author: B. B.

description: SFO, no need to go to Italy...the BEST pizza is right here!!
author: A P.

description:
I've been dying to try this place out for months. Finally found the time to go last weekend. The wait wasn't bad at all, roughly ten minutes to be seated. The service was a little slow, but the servers were very respectful. 

First we ordered the mixed chicories, white anchovy (on the side, cause thats just nasty), garlic crouton and creamy pecorino vinaigrette salad to share. It was different than any salad I've ever had: zesty, bright, light, very enjoyable. Then for the meal, we ordered the funghi: roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic pizza with two eggs on top which is what we had come, just to try. It was so delicious. The consistency and the textures were the perfect combination of flavors. 

I remove half star for slow service and another half star for the egg white not being cooked to perfection (which is actually not easy to do).

I will definitely be returning.
author: Kerry Z.

description:
Our server was absolute perfection. Attentive, kind, but not to the point of being fake in doing so. Anticipated what we wanted. Didn't try to inveigle us into anything. Answered q's with ideal level of detail necessary.

The food was... Uh, wow. The lasagna was earthy and oh-so-unique. I'd never had nettles previously. That's gotta happen again.

Since gone back to have more of the upside-down blood orange pound cake. We each ordered one seeing as we're both the edacious type- Still planning on delving into the margherita pizza with two eggs at some point soon seeing as the vast majority of other yelpers are bat-shit-crazy-in-love with it.
author: Carrie S.

description: My fiance and I went to Wine Works for a little city wine tasting this afternoon.  After some afternoon drinking we had a craving for some good pizza, so we walked 2 blocks down to Piccino around 2:00pm.  We were seated right away and our server was there and very friendly immediately.   We decided on a carafe of chianti and I got the margarita pizza while he got the  sausage and onion (can't  remember the name).  our wine came right out and our pizza showed up in a very timely manner.  its not often you find a thin crust gourmet pizza that you can actually pick up and eat without it wilting in your hands.  we were both very happy with our choices and enjoyed the simple and clean decor.  we will definitely. be back next time we go wine tasting over there, the pasta dishes and salads that the neighboring. tables ordered looked and smelled amazing as well.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Great neighborhood gem in the dogpatch.  Ordered the pizza and it was delicious.  

Want to try pancetta and Meyer lemon pizza.
author: around town e.

description: Food was good. Staff was decent. People in the restaurant? It was like a parallel universe! Felt like i had been transported to a douchey/dorky place in LA. Based on the clientele, I feel like I will never go back. Sadly, the food was pretty good and the wine list had good wine at good prices. If you venture out there and then suddenly ask - where the f*$k am I?...Don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Brianna M.

description: I had dinner with my son here tonight 4/25/14. Food is excellent. Started with soup and meatballs then came pappardelle with rabbit and sausage pizza. Staff is professional and polite.
author: Kathy D.

description: This week I was meeting up with some mom friends along with our still small enough to sleep through lunch babies and decided to go to Piccino. Not only was our meal delicious but the staff was super attentive and gave us some extra space for the kidlets. A member of the team also brought over a small container of hot water so we could warm up a bottle. I appreciated the attention to detail and willingness to make sure we enjoyed our time at Piccino. We'll definitely be back!
author: ipvcake i.

description: I need to visit the Dogpatch neighborhood more.  A friend suggested it and I love the area.  Food-wise, I give Piccini VERY high marks.  Every dish we had was delicious.  So why only 2 stars?  The service.  We were rushed thru each course so quickly, plates were being removed from the table before we were done (no one bothered to ask "May I clear this away for you?"), staff were hovering like hawks "Are you done here?" like it was a race to see which table could finish first.  Incredibly rude and a disservice to the chefs.  We didn't have time to savor the moment for fear of our forks being yanked away.  If it were based on the food only, I would go back in a second.  But thanks to the rushed service, you won't be seeing my return anytime soon.
author: Gary P.

description: This place is quite good, but perhaps not as good as they think they are.  The atmosphere and clientele is very sheik for the dogpatch, and there seems to be a bit of a smug vibe.  Mushroom dishes seem to be excellent here, both the funghi pizza and hen of the woods gnudi were very tasty.  The beet appetizer I had with avocado wasn't very good, muddled flavors and textures.  They seem to rely on having really high quality ingredients speak for themselves, which generally I like, but in this case the portion sizes, lack of seeming complexity, and high cost make me feel like I'm not getting a great deal.
author: Paul T.

description: Beautiful decor, excellent polite service, yummy and not overbearing food. Had the bianchi pizza, which had a light and spicy kick. Good wine selection. We sat at the bar, which is fun for watching the cooks. And best of all--ample parking in the dogpatch! :)
author: Robin C.

description:
Spontaneously stopped by here a couple of weeks ago during a week night with my darling. It's in a remote location but definitely worth the trek. 

It's a cozy & cute place with a totally chill vibe. The staff's totally chill and uber friendly which added to the delightful meal we had. We ordered 2 pizza's, one mushroom & I forgot the other but both were yummy! It's super thin crusted and not greasy which is just the way I like my pizzas! 

I've been to the majority of pizza restaurants here (Delfina, Pizzetta, Zero Zero, Flour & Water) and I'd say Piccino gives em all a run for their $$ IMO...
author: Soozie H.

description: When at work and I need a strong cup of drip coffee, there's only one place that I go - Piccino.
author: Michelle S.

description: I totally agree with Morgan R's review that this place has made me a coffee snob. Their Sightglass espresso is the best I have ever had. Seriously, all my coffee experiences since have been lackluster in comparison. Also, the people who work there are actually kind and friendly. I am sad I no longer work in walking distance to this amazing roll-up shop but it's better for the pocketbook :) If you go I highly recommend trying the Vahlrona chocolate chip cookies. TDF.
author: Shawna T.

description:
Sometimes we drive to S.F. just to eat at Piccino.  It's supposed to be a casual Italian restaurant with mostly pizzas and a few other entree options but it's so much more than that.  The flavor combinations are amazing.  I've never had an appetizer, soup, pizza, or any other dish that I didn't want more.  It's impossible to decide what you want.  The salads are just as unique and delicious.  It's the only place we ever eat dessert.  My mouth is salivating as I write.  You won't be sorry.  The wait staff is helpful and friendly.  It's always mobbed with a long line.  Make reservations if you can.  I do not know why anyone would give this place less than five stars unless we are comparing it to linen table kind of restaurants.  Even then I'd take this one.  

In reading some of the other reviews I see someone who said waiters were snobby.  That comment is just strange.  I do agree the prices are on the higher side but no other pizzeria does food like this.
author: Diane D.

description:
I'm a late adopter of this fancy thin crust pizza trend, unless you count the Trader Joe's frozen three cheese pizza that I've stayed devoted to for about 5 years now. So, I'm not falling victim to the hype. I wasn't impressed by Gialina, I've only been to Beretta once way after it opened, and I'm staying away from Flour + Water until the wait dies down. 

But, I was in Potrero and needing a quick place to eat so we could catch a movie. Piccino is in the Dogpatch, where parking is aplenty. It was surprisingly easy to get a table at with 10 minutes notice, and with it being a warmish night (for SF), we were able to sit outside. Easy menu choices, great meatballs (aka polpette), and pretty decent pizza. I liked the crust's flavor and the lightness of the margherita and pepperoni pizzas' sauce. They also have maybe three beers to choose from, but they are all great local choices, and I definitely recommend this one in particular if I could remember its name (it'll come to me...). As a cheese lover, I would recommend a little more (ok, a lot) more cheese on the pizzas though. 

This place isn't all about the hype and the food is good quality, so I'd recommend it even over my Trader Joe's frozen stuff!
author: Kim S.

description:
good food but uninspired; nice atmosphere and service but not exceptionally so

skip dinner and get a latte instead at their coffee shop right outside
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
I wasn't a big fan of the old Piccino.  It wasn't that I hated it, I just never understood all the fuss about their pizzas being so great.  To me they were like putting cheese and toppings on flatbread, putting it in the oven, and then serving.  The pizzas were super thin, tiny, and not very satisfying.  

Even though I live very close to Piccino, I had't been to the new restaurant down the street from the old one.  I was meeting a friend for lunch and suggested we go to Piccino so I could finally try it.  We were meeting for an early lunch at 11:30 so when we got there we were the only ones in there.  When I first walked in, the first thing I noticed was the natural earthy feel of the restaurant (light wood floors and wood tables) and all the natural light the restaurant receives.  It has very high ceilings and there is lots of space in the restaurant.  

The first thing I ordered was a Diet Coke, not thinking I was saying anything wrong.  I was rebuffed by the waiter who informed me that Piccino does not serve soda because they want to serve healthy options.  What??  No soda??  Shouldn't you leave the decision about soda up to the customer?  I understand the healthy angle, but its not like you guys are Cafe Gratitude.  You can't serve pizza and not serve soda?!?!  They go together like peanut butter and jelly, ice cream and pie, Eddie Van Halen and David Lee Roth!  Having one without the other is a crime.  (this is why its 4 stars instead of 5)

My friend and I started our meal by sharing the two appetizers.  We ordered the 'Caramelized squash, farro and almond gremolata' and the 'Pork and beef polpette' which is a just a fancy italian name for meatballs.

Both of the dishes were delicious although I think $12 for 5 small meatballs (especially being an appetizer) is too expensive.

Not being a fan of their pizza, I ordered the 'Chickpea fritter sandwich which had lemon yogurt and red pickled onions inside.  The sandwich also came with a small side of arugula salad.  The sandwich was small but in the name of healthy it was the right size as I had no intention of wanting to be bloated.  The sandwich was delicious and I would definitely order it again.

Overall I like the new restaurant, but I'm not sure it would have the same feel at night.  Also, I think this restaurant is overpriced.  Our final bill with 15% tip came to be $50.  $50 for lunch for two people is too much.  Also, this soda thing is a real problem.

Definitely worth checking out, but bring your own soda to go with your pizza.
author: Ash S.

description:
Me love pizza...sauce!  
My gf read up on this restaurant.   We were able to get seated at a table almost instantly.  It was packed for a Friday afternoon around 1pm.  
We took the waiter's advice and shared the asparagus salad.  He was right - light  & summery fresh.  It was great because it had sprinkles of either sea salt flakes or some goodness.  We also shared the margherita pizza.  Can I just say WOW - the sauce here is awesome.  

Parking is easy, convenient location, open-airy-clean ambiance.  

FYI - they don't serve wine for lunch but instead I opted for the Arnold Palmer served unsweetened.
author: Meredith K.

description: Went here for a birthday dinner. We couldn't decide what to get because everything looked so good, so we asked the server his suggestions and went with all of them for apps, entrees, and dessert. Everything was amazing. We kept interrupting our own conversation to announce out loud how delicious the food was. Plus, the atmosphere was cozy and the staff were very friendly and clearly had great taste. Whenever someone asks where to go to dinner for a birthday or with family, I suggest Piccino.
author: Alexandra S.

description: Great pizzas and desserts!  I am not usually a fan of dessert but I had a hard time deciding as they all look good.  They definitely pay a lot of attention to the presentation of food but what is really nice is that the food taste so good.  Very simple but flavorful.  It is definitely one of the top places for thin crust pizzas!
author: Amy C.

description:
We came here on a Friday night, found parking literally across the street, and were able to be seated right away.  This would usually make me nervous, but Piccino is a tiny (don't come here with too many people or you may have trouble finding seating - it's best for a group of 2-4) out-of-the-way establishment, and not exactly a place you would expect to be hoppin' on a Friday night.

I had originally scoped this place out for dinner with a vegetarian friend because of the large selection of delicious-sounding veggie-friendly pizzas.  We unfortunately had to cancel, but I came here literally the next day because the menu was so appealing and I couldn't stop thinking about it.

They were unfortunately out of the Red pizza which I desperately wanted (tomato sauce, goat cheese, roasted peppers, olives and arugula - i'm drooling just thinking about how amazing that is going to be...), so we instead shared a Margherita and a White pizza and added 2 eggs to the white.

The pizzas were both EXCELLENT.  The fresh tomato sauce on the red was tangy and delicious.  There was not a ton of cheese, which I was at first disappointed to note, but it actually did not matter.  It was still wonderful pizza!  For this little cheese fiend to say that, you KNOW it has to be good!

The white was the standout pizza of the evening.  It had a perfect blend of fresh tomatoes, zucchini, fresh oregano and herbs and garlic.  It was Cheeseboard-esque and bursting with flavor.  The two eggs on top were an awesome touch.  If you've never had eggs on top of your pizza, I highly recommend it.  We dipped the pizza in the runny yoke and were in heaven.
author: Julie S.

description:
The espresso /americano (my drink of choice) and cappuccinos are fantastic! The staff is amicable and authentic. 

The reason this is not a 5 star review is two-fold: 
* The selection and quality of their pastries is "lack luster" to put it kindly.  

* At the busiest time of the day in this industrial area I happen to live in (prior to 9 pm) there only ever seems to be 1 person working there; making the beverages AND taking the orders AND working the register.  As a result it can be a 15-20 minute experience at times. Forcing my business to other shops in the neighborhood that have 3 people working at that hour especially. 

But the building and location is GREAT too!:I recommend checking it out when you have time to chill and wait...
author: Summer H.

description:
Review of Piccino for their Coffee Bar only. 

3.5 stars.

I stop by here on my way to Modern Nail Bar for coffee. I have to say, their coffee is pretty good. I have only tried a latte. The first time I had one, I felt like a drank 20 gallons of thick thick milk. The second time, I remembered to ask for nonfat milk and I didn't feel heavy afterwards. Next time, I'll try a cafe au' lait.

I may even buy a pound of coffee after I finish up my peet's organic gaia.

The pizza always smells so good, but I'm never hungry enough to order any. The coffee bar is so small, I always feel like I'm in the way when I order and wait for my drink. They even have stools there, it's just not inviting for coffee unless it's a slow period for pizza.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
Funghi, Funghi, Funghi!



That's all you need to know when you come to PIccino. This pizza is quite simply amazing. The pictures don't do it justice and the chopped up mushrooms do indeed look like dirt but once you take a bite, get ready to have your life change. You can finish the whole pizza by yourself without feeling to full since it's so light and thin. ( Eating just half the pizza is a tease.) I've tried splitting a Pizza and a salad with another person but you're gonna wish you had a whole pizza to yourself.

All of their Pizzas are super thin crust and crispy (unlike most other places that can't pull a thin crust off without it getting soggy). 

Here's what I'd recommend:

1) Funghi
2) Mais
3) Margherita


I do NOT recommend the Salsiccia. It sounds appealing but it was very bland in flavor. Piccino changes their menu and they need to replace or change that pizza asap. 


The Salad, appetizers are on the small side, tasty but not worth the $$. Pork and beef polpette (basically meatballs) is tasty but not worth $12. 

I'd rate this place 4.5 stars but gave it a 5 since the Funghi pizza is mind blowing. The decor, new location is all nice but I'm here to rate the food. I'd highly recommend this place to anyone.
author: David N.

description: The pizza is bomb. The pasta is bomb. salads are okay. The restaurant itself is gorgeous, warm and inviting . Great for visiting family, work dinners, or romantic dinners. Kinda love this place
author: nathalie n.

description: I really wanted to like this place more than I did. The ambiance is lovely, but the food just doesn't quite live up to it. We had two pizzas-- the Bianca and the funghi. The funghi absolutely covered in mushrooms, with maybe 3-4 spots of cheese. The mushrooms were good, but it was very overpowering with barely anything else except bread. The cheese, when I got a taste of it, was delicious. But unfortunately it was much too sparse for me to even really consider it a pizza. The Bianca was better, and had a nice variety of flavors, but even that one also felt overpowered by the spice and the Parmesan at times. Considering the small menu and the higher prices, I would have hoped for a little more from the food.
author: Susannah C.

description:
i went to Piccino tonight.  I have always thought of coming here and finally I got the chance.  I live a busy life with a great boyfriend and lots of professional and social activity...I can't remember the last time I took myself out...alone.  

And, I came here.  No company to distract me from every detail of this place.

They seated me right away on a Saturday night.  Nice.  It was busy, but, I was only one tonight so easy to fit in.  

The service was great.  They didn't dote on me, but they didn't ignore me either.  It was the perfect amount of attentiveness.  

The food was very good.  The proportions were perfect.  I never eat my pizza crusts, but I couldn't help eating ALL of my pizza here.  

The kitchen staff is visible while cooking and everything was clean and tidy and comfortable.  

I kicked my table while getting up to use the ladies room and this spilled my coffee, wine, and water  a little and by the time I returned, the server had already wiped my table and replaced my napkin.

One of the cooks emerged from the kitchen with a complimentary fresh biscotti for me to dip in my remaining coffee...this absolutely made my night.

What a great little place.  Nice wine list...good coffee.  Coffee was well enough prepared to enjoy without cream or sugar.

Thanks, Piccino, date night for one was a hit!
author: Jessy B.

description: This is literally the best restaurant I have ever experienced. The goat cheese is to die for!
author: Cybill O.

description:
Cute tiny place, cute hand-made cups, good espresso drinks, and
they're not jerks. What more do you need?
author: Max R.

description:
The good about Piccinos is it's local, cute, they serve Blue Bottle coffee & they serve the best yogurt and granola ever.

The bad is the space can get pretty cramped during busy hours & there can be a little confusion knowing when your order comes up.

I accept the good with the bad.  I still love this place.
author: Delilah B.

description: i love the new space, and the yellow exterior! The pork belly sandwich was pretty good as was the pizza and the secret meatballs. They serve Sighglass cawfee....mmmmm. I'm loving eating in the Dogpatch area.
author: Emm C.

description:
Delicious thin crust pizza served out of a tiny cafe in the Dogpatch neighborhood.

The pizzas are small but full of flavor.  Me and my girl got two pies to share.  

The first was the margherita (marinara sauce, fresh mozzarella, and oregano).  I'm used to basil on margherita style pizzas, but the sauce was so good, that it made up for it.  They also could have put some more fresh mozzarella on it in my opinion.

The second pizza was the salsiciccia which consisted of house-made italian sausage, mozzarella, and red onions.  This pizza was fantastic, the sausage was extremely flavorful and really set the pie off.

Dough/crust:  Extremely thin, light, good taste and cooked perfectly.  They have an excellent dough recipe here.

Cheeses:  The cheeses they used on their pizzas are all rich and tasty.

Sauces:  One word: delicious.

Other toppings:  Fresh and full of taste, and all worked well with the rest of the pizza, especially when complemented with a few red pepper flakes.

The service was friendly as could be.  I definitely recommend this place and plan on returning soon.
author: Brad R.

description: Fancy pizza place. Went here for lunch with my coworkers on a Friday. We ordered pickled vegetables which was really interesting and delicious. Then can three pizzas. They were pretty good but I didn't see what the hype was all about. It's just pizza...
author: Leslie C.

description:
The operating word for Piccino's is pretentious.  The price for a cup of their premium coffee is high, fine, I can get with that if I feel taken care of.  But Piccino does not even bother to put out a selection of accessories to go with their coffee.  There is only one dirty pitcher of milk out and it is always empty or on the verge. No cream, no %.  The sugar is white (white!) and must be spooned into your cup, which means there are crusty balls of second scoop throughout the bowl.  And either they don't have hot sleeves or they were just out the three times I have been there but that seems pretty basic to me. 
It seemed to me that the crew was far too involved with making that perfect cup of coffee to be bothered with keeping the place clean.  Wind blown napkins swirled around my feet as I waited for what seemed forever as they "crafted" my order with cute foam designs.  
Let's be serious, it's coffee.  I know the more one pays for things the better they taste, but Piccino is simply insulting to me.
Oh, it is in a great location.
author: Sean K.

description: Fantastic food, great service. Our new go-to eating joint in the City. Sunday lunchtimes are the best!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Returning from a week long Vegas biz trip, I was so jazzed to be back in SF for great food at reasonable prices. So, on the way back to E Bay during Fri rush hour, we decided to try Piccino in Dogpatch. Sat at the bar & were served by Julian. We chose items recommended by him- a delish Heirloom Polenta & Burratta- quite lovely . Also ordered Roasted Cauliflower & Chicory w/Creme Fraiche & anchovy salad. This did not arrive until after main course as it was forgotten.. Beef Cheeks w/mashed rutabaga & cippolini onions.  Unfortunately, the beef was very fatty/gristly, rutabaga intensely over powered with horseradish.  I think we ordered wrong. We mentioned this to Julian, who apologized. & then brought out the forgotten salad, which was very tasty. We did order dessert (passion fruit tart?- good ),
Enjoyed some really nice wines from their selection. 
So, the food experience was just OK. Darn.
BUT, gotta say that they know how to take care of their customers, because Julian knew we weren't really happy with the meal - he comped us for both the salad & main course . THAT was CLASS & a great operation!  Thank you Julian, we will come back again.
author: Stephanie R.

description: We come here about once every 2-3 months and always have a great meal. Most of the pizza's are great (although we are not fans of the funghi pizza) and their ever-changing list of pasta and secondi are always a treat. Also, they have a great wine list with affordable options. Our kids always feel welcome here which is a bonus.
author: Suzanne D.

description: Not sure what all of the fuss is about.  Made a reservation with my husband and BFF for her birthday dinner.  Had an 8:45 reservation and weren't seated for over 30 minutes.  Had some of the house made cheese with salad as an appetizer.  The cheese was tasteless (queso fresco?) and the salad was, well, arugula 'unaccompanied' (read: lonely arugula).  The pizzas were fine, nothing to write home about, unless you like yours on the greasy side.  Our sever was mildly deranged and the music was much, much too loud.  I don't know, maybe it was a full moon or something.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
My new favorite pizza place in SF!  Their crispy, thin crust is perfection...Mmm.  

Margherita pizzas are always my baseline when eating at pizza restaurants and Piccino's is delightful...lots of fresh tomato sauce with a nice balance of cheese and basil.  Their funghi/mushroom pizza puts other restaurants versions to shame.  What sets it apart is that they not only put roasted mushrooms on the pizza, but also spread a chopped mushroom and garlic pesto-like mixture on it as well...all accentuated with a super creamy stracchino cheese.  Absolutely sublime!  

Their gnocchi should also not be missed...very different from your traditionally dense gnocchi.  These huge semolina pillows are served with roasted wild mushrooms and mouth-watering chunks of pancetta.  Already wanting to go back for more...

The ambience and the service were also warm and friendly.  The only downside is reservations are tough to get, but unlike many other hyped up 'gourmet pizzerias'...Piccino is worth it!
author: Karin V.

description:
Somebody brought pizzas over and was nice enough to share. I'm not usually a big fan of super thin-crusted pizzas. But the pizzas I tried were good. No heavy tomato sauce just cheese and other toppings. I had a few slices of the:
 
- Funghi: roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic
The sauce contained ground-up mushrooms and toppings were larger pieces of mushroom. I'm a mushroom fan so I naturally went for this pizza first. It was a simple pizza with just mushrooms and cheese.
- Salsiccia: house made sausage, mozzarella and red onion. Tasty but not my preference. The sausage was tasty but there weren't too many on the pizza.
author: Candace F.

description: A bit overrated for what we got, the salad was good with strawberry arugula, and some other stuff, the meatballs were salty for my taste but the sauce  that was on them was great, ask for bread and dip the sauce. The pizza was not the best ,pancetta with lemon and some other stuff was ok, and the margarita pie was good but much better @ other spots.
author: Chris D.

description: Piccino has one of the best gourmet pizza--thin, crispy and delicious! You can add an egg on top of the pizza which makes it fun, different and very yummy. I tried a pasta dish that comes over a black calamari sauce and it was amazing. Salads are very good. Service is good but too slow. You have to be very patient, don't go if you are in a rush. The restaurant's decoration is very cool. I like the chairs and tables. Very modern.
author: Magoo M.

description: I had a meeting in Dogpatch on a weekend morning recently, and my man came down and met me for brunch at Piccino, and it was just amazing.  So amazing that this review is going to be kind of boring.  The space is gorgeous, in the yellow building, with a huge open kitchen.  The service is awesome, everyone is so nice.  The food was killer, especially the pizza.  I think it will be our new go-to when we want to go out for brunch, and places in the Mission are all crowded.
author: Bobbie J.

description:
I just do not think this place is worth it. The staff is arrogant and pretentious. The food may be decent, but there are too many other choices in the neighborhood. 

Go up the street to Just For You Cafe. They are better http://www.yelp.com/biz/just-for-you-cafe-san-francisco
author: Mark F.

description:
I found this place on a whimsical, unplanned bike ride, in an attempt to fulfill the brief of a school project. And I was pleasantly surprised. 

The espresso was sweeter than other times that I've tried Blue Bottle espresso. My soy cappuccino, which I had ordered mostly out of necessity to remain awake from an almost all-nighter, actually cut through my brain fog. I haven't seen if they offer anything gluten-free to eat yet, but if they do, then I might be sold on the idea of a weekend morning bike ride over to the Dogpatch. And that's asking a lot of my lazy weekend morning self.
author: Helen I.

description:
One little shop at a time, the Dogpatch neighborhood is gradually winning over my heart and the Piccino coffee bar is surely a great contributor to the cause. The staff is super great and down to Earth and with each espresso drink, comes a little foam heart that shows the love. I was 50 cents short of a coffee once and the platinum blonde sweetheart behind the counter still fed my caffeine fix and saved my day with a great cup of coffee. Pretty big fan of Brian too, who is always super nice. 

You know when Blue Bottle produces a custom espresso roast for you, you're legit, and Piccino has truly made its mark in the neighborhood. Great coffee, friendly staff, and a pretty kick ass Italian Plum muffin have won my heart over with this gem!
author: Christina N.

description:
Pros:
1. Beautiful airy sun-filled space - we can on a sunny day for lunch
2. Food was great - we had the meatballs ( excellent but $$$$ for only a few pieces )  and two kinds of pizzas
3. Blue Bottle Coffee

Cons:
1. Pretty pricey place for the modest servings you get - granted the ingredients they use are "primo" it still is an expensive meal for a semi-casual place.
2. Pizza was very good but pretty expensive 
3. Service was a little spotty - I do believe they were only open a few days when we stopped by for my birthday lunch so they are excused for now.

My suggestion is to try it at least once.  They do have good food its just quite expensive in my opinion.
author: Kitty C.

description:
This review is only for the pizza & soup fyi.

Came here to pick up my CSA box with friend. We've always wanted to try Piccino and finally found a open table on our last outing. We tried the corn soup and margharita pizza. It was the most simple, well executed pizza I've ever had. Unbelievable quality ingredients go a long long way. 

Out in the dogpatch but worth the drive
author: Rich B.

description: My favorite restaurant in the city. Marinated Olive is awesome, all the pizzas are recommended. Their salad is extremely fresh and tasty. You can also drink Blue bottle coffee at the end. I not only love the restaurant but also the neighborhood around it, which is called Dogpatch and Potrero Hill. It is sunny side of the city and you will be happy sitting outside in the sun for lunch.
author: Hyejin K.

description: Food is good but our dinner came after three parties that arrived after us were halfway done with their dinner.
author: Ari E.

description: Food was awesome. Had the Lamb, which was perfect. Service was attentive but not overwhelming. Comfortable place to go.
author: Carl B.

description:
The destination of a long-awaited girls night with three dear dear friends. I didn't realize that they serve all pizza and a pasta special, and I like to say that I don't eat pizza, but hey, when in Rome (or Dogpatch, imitating Roma).... 

I shared a funky-fresh funghi pizza after devouring the perfect gazpacho soup (how often is it 90 degrees at night in SF? They put the right thing on the menu!) and meatball appetizer. Anytime I can order meatballs by themselves just because, I have to do it, and these were moist and delicious. 

We loved sitting outside, Harleys passing by and all, and the service was spot on. Can't wait to go back and pretend some more that I don't eat pizza!
author: Gretchen T.

description: Cool place in the dogpatch.  It was sunday and everything on this block closes at 5pm.  You may get shot here but the new restaurants going in are lookin good.
author: Fatty A.

description:
The food is lovely. Fresh flavors, quality ingredients, a well oiled/run and talented impeccable kitchen. Bravo for that! I have been here several times and each time enjoyed the food immensely.

However, the service here is abysmal. It's not only the apathetic service but the sheer lack of hospitality, friendliness, and basic attentiveness.  Come on people, It's a neighborhood place, we don't expect much but some warmth, a feeling of community, maybe a smile would be nice. Like a real genuine smile and a thank you wouldn't hurt either.

Our server tonight, at the bar, should not be in this industry. She looked annoyed, bothered from start to finish of our meal.  That's after spending almost $200 sitting at the bar for two people. 

I even told our host and server it was my friends birthday and at no point did they acknowledge it.  I've never been to a restaurant where people basically say, "so what?" which is how they treated us. 

It's a shame because I LOVE the food. It's the perfect combination of fresh and hearty and makes you proud of what the bay area offers in refined, natura, innovative traditional italian meals. Piccino knows how to use their flavors and do an impeccable job of combining a perfect balance of flavors.
