But again, the service is cold and leaves a sour taste in your mouth. Instead of going home full and happy you go home full but with an uneasy sort of feeling that you've been taken advantage of. 

Again, love the food but won't be coming back because I'd rather go somewhere with some warmth and hospitality. 

btw, I noticed a server on the main floor and she seemed to be totally on top of things and very friendly, with a smile on her face, very professional, and I could tell the customers just loved her. I wish she was our server instead!
author: Junebug L.

description:
Wish this treasure of a restaurant was in my Brooklyn neighborhood and not on the other coast!

Tried to eat things that I could not get in NYC - fungi pizza!  Amazing salad involving watermelon and a watermelon radish that was sliced so thing it was translucent.  (Could the watermelon have been pickled?  Hard to believe it was pickled watermelon as I have had such mediocre meals in NYC involving same.)

Great iced tea, lemonade, mix them for an Arnold Palmer.  Sit outside in the SF summer called October and feel lucky!
author: Danielle G.

description: this is a great neighborhood restaurant. the place is bright and inviting, the ingredients are fresh and the food is tasty but not overly contrived. i've been once for dessert only and once for brunch and would love to check out dinner. i will say that their brunch egg dish was very small and was definitely not enough food to fill any man's hunger (my boyfriend had to eat half of my pizza to make up for it). still, it was a great meal overall. the french toast looks awesome so i'll be back for that!
author: Regina C.

description: Amazing place!  We had the beef carpaccio, which I typically dislike but now I'm a believer.  The beef was so tender and thin, and the deconstructed version they made on a board was very nice in presentation.  We ordered the broccolini pizza which had a delicious cheese on top, almost like a sauce, and almond slivers.  I'm determined to try to recreate this at home.  It seemed "healthy" which is my jam, but who knows, nonetheless it was delicious!  Despite the strange and spotty, borderline neglectful service, I'd definitely go back for some wine and pizza.
author: Terry K.

description: more spacious than their original bar in the old cafe and even more spacious than the little shop they put in next to it.  cute, bright, fun, excellent coffee, beautiful pastries.  I had a muffin that had lots of fruit and nuts in it.  you can even plug in your electric scooter!  At least one guy did when I was there.  very nice.
author: cindy b.

description:
Food was good. Brussel sprouts great. Pizza OK.  Mostly expensive French wines - weird for a California pizza restaurant.  How about some affordable California and Italian wines? 
We had a reservation but our waiter all but told us several times that we had to order family style for our party of 9 because the kitchen is small.  I'm not accustomed to being told how I have to eat my food  when I am spending a good bit of money at a non-family style restaurant. Place is noisy and parking difficult.
author: Peter W.

description:
great lunch spot.. dinner not so much.. its appraent that families in the local area have found this their haven so lots of kiddies at night! Whilst I do love kids it made for a interupted dinner with an old friend. 

Only dish i did not like was the ricotta gnudi.. sharp falvors that were not balanced..

i for one love the clam pasta though!
author: Michael M.

description:
When I first moved to SF several months ago I walked down the street from my flat and went into the Piccino's Coffee Bar, a tiny little closet of a place with a little line of people and dogs forming out the door.  Having just moved from Colorado, I was not used to the higher coffee prices in SF and initially balked at the $2.50 Piccino was asking for a regular-sized coffee.   

But after tasting my coffee I found myself saying, "This is a a great cup of coffee".  Not just good, but great.  Like you don't ever want to the cup to end kind of great.  Like "$2.50" is MORE than reasonable kind of great.  The coffee is so rich and robust you don't even need to put sugar in it.  It almost has a sweet smell to it.  

And the service is also wonderful and prompt.  I don't know that I can offer any complaints whatsoever about my experiences at Piccino since that first day, except maybe that I wish there was a large size coffee on their menu.  The coffee is just so good you want it to last a little longer.  

Thumbs up to the Barrista staff (Aussie Guy, Tall Blond Smiley Gal, Dark-haired Beanie Kid, Asian Gal, Thin Beard Man, Serene Librarian Guy with Glasses).  Even with a longish line and time intensive Blue-Bottle coffee making methods, they manage to keep things flowing at a good clip.  And they even manage to bust out some totally apropos tunes on that little Macbook they have behind there:  Leonard Cohen one morning, some Elliott Smith on another, groovy electronica mixes the next.

Cold, drizzly SF morning, Cohen's "I'm Your Man" drifting out the Piccino window, great coffee.  What could be better?
author: Aaron A.

description: Very family UNFRIENDLY.  We brought a toddler to brunch, but does that really merit a whole staff going out of their way to make us feel unwelcome?
author: Carrie Ann P.

description: One of our favorite lunch spots in San Francisco.  We usually get a mix of appetizers, salad, and a pizza to share.
author: Kevin T.

description:
It's 3pm, most places have stopped serving lunch, dinner is a few hours away, and you are starved for a decent meal.  Where to go?  Piccino, which serves food from 11:00am - 9:30pm.

I recently tried this tiny restaurant after passing it 4,598,276 times and saying to myself "oh, I keep meaning to go there".  I had just picked up my friend at the airport after a long international fight and we were due for a catch-up and some real food.

We had the place to ourselves at this odd hour of the day, and settled into a nice corner table with a couple of pots of Yunan Black tea.  We then shared a Caprese Salad, which was small but full of delicious things like fresh mozarella, pickled red onion, and parsley, and you couid tell that the ingredients were of great quality.

We waited for what seemed forever for our Wild Nettle & Mushroom pizza, and finally a server explained that they had overcooked it, and had just put in a new one for us. ("But, but, but, we are the only people here!" my mind protested)  To stave off our hunger, she brought us a platter of pretty radishes in olive oil and some flatbread, which was a nice gesture.   When the pizza came, it was tasty, with good flavor - not the best thin-crust I have ever had, but with good toppings.

My favorite part of the meal was the slice of lemon tart that we shared for dessert.  Buttery crust, perfectly tart filling, elegant in its simplicity.

Had we not had a lot of catching up to do, I probably would have been somewhat put out by the time it took for us to have our meal (almost 2 hours!), but I realize that this is not a normal practice there and we did really enjoy everything, although it was a bit pricey for the quantity of food that we ate, even including the extra "tide us over" plate. 

I would definitely stop by in the morning for some Blue Bottle Coffee (the coffee bar opens at 7) and a pastry.
author: Liz S.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to a "total-package" restaurant in SF, and that's not for lack of frequent visits. 

Piccino is high-quality at every level: fresh ingredients, creative menu, great service and a gorgeous space/ambiance. I can't tell you how many times I commented on the beauty and design of the open kitchen and wood paneling. 

We ordered the pulled pork panini and the funghi pizza for our saturday morning brunch. Both were packed with flavor. As was the green juice (celery/apple) and of course sightglass coffee. 

If you are looking to stuff yourself silly, this may not be the place for you. The portion sizes are small on a good-ole-American scale, but I nonetheless left feeling satisfied (and I'm not a small portions eater). The great food coupled with the ambiance and great location/weather creates a rounded out dining experience. I'm excited to try Piccino for dinner!
author: gloria y.

description: I just temporarily moved to dogpatch for work and was in search of a cute and quiet little cafe to get away to.  Piccino was the perfect find for this! The personalities behind the coffee bar are nice, caring, and easy to talk to.  Ask about their tasty little treats they have to go with whichever beverage you choose ... if they have their fig newtons available - go for one of these!!
author: courtney l.

description:
Best thin crust pizza I ever had! Usually, I don't really care about pizza but DAMN this one is bomb and mouth wateringly good! I actually had half a pizza to myself and took the rest to go. yummy... Still good.

PS.
For some reason, there are 3 Piccinos on one block - the restuarant, the coffee bar, and the soon to be remodeled Piccino.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Big G and I wanted to try a place out of our 'hood so stopped in here because of the Yelp reviews. Yup. I agree. The pizzas are the best thin crust pizzas I've had in SF (so far). Better than Little Star and Ragazza. Service was very nicely timed. Wine was lovely (but why only one Californian red wine?).

We shared:

Margherita's Pork & Beef Polpette - delicious meatballs but the tomatoes tasted canned (4 out of 5).

A salad consisting of kale (I think), some kind of cheese, nuts, and yellow and red beets (4 out of 5).

Seasonal red pizza with the eggs (5 out of 5). This was perfectly balanced in flavors, perfectly cooked - esp. the eggs, which is a dealbreaker for me - and perfectly presented. I had to fight Big G over the last slice (I won!). 

We were too full to try a dessert, although they looked delicous and I could hear our neighbors' happy noises when they ate theirs.

All in all, a lovely experience. I would definitely go there again. My ONLY criticism is that it was really warm in the restaurant! Both of us were really baking. Maybe it was just a one-off though, and woudn't put me off going again (I'll just wear less clothes!).
author: Mi M.

description:
Summary based on one mid week lunch:
--decent pizza
--average service
--ok prices
--parking challenging

Came for a work lunch meeting with a guy who had been here before and recommended the pizza.  I had the seasonal white pizza, which was better than average (using Berkeley and New York for calibration).  Service was typical lunch service, that is, ok, but not out to make a lasting impression.

I was actually surprised how few people were there since there's not a lot of competition in the immediate area, but maybe all the hipsters were out of cash or something.  

Nice attractive ambiance in the place.  In the immediate area I probably would come back here before walking down to 3rd for Serpentine.  If it was full, you might get a little too much cross talk from adjoining tables.  

There's ok parking about a block away on Minnesota.  No opportunity to sniff wifi, but I'll try when I return.
author: Rich H.

description:
Piccino is one of my very favorite restaurants in the world.  That's saying a lot.  And I mean it.

I think a lot of the less-than-stellar reviews are from folks who just don't "get" this place.  Piccino is different, it's very much its own place--go there with an open mind and senses, not in a rush, and you will love it.

What is it about this place?  Piccino has nailed a wonderful and difficult-to-achieve aesthetic in every aspect of its operation.  The service and ambience are friendly and comfortable.  The food is superbly fresh, simple, restrained, and beautiful.  It's much closer to what "homemade" would be if you were a stellar cook than almost any restaurant food available these days.  That's the whole "restraint" thing: nothing at Piccino is over-salted or over-cheesed or over-buttered, like you get at most restaurants.  Restraint in food is so hard to find in this day and age...

Yet Piccino manages that restraint while still being creative and inventive (and a little bit funky).  Which is to say that while it's never boring, there is also never anything fussy about it. You'll find none of the rampant "novelty for novelty's sake" trend that tends to dominate the restaurant industry.  Just beautiful food.

As many have pointed out, the pizza is fantastic, wonderfully crisp and just the right amount of toppings.  We often try the specials, but we particularly love the funghi pizza with egg (divine). The salads are delicious and inventive while remaining somehow classic.  I also love the antipasti platter and the polpette (meatballs).  And blue bottle coffee!  The wine list is also well-edited. For a reasonable splurge, try the Sesti.

For the quality of the ingredients, and working closely with farmers, this place is not overpriced--in fact, I think it's an amazing value given the overall quality of food.

If only there were more places like this!  Viva Piccino!!
author: Bumble B.

description: Really really really good coffee--although the people working there weren't exactly friendly and focused on talking with other people behind the coffee bar.
author: Paul C.

description: Atmosphere and location were great and the food was good but very small portions.  The woman that took us to our table was rather surly--no smile, no words--and the place was empty so she sure wasn't busy.  Same with the waiter--he was very perfunctory and "quick" with the food--in fact, we were rushed in and out in no time.  He also made a negative comment to the busboy about us, and we got a "look" that would kill from the busboy.  I think they realized, too late, that we saw them.  For what reason they didn't like us, we don't know!  (There were 4 of us for dinner.)  As I said the place was not crowded, so their behavior made no sense.  On each course, the busboy removed plates before everyone was finished eating which seemed very unprofessional and rude.  No smiles or nods from him either. We'll never go back and would not recommend it.
author: E. G.

description:
Sorry, this update is LONG overdue. This place went from being one of my favorites to one I avoid. The last time I was having outdoor lunch here on a weekend, another table set down all their plates and bowls on the ground for their DOG to lick clean. Disturbingly the dog licked clean every plate and dish presented to him while server walked by. Neither the servers nor the manager said anything. When I went up to the manager to ask if this was common he informed me that there are a lot of dog loving customers "especially Europeans" who don't mind sharing their plates with their dogs, but he assured me that their dishes are washed at a very high temperature and I shouldn't be worried. Eeesh! Wrong answer. I wonder what the city health code says about mingling doggy dishes with those meant to serve your patrons. The manager clearly choses the doggy dish sharing patrons to those of us who expect to observe some propriety or have OCD.
Just then my lunch was served and I returned it untouched as I could not bring myself to eating out of a plate that had possibly been used by a furry friend. I paid for my lunch in full in case you were wondering.
author: Molly S.

description:
This place is so damn good, even when the service is slow I don't even care!  Beautifully and simply designed - the space is a perfect match to the food.  And many of the food combinations are surprising and refreshing!

Bianca Pizza is a must have amongst many other dishes!!
author: Natalia S.

description:
There's much better pizza to be had, especially for the premium they're charging.  Lack of a convincing beer/wine menu didn't help the unimpressive food.  

Lentil "fritters" were hardly inspiring, margherita pizza (which should have been excellent) fell flat with so-so sauce, and our mushroom pizza had a large chunk of cardboard in it..(they handled the situation professionally which was appreciated).  The waitstaff seems to vary quite a bit too.  Our guy recommended a pinot blanc when my friend asked for a pinot noir recommendation which he seemed oblivious to the difference.

Really nice atmosphere, and conjoined coffee shop is spot on, but the food and drink here just doesn't justify the tag.
author: Graham S.

description:
Awesome Coffee.
Great Pizzas. 
Relaxed and Accesible, what else can you ask for?
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place.  I remember coming here once before for lunch, and so when friends and I were craving Italian, we dinked around yelp, and decided to come here for dinner.

Oh my goodness were we happy!!

Intimate setting, not too noisy, impeccable service, the food is delectable.  I'm a vegetarian, and they had some yummy options for me as well, and my meat-lover friends were just salivating over their meatballs.

Perfect, cute little place for dinner with friends, or just a weeknight date.
author: Rollio R.

description: Very bad service, long wait. Especially the cafe. You're better off getting better food at a friendlier service elsewhere.
author: Teresa W.

description:
Decent food, nothing super special given the other good pizza options in SF.  Service is very poor, slow, disorganized, and slightly bad attitude.  

Restaurant has moved down the street from its original spot into a nice new corner space surrounded by a pretentious, over-priced craft and clothes shop and a wine store.   

It's all so precious and overdone that it feels like that self-conscious/self-referential smug vibe that Portlandia so aptly mocks --  times a million.

Will avoid it in the future even though I live pretty close.
author: Jennifer T.

description: We arrived in the late afternoon and had the large, airy, sunny place to ourselves. My boyfriend ordered a margherita pizza. I had already eaten lunch and got the homemade sesame, poppy, and nigella crackers. The pizza arrived with a charred, crispy crust. Both the waiter and chef offered to let my boyfriend have it and get a new pizza, on the house, without the crispy crust. He said, okay. I tried a piece of the crispy pizza, and thought it was perfect. It matched my pizza criteria. When the new pizza came, I must confess I didn't like it as much because the crust wasn't as good, but I thought everyone was super sweet to offer it to us. And my crackers were fabulous, far better than any store bought crackers. The desserts looked divine, but we were stuffed.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
Much like the super hot boyfriend you secretly hope will pack on 40 pounds so slutty girls will stop eye-groping him, Piccino is a tad too popular for my taste.

I wish it were my little secret.  But it isn't.  Other people know about it and that pisses me off.  And since the law says I can't build a compound in my backyard and keep Piccino there forever, then I'll need to embrace that this is a damn fine lunch/dinner place and sometimes my butt will be required to wait for a table.

Ideal for languid lunches and get-to-know-u dinners, the space is small but the mood is lively.  The servers are cute and trendy in the Tartine Bakery way.  And who knew tap water tastes better chilled and served in Strauss milk bottles?
 
My favorite:  Green Salad followed by the Salciccia Pizza.  

Romantic spot to bring a love interest like me if parking downtown makes you punch bystanders in the face.
author: Janney B.

description: After perhaps 20+ visits to Piccino we decided to skip the pizza.  The pizza is so great that it was a tough decision, but we didn't miss it.  I had a generous octopus salad, and my wife had a perfectly dressed Little Gem lettuce salad.  I had the garganelli pasta with kale, bacon, and a wonderful "cured egg yolk".  My wife had ricotta gnudi, delicate dumplings mixed with wild mushrooms and Brussels sprouts.  We mopped up every morsel.  The wines (1 white, a rose, and 2 reds by the glass) were lovely.  We reluctantly skipped dessert.
author: Robert W.

description:
Two star service, four or even 5 star food.  I've eaten here tens of times, before and after their move to the new location, and I've never had a bad meal.  However, the service is spotty and can be really quite bad.  It's often hard to get a refill for a glass of wine, so start trying to flag someone down when you still have about 1/3 glass left.   

However, the worst experience I ever had was with the short female hostess who works on weekends.  A few months ago we had an 8:00 Friday reservation and when we arrived there were a lot of people there waiting.  I understand restaurants, particularly popular restaurants, running behind on the weekends.  I'm from New York, I'm used to waiting.  However, after 15 minutes we ask when she anticipates we might sit down.  She says "we're very busy tonight."  No kidding?  We ask after another 15 minutes and she still doesn't know.  However, this time she asks: 

"Can I at least get you a glass of wine...on you, of course."  

Are you f***ing kidding me?  

Let's be clear here, I do believe if a restaurant is way behind on reservations that they should offer a glass of wine to recognize the inconvenience to their patrons.  It doesn't need to be an expensive wine; it could simply be a glass of house wine, just a little something.  It goes a long way to making an unhappy client less unhappy.  Frankly, if they just had a bar where we could have ordered drinks while waiting, I still wouldn't have minded so much, but to have the hostess spell out that any wine we ordered would be "on us" after having us wait 30 minutes.  Seriously, I was ready to bitch slap the woman.  I am still amazed that anyone would say that to their client.  Needless to say we got into a little bit of a verbal altercation.  When we sat down, about an hour after our reservation, the waitress apologized and was excellent.  The wine we ordered while waiting was on the bill.  No surprise there but still notable.  

This only happened once, but then we don't normally go to Piccino on weekends.  Anyway, despite this, the food really is quite good and worth returning for.  Though perhaps not on a weekend.

Items not to be missed include:

The squash and faro appetizer
The Fungi Pizza 
The lamb ragu
Almost any of their side veggies (brussel sprouts and carrots were excellent)

I love sitting at the kitchen bar so you can watch the chefs work.  The atmosphere is great and the wine list small but pretty good.  A bit on the expensive side for the menu.  I would expect a few more lower priced glasses (most were in the 13 -14 range), but it's still good.

My recommendations to Piccino are:

1) Fire the awful hostess
2) Take over the clothing store next to restaurant and turn it into a wine bar ala Bar Jamon/ Casa Mono in New York.  Give people a place to wait and order a drink and perhaps even a few snacks.  Dogpatch could easily support another wine bar and it just makes so much sense given Piccino's popularity and long wait times.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Fresh & vibrant ingredients! Eggplant app was nicely textured and underwhelming. Brussels sprouts app was perfectly charred and flavored. The sauce on the homemade stracci w/ hen of woods was spot on!   Saving the best for last... the funghi and ortica pizzas were crisp and nicely topped with excellent ingredients!
author: L T.

description:
First off, let me just say...that I was just SHOCKED when I walked through the doors of this restaurant.  It's in the heart of the Dogpatch neighborhood, so you already know what the parking situation is going to be like! :-)  (The Muni train stops a block away---T Line)  From the outside, the restaurant looks like a cute "little" yellow house on the corner.  But when you step in these doors...honey...let me tell you the decor was very chic and hip!  Loads of wooden tables accented by mesh metal chairs, and big windows that let lots of sun light in.  I was not expecting that at all within these walls!  Lol....after I finished drooling over how awesome the set up was, I ordered the Bianca Pizza with parmesan, pecorino, mozzarella, shaved garlic and chili oil. Talk about pizza heaven!! Deliziosa! I-ATE-IT-ALL (maybe I shouldn't admit that...lol). But let me warn you....unless you plan on kissing a few frogs after you eat this, you must have on hand gum or mints as the garlic content is pretty high.

Slam dunk for Piccino!

PS. Just a note, even though this is an Italian restaurant, they serve very few, if any, pasta dishes at lunch (mostly salads, pizzas, and a few soups). Because of the small space of the kitchen pasta is usually reserved for dinner and at that it usually is only 1-2 dishes (our waitress gave us the run down).
author: Anisha W.

description:
At the edge of San Francisco, a couple of small, unique restaurants spot the area, and today we decided to try Piccino-- 4 1/2 out of 5! =) 
We had the squash antipasta ($6), light and healthy w/great dressing 
gnocchi- a little expensive ($15) but interesting, in a good way, taste
and funghi pizza ($16)- super thin crust, cheesy w/ mushrooms yum

Everything was delicious and unique-no complaints!
author: Nonia H.

description:
Pros: best thin crust pizza you can find in the city, not overloaded and not frilly; super friendly staff; easy parking

Cons: although I love the neighborhood vibe here, it can feel a little frantic because the tables are crammed into the space at every angle - I really wish there were more outside sitting space; their nonpizza menus are good, but not great, otherwise would be 5 stars for the pizza
author: Nina S.

description: Yum. We just ate here last night. Got there a bit on the early side to avoid the crowd. The staff were super friendly. Our first dish, the farro verde (with cauliflower, grapes, pine nuts) was phenomenal in it's freshness and uniqueness. We also enjoyed the artichoke starter (fried), and the burrata (with watercress, sea salt, polenta). Order 2 of that last dish to avoid an embarrassing fight at the dinner table. We continued with the beets and tagliatelle (with mushrooms, crescenza, chervil). We ended on a high note with the bianca pizza (parmesan, pecorino, mozzarella, shaved garlic and chili oil). We added an egg on top of it! I can't stress these two points enough: 1.) The pizza is some of the best in the SF (and blows A-16 to Italy and back); and 2.) Get the egg on top of this one. Dogpatch is far from my digs, but I hope to come back to this place again and again. Easy corkage as well. Epic!
author: Brian J.

description: Best for meals enjoyed slow.  Portions are smaller than the usual; Nonetheless filling.  Quality ingredients, fine, delicate flavors.  I love the furniture and interiors as well.
author: Caroline P.

description: Best thin-crust mushroom pizza (funghi pizza) I've ever had in the city! YUMMY! Their menus change seasonally.  I've heard that many other items on their menu, including their strawberry salad, are spectacular as well.  Attentive service, great décor, low-key ambiance and quality fresh food!
author: Teresa C.

description:
Pizza: 5-star (Love it!!)
Cappuccino: 5-star (perfect)
Price: 4-star ($10 or more for a Pizza)
Service: 3-star (not easy to order second beer)
Atmosphere: 5-star
Temperature: 5-star
Brightness: 3-star (dark in the evening)
Table: 5-star
Cleanness: 5-star
Bathroom: 5-star (very clean)
author: Yosuke K.

description:
I head about Piccino and their Rosé and Pizza Festival from the tablehopper email.  Normally, I would not be in Dogpatch, lovely as it is, so we made a special trip.  What a delight!  

Piccino had a wide variety of rosés, available in tastes, glasses and bottles for this special event.  We ended up tasting 6 types and ordered two pizzas.  The pizzas were very tasty - not my favorite of all time, but still very good.  One was a standard margherita and the other was a special white pizza with salt cod, green tomato and lemon basil.  The second was divine!  I really loved the tomato sauce on the margherita and fish on pizza is still new for me, but I LOVE it!

It was also fabulous to sit outside and enjoy the brisk day under the warmth of the heat lamps.  Love to sit outside - next time I'd love to bring my pooch!

So, I'm sure we'll go back to Piccino, maybe not regularly as it's quite far from home, but it's worth the trip to be sure.
author: Mac M.

description: 3.5.  The pizza and salads are very good.  The service needs improvement.  Just set aside lots of time if you decide to dine at Piccino.  It took an inordinate amount of time just to flag down a wait person to take our order.  There was an extraordinary long wait for salads and another very long wait for pizza....and another very very long wait for the check.
author: Bleep S.

description: My review is way overdue.  To put it mildly, I enjoy the abundance of great restaurants we have in SF and this has been my overall favorite for several years now.  The food is consistently innovative, beautifully seasonal and begs to be savored.  The wait staff is unfailingly interested in the quality of my meal...and, since their wine menu has many offerings I'm unfamiliar with, I now figure out what I want to order then ask the server for what would best complement.  They nail it every time - and, yes, it's fun to expand my wine knowledge.   Last, I have to mention the vibe of Piccino - welcoming, informal, and a place they make it so very easy to hang out and enjoy.  Thank you Piccino!
author: Judy T.

description: Don't like coffee. Liked this. 'Nuff said. Go now.
author: Ron Z.

description:
Piccino Coffee Bar is awesome.

Their Blue Bottle coffee is fantastic!  They have one bench inside the coffee bar, so there is little room to sit inside, but there are a few benches outside.  

Usually if you hit a prime time where people want coffee (before work, or on the lunch break) you might have to wait a few minutes, but the quality is great.  

They also have some sandwiches you can order, biscotti, as well as farm fresh eggs.  Yum!

Good prices too!  Check it out in the Dogpatch!
author: Ana M.

description: The coffee here is absolutely delicious. If you can stand the Alfa-Romero entitled yuppies who cut it line, the place is great for coffee. I would give it five stars but it needs a better place to sit and most places with overpaid yuppie clientele annoy me because frankly those entitled wasps are a destructive element to society. But seriously, the coffee here is SOOOOO GOOOOOOD.
author: LaMouche M.

description: Fantastic little gem of a spot near my accountant.  I just had my taxes done and was a bit grumpy., I spotted this place empty at 11:30 am on a Wednesday, but the vibe looked good so i gave it a chance.  The pizza was perfection (I really should not have eaten the whole thing, but whoops-a-daisy, the whole (sausage/onion) pie fell into my pie hole.  SCUMPT-DILLY-ISCIOUS!
author: Amy W.

description:
I love how this place looks inside.  Very homey but contemporary and with lots of natural light.

The menu is seasonal and pretty limited, but there are always quite a few vegetarian options.  I've dined here several times and I almost always get the funghi pizza.

I like the food, but I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're a big eater.  At my hungriest, I can easily finish a whole pizza by myself, and even their secondi options are not all that large.
author: S L.

description: Went to this place a few months back for dinner and I thought the f old was quite good...we had a few appetizers including the gnocchi, tagliatelle, and one or two others. Each of the three of us ordered our own pizza which one is filling for a person or possibly can be spit between two people if ordering several appetizers. All the food was good and I really like decor of the restaurant -- very open, airy, and hardwood floors. Service was friendly and quick. Looks like they had a couple of tables for outdoor dining that I'm sure would be really nice for weekend brunch of a nice day.
author: Kent W.

description: Love, love, love this place, especially since they switched to Sightglass - whatever they're roasting now (late November) is fantastic!  Lovely baristas and excellent baked goods too.  Now that they've relocated down the block, they've even added a few tables and chairs to boot.  Highly recommended.
author: Katy M.

description:
I've been here a couple times and it's never disappointed.  The pizza is really quite good.  Especially with two eggs on top.  Service is pretty good as well.

Haven't tried anything besides the pizza due to financial constraints. It looks good though.
author: Hugo T.

description: We went here after waiting in line at 5pm for 30 minutes for Flour and Water only to get turned away.  Ugh.  Well folks I would say Piccino is right up there with Flour and Water, in fact I would say their pizza is far superior to F&W.  Everything we ordered was amazing, great service and friendly atmosphere.  We will definitely be back for more.
author: Greg G.

description: I'm a huge fan of their pizza! Capers, anchovies,pine nuts and arugula-- perfection on a thin crust!
author: J D.

description: Yummy little coffee bar... Made a delightful chai
author: Sarah N.

description:
Showed up here with my friend around 8'ish on a Thursday night without reservations. We walked in and was greeted by the hostess and was told that we had to wait for about 20 minutes or so but while we waited, the bartender discussed some wine choices for my friend (I don't drink) and my friend settled on something for while we waited. I was offered non-alcoholic beverages but I opted not to. There wasn't much space for a waiting area which kind of sucked but it wasn't terrible either although we did needed to dodge people coming in and out. About 15 minutes went by and we were seated at the counter.

Menus were brought out to us and we started with the burrata, asparagus, polenta, and sea salt salad to start. It wasn't bad but I felt like that the dressing was a bit too strong, especially on the watercress when being paired with the more delicate flavors of the polenta and asparagus. The polenta and asparagus was very good though.

I ordered the funghi pizza while my friend ordered pappardelle with peas. It took a while for our food to arrive and unfortunately, my pizza arrived before my friend's pasta which isn't a huge deal for me but I can guess some people may have some issue with that. The pizza was okay but was sort of one dimensional. What I mean by that is that even though the flavors were there, it was sort of the same thing over and over again without variation. The pizza had some sliced mushrooms as well as what I can only describe as globs of melted cheeses here and there. The base of it was covered in a ground up mushroom paste/sauce. After a while, I was sort of bored with it which is unfortunate but luckily my friend helped me with it, otherwise I don't think I could have finished it by myself. I like mushrooms but the pizza didn't cut it for me.

Our waiter came by to check in with us and offered my friend a different wine and he tried it out and decided that he liked it more than the first and got a glass of it. The bartender also came by at one point to ask if my friend wanted something else to try while we were waiting for the waiter to come by with the wine so that was nice.

We finished our entrees somewhat late, around 10'ish and our waiter brought the dessert menu over. We decided to split an ice cream sandwich (no idea how we were going to do that but we were determined) but unfortunately, the waiter told us that they were all out and suggested an alternative. Nothing else seemed to interest us so we decided to skip dessert.

Over all, I enjoyed my experience here and wouldn't be opposed to coming back. Based from my pizza, it was a 3 star and I would give service 1 star (I don't think I would give any service more than 1 star in case that seems little to some of you). I would definitely try some of their other dishes next time.
author: Richard C.

description: Perfect pizza. It's hard for me to ever say this. Crust = perfect combination of crisp and acknowledgement of soft dough; perfectly melted cheese (I want to know what type it was), perfect blend of spiced sausage; morsels of thin red onion cooked in the pizza oven, topped with arugula tossed in light olive oil; fresh red pepper. Amazing Italian wine with a mineral finish. Didn't hurt that it was a sunny afternoon and we got to sit outside against a beautiful yellow backdrop!
author: Jackie G.

description: On a sunny day I love to move the outdoor table and chairs further into the sun and take my time eating their wonderfully prepared foods. The food is not fussy, but it's always satisfying with simple and fresh ingredients.
author: Andrea Y.

description:
Love this place...friendly staff and very chill atmosphere!
The best pizza ever...my fave the Bianca Pizza...so D'lish.
Great local beer, tasteful wine and awesome Mimosas and not to mention their coffee is the best!!
author: Alma R.

description:
I've previously complained about Yelp not supporting half stars, forcing me to wait to review a place until it resolves one way or the other. Piccino, being a solid 4.5, fell into that basket until tonight, when an unexpected side effect of their open kitchen pushed it firmly into the 5 star range. I'm afraid saying why is going to breach a rule of etiquette, but I'm reporting something that reflects well on them so I'm going to make an exception.

Just so you know, ordering more than 2 or 3 items blows this place out of the $$ range into the $$$ range, and it's best for people with moderate to small appetites, but the quality makes it a worthwhile choice. To their credit, they post their prices on their website menus, so you can judge for yourself.

I started with the pickled vegetables, 4 stars. What set them above others I've tried elsewhere is that you could taste the individual ingredients through the pickling flavor. A bit pricey at $6.

Next, the broccoli pizza with crescenza, olive, almond and calabrian chili. The flavor was wonderful, the crust crisp but not burnt, and the broccoli well shredded so I wasn't biting into big chunks. 5 stars

As an aside, I had a side of roasted baby carrots with sherry and cumin. Luscious, 5 stars.

For dessert, warm cinnamon apple cake, candied walnut, mascarpone ice cream. Small serving but quite good, 4 stars.

They place the tableware directly on the wood counter, a squick of mine. Even worse, the pickled veggies came in an odd-shaped container so I couldn't really rest the used fork on it, leaving me to put the used fork back on the counter and raising my squick to a new level. Eww.

The counter seating is reasonably deep underneath and comes with a cushion; the wire back of the chair is a bit uncomfortable and doesn't supply easy support. So overall the maddening 4.5 stars at this point.

But the cool thing is you get to watch the kitchen folks do their stuff. And that's where the etiquette violation comes in. Because you're not supposed to eavesdrop.

They serve pasta. What I didn't realize is that they make their own. Because right in front of me as I ate one of the line cooks started making pasta, flattening the dough and running it through a pasta machine. After doing this to a bunch of dough a few times, he called the guy in charge over and said something like "I think I can save this, but" and stopped. The "but" hung heavy in the air.

A few minutes later the pasta was gone and the guy in charge was carrying off the pasta machine and there was no more working on pasta.

So, I learned three things about this place that push it into the 5-star realm:

1) Piccino's kitchen has nothing to hide.

2) The kitchen staff cares about the quality of the food.

3) The guy in charge cares that the kitchen staff cares about the quality of the food.

I hope they forgive me for this etiquette violation.
author: Charles B.

description: Great food, casual vibe, modern interiors. There's an open kitchen that is lined with a bar that you can eat at which is pretty cool - I love seeing chefs in action and how they prepare the different dishes. Everything we ordered was really good - the polenta, carrots, spring pizza, and some sort of lemon barish dessert. The pizza was great - thin crust but not at all "droopy" - so you can actually pick it up without the toppings sliding off. Our server was very friendly and helpful with the menu. It did get super busy so would be best to get here early or expect to wait.
author: Gina C.

description: For the Europeans out there that complain about American coffee, this place is worth a try.  My husband takes all of his visiting friends here.  The pastries are amazing!  Although they stopped making my favorite...it was a chive and prosciutto scone (yum).  There is a ton of butter in these delicacies, but so worth the occasional splurge.  I am not a super strong coffee drinker so I stick to cappuccino which is perfect every time.  The only reason I don't give this place a 5 star is because the wait often is a bit long.  I realize individual drip coffee takes time but it seems like they could improve their operational efficiencies to get people in and out faster.
author: Keri K.

description:
I love Blue Bottle Coffee but hate Blue Bottle for a couple reasons. The first is the line, the second is the ultra hipster feel and the third is the pretty shitty pastries.

I found myself in the Dogpatch at Rickshaw Bagworks across the street and felt the need for a cup of coffee. I went into the unassuming, bright blue building  because it felt like the sort of color that would have great coffee. You know how that goes.

When I went inside, I saw no tables and no chairs. There was just a table with cream and and sugar and a counter with espresso machines. 

The service still feels a bit elitist, but there's no line like at blue bottle. There might not be any chairs or tables, but there are the outdoor tables at the Piccino restaurant a couple doors down. There are efficent and your coffee comes to blue bottle perfection.

I ordered the nonfat cafe au lait, which I realize is unfashionable compared to a latte, but I had to order it when I realized they had these amazing looking (homemade!) pistachio cranberry biscotti with just a hint of anise. They were the exact right texture and so much more interesting than the traditional almond stuff you find everywhere else.

It was a perfect mid-afternoon treat. Blue bottle coffee with no line in an unassuming neighborhood...
author: Stephanie H.

description: Great pizza and dessert, but no pasta??? (Older crowd for those who care)
author: Djjr R.

description:
Found Piccino with the trusty iphone yelp app after volunteering with a few friends at the Food Bank on a random Wednesday night.
The exterior is so adorable.  Situated at the bottom of the cutest purple and teal apartment building, Piccino has an inviting sign and friendly staff.  

A couple of my fellow diners are on the picky side, so I sat back, said I'd eat anything (OH, I will, things have changed since my adolescent, picky years), and let the rest of the crew order.  

We split four pizzas between our party of five.  The Bianca -three cheeses white pizza with garlic & parsley, the Salciccia -white pizza w/ sausage, mozzarella & red Onions, the Margherita  -tomato sauce, mozzarella, and basil, and the Pepperoni -tomato sauce, mozzarella, and pepperoni.  I honestly wish we would've ordered a few of the specials instead, but oh well. My two favorites were the Margherita and the Salciccia. The tomato sauce was soooo scrumptious and mouth-watering, I'm going to go as far to say it's better than Pizzeria Picco in Marin...I seriously could've been content with a huge bowl of their tomato sauce with some ground turkey and parmesan cheese.  Uhhhm, double mmmmmmmm!  
   
They also use their own blue bottle blend. Yes, I said BLUE BOTTLE!!! Phil H, give it a try. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jenny W.

description:
We live two blocks from Piccino, and it's pretty dangerous. They are always piping delicious smells out onto the street and tempting me with their wares. 

There are some reviews here saying the crust is like a cracker. Let me start off by saying if you don't like gorgeous, crunchy crust pizza and for some reason I can't fathom, prefer soft, doughy blobs with tons of stuff all over it, this place is not for you. Piccino is about beautifully crafted food with simple ingredients and the pizza is more East Coast Italian style. Thank goodness. 

The red sauce is well-crafted and slightly sweet most days and the menu changes up often. We are here at least 6 times a month (!) and are never bored. I've never gotten the special entree (the funghi, it calls to me) as the pizzas always seem better bang for the buck. The appetizers are fun to share.

Last tips: 

There are often little kiddies running around on the weekends. If you're a child hater (I don't really mind kids, most of them seem pretty well behaved), come on the weekdays. 

When things get busy, the tiny kitchen and seating can sometimes get overloaded. Trust me, I'm pretty impatient (raised in the tri-state), but the service is good and they will usually give you something for free for the wait if it's long and you are not an arse. Even then, I feel like they would give you something, they are so nice. 

AND it looks like they are opening a bigger location just on the other side of the block...so don't think they aren't concerned about it :)
author: Ash H.

description:
Out of the way, but with a nearby MUNI station, Piccino is convenient and at the same time feels like an escape within the city limits.  Part of that is simply due to its location in Dogpatch, which feels serene and earthy even at weekend prime time.

I've been to Piccino four times now.  Twice for lunch, once for dinner, and once for take-out pizza.  Well, I ORDERED take-out, but also ordered a glass of wine while waiting for the pizza.  Then the pie came out while I was only half-way through the wine, so I had to open the box, sniff, snatch a bite, and, long story short, two glasses of wine and an empty pizza box later I'd had another dine-in experience at Piccino.

I'm not going to recommend anything in particular from the menu this time, because I've tried something different on every visit, and been positively impressed each time.  Any pizza + contorno makes a fine small-ish meal for two.  Daily specials are divine.  The wine list is impressive in that the selections complement the menu beautifully and are in the low-to-medium price range (the pricing thing probably being a necessity for restauranteurs in the current economy, but Piccino took this approach from their opening, before our esteemed representatives in D.C. fell asleep at the wheel, drove the economy into a ditch and convinced everyone it was Wall Street's fault).

Service is friendly and professional, and the decor is tasteful, functional, and comfortable.

Get to Piccino before Indian Summer fades -- maybe between the lunch and dinner hours -- snag a table outside, and bask in your good fortune at having logged onto yelp today!
author: Francisco G.

description:
Don't eat here if you want to have a lunch in UNDER an hour and a half. They seem to be totally incapable of taking your order, making your pizzas and serving you a dessert in that amount of time. 

Why a two star? This is not a four star restaurant and I'm"m doing my part to let others know. 

This was my third trip here over the last three years. Each time the pizza has been almost unrecognizable from the others. My first time there was shortly after they opened and I can honestly say that it was the worst pizza I had ever eaten. It was like someone had spread ketchup over a cracker with some mozzarella on top. The second seemed more like the dough you'd see over at Delfina. Much better, but still really sweet and "ketchupy". 

This last trip was a week ago and I went it with my friend for a weekday lunch. We had a marg, a crescenza radacchio sausage pizza, an upside down blood orange cake, and a couple of drinks. 

The pizza was ok. The marg was completely overpowed by the saltine-like "thin" (quotations are used because for a supposed thin pizza crust it is fairly thick) crust and sweet one note sauce. I would still relate it to ketchup. There were maybe 6-7 small bits of mozzerella and some dried oregano. I'm not a real cheezy pizza lover by any means but when your sauce is that sweet and your crust that thick the cheese is totally lost on your pizza in that quantity. It was boring. The special pie was a little bit better but really randomly over salty in areas. I'm not sure why as the sausage wasn't very salty. I like salt though so it wasn't a deal breaker. It was the better pizza of the two. 

We wanted to try their desserts so we ordered an upside down cake. About fifteen minutes later, no exaggeration, our server came back and told us that they had run out of the cake on Sunday, this was a Tuesday, and didn't know if their baker had been in on Monday to make more. I guess they don't make their desserts fresh daily? They dug one up from somewhere. It was this tiny little cake soaked with some syrup and a slice of "jerkyish" blood orange on top that was so dry and tough you had to actually saw through it with a butter knife. It was terrible. They charged us 7.50 for this piece of leather. 

In general the food is very expensive and I, like others, felt slightly ripped off. This was my last trip to Piccino.
author: Jack M.

description:
So good that in one long weekend I had both dinner AND brunch here.
A good friend of mine lives only a couple blocks away, so it was just a short walk to get to this cute little place.

Yes, it is little.  It's little, but adorable! Dinner was a little crowded, I felt like we were sharing our table with 3 other people... we were that close on the booth side (but it's all good).  I love how loud and warm it gets at night, like a perfect little corner bistro.

Food:
 
Funghi Pizza: Deeelicious.  We decided to get 2 eggs on top.  I think they really made the pizza.  Those are some FRESH eggs, delicious.  There is no sauce to this one, just straight up mushrooms.

Margherita: Ooohhh so good.  I had this for breakfast, with the 2 eggs of course.  One of the best "morning after a long night of drinking" breakfasts I have had in a while.  Their pizzas are so thin and baked to perfection.

The other things my 2 giiirls got were only on the summer menu, I am sure, but let's just say "delicious."  I am so glad they use what is in season and do it well.

Overall: I would come back for the pizza, the ambience, and the delicious eggs.  Also, I am very interested in their roasted fruit bruschetta.
author: Isabella O.

description:
We found this cute and cozy neighborhood restaurant and decided to give it a try. 

We didn't have reservations but got seated within 15 minutes. Not bad for Friday night dinner time. The place is very small, the tables are right next to each other, I felt like I was having dinner with the 2 dudes next 2 us. Don't expect to have a private conversation.

House-made "flat bread" was served, we didn't quite like it. Tasted like dry but humongous tortilla chips/pita bread to me. It came with a whole roasted garlic for the bread. The caprese salad was fresh and delicious but the portion was very small. And then came the entree, pepperone pizza. It is simple but with high quality ingredients. very nice thin crust. Wish there was a bit more cheese or just one more slice of pepperone tho. If you like your pizza hearty with lots of toppings, don't come here. This place reminds me the kind of food you would get in Italy. 

We didn't order dessert cuz we were still hungry after...
author: Ling Ling Z.

description:
following the blue bottle epidemic in good form, Piccino is a much enjoyable sign of Gentrification in the Dogpatch. Much appreciated for my long Tues&Thursday's at work, but the hipster attitude with my latte isn't always appreciated. 

Love/hate kinda relationship going on here...
author: Tina D.

description:
been hearing about piccino for a couple of years now, but today was the first time i've eaten there.  it was fantastic!!!  really really fresh ingredients; fantastic but simple flavor combinations; obvious great care in food preparation.

the atmosphere is clean and serene . . . very california, very light and airy.  and the staff are lovely.

eat your next meal out at piccino!!
author: Kathleen M.

description: Sorry Caffe La Stazione, you've just been outdone. My latte was smooth and velvety and the sticky bun totally made my morning. It's a bit farther away from the train station but I can definitely see myself coming back if I have extra time before train leaves.
author: Tatyana K.

description:
we came here after a huge brunch in search of coffee, and we were  delighted that they were able to curb our caffeine fix with blue bottle coffee made in a percolator and a cappuccino.  we were celebrating a birthday with mini cupcakes, and asked the waitress if it was okay to eat them with our coffee.  she said it was no problem, and was still quite attentive granted we were only in for coffee and provided our own dessert.

the pizzas and salads looked pretty good, so i'll be back for a meal at some point.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Piccino is definitely one of those rare gems that you only find out about when someone drags you half way across the city for some pizza. This however, was not the case with me, I can tout myself as a local of 20+ years. But that's not the point. The point is this place is amazing. It's a cute little pizza place with excellent specials, reliable delicious paper thin pizza and a lemon tart to DIE for. I have actually stopped in just for a slice of the lemon tart, it is that good.

I would highly recommend both the fungi and margarita pizzas, my only gripe with the latter is that I would really appreciate more cheese.
author: Allyson S.

description:
what i ordered... pizza with sausage

neopolitan style pizza was good, 12 inch size was nowhere to fill me up, crust was crunchy chewy and so thin, homemade sausage was different but good and blend well with the sliced purple onion and cheese was just a drizzle to taste.

ambiance... good(simple yet chic)
service... good(nice)
cost...$$(expensive)
author: Gors P.

description: You know if they serve Blue Bottle, then it has to be good.  I mean they'd have to be pretty bad at brewing coffee to mess up a very quality bean.  I got a mocha.  It was a very dry style of mocha that tasted great because it didn't overwhelm the coffee flavor.  The store is very small with only 2 tables.  The coffee is pretty pricy and while the owners weren't unfriendly, they didn't convey any excitement for being there.  Not the best, not the worst.  My SF coffee tour continues...
author: Jeff G.

description: Piccino's has the best SEASONAL pizza I've had so far in the city. They use fresh ingredients and pair them with unique varieties of cheeses and the crust is thin just the way i like it! The new location is great and much more spacious, and while there definitely is a wait sometimes, they have some great wine and champagne to hold you over.
author: Janina T.

description: Wonderful latte accompanied by a quiche/ricotta item. Very friendly barista and counter person. I spent an hour of so sitting at one of the tables, enjoying the friendly atmosphere. It can be chilly, as the cafe opens to the sidewalk, so dress for the weather.
author: Beth W.

description: I'll be brief.  With so much good food in San Francisco, I'm amazed that this place was fairly busy during my first and last visit for lunch.  we ordered the blue cheese with strawberries with balsamic honey appetizer and it was just laughable.  the wait person said that they've added "sprigs of celery leaves" to the dish.  there was one wilted, old celery leaf atop three minuscule, old , gross strawberries with about a teaspoon of honey that did not taste as though it had balsamic in it. no bread or crackers to eat it with.  i asked for bread from three different people and 15 minutes later, I was give two pieces for our table.  then came the pizza.  crust was OK but the tomato sauce tasted like canned sauce. not good at all.  the soup was also tasteless (it was a white corn with cumin and yogurt  and I could not taste any cumin at all - just blah).  I don't know where the other folks get the 3 and 4 star reviews but that was not our experience at all I'm sorry to say.
author: Ali B.

description: Met friends there for dinner and it was excellent.  Can't wait to go back.  The food was delicious.  They have s great wine list.  The service was extremely friendly.  Highly recommend the meatballs, so good we ordered seconds.  Brought our kids and they really enjoyed themselves too.
author: Neal S.

description:
this place is super cute.  i made a reservation for my father in law's bday last week, and everyone loved the meal.  it is a pretty veg friendly restaurant, but the only bummer was that the fried brussels sprouts had infused anchovy oil in it, and they couldn't make it w/o the oil.  everyone raved about the brussels sprouts in their review, and i really wanted to try it, but i wasn't able b/c no one else at my table could eat it.

we shared the cauliflower w/ farro, the sides of greens and roasted carrots, the pickled veggies, the mushroom pizza w/ an egg, and the pancetta pizza w/o the pancetta.  everything was good, and i loved the egg on pizza.  we also got the donuts and the lemon crostata as desserts.  i only had the crostata, but everyone else loved the donuts.  i want to come back for the brussels sprouts next time!
author: Helen T.

description:
I'm always a bit apprehensive when ordering Blue Bottle coffee at a place that isn't ACTUALLY Blue Bottle, but Piccino does it right.

The baristas are skilled and my double shot americano (the firing squad) was spot on. Great spot in a neighborhood that's often overlooked.
author: Dan W.

description:
I wish I could give them 5 stars. We used to be regulars at the old space and loved the staff and the food. We went a few weeks after they moved into the new space figuring they'd need time to work out any kinks with the transition. Well, we waited a very long time for our food. The waiter screwed up the coffee press. When we ordered the french press for 2, we used to get 2 cups from one french press but they used the same amount of coffee grinds  with 1 cup so it came out super strong. And out came 2 french presses when we ordered 1. They also charged us for 2 french presses even though we told them it was not what we wanted. They tried to fix the french press issue with it coming out thicker than turkish coffee but it was pretty gross. 

We felt pretty bad for the people sitting next to us. They were from LA and wanted to try this place but we were already done eating while their food did not come out. The wait staff got both of our orders totally messed up so we would get their food. We were done eating and they still had not received their food even though they ordered before us.

We told the owner about this and she knew about the transition.  The food, on the other hand, was delicious since it was the same chefs. The wait staff was horrible and clueless. They did not look happy to be there.

We waited a few months before venturing back. I like their food, but the rest of my family hated the service and vowed never to go back. Made my husband go do take-out and he went through the main restaurant to pick it up. Since we had not gone there for take-out after they moved, we were not aware you had to pick up food from the cafe (another entrance). The waiter yelled at my husband and asked him what the hell he was doing there in the restaurant. Hello? If we were first time diners, we'd NEVER come back here again (and not sure we'd go back there again). It was around 5:30 pm and they were pretty empty. Not sure why the guy would yell at a customer regarding a take-out order.

I wanted to write the owners directly, but there was no email to be found on their website. I'm guessing even if we did, they would probably not do anything about it. It feels like they had a great thing and expanded way too fast without hiring good people. 

I miss the old cozy space with nice wait staff who would take the time to chat with customers with a smile. The wait staff now have scowls on their faces and are absolutely rude.  I would give 1 star if the food was not so delicious :(.
author: Elena R.

description: This place is listed on the 100 best restaurants in the bay area as published by the S.F. Chronicle, and gets great marks on Yelp.  But our experience was completely different.  We did get a nice, quiet table for 3 and the noise level was not too bad.  The steak tartare was good, although not the best, and meatballs exceptional.  But the pork loin was not a loin but a number of pieces of exceptionally fat, and tough, pieces of pork--we sent it back, and the pork belly was even worse.  The salmon, brought as a replacement, was better but a little undercooked.  The broccoli, ordered as an appetizer, was oversalted even though we requested lite to no salt.  Deserts were all right.  The food, in short, was profoundly disappointing, particularly given the reviews and its listing.  Not great at all, and in some respects, hardly acceptable.
author: Jeffrey P.

description:
We have been fans of Piccino since they were in their original space, so this review is long overdue. The dining room is light and airy, and the staff is friendly and professional. Every time we are here, the tables are packed. 

Last night, we had the following dishes:
- asparagus, burrata, heirloom polenta, watercress, salsa verde
- pappardelle, penn cove mussels, spinach, marinara    
- ricotta gnudi, hedgehog mushrooms, walnuts, parsley   
- pan seared trout, green garlic risotto, sunchoke, black olive tapenade   
- warm cinnamon apple cake, candied walnut, mascarpone ice cream

We requested that the chef go easy on the salt, and they readily complied. Not all restaurants follow through, so we were very pleased with Piccino. Everything was fresh and seasoned well. In our opinion, the star of the evening was the trout, which was perfectly cooked and paired with a lovely risotto and crunchy sunchoke chips. The dessert faltered a little because the cake was a bit dry, tasting more like a bread or muffin. However, the ice cream and candied walnuts were a great combination.

We are thrilled that they are now on Open Table - we can't wait to go back!
author: Twocents F.

description:
Friday early dinner with two other my girl friends, plus my little one. 
My 4th times already after the first meal. Yummy
author: Elisa C.

description: Tasty pizzas and paninis in Portero! Love the outdoor area. They get busy at lunch so if you have a group make sure to make a reservation. The goat cheese app was delish- recommend that and a thin crust pizza. The service was great, just the right amount of checking on you.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Possibly it was an off night but the main dishes seemed on the salty side and the portions are a little too small.

Started off with the crab salad which was fresh and delicious.  Tried a slice of the sardine pizza which was too salty for my liking.  Had the pappardelle with braised beef, which was slightly too salty and the pasta was a little to firm for my taste.  It did have a good flavor though.  It's a nice restaurant and I'll probably have to give it a second try to confirm the quality of the food.
author: Peter S.

description: Holy brussel sprouts! My husband and I got out for a date night while our kid played at My Gym's Parent's Night Out event and Piccino was literally half a block away. The staff was so lovely and gracious, the loft-like ambiance was warm and inviting, and the food was beyond expectation. As I said, the brussel sprouts blew me away - they popped with flavor and juice almost like a sausage would. My mouth is watering all over again just from thinking about them while writing this review. The pizza was also incredible - esp since it was topped with paper thin lemon slices. Who knew sour lemons could taste so sweet! I also liked that you could buy wine by the glass, carafe, or bottle. Since my husband and I differ in wine tastes, 2 separate carafes solved our issue. In all, a lovely spot for a lovely meal.
author: Kristin S.

description: Not happy to drive 45 minutes to enjoy recommended best pizza ever only to be told they are CLOSED between 3-5pm.  Especially when on yelp they are listed as OPEN! Not fair...
author: Rose M.

description: Margharita pizza - must eat it there while the crust is crispy!
author: E T.

description: We made a reservation at Piccino after reading about it in Bon Appetit this month.  It was just a fantastic dining experience.  The open kitchen and airy feel of the dining area make for a delightful ambiance.  The host was so friendly and inviting, that we did not mind our brief wait prior to being seated.  We ordered the pisello pizza and the bianca with an added egg.  Both were delicious, but you cannot miss the bianca with the egg addition - i promise, go order it now.
author: Leah G.

description:
PROS
Great service, friendly and attentive
Fresh, quality food
Nice atmosphere & cool location
Delicious mains

CONS
Charged for sampling the wine 
Small, expensive portions
Difficult to make reservations
I've had better pizza

3 of us had a birthday dinner at Piccino last night. I called 3 times to try to make a reservation. Finally, I decided to wait through the lengthy message just to get to the point when I could request my reservation. 
TIP: dial 10 to skip the long message and get to the reservation line.
You leave a message and then they need to call you back to confirm that you have a reservation. 
I never got a call back and once we arrived, we had to wait 45 minutes for a table to open up. 

Wouldn't it be easier if someone just picked up the phone to take a reservation in person?

While waiting, the bartender offered to let us taste from some wine selections before purchasing a bottle (though, come to find out that we were charged for the tastings which we thought were complimentary). We ordered a bowl of delicious house cured olives and a plate of figs, honey and cheese which turned out to be a $9 rip off. Sure it was tasty but it was a minuscule portion - one ounce of cheese and one half of one fig. Really?

Dinner was lovely - both the mustard green salad and marinated cucumber salad were tasty, with super fresh greens and interesting textures. 
We also ordered the $23 steak which was cooked to perfection (though served pre-sliced rather than an actual piece of steak), the rabbit ragu on a bed of fresh pasta - divine - and the sausage pizza (meh).

Though the waitress proclaimed that the portions were large and we could share, the reality was smaller than her imagination (and we don't like huge portions). 

Overall, we had a nice time however, being unknowingly charged for the wine tasting, getting an expensive, barely there fig/cheese app., and just a so-so pizza sorta put a damper on the experience.  

I would have rather spent my evening in a beloved favorite like Delfina.
author: kathryn k.

description:
I don't know why, when hearing about pizzas, Piccino is a little under the radar. This place has the delicious gourmet pizzas you're looking for. And the atmosphere is so relaxed and comfy. They offer a wine list at lunch ... and you might want to order a glass or two. It

The combinations are unusual, but totally approachable. Fresh tuna salad on a panini with meyer lemon. Pizza with wild nettles, mushrooms and mozzarella. Fresh lemonade (if wine at lunch makes you sleepy).
author: maureen f.

description:
Normally much better. But maybe a little arrogance is creeping in here. 
Service was very poor (from 3 different people). To make it worse, the food is usually very good. But not this time. Pizza was served cold. Tomato sauce tasted bland. Nothing even a tiny bit special about it. Might give them one more chance, but the attitude seems to have changed in the last few months.
author: Michael C.

description:
For their food, it's three stars. For their attitude to accommodate families with children, it's one star. One of the owners "informed" me that my stroller is not allow in her newly relocated restaurant per the Fire Dept. Really?  Her waitress had poured food on babies in strollers before in her restaurant. Scary!  And she doesn't have high chairs in her restaurant!  So what are we suppose to do?  Eat with our children on our lap or leave them crawling around on the floor underneath our table?  Or just leave...
Raising kids in the diverse city of San Francisco and yet being marginalized by this restaurant truly caught me by surprise.
author: Mary S.

description: Love the decor and that it's next to a wine bar. Stopped in for a business lunch and ordered a salad. It was great. Loved the flavors, but left the meeting kind of starving still... I would totally come back for a bigger meal or keep this on my list of places to go when I'm dieting...
author: Patricia M.

description:
There is way too  much buzz around this place. One star only cuz the average rating must go down.

I'm surprised at the positive feedback this place is getting in a city that boasts some of the best Italian restaurants in California. My judgment not only references the legendary places like A16 and Pizzaiolo, but also my 20+ visits to Italy.

The appetizers are tiny and strange. The waiter has to explain to you that the gnocchi are not really gnocchi, and indeed they have nothing in common. Just keep things authentic, will you! They're also over-priced. Maybe they're trying to compensate for the fairly-priced "pizza" here. BTW, visit Pizzaiolo and have a real pizza.

The receptionist has the aura of "who the hell are you and how dare you walk in without a 3-month-in-advance reservation. We're full tonight." Only the Slanted Door is allowed to pull that one off because they've earned it.

I will grant 4 stars to the overall design of things ranging from furniture to napkins to atmosphere. Pity I'll never get to experience that part again.
author: flojo x.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Foodie friends have said it was crappy and not worth it but I didn't want to believe them.

For such a pricey place that touts itself as serving "pizza," I was expecting pizza like that found at  A-16, Gialina, Del Fina and especially the Oakland joints Pizzaiolo and Boot and Shoe Service, etc.

Unfortunately, the pizza here STINKS. Really. Underseasoned sauce and crusts that are so thin they are absolutely floppy and soggy. How this restaurant can get away with charging what they do for such crappy pizza is beyond me. Honestly, if you want a pizza 10 times better, fork over $4 for any Trader Joe's frozen pie and bake it in your oven at home. 

Another thing. Calling something "fava bean fritters" on the menu and then f*cking serving FALAFEL is ridiculous. Call it f*cking falafel! I understand that trying to hide the fact that it's falafel justifies your right to charge $10 for 4 tiny balls of falafel, but it's a dumb scheme, and a foodie will not be amused.

2 stars for the new place in the Yellow Building. It's beautiful and open. While the little coffee shop next door is wonderful, I will not be returning to this rip-off of a place. Round Table makes pretty good delivery pizza if you're in a pinch, and you'll get more for your money.

I'm so mad I wasted money here. I haven't been this mad about food in a while...

PS: To the people who think this pizza is amazing, umm. Trying to figure it out...
author: fatty m.

description:
I love Piccino.  Hesitant to give it FIVE stars only because I want to be able to get a table when I go -- but they've earned it!  

The pizza, atmosphere, location, and quality are all top rate.  Their starter plates (and salads) are the perfect size to get you ready for the thin crust pizza that follows.  I find the changing menu always offers something fresh, new, and seasonal.  Lately, the best for me is the Fungi with TWO eggs!   

The service is always great.  The guys and gals that work there seem to stay there for awhile...and they have always been smiley and nice...which make the food and wine (or beer) taste that much better!
author: vince b.

description: The funghi pizza and the red squirrel ice cream are incredible -- stop what you're doing right now and go try them. The rest of their food is great too, though I wouldn't recommend the anchovy pizza -- the flavor is too strong and salty. The atmosphere here is great for causal groups or for a romantic dinner -- not too loud, but still happening, with lots of light and great service.
author: David B.

description:
A small and charming place in the burgeoning Dogpatch neighborhood, Piccino has excellent thin crust pizza. It rivals that of my favorite thin crust go-to in NYC, Posto. Hooray!  (...and thank you to my foodie pal for introducing me to this spot.)

The menu is small but simple and focused. A short list of apps and pizzas is rounded out by a single daily entree special. I have only tried the White and Margherita pizzas, and both are delicious. I will certainly be returning to methodically work my way through the rest of the menu.

Service was excellent-- friendly and charming.

While the space is small, it does have a few seats outside. This is one of those spots that is a small neighborhood gem, and I hope it stays that way!

(P.S.  For $2, you can add 2 eggs to the top of your pizza.  This stroke of brilliance needs to be imparted upon the NYC pizza shops!)
author: Jen Y.

description: This is kind of one of those hidden gems, because it is out of the way in a random neighborhood in SF.  However, it is one of my favorites  because of the food, the space itself and the attentive staff.  I chose to have my birthday brunch there, including a large group of friends and my baby + stroller and they accommodated everyone.  We brought champagne, they were quick to chill it for us and take photos for us and were just awesome.  We did not feel rushed ever.  The food was impeccable.  The pizza with the egg on top, is a delight.  The coffee is delicious and out of all the amazing eateries in the city, this is one spot you don't have to wait an hour for, or deal with a waitress that is slammed and never brings you the extra drink.  Its an awesome place, and I highly recommend it.
author: tammy b.

description:
The few times I passed by Piccino, the cafe-goers seemed content, so when some friends suggested we go I was cautiously enthusiastic.

My cautiousness was unwarranted.  The food (mostly pizza) at Piccino was delicious.  We started with the antipasti, which was tasty, but it's hard for an antipasti platter to really standout. With that said, the accompanying crispy flatbread was quite nice. For mains, we ordered the Margherita, Fungi, Napoletana, and Salsiccia.. Copious sharing ensued.  The crust was quite nice -- fresh, thin, kind of crispy at the edges. Among the four, the Napoletana was my fav with the Salsiccia running a close second.  While mushrooms are not my favorite food, everyone else in the group seemed quite pleased with it.  Piccino serves Blue Bottle Coffee which I really like, so that was another plus. And the service was great. Since lunch followed a morning tour of the Anchor Steam Brewery, I'd had plenty to consume and and decided to skip dessert.  But, look forward to next time...

For CalTrain commuters, highly recommended to take a small detour on the way back to your car/bus and check Piccino out.
author: Tom Y.

description: Great pizza! Yes, it's pricy, but what good SF food isn't these days.  I like the unique menu and would definitely go back.
author: Katy W.

description:
they have blue bottle drip coffee and really good brownies. you must expose your brownie to direct sunlight so the chocolate chips inside get all gooey, and then eat it with ice cream from mr. and mrs. miscellaneous (which is down the street).

i like how this coffee bar is located in a little garage. very cute
author: Jessica C.

description:
I want to like Piccino. In theory, I should. The pastries always look good, and the coffee actually is good. I know it's not a Starbucks, and we're now in the slow food movement.  But seriously, it took me 15 minutes to even place an order, and there were only 3 people in front of me. Waiting for regular coffee, let alone something from the coffee bar, was no longer an option. 

They are located just 2 blocks from the train station; there is no flexibility on my timing to get out the door. And, I am not the only one.  Running to the train with coffee counteracts any fuzzy feeling I've just bought for a $4 coffee. Not sure what kind of experience they are aiming for; if it's disappointment and frustration, they are successful. 

I gave them one last shot with their new space thinking that with new space would come new service. Very sadly disappointing. Today, I have been in line for 10 minutes and haven't even moved. At this point, I'm just curious as to how long they can actually expect people to wait.

The next test is whether or not ordering an extra hot latte will bring me anything more than luke warm. If the past tells me anything, it's that I already have my expectations too high. 

Well, I can't speak to the temperature because 25 minutes in line didnt even afford me the opportunity to place an order.

So much for trying to stay local. Help me, help you. Piccino, I am through with you; that's is now 5 for 5 times ( in the last 2 weeks) of giving you more than ample time.
author: Sunny Y.

description:
My favorite spot in SF!  

Fresh fresh fresh local ingredients assembled with care and attention to detail and love of food

Incredible salads

Perfect pizzas

Great community

Just go.
author: Klevy K.

description:
Umm where else can you get a cup of Blue Bottle Coffee with no lines!
Cafe serves tasty baked pastries and home made sandwiches. This Cafe is a true gem in the Dogpatch!
author: Christian S.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a place to eat and came across this cute little restaurant in a Bright Blue building. It was a Sunday around noon and there were a few tables open. The restaurant room is small the smells are fabulous. All the ingredients are local and fresh. I chose the poached eggs over sausage and lentils. I was so yummy!!!!! I normally do not eat eggs but this was my way of starting of 2011. I also had coffee, it arrived in a french press, nice! 
Staff was great, very helpful and quick. 
I will be returning.
author: Jill H.

description:
I feel kind of guilty giving really nice little Piccino, with it's cute eat outsid fun and obvious passion for fresh farmed organic goods an A-OK! three stars but I do have a few points of constructive criticism from someone who truly loves this sweet little place.

The first---menu options are slim. Even the pizza options only include like 6 pizzas and the simple margerita is by far the best, funghi is too strong, but I could house like 5 of the margeritas at one time.
