Two--if your cafe a door down is where you get the coffee for the restaurant customers, then you have to be prepared to catch a little flack when our coffee that we ordered at the beginning of our brunch is not ready until after we finished our meal because the cafe 'is really busy'. Of course it's busy. It is Sunday morning and your coffee is DELICIOUS.  But now you are dealing with making a restaurant guest's experience 3 star instead of 4. Am I wrong to think that you should either plan for this kind of back-up, prioritize restaurant guests or have another coffee system going for diners?

Third--unfortunately, your desserts/baked goods leave something to be desired. (with the exception of the muffins which are fluffy, melt in your mouth, buckwheat? delicious) There is not that same uumpf and attention to detail that you put into the fabulous little pizzas with their fine flour crust and smooth sauce.  

My wholehearted recommendation if you go there is sit outside,don't be too hungry, get a special salad, get a margherita pizza and a glass of wine or cappuccino but you might regret paying the $$$ for the other items on the menu.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Look. I'm NOT a coffee snob at all. Never had anything other than drip coffee. I usually just throw whatever drip coffee in and/or around my mouth to wake up in the morning. 

When i walked into the tiny little coffee shop (very tiny, could fit about 7 customers), I noticed their 2.50 price for a small cup of drip coffee. I knew something was up. The Australian gentleman makes each cup of drip coffee individually. No machine dripped coffee. No giant tub of drip sitting there since 4 hours ago. This cup of drip was made just for me!

The coffee was delicious. I'm not going to tell you that this was a life changing experience or coffee is no longer considered coffee but poop unless it's made here or something...it was just a damn good fresh cup of coffee.

My gripe is that this place did not have a convenient place to sit and drink your coffee. The place is very small and I couldn't sit down to drink my coffee inside, and the outside benches fit 3 people and they were taken. Would love it if they just set some chairs out for the people who just want to sit and enjoy the coffee.
author: Ronny D.

description:
Excellent!

Went here with a group of 6. When I initially called to reserve, the woman who answered the phone was very helpful and friendly, even giving me tips for reservation strategy for groups.

When we arrived, we were seated at a communal table near the door.  When we asked to move because we were too cold, they accommodated our request.

The starters we had were transcendent:
Farmers cheese
Polpete
Something else delicious I can't remember

I had the pea shoot pizza and it was delicious. Flavorful and complex with a good bit of Meyer lemon essence.  I also tried my boyfriend's handmade pasta dish, which was excellent.  Pasta was fresh with a good texture and was very flavorful.

My only complaint is that the seats were not comfortable.  Yes, this might seem weird but it greatly affects my dining experience.  The chairs were too low, we felt like we needed booster seats, and not very plush.

Other than that issue, a great experience!
author: E C.

description: We used to live in the Dogpatch, and we used to eat at Piccino about once a week when it was a tiny spot that seated about 10 people. What a bittersweet memory. Of course, we have since been back and been bowled over by the "new" much larger location just a block down from where the restaurant originally was. The food is still great, and the salsiccia pizza was delicious as ever. Come ready to share smaller plates, all of which are delicious and prepared with great care.
author: Jill K.

description: Been to the new location and the food is much better, still too pricey/pretentious for the quality/serving size of the food in my opinion but better than my first impression. Some items are interesting, pizzas are good.
author: caro S.

description: Terrible Service - Our waiter Seth was absolutely the worst waiter I have had in my years of eating out at restaurants. Also, this restaurant is not baby friendly. Not sure why people are raving about the food here. The pizza was ok -- Zero Zero has way better pizza and service compared to this place. I won't even try to compare this with Flour+Water. Anyways, quite disappointed with the whole experience. In all honesty, I would give it negative stars...but can't do that.
author: LucidEye B.

description:
A solid place to go to if you live in the Potrero/Dog Patch 'hood.  Food is all local and seasonal which makes it extra tasty!

Not a huge amount of meat on the menu (which I prefer). We started off with the antipasti platter which housed: radishes, carrots, olives, flat bread and something slightly reminiscent of hummus. We later dived into pizza, Margarita for me and Napoletana for him,  and our out of towner enjoyed the daily special, Veggie Risoto.  I added the two eggs onto my Margarita pizza, which was a mistake. I had imagined that these two eggs would be slightly runny and glide all over my pizza, when in fact they were practically hard boiled. My mouth and stomach were confused, is this dinner or breakfast?  Again, tasty, but just not what i was expecting.

Since it was a birthday we got the birthday boy the flour-less chocolate cake as well as split the panna cotta. The panna cotta was AH MA ZING!!

The service was great!!! Our waitress was very friendly, attentive and as cute as a button! The size of the restaurant is rather small, so not a good place to go for groups larger then 4, a date night when you want to mention unmentionables or for those with children as you sit very close to your fellow neighbor.
author: Rana A.

description:
It is really sad to see this once favorite place become what it is now.  While the quality of the food at Piccino is good, it is entirely overpriced for the "tapas" size portions.  I recently had their trout entree and it was probably a 2 oz. portion of trout with 4 halves or fingerling potatoes (i.e. small potatoes) and a small garnish of a vegetable for $20!!  It appears that moving to a bigger space has caused their prices to increase and their portions to shrink.  Anyway, I'm all for reducing the typical American restaurant serving size but not to appetizer portions at entree prices.

If you are really hungry, you are probably better off going somewhere else like 18th street.  There you will get some excellent food and not feel you were overcharged for what you got.
author: Bettyann C.

description: Excellent!  Pizzas were superb, meatballs w sauce tender and tasty, chocolate cake spot on, lovely pinot. No IPA but the APA (American Pale Ale) was exceptional.   Friendly crowd at the bar. Modern clean decor.  Will make this a destination.
author: Art A.

description:
I love this place!

A friend of mine took my family and I here and immediately fell in love with the place. The aromas smelled were vibrant and the restaurant, was small, quaint, and had a fresh young appeal to it. The weather was so awesome that we wanted to sit outside but all the tables were taken. 

Between the 3.5 of us, we ordered 3 pizzas, a house salad that my friend and I shared, while my husband tried the soup of the day, Moraccan soup. The 3 pizza's we ordered were Margherita, Bianca (we added sausage), and Funghi. All 3 were exceptional!! The Bianca had a kick to it because it had chili oil and the sausage was homemade and VERY delicious. The pizzas are about 12" perhaps a little bigger and they are super thin crust pizzas. 

Food comes out a little slower than other places, perhaps because everything is made to order and very fresh. I don't mind the wait at all, especially since the food is quality!

We wanted to try the Zeppoli's (Italian donuts!) but we ran out of time because we needed to head to a party. It looked sooo good though. The lemon tart sounded good too!

We will definitely be coming back for more and I hope you all try it too.
author: Jenn V.

description: Came here on a Sunday with my girlfriend and her family and I was very impressed. I've always been a fan of the Dogpatch area and this is just another reason to come. They know how to do pizza right, so really anything on the menu is a great choice. The one thing I recommend is ordering a few of them, because the pizza will vanish before you know it and you'll probably still be hungry. Definitely coming back here soon!
author: Michael N.

description: This place is transformed.  The new location is fantastic.  The pizza (especially the funghi with an egg added on top) is stellar.  The cauliflower with farro is mouth watering.  Whatever soup is on tap is worth every penny times two.  The desserts are housemade and off the charts.  And, the coffee... Not only do they sell Sight Glass beans (some of the best along with Blue Bottle and Stumptown, which isn't available in SF yet), they have expert baristas preparing the shots and milk.  I have been to more than one outpost that sells another outfit's highly fussed over beans and been sorely disappointed (see Blue Bottle beans at Summit Coffeehouse or Sight Glass beans at Dolores Park Cafe).  Piccino walks the walk.  They are dialed in in the best ways possible: local, sustainable, conscious and friendly in a way that is all too rare in SF
author: Andrew P.

description: Excellent food....everything from starters to desserts!  Started with lentil and lettuce soup that was rich with broth but not overly salty, plenty of veggies. Had the house famous meatballs that were succulent and spicy. Shared a brisket sandwich on a crunchy on the outside but soft on the outside urban bun, cherry tomatoes and spinach that complimented the BBQ sauce. Waitress was extremely helpful with an appropriate wine selection. Cute place, will definitely go back!
author: P G.

description: I love Sightglass coffee, which is what they roast. Friendly people too. Great espresso and personal drip. Don't expect speed, though. Especially when there is a line. Worth the wait.
author: sam l.

description:
must say I was completely and utterly disappointed.

we had a 8:15 reservation and didn't get seated until a little past 8:50. we were starving at this point.

 I didn't choose the restaurant but when I checked out the menu there wasn't much I was going to like or wasn't allergic to. I ate a little bit of everything anyways...not worth the stomach ache I got after for eating wheat based items.


ordered 3 pizzas to start
funghi:  roasted mushrooms, stracchino and shaved garlic - had a bite and it was good but i'm not huge on mushrooms (this was everyones favorite)

salsiccia:  house made sausage, mozzarella and red onion - my fav of the 3 pretty tasty

pancetta:  tomato, broccoli shoots, meyer lemon, garlic confit and romano - i liked everything but the meyer lemon part, it was too strong and it overpowered many of the other flavors

margherita:  tomato, mozzarella and fresh oregano- had a slice from the other side of the table and it was so bland

asparagus soup, fried shallots and chervil - was probably one of the better things but it was just ok

baked semolina gnocchi, poached egg, root vegetable caponata, black olive and dried plum- such a huge disappointment, everyone who tried a bite said it was "interesting" not a good interesting but a kind of huh? weird. I had 2 bites just to make sure and I gave it back to my bf to finish off, which he didn't

leg of lamb, cranberry beans, kale and salsa verde - everyone at the table enjoyed this dish, but I thought that it was just ok, it was cooked well but i think it was thyme? or some other spice which just overpowered the entire dish

pork and beef polpette, crushed tomatoes and parmesan- this was GOOD! I stole a meatball from my sis and it was delicious...unfortunately I had filled up on other items from our meal that just weren't as tasty. sigh...

dessert- was an affogato with amaretto ice cream and it was yums!
author: Bon N.

description: It was outstanding when they served blue bottle coffee... but... they recently switched and the quality is noticeably inferior.  Sad,  this was my favorite cup of coffee in SF but they clearly need to make better margins to support their recent remodel
author: MLK R.

description: Pizza is delightful. I go here to get better cooking my own when I cannot visit San Fran.  The environment is wonderful with an open kitchen, wood furniture, great people and a lot of windows to let in light.
author: Derek Y.

description: I'm not going to lie.  The funghi pizza looks unappetizing.  It looks like someone made the pizza out of dirt.  However, it's actually one of my favorite pizza's in the city.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and in a nice remote location in the city.  Easy parking and perfect for a long lunch break during a rare sunny day.  They have a nice selection of wine.  I've tried a bunch of Piccino's other pizza.  I also recommend the mais pizza.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
I am a sucker for a thin-crust pizza with simple, delicious toppings, a good red sauce (had the Margherita) and some hot pepper flakes sprinkled abundantly on top just before I take a bite. 

The pizza itself is almost on par with Pizzeria Delfina, the thing that makes me put 5-stars v. 4-stars, pretty awesome not to have long wait or crowded restaurant for some more than decent slices, piping hot from the oven in minutes.

Add to that the relaxing ambiance, no rush dinner with my sister who I rarely get to spend time with, the great service, good glasses of wine (Merlot and Nebbiolo) yummy salad (arugula w/corn) and dessert ("apricot" gallette, we think it was peach actually with freshly whipped whip cream) and yes, I give it 5-stars.

Also pluses: plentiful street parking, baby-friendly (but not obtrusive) and heat lamps outside. 

Around the corner is Yield Wine bar, start there and make a night of it. 

Finish the meal with some Blue Bottle coffee.
author: Abby W.

description:
Piccino is one of my favorite places to go with my family. I've been for lunch and dinner and both were great. We normally skip the starters and go straight for the pizza, which is incredible. I'm obsessed with the Bianca, but we always opt for family style so we can sample their seasonal pizzas as well. The service has always been great, and the waiters are friendly and helpful with the wine selection.  
 
I'd recommend making a reservation, unless you don't mind being seated at the bar or a communal table. If you have time before you're seated you should check out the store next door. It's expensive, but they have a gorgeous selection and it's always nice to look around.
author: Ranee B.

description:
I visited Piccino for dinner multiple times over the past year since I lived super close and always felt ripped off by the time I was finished with my food. I love the appearance of the location from the street with the outside seating. It looks great from a distance, but he inside is a different story. The inside of the restaurant is uninspired and the metal on the tables is peeling back and will probably rip some peoples clothes as they maneuver around the cramped space. 

The service was only fair on my visits. My biggest problem with Piccino is how skimpy they are with their toppings and cheese on their pizzas for the price. I would give them four stars for taste for their pizzas however every time a pie is delivered to your table you feel like their trying to save money on every part of the pizza. I remember coming home from work one time, looking across the street at a lady eating a slice of Margherita and it had the tiniest piece of cheese in a sea of red. Come on, just add a little bit more to your pies and I'll increase the rating. It's not the worst place in the neighborhood, but it isn't the best either.
author: T O.

description: If you're looking for fresh, local and simple but incredibly tasty food with an Italian twist, this is the place for you.  You can fill up without feeling heavy, and the space is welcoming and comfortable with Eames seats or wooden benches, and an open dining room with high ceilings and a view of the kitchen.  Their pizzas have a wonderfully thin crust and are complemented with lots of greens and tasty cheeses.  Super yummy all around.
author: Amy C.

description:
I am really into Piccino in the Dogpatch area.  This great cafe serves thin crust pizzas, soup/salad, and unique desserts all made with organic ingredients.

I ordered their red lentil and lime soup along with their baby lettuce salad with parmesan and herb vinaigrette.  You can't escape the freshness of both as they are light and tasty.

Also we order their mushroom (funghi) pizza.  Instead of tomato sauce, the pizza has finely grated mushrooms on top, garlic thinly sliced (using a mandoline, I think), and crescenza which is similar to brie as the cheese.  This is one of the more unique pizzas I've had and I highly recommend it.

For dessert, they served a blood orange upside down cake w/ organic whipped cream.  Think pineapple upside down with dark oranges.  Up to this point, I thought I couldn't be more wowed over.  But I was and it was a great ending to a lovely lunch.

Piccino, by now I guess you know that you are the bomb diggity for lunch!
author: Janet H.

description: Great food! Went on a Thursday night and the place was pleasantly busy. Very nice service and ambiance!
author: Massimo L.

description:
Went for lunch December 1st. We had a delicious pizza and a salad. The pizza had a crispy  crust and just the right amount of toppings; rosemary, peppers, a delicious cheese and seared arugula. 
They have a small but nice wine menu.
The service was great, our waiter was amazing, he was very knowledgable and made everything sound so good, and he was right!
author: Sharon B.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee a little too bitter for me...even with the pints of half-and-half I dump in mine. But other peeps love it. So think that aspect is just me. Stars intact.

However, those making the coffee pretty much always seem to be concentrating the majority of their effort in maintaining the stereo-typical coffeehouse 'tude. Much prefer the vibe at Farley's. Knock a star. 

The food is really delicious...dined there party of two. Had an awesome special of house meatballs and a pizza...gem salad for an app...lemon tart for dessert. The tab was about $80, but we were still actually pretty hungry when we left. Hence, another star bites the dust.
author: Elle N M.

description:
this is your quintessential coffee bar. it's a walk-up that's part inside and part outside. this is a neighborhood coffee spot that makes you a single cup drip or the barista whips up your fancy. the coffee is high quality, but not too high a price. the treats and snacks though are to die for. not even enough of the locals know how good they are as the chef's just play each day inventing little delights that often get passed up.

if you're a blue bottle type or seek out coffee joints, you have to come visit us in the 'patch.
author: Darin A.

description:
This was easily the worst service I've experienced in a long time. We arrived a little after noon and were told that no tables were available, despite the fact that there were obviously open tables and seats at the bar. We pointed out the seats at the bar and were seated. We then proceeded to wait over an hour for a pizza and two paninis. The tables that were seated after us received their food and were halfway through their meals while we still hadn't seen our food. We asked what was up and were told that the food would be right out, but ten minutes later, still nothing. At this point, my dad had to be back at work so we finally just asked for the food to go - there were no explanations or apologies for the bad service. 

*Let me repeat- over an hour for one pizza and two paninis, one of which we could see them making right before they finally handed it to us after we told them we needed to get going.*

My first thought at their initial rudeness and the poor service that followed was that they were treating us like crap because my dad was in his work coveralls (and his coveralls were clean before you say he shouldn't have been eating at a nice restaurant or some b.s. like that)- he's a mechanic for the city of SF (that's right, he keeps your damn roads paved and clean). If that was the case, that is SUPER LAME, and you should learn to appreciate the people who keep this city running - just because he's blue collar doesn't mean he doesn't appreciate good food. And if you didn't want to serve us for whatever reason, maybe you should have just said so rather than seating us and then acting like dicks.

So although the food was actually pretty good (thus the two stars), we will not be returning - there are plenty of places in this city with amazing food and the service to match.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Great coffee, great hot chocolate, and the best thumbprint cookies ever! I wish I could learn how to make thumbprint cookies this good. The service is very friendly and fairly mellow.

This place makes me love my neighborhood all the more!
author: Holly T.

description:
Everything I love about San Francisco cuisine in a small, tidy pizza shop. It's a quintessential Bay Area culinary experience. From the organic and fresh local ingredients used to make every single thing on the menu, to the ridiculously high quality of the accompaniments (blue bottle coffee, local beer and wine) Piccino is like the restaurant you wish you were at when you're stuck at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market on a crowded weekend.

Piccino is a tiny, tiny pizza shop tucked away on a tiny, tiny, corner of the tiny, tiny Dogpatch neighborhood. If you've never been to the Dogpatch before, it's OK. I've lived here my whole life and only found out about its existence when it became relevant a few short years ago. It's super-charming. It's like Portrero Hill, but even charmier and with less of a view. This location does wonders for not making it a busy mob scene, for parking easily, and for enjoying the fun-ness of the city without all the drawbacks. 

The pizza itself is a wonderfully yielding-but-crispy thin crust with the most organic-tasting tomato sauce on this planet. The pepperoni is locally made and completely worth it. The salads couldn't look greener if they painted them. Lastly, the ice tea is fresh and organic as well.

The service is efficient and done with a smile. Not a southern "honey" kind of smile, but a more modest and non-condescending "of course this pizza rules" smile that you can only understand and appreciate if you're a Bay Area native. 

We all all live here because we search for the best things in life - the best landscape, the best weather, the best technology, the best architecture, the best wine, and, of course, the best food. Piccino reminds me why it is that I live here. And it makes me smile.
author: Tolga E.

description: Quite honestly I was very disappointed with Piccino. It's like 2 blocks from my house and I had been meaning to try it for over a year. I finally did, and found that the pizza was just blah, and very overpriced. Two of us, mid afternoon for one pizza to share and a beer for each of us: $50 with tip?? Hmmm... not to mention once we were served our pizza, we had not one person stop by our table to check in on us. In that tiny place? Where there were like 5 people working? And not an offer of more water, dessert (not that I would have paid or it at that point anyway) or just to see if we were satisfied? Boo Piccino, Boo.
author: Rob G.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants of all time.  They care about everything they do and care about their community and it shows.  I moved from SF to Ferndale not long ago, but before I left, Piccino was my favorite place to eat and my favorite place to get coffee. 

I could be having the worst day, but an hour here and I would feel on top of it all.  

Fantastic Pizzas!!!  MY fav is the mushroom pesto with two eggs on top - yes eggs - ask for it you will not regret it.

All of their salads are perfect.  Many dishes are served with fresh pickles veggies they do there.  Their soups are also perfect - one of my favorite all time soups was a nettle soup I had their.

Their wine list is inspirational.  

Their deserts are always a treat - one of my favs to date was a burnt caramel iced cream served with nice torte.

The service is always awesome - this is a place that is easy to become a regular at and that experience is a treasure.  

I sure miss you guys - I will be back down soon!
author: andrei h.

description: My sister told me they switched from Blue Bottle to Sightglass coffee, which she does not enjoy as much.  I thought it was still pretty good, probably because I like Sightglass anyway.  I pretty much stop in here every time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Seong P.

description:
I was there to have a late lunch on Sunday afternoon.  Their pizza is unbelievable!  Probably the one of best pizza around the town.  Though it took a while, but it definitely worth the waiting.

I had their daily Contorno, which was cooked tomato filled with barley.  It was also great.  It's easy to tell that these guys truly understand their materials and cook them well.

The atmosphere was great in Dogpatch with sunny sky in this lazy afternoon.  And a sip of espresso after the meal really made it a perfect sunday afternoon.
author: YC L.

description: Amazing flavors, roasted carrots, house-made sausage pizza, super nice staff even replaced my half full wine when a little green bug jumped in my glass ( don't worry we were outside eating on the dog-friendly patio). We will definitely be back- and just for fun it's hipster-watching paradise! Go to the amazing Mysterious ice cream shop two blocks down for the perfect sweet treat.
author: Spunky M.

description:
A good though tiny restaurant, I've been here maybe four or so times over the last year. Fresh, seasonal produce; trendy but simple decor; great and very friendly staff.

However, I can't give them any more than 3 stars based on what you get for the money. Everything I've tried has just been ok - fresh, good perhaps for a quick weeknight dinner - but nothing that really stands out. There was something missing from every salad, soup, pasta or main meal that I've tried. I think their dressings and broths are their downfall - more flavor needed (and some bread would help). If they could improve the food this place could be great.
author: Pete F.

description: Knowledgable staff and great ambiance. Sat outside facing the pocket park. Delicious pizza. Heard its also great even as a take-out.
author: K P.

description: I've been before and gotten an amazing cup of coffee the last time. This time, though, at 10am on a Sunday and no decaf!?!? I was crushed...she offered me a single shot latte, but that's no decaf and I had to say no. I was crushed...I'm hoping that the coffee bar has (decaf) COFFEE In stock next time I show up.
author: Jason L.

description:
My friends and I love pizza, and had heard great things about Piccino.  While it was good, it wasn't amazing, which it has to be to compete with all of the other great pizza places in SF.  On food alone, I would give Piccino four stars, but I have to agree with many of the previous reviewers on the sub-par service.  We started with the fried brussels sprouts, as well as the chicories salad.  The brussels sprouts were delicious, but I thought the portion size was a bit small for $10.  The salad was good too, like a fancy caesar.  For pizzas, the four of us shared the Salsiccia, Rosmarino, and Pancetta pizzas. The Rosmarino was our favorite, with the squash and gorgonzola making for a great match.  The housemade sausage was good, but there was nothing else special about the salsiccia pizza.  The sauce was very good on the pancetta pizza, as were the cheese and and broccoli shoots (and I don't even like broccoli), but the pancetta was not crispy enough, and I thought it was cut into a weird size.  The crust of all the pizzas were pretty good, but not chewy enough. Both desserts -- the zeppole and the persimmon creme brulee -- were delicious.

However, we couldn't get past our waiter.  He was sort of spacy throughout the meal, more than once taking our order by memory and then halfway through changing his mind to try to write things down.  He was good enough to repeat our orders, which prevented a few mistakes.  But, even after repeating and writing down our dessert orders, he came back a few minutes later and still had the wrong order!  Also, strangely, our first two pizzas came out at the same time, but the third pizza didn't come out until about 10 minutes later.  We were nervous that our waiter forgot about it.  

The wait for our table was a little bit longer than the quoted 45 minutes, but that can sometimes be hard to predict, so I can't ding them for that.  I would probably go back to Piccino if I could get a reservation, but it's not on the top of my SF pizza list.
author: Pilan C.

description:
I work in this neighborhood and go the 3rd street boxing gym every morning so basically i am within 3 blocks of this coffee place from sun up to sun down.
Like most, I really want to like this place, but 95% of the time the service is so SLOW it's excruciating!
The majority of staff simply cannot do more than one thing at a time; multitasking does not exist here,  that means even if there is a line of 8 people, the barista, who most times has his back to everyone and is SLOWLY pouring milk or hot water into something is oblivious that this is in fact someone's business and is relying on them to make customers happy.
Happy customers = successful business($$).
I myself am a business owner and have been in the restaurant/food world for 15+ years and it takes all of my self control not to bellow at the staff to "move it!", as I hear fellow customers grumbling about how service could not be slower.
It makes me wonder if the owner knows how frustrating it is to get coffee here, or maybe is so caught up in the pretense of the hipster coffee culture that he doesn't care.
I will say that they now have quick brew, so if you want a regular cup of coffee it is a bit better.
Please know that we want to love this place, if customer service wasn't an after thought.
author: jennifer S.

description: I love the location, atmosphere and coffee.  The cauliflower dish was very tasty.  The mixed chicory salad had a bit too much dressing and was a little disappointed with the pizzas.  I really wanted to love this place more and might try it again if I am in the area.  Service was okay.
author: Sarah L.

description: One word: AMAZING!!!!  This restaurant is SO cute. The atmosphere is casual/classy and the food is top notch. The cauliflower and farro salad just melts in your mouth. Order the bianca pizza if you are a cheese lover!  Drooling in lots of cheese YET does not feel heavy at all. The pizza is thin crust. Big enough to share, but I guarantee you won't want to!  The service is a bit slow, but if it makes sense at all, slow in a good way...so you can enjoy conversation with the person you are with and not overbearing by coming by every 2 seconds. We didn't have a reservation, but went at 6pm and we were able to be seated at the bar, which, IMHO, is the best spot in the house because you can watch the cooks make all the food :) This is going to be my new regular spot for sure! :)
author: Nicole M.

description:
Excellent food and service.  The ingredients used are always seasonal and delicious.  Today we had the asparagus salad w/ sieved egg. OMG the asparagus was the freshest I've tasted in a long time.  We shared the mushroom pizza and was super pleased.  You have to like mushroom as it was spread all across like a paste. Service is always friendly and efficient.  A true local gem. 

Another plus is they are dog friendly...many table outside to enjoy your meal with your pooch.
author: Puff G.

description:
Popped in for a bite after a site visit on 20th and Wisconsin today.  I was hungry.  Really hungry.  Admittedly, the person directing us to this spot was not quite sure of their breakfast menu

My cappuccino was good.  Really good.   My apple tart wasn't so good, sort of tasted like a drier version of the ones at the organic bakery on 18th Street in Potrero.   

Mediocre ambiance and there was ground pepper floating in the water carafe given to our table.  But seriously, the cappuccino was really good.
author: Gabrielle K.

description:
The coffee is noticeably better than average coffee because it's Blue Bottle. I was particularly impressed by the one guy manning the bar by himself on a busy Friday morning. He took orders, skillfully made the drinks, and even made one of those glorious leaf patterns on the top of my latte. And it was tasty - really tasty. Take note that this place is cash only (and there isn't an ATM nearby). 

Those of you that complain about the prices - don't really know where that is coming from because it's comparable to Starbucks or Peet's and the quality is really up there (infinitely better than Starbucks at least).
author: Sherene C.

description:
I develop inappropriate crushes.  Not inappropriate in the sense that they're wrong - I just develop instant unrequited love for the one thing/person nobody thinks is crushworthy.

The adorable (but old) science teacher in high school with the habit of talking to frogs.

My neighbor's ugly-as-sin, half-dead, bald, bitchy, rescued and NOT grateful pomeranian.

Piccino's tarts.

I know, I know, I should have fallen for their delicious flatbread pizzas, that's what everyone else raves about.  That's what they're known for.

But no - I fell into complete, passionate, headlong love with the most decadently delicious tarts.  And I'm so weak...I love both the lemon and the orange-glazed chocolate.  *sigh*

My one consolation...I'm pretty sure the chocolate tart loves me back just a little bit.
author: Suzanne B.

description: As a frequent customer of this great restaurant and cafe, after visiting today I am yelping for the first time ever. Disregarding the advice of friends who were also regulars and no longer go to the cafe section of piccino because they have been saying that the coffee has gone down hill I turned up this morning and ordered my iced latte. My coffee tasted terrible- like the machine was dirty- and after having my friend taste it and agree I decided to take it back and ask for a drip coffee. When I told the girl taking orders that my coffee tasted bad and that I'd like to swap it for a drip coffee she sniggered at me and poured me a drip coffee and asked me for $3.75.  I asked if she was really going to charge me for a replacement for bad product and she said "I'm sorry if you don't like our coffee... We keep our machines clean..etc". I asked if she'd heard the saying "the customer is always right ?" And that I'd owned a cafe for years and knew the taste of a dirty machine. At this point the barista came to her senses and told her to just give me the replacement and she did. Sniggering again. That'll be my last visit to the cafe- the restaurant is always amazing- I'm joining my growing list of local friends who are boycotting their coffee! Congratulations lank blonde hipster girl- you go on feeling righteous.... But we are voting with our feet!!
author: Eszter M.

description:
Piccino was the perfect place to end a girls' night out.  We unwound at Yield, and then sauntered over to probably the tiniest restaurant I've seen.  There were tables aplenty at the moment, so we sat right down and ordered up some delicious treats from a super-friendly waitstaff.

The thin-crust pizza was indeed "wafer thin," and had a nice sauce and composition.  I approve.  But oh, the tarts...  tender, buttery crusts, vivid fillings.  You could tell they'd been baked by someone passionate about dessert.  

If you want to stalk me, start here.  Because this is my new favorite restaurant.  If I'm not there, grab a table and call me -- I'll be there in a jiffy.
author: Andi T.

description:
First off - if you're going to serve me wine for $9.50 per glass, I'd appreciate nice, big wine glasses.  Not little water cups.
 
Second - if you're going to serve me salad - - I'd appreciate non-wilted greens.
 
Third - I don't like pizza.  That said, yours was decent, but didn't bring me even one step closer to liking pizza.  It was OK, though.  Your Pancetta Pizza was pretty good - the sausage was pretty good, but your Margherita was really mediocre.
 
Fourth - I don't like Lemon Tart, but since that was the only dessert we ordered,  and I have to say that was the best lemon tart I have had to date.
 
Fifth - wow, I can't believe how small this place is - - only some 4 tables inside, but then kudos for having ample seating OUTSIDE with some mega-powerful heat lamps.  We hung out there for a bit after dinner and I felt FRIED.
 
Sixth  - and most definitely not the least - - you serve Blue Bottle Coffee.  And it was  good.  But you don't' stock Equal.  What a cruel joke....

Seventh - Service was really nice, especially by one girl. The other - not  so much, but the first lady made up for it.
 
Finally - -  the final total.  For mere pizza, salad, and alcohol - - I thought it was entirely too expensive.  It wasn't the cost of the pizza actually - it was  the cost of the wine, bringing me back to point #1 - - you know, the one they serve in itty bitty water cups?
author: Grace K.

description: Very poor pizza. I dont know how anyone can call it gourmet...more like off the kids menu. The poor service didnt help. I think the reviews are from owners friends. The pizza was that bad. Eat at Tony's for real SF pizza not this hipster crap.Skinny people dont know food
author: Morris L.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee.......yet.....in a clean enviroment.......with seating.... and no line??? 

It is true. They make a damn fine latte, and I will be back for more.

*disclaimer - I have not eaten here, I might not ever eat here, I dont need to eat here when the coffee is this good
author: Drue C.

description:
Piccino is one of my/my families absolute favorite place to eat.  The food is incredible!
  
We've been coming to the restaurant for years now, when it was just around the corner in a tiny space.   We loved it then, but since expanding to the larger space, their menu has expanded as well.  Their pizza's are always delicious and offer delicious and interesting choices depending on what's in season but what I love more than anything is the great variety of interesting choices when it comes to vegetable dishes.  Their salad's, soup's and vegetables are always beautiful and delicious.  Following the seasons and what's available locally, they prepare gorgeous entree's as well.

So often these days restaurants use words like "seasonal" and "local" as buzzwords to attract business, but Piccino is the real deal!

Highly recommend it!
author: Monique D.

description: Everything we had was great! Even the simple green salad had special purpley arugula-looking lettuce. On the menu is some of the best thin crust pizza I've ever had. Friendly and sociable staff and interesting wine offers.
author: sarah m.

description:
Whoa, it's not just the Blue Bottle beans. And I don't think of myself as a coffee snob or fiend, but this place might just make me into one.

I had given up on mochas - made with too sweet syrup, too bitter chalky albeit real cocoa powder, some combo of the two that sometimes I suspect might have a brown bunny on the canister. And that's even at "good" coffee places. I decided on my first visit to renew my faith in chocolate plus coffee, and I had the best mocha I've ever had complete with chocolate shavings on top. Brian is also a genuinely super friendly and knowledgeable barista. They all take the time to even make a sweet heart in your foam.

They also have fine pastries and possibly the best scone I've ever had studded with candied ginger (looove ginger anything) - not the leaden rocks you might get at other places. I think the light crumb might be pastry flour instead of all purpose. It's hard to find a place that has both amazing coffee and pastries.

Only thing is while it's worth the price, and I wouldn't subtract a star for it at all, I can't afford to make it into a daily habit or even close so it will remain a well deserved treat.
author: Myla A.

description:
Wow, this place has been open for one month people!  Geez, yelp leaves no new restaurant un-reviewed.  Went in today with the boyfriend to check it out.  A friendly, jovial grey haired curly man was making beautiful espresso drinks with those beautiful and cute foam hearts on top. 
The restaurant's hours seem odd and I get the impression that this place is a labor of love and that-rather than a place that the owner is betting his chips on it's success-it has an air of casual fun.  As in, I feel that the owner may have awoken one morning and decided that this might just be a dream of his.  These aren't facts mind you...I don't know the complete true story.  But I'd like to come back and check it out further...
author: Lauren S.

description:
UPDATE: Piccino is now serving weekend brunch and dinner (not sure which nights)!  Brunch consists of pastries, pre-prepared dishes like quiche and hash, and of course their amazingly great Blue Bottle cappuccino.

Food: 5
Decor: 4
Service: 4 (friendly but forgetful)
Ambience: 4 (it's hard for a cafe to earn 5 in my book)

Stopped in for take-out lunch today and walked out with a Napoletana pizza (tomato sauce, black olives, and anchovies - no cheese) and their celery root, egg & horseradish salad.  YUM!

The pizza was delectable.  A thin and perfectly crunchy crust that I'd eat by itself.  Excellent and expertly applied tomato sauce.  This is not a million-calorie job that will satiate a small family, but it was a perfect size for me to tackle for lunch.  I only had room left for a few nibbles of the salad, so I finished it with my dinner.  The egg and horseradish are really unique and play well together.  A great, healthy salad, all in all.

I look forward to trying the blue bottle coffee and pastries sometime soon -- the apple-tea cake on display looked scrumptious!

I asked about the Pizzetta 211 connection and the waiter confirmed that one of the owners of Piccino used to work at Pizzetta 211.  I love Pizzetta 211 and can see the attention to great pizza shining through.  As far as the weird hours are concerned, I heard that they're just getting going and will expand their hours soon.  I sure hope so as it's hard for me to make it there on a weekday for lunch.
author: Nate B.

description: Neighborhood yumminess! We walked into Piccino with relatively no wait on a late Sunday morning (almost impossible in our hood and surrounding areas). Had the super intense BLT sandwiches....the BACON was super yum! Felt their menu was a bit limited with no brunch items....just some sandwiches and pizzas. For such a great spot I wish they would expand their menu then I'd be back ever more frequently!
author: Lee M.

description: One of my girlfriends introduced me to this place in the Dogpatch. I really enjoyed our lunch there. The food was simple, fresh and honest. I had their chicken and beets panini, it was not a combination that I'm used to but it was really tasty. The beets were really sweet and the chicken breast was not too dry. It came with a side of salad that was also delicious. Their menu changes constantly which is also great because then you don't get tired of eating the same thing over and over again. The dining room is very simple and clean, lots of natural finishes and textures. I'd like to think that this is a reflection of their food.
author: Lai T.

description:
Tasty food.  Crummy service.    I'd like to give a 3.5

Waited over 25 minutes to just get seated, the table cleaned off in front of us and our bottle of wine order placed at 2pm on a Wed afternoon.  Granted, the server was by herself, and I did give her the look of empathy and told her "no worries."  I should have specified  "no worries for another 5 minutes," not another 20!  

Delish pizza.  Ultra thin crust, nice amount of acidity in the tomato sauce.   Nice to walk down the street to get a Blue Bottle at their coffee shop to go after.  BUT....don't go, or it will take even longer to place a drink order!
author: Elle S.

description:
I really want to like Piccino more.  The space is gorgeous and has a really nice vibe.  I love the Dogpatch neighborhood and was excited to have a cool restaurant there to visit.  

However, the food is really uneven.  The starters were really off, especially the mini-size portion of the fried green tomatoes.  There are so many incredible thin crust pizza places in this city, theirs fell short.  The pizza was just unsatisfying and not that flavorful.  I ended the meal feeling like I needed dessert, which I never feel I need after pizza.  Unfortunately, we ordered some.  Again, tiny portions and a tart with an extremely dry crust.  Sad.
author: Kate F.

description:
So good we got the reg. margerita side anchovies for me
the polenta with beets
will return
almost as good as ny pizza!!!
author: Denise n.

description:
EDIT: I previously redacted my snarky comments about the overall attitude at this cafe. I moderated my post in the interest of good neighborship. 

I now de-redact as follows: The management must have said to staff: "Treat customers like they are guests in your home" BUT this has been interpreted by staff as "Act like these people showed up in your kitchen uninvited and demanded coffee. Treat them like you want them to leave so you can drink all the coffee yourself." 


Review of Piccino for their Coffee Bar only. 
Extremely well-crafted coffee and nice pastries. 
One-Cup-Drip is labor intensive, compared to other ways of preparing coffee. Don't go if you're in a hurry or late for work.
author: steve m.

description:
Did I eat at the same place as all of these other people?  I would definitely say that my experience here has left a gnarly taste in my mouth...literally.  

Yes, it's totally cyuuute.  No, the food did not taste good.  

You could call this a leisurely dining experience because we got our salads after about 45 minutes after ordering.  And after waiting...and waiting...and waiting, one of the three random people waiting on us had no other choice than to give us a free bottle of wine.  And finally...the main, and very disappointing, course.  By this time we were inching onto hour 2.  I can only speak for four out of five of us at the table because only four of us actually got our food.   After about 15 minutes we were finally able to get someone's attention, and all they could say was that the entree had been ready and they just forgot to bring it out.

At this point I was about to eat the Ikea silverware that sat before me, so I ate the pathetic excuse for a Margarita Pizza that was served to me.  It had some lukewarm tomato paste and a few pieces of half melted cheddar.   Totally not worth the 14 bones I had to throw down.

Let's just say, that if I had to choose between Piccino and Pizza Hut, I'd go for the stuffed crust any day.
author: Cims B.

description:
One thing about Piccino that you can't help noticing is that it's tiny. I mean that's the namesake and all, but it's a good warning that you should be prepared to wait for a table, as there are about four inside and maybe twice that outside. I went for lunch on a weekday, so there wasn't too much of a wait, and if you can do that, you'll be in good shape. 

Service is friendly and casual, but you're here for the food. Next time perhaps I'll try one of their paninis, but you have to at least try their pizza first time around. Nothing fancy here, the choices are few but that works out fine since the pizzas are all delicious. You should order individually, each pie is perfect for one, and then you'll be able to mix and match. The daily specials give you enough variety to make this a regular destination as well. 

I hear their weekend brunch (they serve Blue Bottle Coffee!) is packed, but maybe with Just For You down the street, you'll have a shot at one or the other. 

If I lived in the Dogpatch, I'd definitely hang out here more often. On a sunny afternoon, on my way to work, after work with a glass of wine (a small but tasty "under the radar" selection of Italian), Piccino would become that perfect neighborhood cafe (that just happened to serve phenomenal pizza, capable of attracting foodies from all over).
author: Nish N.

description: Got a macchiato today. The coffee was so sour it was undrinkable. My friends got some too. We all agreed it was one of the worst coffee experiences ever.
author: Thomas K.

description:
When I went to Gialino's, my friend suggested I check out Piccino in the Dog Patch. I ventured out there in search of an Italian pizza gem and came back a little uninspired...

The menu is pretty minimalist...so if you aren't looking for lettuce, pizza, or umm...coffee, then go somewhere else!

The skinny on Piccino: everything is mini-me

*3 tables - prepare to wait
*salads are small - eat a snack before you come
*antipasti platter - salami and mortadella are about 1 inch in diameter (the most plentiful thing we got were the crackers that came with it - that was mounded on one of their signature "broken" Academy of the Arts student pottery projects)
*pizza - 5 to choose from - margherita, cheese, pepperoni, anchovies/olives, garlic sausage with pecorino
--= We had the garlic sausage with pecorino...the sausage was few and far between and the cheese was even more so...

I mean, the place was decent. The food wasn't bad, it just wasn't particularly impressive.... I think I'd rather go to Extreme Pizza...
author: Josephine H.

description: I have been to Piccino half a dozen times.  We are long time Potrero Hill Residents and love all our local restaurants, however the last 2 times here have been AWFUL.  Last nights experience pushed me over the edge.  Extremely rude staff.  (we ordered 1 pizza and an order of meatballs for me and my kids and they said it was going to be 1 hour!!!!)  I kindly asked the person i have seen here several times before if she could do it any sooner so i could get my kids fed, and she said, "sorry we have a dining room full of people"...  okayyyyyy...  really, an hour for 1 10 inch pizza and meatballs????  never going back.  They have always acted with a sense of snobbiness and in my opinion, that is a way to run a bad business.  I hope they go out of business and let someone else in the neighborhood move in who knows how to treat local clientele.
author: Matt V.

description:
What an amazing restaurant!  Went there for the first time tonight and it's now one of my top 3 favorites in San Francisco (along with Nopa & Boulevard).  

I was celebrating my friend's graduation from nursing school.  He's been a cook earlier, and therefore I knew I wanted to take him somewhere great.  He suggested Piccino and it was perfect.  

The salmon was delightful - very nicely paired with nectarines.  Great farmers cheese w/ radish & candied meyer lemons.  Excellent felafel appetizer.  Good mushroom pizza (very mushroom-y).  

Definitely worth the trip to the dogpatch.
author: Suzanne A.

description: Worst place to make the mistake of stopping by at 11 am on Sunday if you would like something to eat for brunch. Honestly, I have no idea what to eat here, and I am not an American in the quest for huge portions. While the dish I had was good, certainly did not meet my expectations of leaving the restaurant full.
author: D T.

description:
We really enjoyed this tiny restaurant on quiet corner of the Dogpatch. It's a great place for a date, though not a first since the tables are close together.

Fairly limited menu, which I like. Everything was seasonal, fresh and well executed. Friendly service, not overly attentive, which I also like, especially on a date.

Recommended: Mushroom pizza - richly perfumed and earthy, with a perfect thin crust. Hand-made ravioli.

My only qualm is that they don't serve bread. There was nothing to sop up the excellent sauces. They do have housemade crackers, which are, however, delicious.
author: Joe J.

description: Been here for dinner twice. It's a tiny place with not much seating (aka "cozy"). Pizza was good, maybe a little too salty, but otherwise forgettable. Wine choices were good. I would go back - it's one of the best options in Dogpatch, and better than any of the pizza options on Potrero Hill, but I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.
author: Sam Z.

description: I love this place!  It is so fresh and tasty.  They start with great ingredients and doing fuss around with them more than necessary.  I love their red pizza's because I could drink their tomato sauce, but every grilled vegetable side I have ordered I have also loved.  The environment and staff are so welcoming and friendly.  It is great for a low key night for a pizza and beer.  Try to save some room for the dessert, I had a great rice pudding the one time I managed to save room.  I don't know if it is the fresh ingredients or the smaller (read:  appropriately sized) portions, but I also have never left this place overstuffed or ill from over indulgence, which is key for me.
author: Jean P.

description:
I am going to give this venue a tentative four-star, on the promise of returning for a slightly better experience.

This is truly the tiniest restaurant on the planet. I am talking Pizzetta 211 tiny, only even smaller. 

I guess you have to chill and be patient while you wait for a table. But it was kinda frustrating as there is really nowhere to stand while you wait and they seemed to have given away the spot at the bar to a party of three waiting ahead of us, and all I could think was "toss them out into the cold - we will eat at the bar!".

I am not kidding - this place is so small that when we finally got a table for two it was literally not big enough to put two pies on!

Any ways - the pizza was pretty good after all the waiting (though not as good as 211) and the Steelhead stout was tasty and strong enough to take the edge off. The salad with beets, grapefruits, and nuts was right fresh and tasty and I would have the potato soup again.

The cookie plate was quite scrumptious and the espressos to go-with were perfect.

I will have to return when the weather improves and we can sit outside - at least that will be a more roomy and the wait ill not be so long and uncomfortable. I am looking forward to trying it again.
author: Kingpin X.

description: Extremely tasty food.  Gotta get pizza with egg.  Service was very friendly and willing to accomodate my friend and I sharing our appetizer and soup.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Love the new Piccino. Great space, great staff, awesome food and wines. Even the sound proofing (my personal pet peeve with restaurants in SF) in the new place is awesome, one can actually talk in a normal voice - such a rarity at restaurants these days. 

I would've given them 5 stars, but...the portions! Come on, you guys, please put more " salad" in my $9 salad! It's just hard to justify paying $9 for it..Either make it more fancy or add some salad. I say - add some salad! The same goes for the soup. It's a recession after all. People want to feel like they're getting a good value.
author: Prem M.

description:
Been to this place at least 6 times and I'm blown away every chance they get.
Food was a 6 if i could give it. Had the halibut crudo, it was AMAZING. Carrots in cumin and herb yogurt, was TWICE AS AMAZING. Salads were different every time I go and the latest one with the cucumbers and fried capers was so different from their other strawberry one. Hearty and crisp at the same time, but i can't wait for winter in the hopes they bring back that butternut squash salad with pomegranates. It was so pretty and I still miss it to this day...
author: Matty R.

description:
Piccino has super delicious small pizzas with thin, crisp crust and really zesty tomato sauce. The menu changes daily, but my favorite pizza is the Bianca, which has three cheeses and a lot of garlic. It's a tomato sauce-less pizza, so I ask for it with tomato sauce added. Because each pizza is made to order, it takes about fifteen minutes or so. When it's really busy in the restaurant (it's tiny and very popular) I sometimes have to get someone's attention and point to my finished and already boxed pizza, which is fine... just know that you might have to be assertive. The staff is very friendly and nice, they're just really busy. 

Re: portion size-- a hungry person could eat the whole pizza (six slices), but you can share the pizza and a salad with a co-worker and it's a perfect lunch that doesn't put you into a carbohydrate coma.

The coffee is amazing, and the iced coffee is really amazing... not your average watered down iced coffee that tastes like ashtray (ahem--Starbucks)... it's Blue Bottle coffee, and organic, real milk. (Soy is an option, but it tastes way more delicious with the real milk.)
An extra nice touch is that the staff will give you a glass milk bottle of iced water to drink while you're waiting for your drink or for your lunch to be ready. 

I'm so, so happy Piccino is walking distance from my workplace.
author: Dani Y.

description:
so I have no clue about blue bottle coffee. I dont know if you have to ask for it, or if it's automatically made that way. I know I ordered some coffee concoction with soymilk (lactose) and it was good and all, but not "oh i jizzed my pants over blue bottle" good. And for a coffee bar, that should be what this review is about.

But it's not. it's about the scones. There were like three things in the pastry display, and I got a scone after the nice bearded dude corrected me when I pointed them and asked for a cookie. He told me they were fresh from the oven and clearly an awesome choice (i'm awesome).

I think I ate the scone in 30 seconds flat. it was delicious. it was fresh. it was crunchy, and then soft, and had a light dusting of granulated sugar on the outside. I dont know if they're always this good, but if they always taste like that even when not fresh from the oven, it's just wrong. it's wrong because I'll keep getting them since it's close to my work, even though I'm trying to go vegan. but I just cant say no to delicious baked goods and friendly bearded men.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Disappointment set in mid way through my meal here.  I'd heard a lot about this place and had received personal recommendations to dine here from friends whose foodie credentials I rate highly.  Piccino's is a cute neighbourhood restaurant that has a homely feel to it.  The exposed kitchen is beautiful and the dining room tiny, yet welcoming.  

On the good side, our waiter was excellent.  Friendly, knowledgeable and creator of one of the greatest shots of espresso I've ever had.  The menu is Italian in nature and we ordered up the salumi plate and little gem salad for starters.  The bresaola was lovely, served with a rough houmous like paste and some of the finest tasting olives I've had outside of Italy.  The little gem salad was ok, but i'm not much of a salad guy.

We selected a couple of pizzas for our mains and a baked meatball dish with white polenta.  The meat balls did not hold together well but tasted excellent, a little gamey and well spiced with thyme.  They were served in a light broth that complemented the richness of the meat and the sour note from the broccoli rabe went well with the creamy polenta.  The menu described the polenta as crispy, but it was anything but.

The pizzas were paper thin with toppings to match.  We had a white pizza with three cheeses and garlic as well as my standard, pepperoni.  Both were disappointing with the white pizza largely tasteless somewhat due to the entire absence of seasoning.  The pepperoni was equally as disappointing with very little pepperoni and a similar lack of seasoning.  Some smoked salt would have gone down well on this pie.  The final nail in the pizza's coffin was the paper thin dough.  When baked it came out more like a flatbread than a pizza and whilst i'm sure this is what many people love about the pizza here, I'm afraid I like my pizza to be more neopolitan in character with a thicker, chewy crust.  I presume the dough here is unleavened which would explain things.

Piccino has a lot of potential and is also a young restaurant, with time I hope it irons out some of these flaws as it has some great touches.  Not least the serving of water in old skool milk bottles.

Oh and the waiter pulled an amazing shot of espresso.  I know I mentioned this already but the Blue Bottle coffee at his hand rendered an amazing shot.  It was smooth, not a hint of bitterness and a taste reminiscent of melted Valrhona chocolate and almost earned this place an extra star.
author: Tony S.

description: Seriously the best mocha ever.  Hot choc for adults.
author: Valerie H.

description: The café has good coffee and the pizza here has always been creative without being too weird. Okay maybe white corn and nettles on a pizza is too weird for my Minnesota relatives but I'm not going to let them set the goalposts.
author: Erich V.

description:
Went here for a scrummy brunch on a rainy Saturday morning with our 14 month old. The waitress first asked, 'Are you planning to eat here?'...er, yes...then she asked, 'Would you like to sit outside?'...er, no...when I asked if they had high chairs, the answer was no. 

So...if you have little people with you don't waste your time...we headed to Serpentine where we were warmly greeted, the bloody mary's were AWESOME and delicious food was enjoyed.
author: Jo M.

description: Nice atmosphere, nice food and wine. I like the people and the location is (in my opinion) unusual. Pretty nice for date - romantic, woody and arid (if that makes any sense).
author: Jason B.

description:
I love this place! I am a grad student @ SFAI. I go here as often as I can. The food options are slim and sometimes the service is slower than desired but It's delicious, and lovely atmosphere. The coffee (Blue Bottle !!!!), pizza, salad... are all consistent and amazing. Example: I had Quail with parsnip puree and almost licked the freaking plate! Not to mention the staff is soooo nice! 

Support it! Love it ! Repeat!
author: Alissa P.

description: Small restaurant in cool part of the Dogpatch area.  They were one of the first to start serving the now super trendy thin crust oven baked pizzas, and I like the add an egg option.  Their apps are seasonal and tasty.  Cool restaurant if/when you want a night away from your hood.
author: Andrew R.

description: This is one of my new favorite restaurants now!  We love the restaurant setting, and it's also kid-friendly.  No pressure for bringing our little one.  We had the roasted cauliflower gremolata, butter bean soup, kale & butternut squash salad, baked semolina gnocchi with poached egg, sturgeon panini, squash and fennel pizza, meyer lemon crostata, and cappuccino -- they are all great!!  Will definitely be back for my parent's birthday :)
author: Elena L.

description:
The coffee is great - the australian guy and the asian girl working together what a damn bad move.  The guys mouth doesn't stop long enough to do his job and the girl cannot keep a thought in her head.

Would the owners of this place realize that they need help that actually helps the customers and doesnt try to be everyones friend!

I mean 10 minutes for a good cup of coffee is cool, but having others served before just cuz the "barrista" knows these others? C'mon now!

Folks get the service act together and your stars go up.
author: patrick d.

description: I had a bad experience at Piccino.  I ordered a pizza to go.  It was supposed to have truffles, asparagus, and farm cheese.  Unfortunately, I didn't open it until I got home.  I must of reminded the chef of someone he didn't like or something, because when I got home and opened it up, instead of truffles it had a single sunny side up egg on the top with only two pieces of asperigus.  Needless to say, I haven't gone back.
author: Robin B.

description:
Some people like weekends so they can sleep in.  I like weekends so I can wake up and see the morning the way it was meant to be seen (hint: it's not from a desk).  Rolling into a tiny latte bar at 8:30 Saturday morning to rendezvous with the FUF folks?  Perfect. 

Simply put, the lattes here are artisanal.  Everything is done to perfection, even the stylish cup you get it in.  The mini-scones they have are astoundingly moist, one of the best complements to coffee I've ever had.  They also had foccacia laying out.  Foccacia and coffee? That's so crazy it just might work!  Unfortunately, it was way too oily and salty, so the results of the experiment were tainted.  Nevertheless, it wasn't enough to sully an otherwise perfect experience.  Also, as you may have noticed, they say the pizza is good here too.
author: Wes M.

description: Absolutely the best.  The chocolate chip cookies might be the best i've ever had.  They can pretty much do no wrong, their lattes are invincible.
author: Rick F.

description: Delicious thin crust pizza, warm attentive service, unique desserts. Lots of space
author: Nors P.

description: In between meals menu is rather limited (interesting pickled root vegetables, but still...), limiting our enjoyment of the sunny quiet street tables (dog friendly). No ice tea refill?
author: T G.

description:
Best pizza sauce I have ever had, truly divine. SO fresh tasting, with a hint of basil and only slightly sweet. Salted thin, paper thin, crust that manages to be crispy and soft at the same time and has no tinge of burnt crispers like many a thin crust pizza. 

They have a potato scallion pizza that appears occassionally as a special and it fantastic, over the top in flavor and depth.

The pizzas are not super filling so order one of their great salads (mango) or an appetizer. Nice selection of tasty reds and italian wines. The waitstaff are extremely freindly and helpful. 

A fabulous addition to Dogpatch and a sweet corner location.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
It is, as everyone says, tiny.  Small space, small tables close together, small menu.   The food was carefully made and delicious.   The salad (last night, beets, avocado, frisee) was great.  The non-pizza dishes are very precisely put together, and I rank them right up there with any place anywhere.   The pizzas are good, though I thought the "white" pizza didn't need a bechamel sauce to hold it together.  (The Cheeseboard and Arizmendi do white pizzas just fine, and nary a bechamel in sight.)  (Of course, I'm just not wild about bechamel, and I think it's always a mistake, but others may differ.)   (I think I liked my flatbread at Yield better.  No bechamel.)   

But I really did like the restaurant.  And there's Blue Bottle coffee, and so Piccino is both cafe and restaurant, and a nice addition to the neighborhood.
author: Laurel B.

description:
I'm on a roll this week with hitting up great joints for evening grub and libations. Sampled some fantastic fresh corn soup here with padron peppers to add to the fun. Moved on to a pair of well-executed pizzas - the standard margherita (their version excels on the tomato sauce front) and a first-time combo of taleggio, plums(!), onions, black olives and chili oil. Crust was a little flatbread-like, but surprisingly pleasant. All of this food joy was accompanied (and enhanced) by a carafe of rose. 
Service was irregular but warm. Space cozy and even warmer. Need to come back to try the famed funghi pizza. But for a first visit, this didn't miss a beat.
author: Purnima M.

description:
I wanted to like Piccino so much.  I mean I REALLY wanted to like it.  On paper, much like an internet date, it exceeded all of my requirements:
1.  Out of my neighborhood -- check
2.  Patio dining -- check
3.  Urban, hip, cool and small -- check
4.  Fresh, local and innovative food -- check

But like many internet dates, things are sometimes better on paper...Piccino does have a small menu, letting them focus doing a few things really well.  But when you're out of 2 of 5 starters and it's only 7.30, you have a problem.  1 option as a main is totally acceptable in my book...but not when your other choices are pizzas which literally swim, yes swim, in butter and oil.

Service really could have made up for my lack of culinary enthusiasm, but they really fell flat on this one too.  We realized there was a problem when our server (or should I say one of 4 who kept seeming puzzled that we were there) stopped coming to us.  45 minutes passed.  No flatbread.  FINALLY it arrives.  And by flatbread I mean pre-baked flat breads and dips.  45 minutes really was a bit excessive when you only have 6 tables.

Rather than owning up to having lost our ticket, the server just said "sorry it took so long, here's some free olives" and dropped the food off.  Which they then cleared and brought us our check...without our salads or entrees.

The upside: if you sit outside you can see the folks entering Serpentine down the street and know with smug satisfaction that they are, in fact, having a much better dining experience.
author: Aaron G.

description: When did Piccino move?! I just had dinner in their new location around the corner from their old one, and I love it -- a larger, open, modern space. They still have a yummy menu with various small plates and different pizzas. Their wine menu seems to have expanded a bit.
author: Joel A.

description:
WOW...  I looked at all the other reviews and all I can think is...Is this really the same restaurant?  I counted 13 tables and three wait staff.  Service was scattered as hell.  Like it was everyones first night on the job.  We had three appetizers and a pizza...  er...I should say that is what we ORDERED.  The wine came right away (though the waitress knew nothing about it).  

Then the appetizers rolled in one by one.  The flat breads with spreads were nice but basically flavorless.  We also had a so so salad of white nectarines and pistachios and lettuce.  Nothing was terribly exciting.  Oh...to be fair...  the bottle of Rose we had was nice.  Then one of the wait staff came by to check to see if we needed anything else.  But we never got the pizza.  he assured us it would be right out and went to check only to return with a poor mouthed face saying...oops...must have been lost in translation.  Silence.  Silence.  Silence.  I finally said, never mind, we'll be OK without it.  He agreed and came back with the bill.  Again to be fair, he also comped one of the appetizers for our trouble and of course sliced the pizza off the bill.  

But, jeez...  13 tables and three wait staff.  Pull it together people!  

The atmosphere was awesome.  Like a dinner in the village in Manhattan in summer.  Sidewalk tables on a quaint corner that was very quiet.  We only found the place because we happened to drive by and stopped and took a table.

Oh....and I cant leave without mentioning the guy at the next table who was wearing a Lance Armstrong "live strong" bracelet on his right wrist and also smoking with his right hand.  Nice.
author: joe c.

description:
mmm...this place was pretty delicious. everything was light and clean (as in refreshing....not super healthy/flavorless)

the wait was incredibly long though. we didn't make reservations and they were all filled up. we waited a long time, but it was ok because we were in good company.

i wish we could've ordered more food...it ended up being about $40/person....there were three of us.

heirloom tomato salad. this was a tasty salad, but definitely not enough heirloom in it!!! this was just a salad. i love love love heirloom tomatoes....=(

pork and beef polpette aka meatballs - YUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM.....i wish they put more meatballs in the dish...i could eat a zillion of these. they're moist, juicy, and they have a nice meaty flavor to them.

peperonada pizza - i thought this was just ok. i don't like onions and peppers. 

pizza bianca - mmmmmmmmmm    .......i liked this way better than the peperonada. the flavors just fit me better....garlic and cheese are always a great combo

paparadelle with chantrel mushrooms - i didn't like the greens that were mixed in with it. it gave the dish an overall sour flavor and i wasn't a fan of the texture...i love paparadelle in general and the chantrel mushrooms were kind of light in flavor. this dish was a little bland...but w/ the greens it was sour.

i wish we tried a dessert but we already spent a lot of time and $$ here.....next time!! =D

PS love the decor and environment....
author: heather l.

description: Possibly the best thin crust pizza in SF.  Vegetarian friendly too.
author: Frank L.

description:
Delicious coffee. That's the most important thing.

The pizza, panini, and soup that change daily here are all also very good. (They offer salads as well, but I've not had one yet.) Whether you get a drip-to-order plain coffee or a signature latte with the pretty artwork of foam on top, you can't go wrong. 

Other reasons I found the food so appetizing: the people are lovely there and it's got a cute, inviting atmosphere. Oh, and the coffee is superb.

I don't think the food is an incredible value per se, and the hours right now are not the most convenient (only open til 3pm), otherwise "*****" especially when you consider there is Blue Bottle coffee two blocks from my work.

Edit 10/5: the hours have improved. 5 stars!
author: Dru D.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm, tasty......  This place has the best thin crust pizza I've ever had.  I admit I'm not a big pizza guy (I hate tomatoes and tomato sauce) so I stick to the white pizzas.  And this place has 3 to choose from.

My personal favorite is the Salciccia.  It's got sausage and onions and is just flat out delicious.  My girlfriend always gets the Pepperone, which she says is delicious (but I wouldn't know because, again, gross tomatoes).  She also loves the olive appetizer.

Piccino is also a surprisingly good place to go for brunch.  During brunch, you can add two eggs to the top of the pizza for a few additional dollars.  For the Salciccia, it adds even more deliciousness to the pizza.  (My girlfriend doesn't recommend it for the Pepperone, though).

The place is pretty small and quaint, but you usually don't have to wait to long.  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in the city (we go at least once a month).  Highly recommended.
author: Chad H.

description:
I really want to LOVE this place, I do, it's cute, the waitresses and waiters were REALLY nice, it has a nice idea, and a cute neighborhoody feel. It's cute, really it is.

But... somehow... That's not enough in a restaurant to me.

The menu was really small and the variation wasn't enough for so few options. 

In a group of 6 we got 3 pizzas. I was still STARVED. The pizzas were really light, crispy, and pretty good. But if you're hungry or have a huge apetite like me expect to want to eat 2 by yourself. Chewing the pizza made my jaw really sore, is that weird?

Also, we ordered the Margherita Pizza and it was totally stingy on the basil. I ordered it because I LOVE basil! There were officially 6 leaves on the entire pizza. 6 small ones. Was there a basil shortage and they were rationing us? It was basically all tomato sauce on a crust with a handful of spots with cheese and 1 small basil leafe per large pizza slice.

So Piccino, in my book, is just A-ok. Nothing impressively great and nothing incredibly wonderful.
author: Sydney T.

description: Looks like you need a membership or something to order a coffee, I was ignored :(, I just wanted some coffee.... A lil too snobby for me ..
author: Karen P.

description: Piccino has great pizzas, salads, and coffee.  The ingredients are always fresh and it comes through in the flavor.  I especially love having a farm fresh egg on my pizza.  Something I can never get right at home!  I like to bring out-of-towners here to experience good food in San Francisco outside of the Mission or other trendier spots.  Big love for the Dogpatch.
author: Suzy K.

description:
I just love a little place that opens in a neighborhood in transition.  These are the places that add so much character to a neighborhood.  They know that cool hip people move into neighborhoods in transition and these same people will frequent their restaurant.  

What a simple place.  Sure it is small but that is what makes it so great!  Today I was in the dogpatch visiting a vendor and on my way down to the T-line I stumbled upon Piccino.  I knew it was here but forgot about it.  What a perfect day to stop.  They have all these tables outside under a big ole tree.  Sitting there reminded me of summer in New England.  In particular Boston, sitting at a quaint little restaurant in the South End. 

I love think crust pizza  and this is their specialty. Each pizza is individual and they stick the basics with one special daily.   I had the three cheese which was cooked perfectly with garlic and red pepper flakes and a drizzle of olive oil to finish it off.  They served it on a piece of wood reminiscent of a pizza peel, clever I thought.  

Service...flawless.  Our waitress was just happy to be helping us.  She was great!    

As this neighborhood grows this place will become even more of a hot spot.   I don't see them going anyplace. 

Also please don't compare them to Delphina..they both have thin crust pizza but they are different places, both just as good in their own right! 

Welcome to the dog patch Piccino!
author: Scott P.

description:
Piccino is an out of the way pizza place that is worth going out of the way for.  This small corner restaurant in the Dogpatch has a simple menu, a handful of pizzas, a handful of appetizers/salads, and desserts.  When you have affordable pizza with quality flavors and ingredients, you don't need more items on the menu to confuse people.  Having worked several years at a pizza place during High School, I can respect a well made pizza pie and Piccino knows what they are doing.  The crust is thin and crispy.  Most importantly, its not burnt.  They top their pizzas with the appropriate amount of ingredients that ensures most bites will have a taste of everything that is supposed to be on the pie.  Definitely check out their new create the "Mushroom Pesto" Pizza,  it is simply amazing!  

Blue Bottle Coffee and in house baked desserts/cookies are offered that keeps locals coming in daily.  On weekend brunches, you have the option to slap on two Farmer's Market Fresh Eggs to any pizza.  Now aren't these enough reasons to get over here?  Like now!
author: Jason A.

description:
Ok, I used to live in Dogpatch and there was, like *no* place to eat. I mean sure there was the tamale lady when I would get off at the 22nd street Caltrain stop. Oh and there was the convenience and ahem, liquor store, of which I was a loyal customer. (particulary the sad frozen foods section in the back -- " *sniff*, frozen pizza for one, *sniff, sniff"). And maybe if this place had popped up a little sooner I wouldn't have tied up my hobo bag and crossed the 101.
