Let me make that clearer -- if Piccino had opened its doors a year ago, I would have been "that girl" that was always there, hanging around drinking the Blue Bottle coffee, eating ricotta gnocchi and pizzas off the gorgeous artisanal plates, drinking the chianti served Italian-style, maybe doing some Oprah-encouraged journaling at one of the outdoor tables. Ah, regrets.
author: Mission S.

description: Great atmosphere and I had an amazing rabbit and chanterelle pasta dish.
author: Joe P.

description: Lovely space, lovely food. Possibly the best thin crust pizza in town. All protiens and produce are carefully procured and handled. Pasta and pizza dough is made in house daily as well as the baked goods served in the coffee shop. With so many options to choose from it may take several visits to try them all. All dishes are a perfect size for the price point and healthy to boot. Didn't feel like a glutton after chomping down a salad, pie and pasta. A perfect place to take a date or to chat w/ friends over lunch. Hi Vern!
author: I D.

description:
Some experiences move you to get to your keyboard and rant. Piccino has so moved me twice now.

Barristas are totally oblivious to the world around them; they don't notice clients, don't make them pay in a timely fashion, and although apparently friendly with regulars, they aren't at all interested in whichever constraints frame your schedule.

Furthermore, the coffee is bitter yet tasteless. The kind that makes your milk turn sour and your cup visit the garbage bin on the early side.

You won't find me there again. Twice is enough.
author: E P.

description: Great coffee. Nice people. Lovely space. (and you can walk to Just for You)
author: Ashley C.

description:
I've had the pleasure of eating at the old location and now at the new space. The new location has an inviting modern decor and feels like an actual restaurant as opposed to a cute hole in a wall. The servers were friendly and attentive.
     Overall, the food was very good.
     The friend green tomatoes were delicious. The seasoned batter added good contrast to the tangy little tiny tomatoes. The romesco sauce was delicious.
     The gnocchi was also delicious. They were light and fluffy. The sauce was well seasoned.
     The sausage and red onion pizza has been a favorite of mine since the old location. The sausage is flavorful and the crust is EXTREMELY thin. Unlike other reviewers, I've never felt that the crust got soggy. If anything, its almost like eating a cracker.
     The one knock about the restaurant is indeed the portion size. A couple of baby fried green tomatoes for 9 dollars and 3 gnocchi for 12 bucks is definitely a poor value. There is no doubt that the food is good, but if you wanna leave satisfied, you will definitely pay more than you would expect.
author: Siao W.

description:
Pizzeta 211 wannabe????

PIzza is good. Seating arrangement is funky. Feng Shui practicioners would have a field day. Style is a little on the weak side. 

1) In dire need of someone to redo design of menus (I can recommend some incredible people if you guys are reading this), business cards....if you are going for the local , slow food crowd, you gotta make sure all the aesthetics are in place and the menus, plates, bowls, and cups a don't really go with the idea. 

I guess I should get over this stuff, however I have heard some big game talked about this place and these were the things that I thought were pretty weak about the experience. 

Onto the food. Pizza, soup and salad were good,  in fact for all you pizza lovers I recommend you try it out, but there are better places. Vibe in neighborhood laid back.  Kind of hard to find. 

Also their were tons of people waiting to get into the place and they seemed to linger which was a bit uncomfortable while we ate. Like I said, in dire need of some feng shui. Hell, I'd go back.
author: D M.

description:
I have been here a few times and their thin crust pizza is a welcome addition to SF's pizzascape which is so often dominated by too-much-dough type crusts. They don't overdo it on the toppings, everything is seasonal and fresh, plus the specials and usual suspects on the menu are equally delicious. Shared an amazing butternut squash soup and tasty beet salad last time too.

Special bonus: the new mani pedi salon (Modern Nail Bar) next door is a bargain, with super-friendly owners, and clean and esthetically pleasing decor. So Dogpatch now makes for a great location for a girls-day-out  with lunch and grooming!
author: Aimee G.

description:
I have a neighborhood spot! Yay!

I've been here a few times with my honey for a casual dinner. We like to each get a pizza and sometimes share a salad or appetizer. 

I like the white pizzas the best. I usually choose the white special. Last time I had the white special and it had mozerella, fig, mint, and some tasty, thin cut pork thing. My boy had the funghi special with mushroom pesto, some kind of mushrooms, and cheese. 

The salad always sounds good and are very fresh and interesting.  We also like that their wine menu is affordable. Last time I was there, I tried a rose by the glass that was good. 

I think I'll be over there on a regular basis.
author: Kitty H.

description:
I was having one of those days, you know? After dealing with too much family time, I was either going to hole up with the cats, a gallon of wine, and Dancing with the Stars or I was going to have a perfectly lovely, early dinner at Piccino w/ a lady friend. I opted for the latter and my day was redeemed.

Piccino has been on my list since it opened. Like many of the other thin-crust pizza eateries in SF (Pizzeria Delfina, Pizzetta 211, Gialina, and so on), it is tiny in stature, but offers a lot in the way of redeeming a bad day. I arrived first and opted for the indoor corner table as the wind was starting to pick up. Large windows open up the tiny room to the Dogpatch street scene and let in a lot of natural light. 

My dining companion arrived and we decided on a half bottle of Sauvignon Blanc and two pizzas. The Margherita was required, as it is the benchmark of a true pizzeria; our other choice was the white special of arugula, english peas, green garlic, and sorrel pesto. Presented on wax paper-covered boards, the pizzas arrived at the same time. I was surprised that the thin crust was crisp enough to be picked up without any noticeable droopage in the center. The white special pie read so well on paper with all of its quintessential seasonal ingredients, that I was a little let down by it. I think it need more oomph, perhaps by upping the green garlic and/or pesto. 

At this point, people started to swarm for tables as the dinner rush hit. Our poor solo waiter was a bit swamped but heard us calling for a half bottle of the rose and quickly dropped it off with fresh glasses. The Margherita was the favorite of table, but it was very simple. I have a suspicion that the funghi pie or a pizza with anchovies or a salty meat/cheese might be the way to go here.

All in all, girl talk, pizza, wine, and that neighborhood gem feel redeemed my day.  3.5 stars.
author: Candice L.

description:
The Pizza!

best I've had in this city - which isn't saying much, i know.
I too, am a pizza snob.  This pizza is similar to southern italian - thin, light crust with fresh ingredients.  You can actually eat this pizza and not feel fat and unhealthy afterwards.

The overall portion/price ratio is comparable to Nopa and other small plate style restaurants, nothing inappropriate given the quality of ingredients and preparation.

I've been twice and have been equally impressed with the food both times.  
Service is casual and familiar, matches the style of restaurant and cuisine.

Cheese plate & coffee are also amazingly good.
Other desserts have so far not been as impressive as the rest of the food, but not so bad as to reduce the rating a star.
author: laura g.

description:
Overall: 3
Get the pizza. Sklp the rest. Not sure if I would return. 

Food: 3
Tasty and creative mushroom pizza. Thinnest crust I've ever had. 

Decor: 3
Tiny. Try not to sit next to the door because you will get drafts. 

Service: 4
Our food came out fast but I never felt rushed. The server was very friendly.

Value: 2
Pricey. Small portions for the price.
author: Roger H.

description:
I've been there in this morning. Actually, we tried to went to different place for had breakfast located near by Piccino. But it was closed, so we went to Piccino without any expectation.
 First of all, I felt its atmosphere is ok, not so interesting, but the place is clean and waitresses seems like a hipster.
 
 We ordered 2 kinds of food( I forgot the name). One was sauteed cabbage and bacon with egg. It was delicious! I enjoyed the sauteed cabbage with melt egg yoke. Another one was home made donuts. It was also delicious. It was very fluffy and warm, not too much sweet. Although I didn't eat pizza, I satisfied those Sunday blanch.
author: ako h.

description: I was looking forward to dining at Piccino again after having eaten here about 2 years ago. It was another rainy night in SF and our reservation was for 6:15. We hit traffic due to the rain and we got to the restaurant at 6:25. When i gave my name for the reservation the host quickly stated that our table would need to be vacated by 7:30 as there is another reservation for the table. They would be happy to sit us at the bar if we wanted to stay longer than 7:30. I was very surprised by this greeting to a fine dining restaurant. I did not think I was going to a fast food joint that I only had 75 minutes to enjoy my meal. This restaurant is not cheap and it is not the type of greeting I would expect to receive. This was a celebratory meal, and I bit my tongue as I did not want to say anything to upset my dining partner. We were seated and the waitress came over and gave the menus and said, I understand that we are in a time crunch here so I will be right back to take your order. She took our orders and said she would put them in right away. We ate our meal, but did not really enjoy it due to the start of the meal. We finished our meal around 7:35 as dessert took about 10 minutes from when we ordered. The 2-top table adjacent to us got up around 7:15 and was not seated by the time we left. We went to the restroom after the meal and waited for Uber to come and left around 7:45 and our table along with the adjacent was still empty. I work in customer service, and the way that this restaurant handles customer service is really poor and needs improvement. I will not be returning and would highly warn future diners to inquire how long you have to dine at the restaurant as I have never eaten at a restaurant where there is a 75 minute time limit at a table, except for a fast food restaurant.
author: Todd R.

description:
Small little joint with big heart and caring staff. Oh and yummy thin crust pizzas. 

One of life's little surprises: when you have young toddlers, you tend to fall into an eating schedule that closely mirrors that of the grey set. More often than not, we show up at a restaurant right as their senior specials kick in. (5-5:30pm)

So when we arrived at Piccino's early in the evening with two kids, were seated quickly and able to enjoy a very nice little meal in a cozy atmosphere...well what can I say? All was good. 

We enjoyed a few of their appetizers and split several pizzas. All the ingredients were fresh and full of flavor. My son enjoyed (from a distance of course) watching the chefs make the pizzas in their open kitchen.

Best of all, the woman who waited on us was a sweetheart. 

Yea for Piccino's.
author: Stephanie I.

description: $200 including tip party of two and the one great thing was the apricot preserve on the cheese plate (and the cheese.) customer service ... nope. not a great experience.  only posting this cause there are so many other places to go to.  in the soma area fringale would be it.  zero zero. anywhere but here.
author: Amanda J.

description:
What a great neighborhood place.

Piccino lives up to the mantra that it's better to do fewer things well, than to over-stretch yourself.  Yes, the menu is small, but it's a well-edited list of quality selections.  Simple, well-executed Italian dishes are served here rather than meals with descriptions that run off the page.  The menu changes frequently, possibly even daily so even with a small menu, you can come here often without getting bored.  Plus, you're assured of seasonal quality.

Only thing i wasn't a fan of was the glass of cabernet franc (on the menu June 2007) - characterless and at $9 a glass, overpriced.   But overall the experience was lovely and just what i was in the mood for on a Friday night at the end of a long week.  

The food, plus casual, friendly service and fantastic coffee make this a place worth stopping by on a frequent basis, even if you're on your own coming home from work, if you live nearby.  

Which I do.

Lucky me!
author: Liz O.

description:
This place is great, one of those places you are almost hesitant to review because you don't want the word to get out about this little neighborhood gem.

Think "Pizzeria Delfina" without the lines, parking issues, over-stimulation, or hassle.  I love PD, but groan at putting my name on that chalkboard with so many names above me.  This place serves up equally good thin-crust pizzas, but it's mellow and much more of a neighborhood feel.

Only wish is that they were open just a little bit later - often times I've come home late from the office and would love me some Piccino pizza and just miss them by a few minutes.  They have small liter-bottles of wine, which is nice too.

Excellent pizza, great place, friendly staff.
author: Doug M.

description: I've been waiting for a take out pizza for almost 45 minutes (2pm on a Sunday). Might change my star when the pizza emerges, but this is absolutely ridiculous. I've eaten in the restaurant twice before with slow wait times, but this is the longest I've waited for any take out in San Francisco. The staff is courteous but the kitchen clearly needs stronger management.
author: Lucy B.

description:
I stopped here for lunch several months ago and had a really great foccacia sandwich and a very good fresh green salad. This week, I returned with a few co-workers. I was disappointed that sandwiches were no longer on the menu, but that turned out to be the least of my worries.

We showed up at 12 noon. The waiter announced that the soups were still cooking and not yet available, despite the Specials board which advertised the soup of the day. About 20 minutes after we arrived, the waiter informed a neighboring table that the soups were now available. And 20 minutes after that, the same waiter went up to the Specials board and crossed off the day's soup, writing OUT. So much for the soup. 

The green salad was really excellent -- fresh, with only a hint of oil and  vinegar. Perfect for a warm day.

One of the other specials was not available either, and we were informed that the polpette (beef and pork meatballs) came without pasta. There is no pasta to be had; their kitchen "is not large enough to keep pasta fresh." I'm sure that makes sense to someone in the restaurant business, so I won't challenge it. In any case, the waiter informed a nearby table, around 12:30 pm, that the meatballs were also OUT. 

I asked at one point if there was sparkling water available. There was --  then there wasn't. They were out of that too. This was becoming a bit comical.

We all ordered different pizzas. They arrived in a reasonable amount of time for pizzas, no worries there. And each was really good: my meat pizza, my co-worker's tomato and basil pizza, and another's mushroom specialty. We all shared slices, and all the pizzas (about 12") were consumed then and there. The crusts are very thin and on the whole the pizzas are great. 

To sum up, what we were able to order was great. But you'd think they'd have things a little more together, even if it was noon on a Tuesday.
author: Mark P.

description:
Went there for Valentine's dinner with my husband... and let me say we had been trying to get in there for months.  We didn't have a reservation, and we thought we'd be out of luck, but we were seated at the bar, and it was just fine!  Our server was great-- very knowledgeable about the wine, beer and all the food.  

We ordered the mixed chicories salad, the fettuccine with fennel, dungeness crab and  meyer lemon, and the pizza with the house-made sausage and red onion.  First of all.. EVERYTHING is made fresh to order-- you can see it all being made in the open kitchen, which is FASCINATING.  All the dishes were amazing.  Hard for me to say which was the best.

The wine list is huge, and I have to say, I was not familiar with the choices (most were from Italy). However, our waiter knew a lot about them, I told him what I liked and he selected the perfect one.

From beginning to end, a fabulous evening, and a fabulous meal.  We will definitely be back. The selections are affordable, and with drinks and dessert for the two of us, we got out of there for under $100!

HIGHLY recommend!!!
author: mindy r.

description:
Just moved to Dogpatch recently, and this place is just one more reason that I love this 'hood.  

I loved the pickled veggie antipasti, and the Funghi pizza? Killer.

I wish they didn't have the little cafe that serves Blue Bottle Coffee in the mornings, because it makes me upset that I can't wake up a few minutes early to run over and grab a latte.  Oh, and tried the mocha once, and it was worth every single penny.
author: Mollie T.

description:
Total neighborhood gem. I've been in many times for lunch and service is generally slow, but the pizzas are thin, crisp and delicious served with a small bowl of chili flakes for sprinkling. My all time favorite was the bianca special with pancetta and wild nettles, although there's nothing on the menu I haven't liked. 

You can also sit outside (under heat lamps if need be) and watch the neighborhood go by - big plus!
author: Crissy G.

description: I considered not writing this review because part of me really wants to keep Piccino a secret.  This place is amazing.  First of all, the restaurant is charming and intimate, and the owner and staff are so nice.  They always make you feel welcome and right at home.  Secondly, the Bianca is the best pizza I've had in my life (rivaling some of the world-class NYC/Brooklyn pizzerias).  Finally, they're currently serving a "stuffed avocado" which is really a lovely green salad with avocado, strawberries and other fruit, and wonderful roasted almonds.  Everything at Piccino is to die for.  I just hope it doesn't get so popular that it loses its magic.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
it's been years since i've been here. but i went a few days ago& had the best salad of my life - chicory& pt reyes blue& hazelnuts& balsamic dressing. it was $15 - a lot for a light salad - but it was incredibly delicious & beautiful.
i would go back for that.
author: Kim Y.

description:
Hog Island is doing a BBQ thing here?  Awesome, thought I.

Well, that was the awesomest part about it.  I liked that they had heat lamps outside, but they were nowhere near strong enough for us, so we almost left, but then an inside table opened up.

This was some sort of special day where Hog Island was grilling oysters and serving them raw.  We decided to go all out--BBQ'ed oysters, raw oysters, and pizza.  Well, the oysters were delicious.....the pizza--not.  I was dismayed to find that my pizza tasted mostly like cardboard, with the exception of a flavorful bite here and there of gorgonzola.  Our friends got the sausage pizza and, somehow, the sausage was mushy and watery and tasted like nothing.  I really don't know how they do it, but they accomplish removing the flavor from the ingredients.  The wine list, however, was great and there was a wonderful Loire Valley white that made things a little bit more tolerable.
The worst part was that, after $40, I was still hungry.  I insisted we go to Rosamunde's so I could get a sausage and feel satiated.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I love this cozy little corner spot located in the ever sunny corner of the city known as the Dog patch.  They use fresh local ingredients to create their consistent menu items as well as offering a few specials.  The 2 owners are usually working between the kitchen and the small but efficient dining room to create a warm and welcoming atmosphere.  Their pizza's are delicious though, its really their stellar sauce recipes and value of food that makes everything shine through the way it does. 

The pastries are all made by the kitchen staff and are not to be overlooked as well.  The wine list is modest but well appointed as well .
author: Michael M.

description: Not a good restaurant if you are a vegetarian - not many options.  The pizza was up to par - nothing special.  Also had the fish on the menu, which was good.  Couldn't tell if the waitress was in a bad mood or just upset my table of three was sharing dishes and not order a feast.
author: Shereen K.

description: The new location is a nice, open space.  The food is tasty and reliable - and the space has a nice open kitchen.  I had the margherita pizza - thin crust, tasty and sweet tomato sauce - not exactly Neapolitan style - but good nonetheless.  My husband had the gnocchi, which was a little different because it's made of semollina flour.  I had the mustard greens salad, which was a tasty combo.  The strawberry rhubarb crostata was not that great - not very flavorful and the crust was disappointing.
author: B. Y.

description:
There's something very charming and neighborhood-y about Piccino. The place is tiny, so it's understandable that we had to wait for a table. I observed that they were giving blankets to the people seated outside so that they could wrap themselves up against the cold. I couldn't decide if that was a thoughtful gesture or just plain CRUEL to sit them out there when it was clearly too cold for dining al fresco. The nice guy who greeted us at the door gave us the option of sitting outside or in the corner right away, or else wait 20 minutes or so for a table. 

We decided to sit in a little corner "at" the bar, but really kind of behind it. It would have been okay, despite our scenic view of the wall in front of us, but we couldn't help noticing that our stools were vibrating ever so slightly. It was confounding and irritating. We identified the source of the vibrations as the bar next to us, and when the nice guy checked on us again, he figured out that it was the refrigerator under the bar. Nothing to be done, I guess. 

Meanwhile, we still hadn't seen our waitress. Finally she came and took our orders. Once she noticed us, the service was just fine, but it took a long time before she noticed us. She came with our wine, served in short stubby water glasses. Normally I like to drink wine out of glasses like these, but my friend was drinking Prosecco, and I think it's just wrong to drink the bubbly from anything other than a proper flute. 

Our appetizer arrived - a romaine salad with meyer lemons, walnuts, and ricotta. It was good, but not remarkable. I think I would have preferred something stronger than the mild ricotta on this salad - like a nice goat cheese would have been just right. 

Then we got our pizza, and I have to admit the crust was fantastic. Crispy, chewy, substantial enough to hold without it flopping around messily, but delicate enough to taste light and subtle. The red sauce was too one-note for me. My friend thought it was too salty. I just thought it lacked any interesting variations in flavor. It just tasted like tomato sauce. 

So, all in all for dinner, decent food in a charming restaurant, but too many details that just were wrong. 

I've also come to Piccino a couple of times in the morning for some coffee and a pastry. It takes a long time. Do not go if you're in a hurry. However, the coffee & pastries are really good.
author: Melinda K.

description:
When the restaurant expanded I feared the quality of the food and service would decline.  Not so, the food is excellent. Three of us shared several antipasti, and they all were wonderful. We also had a delicata squash pizza which was delicious...I've had several pizzas here and each of the ones that I've tasted was delicious.  

The ambiance is lovely even in such a large room I could hear the others at my table.

Our food server was friendly,  helpful, and quite engaging. 

My reservation in relation to this restaurant, that is, why I give this place four and not five stars, is the attitude of the "sommelier" (I use the term loosely). 

 Basically, her behavior was rather off putting.  She came to the table with a wine we wanted to taste, sneered at me, tisked and said: "You wanted to taste this?", as if a taste was an annoyance.

She poured a small taste into a glass for three of us to taste, spilled some wine on the table and didn't bother to clean it up, and when we didn't like the wine she made a face. 

  When we did order an $88.00 bottle of champagne, our waiter served it not the off putting wine pourer.  Later when she came to our table she was moderately more friendly.  I guess the one of the most expensive wine choice on the menu melted her freeze, but not enough to behave as if she appreciated our business.. 

I'll go back here to eat, but hope for a different staff member should I want to taste a wine.  I have never before been treated with such distain when asking for a taste of wine before I purchase it.
author: TM m.

description:
I liked this place a lot! The fungi pizza was super good.. and that's coming from someone who doesn't like mushrooms =)

The waitress was really nice and helpful.. it's a fun little neighborhood place where you can just walk in and have a really nice meal without having to worry about which forks to use. 

They also have old milk bottles for water. And I just dig that.
author: Paula S.

description:
I went here for the first time tonight, for dinner, and I have to say, I was a bit disappointed in the pizza. It was cooked perfectly, but most of the ingredients (namely the red sauce and the bread/crust) lacked dimension. I felt like I was eating straight tomato sauce on top of plain bread. We tried the pepperoni and the margherita. The meat on the former was good, though, if slightly sparse.

Starters were, overall, better. I enjoyed the eggplant appetizer, even if it was a bit too vinegary. And the mixed greens, blue cheese, and walnut salad (which was comped because the kitchen initially got our eggplan order wrong) was tasty enough, although I think I would've balked at what I got for the price if I'd actually ordered it.

I enjoyed a tasty wine by the glass whose name I can't quite recall -- it might've been Santa Magdalena something-or-other. Skipped dessert so can't comment on sweets.

Service was great! Friendly and solicitous, very concerned about making sure we were taken care of. Lively yet comfortable atmosphere, too. The lighting is slightly off, but it's certainly not bad. And I enjoyed the misshapen pottery plates, which are apparently the result of a second career of a well-regarded potter who tired of his mainstream work.
author: Tara M.

description: Partner and I, who have been fans of the prior incarnation as a café, enjoyed our first dinner at the new location. The plates are sized and presented to encourage sharing of each dish. The food was elegant, colorful and interesting without taking attention away from the flavors and nourishment, deep / yet light / yet subtle flavors, dishes that were satisfying without being overfilling, the venue was wonderful, and the pottery plates added much. Even the restrooms seemed well thought out - M/F and sinks outside, both of which seem to reduce waiting time. Plus the information, recommendations and cheerfully pleasant demeanor of the wait person all contributed to us wanting to come back. One more indication Dogpatch has been wonderfully evolving in recent years. Spacious dining room good for groups but also lots of one to one tables for couples and individuals.
author: David G.

description: This is the nearest coffee shop to my apartment, and I used to love it the most because they served Blue Bottle Coffee. They changed to SightGlass now, which is good, but not as good at BB. Great when I'm pressed for time and want to get a decent cup of coffee, but no longer my first choice. They have tons of pastry selections, but I'm gluten/diary free, so I've never tried them.
author: Sara B.

description:
I've been here twice now in the last 18 hours... Last night we went for dinner, loved the place, heard much about the coffe on yelp, had to go back for coffee and pastries this morning. Piccino is definitely a great find, a cute cafe in a great neighborhood (close to my house, yay). Sure they have some kinks to work out , but those add to the charm.

First the dinner:
The sign in the dining room says "maximum occupancy" 14 people. We just sat outside instead, no waiting there. The menu is quite limited, but everything we had was yummy. The most expensive wine on the menu was $28, how can you beat that! We had the asparagus salad with prosciutto and egg as a starter. Asparagus was very sweet, my first of the season.
Then i had the Piccino special pizza with peashoots and salumi. I looooved the pizza but not because it was like a pizza. It was thethinnest crust I've ever seen with no tomato sauce. It was great for whatever it was. My husband had the involtini (meatballs wrapped in prosciutto?) in tomato sauce with potatoes. The dish was delicious, but the serving size was tiny and it really begged for some pasta.
For dessert, we had the best biscotti ever. None of those tooth-breaking bricks, this was chewy, mmm.

For breakfast this morning we greeted our waiter from last night (the same staff works all 3 shifts), got our cappuccinos to go. It was good, but I am no coffee conoisseur. For food we grabbed some fresh out of the oven focaccia with dried fruit and nuts. Crazy, eh?

In summary, Piccino has a great future, but maybe I don't want everyone to flock there :(

Notes: Dinner is served thu-sat only (i think), they close at 8:30p. 
No credit cards accepted.
If there is a line, go to yield wine bar around the corner :)
author: Ayse B.

description:
Oh... it's ayight.  I mean, I like the thin crust pizzas on the flat wooden serving board, the glass milk bottle water carafes, and the handcrafted/thrown/fired platters... all very fartsy.  But besides the pizzas and a couple of saladsand soup, there's not much there, there. I've never gone to dinner there because there are usually just two entrees and if neither one of them is appearing fetching to me, I'm not going to settle for a pizza for dinner out.

Don't get me wrong... I've been about four or five times now and I enjoy the pizza but that's mainly why I go.  It's nice to enjoy a well made thin crust pizza. a glass of wine and maybe a salad, to make you feel like you're in Italy somewhere.  A cool hour or so getaway vacation on a sunny day, sitting at the sidewalk tables and people-watching the Dogpatch denizens.  

I enjoy that specific type of experience quite a bit so I do return to Piccino regularly... but just for that.  There's not much else on the menu, the wine list is limited, the parkig is challenging to say the least, and the serving staff is a little too cavalier for my taste.  They're not great on the follow-up side of things and seem a little novice in terms of rounding out a satisfying dining   experience.
author: Ric S.

description:
I went to Piccino on a really nice night in SF, so sitting outside of Piccino was definitely an awesome experience. It's in a quiet residential area, so it's a great spot for a romantic evening. The service was good -- nothing spectacular. 

The food, however, I felt lacked a bit. The thin crust pizza (we got the Red Piccino special pizza) wasn't as flavorful as I expected -- too little cheese, i think. We also got the special entree which was 4 giant meatballs, which were good, but not something that memorable. 

Basically, I would recommend this place if it's a beautiful night in SF and you want to have some nice conversation in a romantic atmosphere with some wine. I would not, however, recommend this place based on the food alone.
author: Roy C.

description: Who would have thought that cauliflower pizza would taste so good?  The bakery pastries are awesome too -- order a brownie or a chocolate chip cookie with your coffee for dessert.
author: Peter L.

description: For a little coffee bar behind the main cafe, it's not bad.  A bit of an afterthought so you can easily walk past it but if you're fortunate enough to see it and take a peek inside, it's cute.  The coffee is pretty good but if you're serving blue bottle, of course you're gonna have a great baseline to work with.  I enjoyed the new orleans ice coffee.  Strong flavor and very refreshing.
author: Karen N.

description: I really wanted to like this place, having had a great first date brunch experience at their earlier, smaller location, but this past visit was terrible.  For one, my order was not taken correctly.  They brought out a cheese plate when I ordered a broccoli app. Our broccoli app finally came out 20 min later with no apology.  We ordered a pizza as our main course and watched pizza after pizza come out to other tables including the one next to ours but our pizza never came.  In fact, the two sitting next to us, who ordered after us, got 2 pizzas and finished them before ours probably was put in the oven...  When we inquired, they said that there were 'a lot of pizzas cooking' but didn't know when ours would arrive.  they offerred us 'nuts' as compensation for the delay and the uncertain further delay.   After 45 min of waiting, we decided to just get the check and go, so hungry were we.   We went down the street to Mijitas by the ballpark and got a delicious taco in 5 min flat during a ballgame which was delicious.  I am ashamed to say that I'll probably never go to piccino's again.   This review garnered 2 stars only because their arugula salad was tasty (though portion on the smaller side).   I never tasted the pizza so can't actually comment on it.
author: Bing S.

description: Super Fab but please don't go as I don't want them to run out of their scrumptuous pizza!
author: G-Rex R.

description:
Piccino Coffee Bar is unpretentious, simple, and nothing fancy- and it allows me to get a fabulous coffee drink, a great sandwich to go, and a treat (the ginger cookies are incredible- as are the plum muffins while they last) without the line that used to be when it was all in the cafe 2 doors down. 
I think the staff, service, and quality of everything has improved after their 3 years  (has it been that long?) in business. 
I see a noticeable difference in consistency, all at a very high level, more than ever. I wish there was a sixth star...
author: pam h.

description:
Simple food executed with care at a hard to find price.

I was stalling for time, waiting for another restaurant to open for dinner when my girlfriend and I stopped in to have some wine and a snack. The wine list was a just large enough list of European selections, with actual, useful descriptions. As an additional nice touch, we were able to order any wine in a carafe. (More restaurants should do this).

The soup of the day, a parsnip & turnip soup, caught my attention, and a salad with roasted cauliflower caught hers, so we decided to avoid the cold night and stay for dinner instead. The soup was hearty, with the broth full of flavor. Winter greens in the soup added a nice contrasting texture. The salad was alright, served with a warmed vinaigrette, though it came with a bit too much anchovy for me. We ordered the Funghi pizza, which came out on a very thin, crispy crust done perfectly. Feeling indulgent, we finished the meal with a simple lemon tart. Nothing fancy, but it was a perfect balance of sweetness and pucker in a just light enough texture.

The service was a tad slow, but very friendly. Judging from the people around us, this is a real neighborhood joint. And you can't beat the price. For a 3 course meal with wine, our total bill including tip was $65.
author: Douglas A.

description: The coffee is amazing - but the brioche cinnamon rolls are the BOMB!!!!!  Get there around 8am to get one of these treats coming straight out of the oven.  I might go back and buy a second one right now, they're that good.
author: Jessica B.

description: Really not baby friendly, the witness is rude towards those family with baby. Not sure about food quality but be warned about the waitress's attitude.
author: Ming T.

description: Seriously, one of my favorite neighborhood joints.  You can NEVER go wrong with their pizzas.  My favorite (and I get this EVERY time) is the funghi pizza.  mmmmm. drooling as I'm thinking of it.  I've tried others and they all are yummy.  They have different fresh dishes all the time.  Everything tastes good, some are better than others.  I love going here on a nice day to sit outside with a glass of wine for a great brunch.  They're almost done building a bigger and better Piccino on the corner....so excited!
author: Sharon T.

description:
I am really not happy about the complete relocation of the coffee bar. Now, when you are seated to eat and order coffee, the order is sent to the coffee shop and someone eventually hauls it over from there. I'm not clear on how long it may sit there before someone can break away to get it & deliver it, but I do know that a latte on a tray on a really cold day isn't going to be piping hot when you bring it to me. 

Coffee temperature is like pizza - it has to burn your mouth a little so you know it's right.
author: Shal J.

description: We ordered a pizza fo we could retire to a quiet evening at home. Picked up pizza , only to find it was cold. Had to heat up the oven before we could eat. Bummer!
author: Alan J.

description: Wonderful bites to eat. Quality coffee to drink. My favorite thing here is nobody is cutting corners. The baristas really know what they are doing. Catch Tim or Derick for one of the better shots in the city.
author: Dorian S.

description:
I really enjoyed this place! It's a bit pricey, but the local sourcing, cozy environment and delicious food make it a must-try in my opinion.

I wasn't as thrilled with the Fatted Calf salumi plate as I expected to be, there were only two meats and they were not particularly tasty. Loved the marinated carrots though. The pizza and the lime-and-milk braised pork shoulder, however, will definitely have me coming back here again. The pizza was thin and crispy and delicious; the pork was incredibly tender and served with a chickpea cake that was just delicious. Crispy on the outside and crumbly and spicy on the inside, I would love to have the recipe. It went really well with the pork. 

We asked the waitress if she had a favorite dessert and she immediately suggested the brownie. Man, was she right. My brownies never come out this good. There was a meringue-like crunch to the top of the brownie that was a great contrast to the chocolatey goodness inside. I had a coffee too, can't go wrong with blue bottle.

One warning (already in many other posts), the place is TINY. I think there were only 5 tables inside, and maybe an additional 4 seats at a small bar. So hit Yield or come early/late.
author: Liboo K.

description:
I've eaten at Piccino on several occasions in the past 4 months and I'm finally finding the time to write a review.  Piccino is a very tiny place that serves quality food in small portions at relatively high prices; they could give more food.  The wine selection is very limited and in my opinion their current selection is poor.  Lastly, their dessert menu is very limited (i.e. cookie plate, bread loaf).

On my first visit I had the gnocchi which was tasty however the portions were very small that it makes me wonder if they want me to order something else.  Well guess what......I had to so I had the salad which was delicious but also very small.  I left hungry and disappointed.  At this point I wasn't about to order another item.  

On my second visit there, I decided to try their pizza.  I ordered the margherita pizza which was not bad.  The pizza had a nice thin crust with uneven distribution of salt.  There were certain parts of the crust that were saltier.  In addition the tomato sauce was bland so I sprinkled it with a lot of pepper flakes to give it some taste.  Ugh!  

One of my pet peeves at this restaurant is the earthen-ware plates that you eat on.  It appears that the dishes are remnants from a pottery shop; uneven edges, chipped and funky shapes.  Perhaps this is the look they are going for but let's face it.......it's really not enjoyable to eat on and the food easily falls off these funky plates.

I give this 3 stars because it has the potential.  I'll wait another 3 months or so before I go back to give it another chance and I'll provide an update.
author: Oscar F.

description:
Piccino is a contrast to most cafes where the baristas are a whirlwind of multitasking. Each time I've visited, the barista was paying meticulous attention to craft each individual drink. The espresso blend that Blue Bottle makes specifically for Piccino is good but not my favorite (I've heard that flavor profile described as "vegetable undertones" which isn't my favorite tasting note for coffee). I'm convinced that it's the craftsmanship that makes each drink so smooth and flavorful.

The tender loving care is apparent in the restaurant half of the house too. We had the squash/prosciutto/basil pizza and the funghi pizza with mushroom pesto. The thin-crust pizzas tantalize the taste buds with flavor. I usually eat a lot, but with such flavorful and tastefully prepared food, I slowed down to appreciate each bite, and the portion size turned out just right. I finished the meal feeling satisfied on account of the quality without having to stuff my face with quantity. Friendly service too.

Picinno also has some prepared food in the cafe, such as sandwiches and muffins, which all look amazing albeit pricey enough that I haven't indulged in too many yet. I had a vegetarian sandwich with a soft cheese (mozzarella? crescenza?), a hard cheese (gouda? pecorino?), arugula, and pesto on house focaccia. It was a great combination, the only fault was that by nature of standing in the pre-made case, osmosis was taking effect on the pesto, so the bread lost the crisp toastiness that it could have had if the sandwich were made-to-order. Still a very good sandwich. Looking forward to try the muffins or scones next time.
author: Boaz G.

description: Since I prefer sitting at bars in lieu of tables, I was happy to see that the new Piccino has a large bar where you can watch the chefs cook.  At the old Piccino, I did not think the pizza was all that. But the new one is great. The wine selection is terrific and do not leave there without getting the semolina gnocci, it's sensational. Splurge and get the Giuseppe Quintarelli Primofiore Rosso.
author: Renee R.

description: Piccino can be summed up by their business card.  Their 'artisan' intent is obvious and admirable but ultimately poorly executed.  The cheese they used on the Margherita ($9.50) was tasty, but sparse, the crust a bit too crispy, the sauce had too much vinegar and sugar, and what  little basil adorned the pizza in the first place nearly blew off in the wind.  I'm also wondering when the term "tables on the sidewalk" was magically transformed into "nice outdoor seating"
author: shawn g.

description:
This is one of my favorite neighborhood spots.  I can always get a perfect latte or espresso.  The margherita pizza is thin with just the right amount of sauce and cheese.  They support local farms and have a seasonal menu and you can even pick up veggie boxes from Mariquita farms there.  
The antipasti is always great with cute little pickled vegetables. 
I wish they still had the bar.  I miss sunday brunch at the bar reading the paper.  It's just not the same at a table.   

Oh and they have a great wine list too!
author: m.e. t.

description: I guess the dogpattch is up and coming. This place is cute, and is mostly a piatti prima and pizza place.  the food super fresh, organic and fun and delicious. Salads were wonderful.  Pizza with pea tendrils was very good.
author: Chris C.

description:
as my neighborhood coffee place.. i want to love it! but, i dont. 

i mean the coffee is amazing.. really cant find better. but the folks working there.. mainly the woman w/glasses and short hair.. hmm.. not very friendly. been there dozens of times.. and everytime its like im a martian. 

pastries- eh.
coffee- amazing
staff- unfriendly
author: Art A.

description:
I RARELY give 5 stars -- and this place impressed me tonight! I wanted to frequent my other 5 star choice, Chez Spencer, but tonight, my dining companion convinced me to try this place.

I take the train every night and I always walk by this place. it's small and intimate with friendly wait staff.

We started with the little gems + goat cheese (you dont need the peaches), and then we had the MOST sumptuous meatballs and polenta. I envisioned heavy polenta in a cast iron skillet with meatballs on top but what we actually ate was the lightest ever polenta + meatballs in a light tomato sauce. we also split a special pizza with homemade sausage and summer squash (lose the squash, it doesnt add anything). the pizza was soo light -- i am usually anti carb for dinner especially pizza, but this was lighter than bread - it was a vehicle for the perfectly freshly flavored sauce!

we ended with REAL whipped cream and a light souffle.

ALL perfectly delightful. I havent been more surprised about quality ingrediants in a long time.

Kudos. well done.
author: Hilary H.

description: This coffee bar uses Sight Glass Coffee.  I always stop here for coffee when I'm in the neighborhood.  Never a difficulty finding street parking in this area.  I really love Piccino's baked goods. Their chocolate chip cookies are delicious.  Lots of chocolate chunks and moist in the middle. YUM! I've also had their blueberry coffee cake, prune espresso muffin, and cinnamon roll.  All are really good but my favorite is the prune espresso muffin ($2.5).  There are whole prunes baked into the muffin.  There is a downside to this place.  Not all baristas work on the same pace so I usually just stick to coffee if I come here in the morning before work.  I've gone here a few times and waiting for a latte or espresso drink takes longer than most places I frequent.  Also, I'm actually use to stronger tasting coffee and the coffee here is on the lite side.  As a result when I go here I take my single drip coffee black with a little sugar.
author: Eileen B.

description: My kids and I love this place.  We always order the polpette and the pizzas.  We each have our own faves.  I love the fungi, my eldest likes the sausage and shallots, my youngest who is 7 loves the pizza bianca and can finish a  bowl of polpette.  I love their coffee too.
author: Cj P.

description:
I used to regularly get a mocha or french press coffee from Piccino. I noticed a dip in the service and quality in the new location, but it was tolerable. However, since they switched to SIghtglass I have had some downright not good, not enjoyable coffee. Despite the awkwardness of going into Serpentine to get a coffee, that is my new preferred place if I don't have the time to get to Philz.
As for the new pastries/dessert offerings, quite a step up, and the best in the neighborhood except for their cookies. Mr and Mrs has the best cookies, no contest.
author: Emily G.

description: I absolutely adore this place. It's just the right size (cozy but not cramped), the food is wonderful, the waitstaff and owner are unbelievably welcoming, the wine selection is lovely, the pizzas are awesome, the main plates are also awesome, and you feel like part of the neighborhood from the get-go. It's one of the best places I know to take your baby with you to dinner. You feel like you're among friends instead of annoying people, which, let me tell you, is a rarity and a treasure.
author: Arwen O.

description: Beautiful restaurant and good food.  I met a friend here for lunch the other day and we had the margarita pizza, heirloom tomato salad, and the caramelized squash.  The pizza was good, not outstanding, but good.  The other two dishes were quite tasty, even better than the pizza.  Even my five year old loved everything.  Service was good too.  I'll be back.
author: Caroline O.

description: TINY little coffee spot in Dogpatch.  The coffee is strong, the staff is friendly, and they have some of the best soy foam I've ever seen!  Great little pastry case, too.  There's just a bench and 2 stools, so don't plan on hanging out, but it's a great spot to grab a coffee and go for a walk. (Cash only)
author: Cate M.

description: We had a delicious dinner from appetizer to dessert.  I don't have a menu(it changes every day), but my salad of tomatoes with burrata over a delicious creamy polenta was scrumptious.  Our pasta was perfect.  The dessert--a goat cheese custard with fruit puree and toasted pumpkin seeds was memorable.  We were there early, so it was reasonable quiet.  Our waiter was very attentive and helpful.  There is a very interesting clothing store attached/next door.  If you arrive early it is worth a look.
author: Caroline D.

description: I had the ice coffee, not very good. But I'd go back and try something else next time i go get a pedi next door. once more shot! and ill rerate this...
author: Cindy L.

description: I've been in the neighborhood for 6 years and hadn't stopped in until this afternoon. I was a teensy bit hung over and craving a decent pizza. Piccino fit the bill precisely with a very quiet corner spot for the Sunday Times and a delicious Italian-style pepperoni pie.
author: Bowen D.

description: This is such a gem.  The coffee is delicious the atmosphere is friendly (Noah is my favorite Barista!) and the tasty treats behind the glass never disappoint.  You cannot go wrong here.  Make sure you have a little time, as it's a super popular place and sometimes there is a short wait in the am between 8-9 am.
author: Julie H.

description:
I got a confirmed reservation for 815pm for Thurs. 4/05/12 on the phone which was all they had even though I had asked for a 715pm reservation for a birthday celebration for a party of 3. OK, so when we go there at 810pm, the hostess said the people at our table were finishing up dessert. We waited until 850pm to get seated. That party of three businessmen weren't going anywhere. The hostess had tried to offer us the end portion of the communal table near the door. I refused since I had made this reservation and we were not just a walk-in. After all the people who were waiting had been seated before us, we finally had to ask the hostess if we could sit at the far end of a communal table set for 5, because nobody was sitting there for at least 25-30 minutes. Why she didn't offer that to us was beyond me? It was completely different from being squeezed in at the end of a communal table with 6 other table. That far table had 2 people dining separated by a floral piece in the middle.

I chose Piccino because I wanted to be certain I could experience a pleasant evening for a birthday celebration with my family. It was just COMPLETE disappointment!! One would think that a manager would come over to apologize or offer us a complimentary drink, appetizer or dessert. No, instead after 20 minutes, the wine bar staff person asked us if we would like a drink, not on the house. Our French-speaking waiter took our order which took awhile, and forgot our Beef and Pork Meatball appetizer because we were already served our 2 pizzas. We had to remind them that they forgot. For dessert (which is NOT their strong suit) they ran out of the Zeppoles. 

In the restaurant industry, so much is relied on good service and excellent management skills. Piccino did not have exemplify any of those qualities that night. I have told my coworkers and friends to not bother with that place. I could never recommend a restaurant based on that terrible experience, especially when the food was mediocre at best. The hostess should of recognized our dissatisfaction and sent a manager over to speak to us and apologize. I work in healthcare and we offer our patients who have been waiting a long time, a snack, a beverage or even a Starbucks card. And in the restaurant business, how easy it would have been to appease us with an apology and a complimentary appetizer? But instead I left with a very foul feeling and the need to spread the word to others that there are so many other great places to dine in the Bay Area instead of this place.
author: Flo H.

description:
I have been on a vision quest to find good restaurants in the vicinity of my office in the Bayview.  For my intents and purposes Piccino is the Gary Danko of the neighborhood.  I can get clean, healthful, flavorful pizza and a nice half-caf cap for lunch.

I felt like it was a little out of place for the Dogpatch but then again it is an "up and coming" neighborhood - translation, white people are settling down here.  As evidence of this, we were seated next to a white woman with dreads.  

I tried the watermelon heirloom tomato salad because I was intrigued by the pickled watermelon rind.  It was refreshing but a bit too vinegary- it hit the back of my throat uncomfortably after a few bites.  I did enjoy the special white pizza - pancetta, figs, fresh mint.  I admit that I'll order anything with figs in it but the combination of fatty pork, dense sweet fruit and brightening mint was fantastic.  

For dessert I ordered the fresh pear tart which was quite sweet and a little too watery for my taste.  I think they need to add a little bit of flour to the fruit or use a more baker friendly  pear like the bosc.  

The service was pretty good.  The standard Mission hipster, tattooed staff is polite albeit inefficient.

I usually rate pizza places by the Margherita (seriously if you can't get tomato sauce, mozzerella and basil right.. don't open a pizza joint).  So since I didn't order that, I will have to reserve judgment for next time.
author: Monica L.

description: Great food.  Delicious pizzas.  Tried the PIzza Bianca and Pizza with Salciccia.
author: Diego V.

description: Nice, focused, small menu with good vegetarian options. Had a margherita & bianca pizza, fruit bruschetta & lemonade.
author: Mihir M.

description: Fantastic pizzas and cannot wait until their new and improved resturant opens around the corner!
author: Patricia N.

description: One cup at a time coffee done well.  Bold, flavorful and rich. Had to try the thumb print cookie.  They live up to true reputation.
author: Rob F.

description: Great food, great atmosphere. Had the funghi pizza. Should try the ridiculous pizza with capers.
author: Jack K.

description:
Five stars for the coffee bar/dessert only... didn't try the food.  

We happened on this place after dinner at the Hard Knox Cafe, definitely an upscale vibe after a soul food meal!  

Anyhoo - barista, I believe his name is Antonio, was very knowledgeable about the coffee drinks, and I had one of the best mochas in a looooooong time - 2 tablespoons of REAL chocolate in it!!  *yum*

Also had the almond cookies - lots of almond, fabulous.  Chocolate souffle was alright, nothing to write home about.  

We also noticed the similarity with this place and Pizzetta, but can't really compare the pizza since we didn't have any!!
author: Hayley L.

description:
Quaint corner place where you can eat outside at the sidewalk tables -- and if it's cold, there are heat lamps to keep you warm.

The food is good and it has great atmosphere.  The only thing they need to work on is service.  Although they are friendly, they need to be a bit more attentive to their tables - see Sarah R's review - she gave a good synopsis of our experience.

I think with time - they will just get better and better.  The food and ambience is excellent.
author: Gina C.

description:
I haven't been yelping in awhile for a few reasons which range from the usual "I'm too busy" to the legitimate "I haven't found anything yelp-worthy enough to cause my face to light up."  Luckily, the spell has been broken.  I came here yesterday for their Rose and Pizza special and boy did they knock my socks off!  

I've come here before for breakfast and while their coffee was fabulous and their fritatta delish, their pizzas really put them over the top.  You know when restaurants try to overcompensate lack of flavor by piling on the grease and the kitchen sink on their pizzas?  This place was DEFINITELY not that kind of place.  While certainly sometimes that's all I need to make me happy - occasionally, I'm in the mood for a pizza that should be a culinary feat, not just a vomitting of ingredients.  Their pizzas here were really simple but really tasty. I had the Bianca which was amazing!  Dare I say, I liked it better than Pizzeria Delfina.  

Definitely extra points for not having a 1 hour wait, for being within walking distance of my apartment but still having tons of parking if I feel too lazy to walk down, and last but not least - for having outdoor seating areas and HEAT LAMPS which makes it feel like it's an 80 degree day - never mind that you can't see any blue in the sky!
author: Jean A.

description:
You're in my hood so I wanted to love you.  I admit, the very first time we tried you was overspill from Just For You Cafe's super long wait.  We came back on our own to give a second try.  Three things going for you so two stars:
- Bread pudding is f'n delish
- Blue Bottle Coffee
- Our kitschy milk-bottle water carafe (our own for the table, thanks!)
Other than that, long waits, being out of items on your already piccino menu, millenial gaps between your server checking on you, and prices that I think are just a wee bit too high for what your servin up...makes it hard to love.  So, if you aren't starving and have all the time in the world (you know like European 3 hour cups of coffee) you might enjoy.
author: Isa L.

description:
I want to change this back to 4 or 5 stars. But I had a meal recently that left me VERY flat. I want to say it is growing pains. Please fix it. The meatballs were chewy. In a town where you can get Delfina and A16 meatballs, this cannot be. They were light grey, rubbery and just off. The pizza we had was a little odd (peaches) but it worked ok. Not their best. I will be back and hope to review with more starts if they can get their act together.

BTW - the new decor is amazing.
author: Robert U.

description: My experience at Piccino was a joke.  When I arrived there was a solitary customer waiting for his drink and chatting with the barista.  I patiently waited for both his drink to be made and the conversation to end before being allowed to order. I asked for a coffee to go.  I received little to no acknowledgement, which would be fine if the guy working was a least providing good service.  The barista turned around to make the most leisurely-paced, semi-full, mediocre cup of drip coffee I've ever had.  All the while, a large line is forming behind me and another worker comes in to make herself a drink, chat with the dude working and leave.  The barista said hardly a word during the entire transaction, apart from weird grunts and mouth noises he made to himself, and proceeded to overcharge me a dollar. I'm a little suspicious he did it intentionally, but I won't go into that. Needless to say, I won't be coming back.  I can handle holier than thou baristas, but not when they do a crap job of making coffee.
author: Alicia J.

description:
Mixed impressions. 

What they do, they do well. The quality and execution of the food was fantastic, prepared with great attention to detail and care and with good ingredients. However, the choices on offer were limited and disappointing, mostly some combination of vegetables and refined flours. It was impossible to find any substantive nutrition on the menu and that left me with the impression this place is more suited for a "late night snack" than an actual meal. Even the antipasti plate had no meat, just vegetables and some fried bread type things. All were delicious but, again, lacking in protein and fats and leaving me hungry and insufficiently nourished. Same for the pizzas, they tasted great, were well prepared with fantastic ingredients, but had hardly any cheese and very few options with protein, more like a snack than a meal. 

The space was nice but the design was impractical. I was with a party of 3 and we were seated two people at a bench and one person at another bench at a 90 degree angle, which made it extremely difficult to talk; there was no way in this configuration that 3 or 4 people could actually carry on a proper conversation over a meal. 

Service was great. Attentive, helpful, thoughtful, and timely.
author: Eater S.

description: I've walked by this place a few times but never ventured in. Ordered some pizza for take out the other day and was pleasantly surprised. Need to come back and actually eat here next time but would def. recommend it.
author: shadi m.

description: can't wait to go back for the kale salad, funghi pizza and zeppole!
author: Dorothy L.

description: I could have brunch here and then stay all day to then have dinner. It's just great. The pizzas for breakfast are outstanding. Sometimes they grill outside as well and that is outstanding. I give them a 4 1/2 star for good food, setting and service. It's just a great place for a glass of wine on a saturday afternoon. Everything I have had was very tasty.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Hurray for a new lunch place that's chic and good locale.

Bohoo for the inconsistent service; made me regret sitting outside.

Ummm for the okay food and the very small portion (what can I say, I didn't feel satisfied after the lunch).  Should have gotten the pizza.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
best gourmet pizza in the city and they serve Blue Bottle coffee!

Brian and Cambria make it feel like home.
author: Minotaur N.

description:
Some might say I'm picky about my pizza, but I used to be just like all the other poor sods who like their crust thick and their sauce sweet.  Once upon a time I consumed *shudder* Dominos (of course it was probably at a sleepover and followed by a game of Truth or Dare), but 8 years on the other coast has helped me see the error of my ways.

Piccino's does Neapolitan style right.  The crust is thin and chewy, crisp in places without being burned black.  The cheese has real flavor. The sauce is tangy and the toppings combinations are well-thought out.  

My only gripe is that they don't deliver so take-out pies are a little chilled after a 10 block ride in my passenger seat.  But that should really be a lesson to me to dine in instead.
author: Sara J.

description:
Not bad...just not great.  

In the morning, if you want a trendy and slightly more expensive cup of coffee that's just OK, then come here.  If you want a really good cup of coffee that won't break the budget, then head one block west to Cup of Blues.  

Went here for dinner one night, and the pizza was pretty good - creativity is definitely on the menu.
author: Chris W.

description:
This place is great.  A little pricey, but you get what you pay for = Blue Bottle coffee, prepared perfectly, nice staff, light, yet decedent pizzas, tantalizing treats, and indoor and outdoor seating. I wish the sun would hit more of the outdoor seats, as it gets chilly, but that's what the coffee is for!

A must try!
author: Bay M.

description: Love this place.  Pizzas are soooo good.  We often get the funghi (assortment of mushrooms),  the margherita, salsiccia, or blanco.  Good wine list as well.  A neighborhood gem.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Rude Rude Rude - worst service ever

After placing an order for  simple panini  sandwich on a non busy Saturday afternoon 2:45 pm . The waitress comes back at 3:05 to tell us the kitchen  doesn't  handle sandwiches after 3. We were Surprised that they would bother making a point of the 5 minutes nor did it help that we placed the order 15 minutes before 3.  The manager apologize for the waitress took too long to process the order but did nothing to help.  The couldn't care less waitress attitude and the fact 3:15 that the table next to us gets a sandwich added to the fine dining experience.  It was so bad we had to tell the manager we for sure will not be ever coming back. She makes a comment " What did the waitress not comp you for it?" . Not only that she didn't make sure the waitress followed her instruction to comp us, when she realized she did not , she pulls a twenty bill from the register and points it to us.

Sorry we decline your twenty , we decline your condescending attitude.
author: eyal h.

description: Wonderful food! I found this gem while my sister was on a lunch break from work. I ate one of the Primi dishes "marinated cucumber, little gems, citrus, juniper and fried capers", this is an amazing small salad I could eat all day long. There is no salad dressing on it but the taste of these marinated cucumbers and fried capers and juniper adds enough flavor to keep your taste buds satisfied. My sister had the "baked semolina gnocchi, peas, carrots, parmesan broth and basil pesto" I tried a small bite and it was wonderful too! My mother ordered the Pisello pizza which was surprisingly tasty! it contains an odd combination of english peas, buffalo mozzarella, pea tendrils and herb pesto. I thought this place was a great hidden gem in the dog patch with creative souls mingling at tables all around me. I loved the cool creative san francisco vibe. The one down side is that it is a bit pricey for lunch, but what good food isn't pricey these days :(
author: Lindsey A.

description: We love this place! Granted we are biased as we live a few blocks away and absolutely love Dogpatch, but Piccino is one of those establishments that actually *makes* Dogpatch.  The food is consistently excellent, fresh ingredients, innovative preparations, and always friendly service.  We haven't been to their new space which is literally around the corner from their old one, but we can't wait to treat ourselves to a meal there soon.
author: sita c.

description:
Fresh, clean, simple, brilliant.
And great coffee from Blue Bottle next door at the end of your meal.
author: Jedidiah B.

description:
My wife and I stumbled into this place a couple of years ago, not more than a few days after it opened.  The employees seemed clueless.  The guy behind the counter did not appear to know how to use a cash register and took like 20 minutes to make our coffee.  As we waited we joked that the place looked like it was run by a bunch of amateurs.  

But then we got our coffee!  Wow, it was simply the best coffee we'd ever had.  Rich flavor, pungent yet smooth, and very fresh tasting.  We learned that they serve the famous Blue Bottle brand of coffee, which certainly lives up to the hype.  And while the counter guy did take a long time to make the coffee, he apparently knew what he was doing, very much so.  We became regulars after that first visit. 

We later tried the food, which it turns out is quite good, especially the pizzas.  I'd go with the Bianca pizza, which is topped with three types of cheese.  But, be warned, the portions are small.  Also, they serve everything on these annoying little plates, which look like a high school art project gone wrong.  

They recently expanded, moving the coffee operation to an adjacent storefront.  This cleared some badly needed space in their dinning room, but took some of the fun out of the coffee experience.  Instead of waiting for your coffee at their old zinc bar and chatting with the people in to enjoy their morning paper, you now huddle in the small dark closet like coffee space.  Also, now you can't get espresso-based coffee drinks with dinner, as the coffee bar closes early.  Regardless, at Piccino, the pluses still greatly outweigh the minuses.
author: Jon B.

description: Food here is very good, especially the thin crust pizzas.  Brussel sprouts were delicious, the chocolate dessert also excellent.  Nice open atmosphere, very clean.  The servers were a bit pretentious and not as attentive as they should be, especially with so many people waiting for a table.  We could easily have been done 20 minutes earlier if the waiter had attended to us more quickly.
author: Nancy F.

description: 5 stars for the Cinnamon roll, which around 7:30 AM is still warm from the oven. i'm a stickler for cin rolls and sticky buns, and there's is a winner. coffee is great too. none of it cheap, but as a treat it's a great spot
author: Eric T.

description:
The food and hospitality make this a must go spot with the Foodies of SF.  I almost don't want to share this gem for fear it will become over crowded!  

Real people serving up exceptional Italian fare in a charming atmosphere is a rare find. Ladies and Gentleman, I refer your cravings to Piccino.  The quaint cafe setting with indoor and outdoor seating is perfect for a quite dinner with good friends or that special someone.  

Chef's Kimi Walker and Carlo Espinas create simple dishes that are bursting with flavor.  It is obvious that the ingredients are top shelf, extremely fresh,  and paired with great wine.  The open kitchen and warmth of Kimi and Carlo make you feel like you are amongst special friends.

We began our meal with a pork pate with Dijon mustard and pickled carrots.  The texture was incredible and the spice of the Dijon went well with the Chianti Kimi had recommended.   

The next course was a beef carpaccio that dishes namesake, painter Vittore Carpaccio, would have been proud of.

For the main course we had a sampling of thin crust pizza.  The three cheese and roasted garlic, and pepperoni and mozzarella were wonderful.  Taking center stage in both presentation and taste was the summer squash and pesto pizza with basil.  Truly fantastic.

Dessert was a pineapple upside down cake that simply melted in your mouth paired with some of the best coffee this side of Columbia.

Make the trip to Piccino!  You won't be disappointed.
author: Ben V.

description:
Nice looking place that adds a lot of color to the area.  I ate there recently and very much enjoyed their special pizza which had 2 eggs on top (don't know if it's always served).  I'm actually writing this review right now because I wish I had that pizza in front of me right now.

Otherwise the other pizza I had with my friend was on the smaller side.  In any case the staff is very friendly and we didn't have to wait long on a Sunday afternoon to be seated.  Also, their coffee is pretty bombalicious.  I love that Blue Coffee stuff.  That's worth going for alone.  Their lattes are pretty awesome too.  I would give this place 5 stars if their portions were just a tad larger.  Otherwise this place is great.

Wish they had more predictable hours, I still can't figure out what their weekly schedule is.
author: Joe P.

description:
Had their two house-special pizzas -- sunnyside-up eggs, and bacon/fig.  Both were terrific.  (Eggs?  On pizza?  Yeah.  A new one for me, too.)   Next time, it's going to be a pizza and a salad, as those looked good, too.  

As mentioned elsewhere, great coffee.  Friendly service, nice atmosphere.  I feel like we must've lucked out, being able to get a seat right away.
author: Tom H.

description:
Sorry, but cute doesn't cut it in my book. Yes, the place is a welcome addition to the neighborhood. The food was good, with some really impressive items (duck leg confit; salumi platter; pizza); some not so impressive items (polenta with mushroom ragu; biscotti). Nice wine list that was reasonably priced. Blue bottle espresso was ferosh. Fact that all the food is local source is a huge plus. But the food here is not the problem.

PROBLEM: The place is insanely small. I think it seats 14. I'm not exaggerating. Unless you show up very early or very late, be prepared to hike around the block to Yield where you can wait for an hour for your table. Which, by the way, the staff were really cool about. They'll take your cell phone number and call you when the table is ready. Considering the scarcity of seats, why they don't take dinner reservations is beyond me. Minus one star.

Unfortunately, the guy who was really attentive when we first arrived and tried to determine if we could get a table, was gone by the time we were seated, leaving us with the B team. His mind was elsewhere this night; definitely not on our table. Considering the small size of the restaurant, you figure clearing dishes between courses would be a priority. Sigh. Other little gaps occurred, which, while not huge, cost them a star.

So, go for lunch, if you're having dinner at 5p, or if you don't mind hanging out for a while at the wine bar around the corner. If those aren't a problem for you, the food is worth it.
author: Arkay K.

description:
I'm grudgingly giving 4 stars based entirely on their food.  This tiny neighborhood restaurant makes their own pizza dough, granola, and other core ingredients, and the attention shows.  I've had several menu items, and the flavors are clean an certainly yummy.  Their full-service espresso menu is wonderful.

But, inevitably, my dining experience is marred by a few problems.  First, they have yet to work out a reasonable service rotation so I always spend far too long waiting to order, get food (that I can see waiting at the pass) and paying my check.  This is inexcusable for such a small place.  Second, the menu is tiny.  Show up only if you're interested in their pizza, because there are almost no other choices (save a lovely ham Pannino).  Finally, the portions tend to be undersized.  This is fine for the average person (I'm 6'4"), but don't pick Piccino if you're really hungry.

Overall, though, it's locally sourced tasty gourmet individual pizzas made with care and worth a visit.
author: Kyle V.

description:
Now you have a reason to visit the Dogpatch.  We accidentally hit it on a super busy night and it took a long time for the pizza but all was forgiven.

I compare pizza places by the standard plain pizza and this place is very tasty.  Thin crust, delicious.   They also serve a Bianca (white) pizza that is hands down the best white pizza I have ever had.

Worth the trip.  Great salads, friendly staff.  Relatively small if it isn't nice enough to sit outside.
author: Narendra R.

description:
Great neighborhood, you can really see and taste the rustic beauty of the local food in all their dishes.

Antipasti Platter: Such a beautiful and simple start to a meal. I feel like each ingredient is prepared and seasoned to deliver it best flavor.  Except this time when we received it there was no spread. I only mention that because it is with flat bread and there was nothing to spread on the flat bread.

Arrugala & Blood Orange salad: Just loved it. Clean, fresh and bright.

Salsiccia Pizza: This pie would be perfect if only they added tomato sauce which is how you would expect it.
author: Gee C.

description: 8 months after our last visit - I can't believe Piccino has taken these heights, from the humble beginning we remember from a couple years back.  We had our meal right between the lunch and dinner service transition.  We sat at the bar and were entertained in the sights, smell, and sounds of the kitchen staff prepping meals.  We started with a strawberry salad and shared a couple of the pizzas (margarita and funghi).  The funghi is served without a sauce necessarily but rather, a finely chopped array of wild mushrooms that provide a base for a gentle touch of cheese and porcini mushrooms.  AWESOME esp with a egg on top.  For dessert we split the hazelnut chocolate torte - it is served cold but melts in your mouth...reminds us of a semifreddo in terms of how it smoothly coats the palate of your mouth in sweet cool chocolate complimented by salty caramel.  With a carafe of wine and tip we plopped down 1 Benjamin.  It was well worth it and makes us miss the city even more.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND - the service was spotless.
author: Sheetal S.

description: the interior of the restaurant from ambiance to decor reminds me of freshly laundered dress shirts...clean, crisp, and airy. it's got very high ceilings and lots windows for natural light to shine through. the menu is short and sweet. i really enjoy the open concept of their dining area and kitchen. it makes the dining experience very intimate. the margherita pizza was solid. not the best i've had, but definitely well made. the baked "gnocchi" on the other hand, looked and tasted more like polenta. not what the bf had in mind. but hey, every institution is entitled to their own interpretation of a dish. i'm not here to judge, i'm just here to eat.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
came here for dinner with my husband and some friends last night.  Nice, cute little place.  We ordered:

- the antipasti plate: great crispy yummy flatbread served with cauliflower, chickpea, raddish, olives, apple slices and carrot slices
- the monterey sardines: fishy in a nice way
- winter chard: my least favorite of the night, a little dry and chewy
- the pork and beef meatball with polenta and tomato sauce: very nice, "spicy" (both hot and full of spices) and fluffy meatballs, paired great with the polenta
- the funghi pizza: nice and earthy, very light taste
- the "red" pizza: panchetta, tomato sauce and red onion with ricotta

For dessert, we ordered the lemon tart, chocolate tart and the olive oil cake.  We ranked the chocolate tart #1, lemon tart #2, olive oil cake #3.

All in all, I think we enjoyed our time because of the great company we have, but the relaxed and friendly atmosphere and service definitely helped.  I loved the thin crust pizzas even though I normally don't eat pizza.  I think I'd definitely come back for lunch on a lazy afternoon.  Though I would not deem the food "exceptional", it's good enough that I'd recommend to my friends.
author: M F.

description: Quite possibly the best thin crust pizza I've ever had! I've tried the Peperonata (gypsy pepper, caramelized onion, green olive and pancetta) and the Bianca (parmesan, pecorino and mozzarella, shaved garlic and chili oil), and both were fantastic. The Bianca was simple and delicious, but I really fell in love with the Peperonata. So much flavor and every ingredient was so fresh and distinct. You can tell that there's a lot of intention in every aspect of your meal, and they really get the details right. Even the simple garden lettuce salad at Piccino's is beautiful, and again, so fresh. I love the bright, open space, and open kitchen, all surrounded by so much natural light. The interior plays into the modern/industrial feel of the Dogpatch neighborhood it's located in, and is very nicely designed. Service from the guy who let us come in at the very last minute for lunch was excellent, however, our actual waitresses could have been friendlier (they might have been peeved since we probably extended their lunch shift...but still). I'd highly reccomend Piccino's if you're a thin crust pizza lover, you'll be very satisfied.
