Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous is just down the street too for some awesome ice cream afterwards --Earl Grey is my favorite!
author: Kamie P.

description:
One of my top 3 favorite cafes in the bay. I live 2 blocks away so any time I'm lazy in the morning (which is more often than not) I walk on over for a soy latte and a ginger scone.

Favorites there:
-soy latte (doy)
-ginger scone (doy again)
-this pear focaccia thing
-chocolate brownie (kinda pricey)

I haven't been there for wine or the pizzettas but I hear the pizzetta is AWESOME. Oh and they also use Blue Bottle coffee (and sell it) but it's a very specific blend I believe that's different from the kiosk on Linden.
author: ShaColby J.

description:
Perfect breakfast before Caltrain =

1. Hand made ceramic drip cup of piccino blend coffee (crack cocaine in a cup) ... occasional lump of brown sugar

2. House made yogurt and granola

3. Dogpatch sunrise coming thru trees surrounding the cafe

Best pre-work morning in town! ... Now they just need to be open on Monday mornings!
author: ed h.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker, so I don't go all ga-ga over blue bottle.  And I think there's room for improvement in the breakfast baked goods -- I've certainly tasted better scones.

However, for dinner I think Piccino is great.  Sitting outside under the trees on a heatwave-warm SF summer evening drinking a glass of wine and eating their yummy pizza is a pretty nice way to pass the time.  The lemon tart is seriously toothsome.  Staff are lovely and will bring your dog a water bowl and maybe even a homemade treat.
author: Annette K.

description:
Great dual-purpose cafe in an up-and-coming neighborhood. Coffee shop by day, light restaurant by night. The menu is creative, very good, and constantly changing. I would broadly describe it as Continental/Mediterranean in flavor, California cuisine in philosophy. Pizzas are properly Italian style. The espresso is the best I have had in the Bay Area, and is the greatest standout here. The configuration and atmosphere is friendly and familiar, but open and relaxing (the second standout feature), and the staff is both friendly and helpful. I am vegetarian and generally survive easily on either small plates or margherita pizza.

Two key failings:

Espresso is only served until ca. 5pm, at which point they shut off the machine. Why? Seriously, it is phenomenal, and people want it -- why send the baristas home at 5, of all times?

Wine is served in short tumblers, and is 100% European. The tumblers make delightful water or juice glasses, but completely fail to focus the smells (and therefore much of the flavor) of the wines, and the European exclusivity in the wine list is just needlessly narrow. Yield, a half block away, is a much better place to properly enjoy a glass or three.
author: Jonathan R.

description: I've eaten here several times and have always enjoyed the food, and the treats at the cafe are especially delectable, which led me to order 2 dozen of their chocolate chip cookies for an event. What I was really impressed with was their accommodating and helpful customer service, as I ran out of time to pick up my treats and make my event in time so they worked with me to get my 2 dozen cookies to me safely and in time for my event! The manager and general manager were very supportive and helpful and I SO appreciated it! Everyone at the event LOVED the cookies and the 2 dozen were gone within minutes.
author: Nicole K.

description: Another treasure in the Dogpatch. I love places that easy, but nice. Pizza was excellent. Meatballs were delicious but a little pricy.
author: B Y.

description:
delicious pizza and appetizers. 

i love the decor--particularly all the black eames chairs in a space with so much natural light.

this is a great spot for a date night, groups, etc. 

definitely worth the trek out to the dogpatch.
author: arielle r.

description: My cousin and I stumbled upon this place this past weekend. We got lost and this place caught our attention. It was perfect timing too because we were starting to get hungry. I pulled up their Yelp page on my phone and the 4-star rating gave us courage to go in and give it a try. We were pleasantly surprised by how nice and clean the decor looked, in contrast with the surrounding neighborhood. We ordered the funghi and salsiccia pizzas. Both were flavorful in a subtle way and the ingredients tasted fresh. I'm a fan of mushrooms, so I preferred the funghi over the salsiccia. My one gripe is that it's overpriced.
author: Mark T.

description: I'm all for blue bottle sold in various neighborhoods in the city. Yay for blue bottle in the Dogpatch! I've been coming here for my fix and it does the trick. They have pastries and snacks too that look pretty yummy. I have yet to try the meatball sandwich.
author: Kristy H.

description: What happened to our favorite neighborhood pizza place? Piccino's has moved from the blue Victorian building to the yellow building on the other corner. They have now more space and full kitchen equipment. Staff is all new and the place has a posh Design Within Reach interior and image. I was so much looking forward to the new place and today went with two friends to try it out. I took two appetizers, first one was goat cheese and artichokes, second one was carrot soup. Both were ok but portions very small. What didn't go well, was that my appetizers were brought to the table both at the same time and they insisted on giving my other appetizer to my friend. They also insisted on giving me fork and knife for my soup. My friends both had pepperoni pizza.... but 40 minutes after I have gotten my two appetizers. The pizza is different now, not as tasty and it was not possible to make the usual alterations. What really was different, was how they are organized.... disorganized.  Waiters did not seem to have assigned tables and they all attended in their own ways to every table. While there was plenty of staff, everybody was annoyed how long it took to be served and servers seemed to continue on bringing cutlery and empty plates to tables and moving them around.The same empty plate came in front of my friend and disappeared three times. Quite hilarious. Our favorite staff that were so much fun to talk to, so knowledgeable, and so caring were not there anymore. We left hungry and disappointed.
author: Kir S.

description:
On coffee, cookies, and crappy crust:

When the waiter told me that they were out of desserts, other than the cookie platter, I was kind of pissed.  I normally plan for something a little more decadent at the end of a meal when I eat out. But may I just say--wow, those are some damn good cookies! Interesting flavors, and just plain kickass dipped in Piccino's really good coffee.

But anyhow, on to the pizza, which is why I'd hopped the 22 to Piccino in the first place. I have one word for you: Meh. I mean, the toppings were good, but the crust leaves much to be desired. It's thin,  which is good, but closer to a tasteless cracker than a good crispy pizza crust (which should be crispy on the outside, but have more genuine breadiness on the inside).  

When all is said and done, I'd give it 3.5 stars.  Hooray for toppings and coffee and cookies.  The crust was my only complaint, but that's kind of the central pizza element.  Which raises a question of yelp protocol... do you round up with an in-between rating? I'm going to have to vote no. Crappy crust doesn't deserve to be over-rated, even if the place has other redeeming qualities.

That said, any time I'm in Dogpatch, I'm making a beeline to Piccino for cookies and coffee.
author: David K.

description:
We know Loring well from other neighborhood activites and were so excited when Piccino opened - 

Atmopshere:  it is well named "little space" indeed - charming and cozy - great for a week night meal or a morning cup of coffee 

COFFEE:  in caps as this is THE reason to go here - blue bottle - need I say more?  YUM!

Food:  perfect pizzas - and this from a woman with an outdoor pizza oven at home - my only criticism is that my husband says he "never gets full" when we eat here - we are both very active people (running, biking, hiking, swimming, yoga etc) so need to "refuel" on week nights after working out and the portions don't quite do it for that - however on the weekends the fritatta or scones with coffee are the perfect breakfast - 

Overall:  we love this place - a very welcome addition to the neighborhood - best cup of coffee in town - and they sell whole beans too
author: Mylea C.

description:
Great Pizzas and great service!
Oh the salad and lemon tart are good too.
author: Frank L.

description:
The cute, little, freshly made and seemingly authentic Italian looking pizzas were good.  Very good.  Probably more aesthetically pleasing than rich in flavor, but still fun.  I remember not being too thrilled with the desserts.

It's a cute spot, a nice little cafe to hit up.  a tad on the expensive side, but kind of understandable when you peer into the window and see the owner creating your beautiful little pizza completely from scratch.  i say sure, give it a go.
author: Hella M.

description: A hidden gem in dog patch.  I came here with a friend who's new to the neighborhood for what was a quick bite.  We didn't expect such yummy homemade pizza and fabulous service.  We shared the pepperone pizza and napolitana pizza with anchovies.  They were made to perfection and so fresh.  Our waitress was so friendly and bubbly.  We ate outside but the dining room inside is cute and perfect for a date night.  I will definitely return for another meal!
author: P.J. D.

description: Unique yet familiar.  Great place for lunch or mid afternoon snack.
author: Sharky T.

description: Gave it another try.  Good food and super friendly owners.  We shared a "pink flight", which was fun.  The meatballs were okay, not nearly as tasty as Delfina's.  The pizza was good and simple (al funghi).
author: Kevin M.

description:
What happened?
My boss always takes me to Piccino for lunch when I visit her. I used to love the friendly young staff, the atmosphere, the "buzz" inside the small restaurant, and last but not least; the food. Today we stepped into this new big "wanna-be-fine-dining" environment. Don't take me wrong, the place looks great, the Architecture has done a great job. But when we had been greeted by 4 different people not knowing that we had already been helped it started to become awkward; don't they communicate in here.  Once we got a table we ordered our food, but it took over 45 minutes for us to get the food. The old "blue corner" staff was gone and the new staff seemed very inexperienced and confused, different people kept on coming to our table either swapping plates, cutlery, or asking how we were doing. Something had changed, their was not the love and caring that the old staff always showed, there was no paying attention to details, there was no good feeling. We both left the restaurant hungry and disappointed. Next time I am in town my boss promised she would take me somewhere else.
author: Marten S.

description: Two things, one they definitely give more than a sh*t about the food, and two when you can walk into a pizza place and NOT have pizza an still end up with an awesome meal. You just can't do much better.
author: Nik H.

description: Wow, what a great place with nice ambiance and excellent service. It's a bigger place so you don't feel crowded. Locally sourced and sustainable food also. There's so much good food on the menu but I can't stop thinking about that mushroom pizza. I love Piccino and when out of towners arrive this is the first stop on their SF food experience.  You gotta try Piccino.
author: M H.

description:
Taking a cue from my fellow Yelpers, I wandered down to Dogpatch to check out Piccino and their thin crust pizza.  One word: Yummm!

Being a thin crust snob, I'm always a little leerly of what others claim in good thin crust. (after traveling through Italy a couple of time, you realize your childhood was robbed by eating cardboard flavored pizza)  But Picciono got it just right.  Crisp, thin, not chewy and covered with just the right about of sauce where you can still taste the toppings.  If I had any complaint, it would be the sauce.  It was a little flavorless during our afternoon visit, but maybe it was just a off-day.  We'll be definitely be going back again, so we'll see.

The service was professional, but not overtly friendly.  The staff actually made a mistake with our order, but it was quickly remedied.

Take a hike over to this forgotten part of The City for some tasty pie made the right way.
author: Karl W.

description:
From the chef's knives in the kitchen, to the fixtures and stools, everything in this room is from Ikea.
At least, it contributes for a new and clean finish.  The menu and dishes are unsurprising, you will find cute local couples from Potrero, having an early dinner at 5pm because they are bored or, i hope, a late brunch because they had sex all morning long.
Good atmosphere, go if you want to have a relaxing, no-brainer kinda experience.
And, i agree, Blue Bottle Coffee is goooood coffee!!  Members from the same family are operating these 2 businesses.
author: Damien J.

description:
Piccino is a lovely and delicious (and TINY) pizza bistro.  The food is great, but the service is spotty.  I love the pizzas and the desserts...cookie plate....and the coffee.  Check out this link for my detailed review of the restaurant:
http://lawyereats.blogspot.com/2007/07/piccino-food-10-service-3.html
author: LawyerEats S.

description:
I lived within site of this gem since before it opened.  I didn't know a single person in the neighborhood until it did.  Best coffee in the city.  Pizza is great and I sure do miss these folks.  Love it.  I am an addict.  

Hipsters beware - Keep going to Ritual Coffee your not cool enough for Piccino.
author: J B.

description: I love this place.  Every time I have visitors in from out of town, or any time I want to just go and have a reliably fantastic meal, Piccino's is where I go.  Their pizzas are SO good - delicious toppings and an always perfect crust.  The servers are friendly and nice, and the wine selection is good.  The lemon tart dessert is always a treat.  Oh - and they always have interesting in-season side dishes too.  Piccino's is truly one of San Francisco's gems.
author: Heather C.

description: This place makes pretty good pizza. Fresh thin crust style and very tasty. But it's one of those fufu pizza joints that's too pricey for my blood. If I was in a higher tax bracket maybe I'd visit here more often. But any lunch over $10 is stretching it for me and just not wise for my sad budget. However the time I did come here for dinner I was not disappointed although I wasn't at all filled. After a Giants' game and a plenty of drinking this was a good option as my car was parked nearby and I needed to sober up fully. However for me, it's a case of quality versus proportion and price when choosing to revisit a restaurant, or not, so I haven't been back since.
author: Epicurious M.

description: Ah, yes. The typical overpriced, pretentious, stylized San Francisco eatery. I recommend two prerequisites before dining at Piccino. One, you should not be hungry. Two, you should have lots of extra money that you don't need and are anxious to throw away.  We arrived to a completely empty restaurant before the lunch hour. Not a soul inside. We asked for a table for two and were asked if we had a reservation. We did not, so we were offered two seats at the bar. When I pointed to the empty dining room, the hostess shuffled some papers, huffed and puffed and miraculously found us a table! Imagine that. I'll skip over the other irrittating details, but the menu featured a whopping two entrees, salads, antipasti and pizza. When I asked if I was missing the pasta or chicken, the waitress told me that the chef was not offering pasta that day. Hmmmm....Italian restaurant with no pasta. That makes sense. So, my tiny $15.00 bowl of meatballs arrived. Each meatball was cocktail-sized and there were six in the bowl. That comes out to $2.50 per tiny meatball. No vegetable, no pasta (not today), not even a sprig of parsley. I assumed that the chef wasn't fetauring parsley that day either. Oh, by the way, no bread on the table prior to the meal being served.  So, I got an eyecup full of mini meatballs and......uuuuuh.....nothing else for my fifteen hard earned dollars. But, I did feel oooooh so very hip and trendy the whole time I was there. Too bad no movers and shakers saw me through the front window. In their defense, the meatballs were very tasty!
author: Scott L.

description: If you'd like to pay to be ignored by a bored hipster while he serves his bud, who strolled in after you, by all means pay this place a visit. If you're lucky, you will have the chance to watch a staff member scratch their chin and explore new depths of conversation with a kindred spirit. Finally, after this beautiful tableau has unfolded, you can participate in a new form of interactive theatre, where you are a protagonist who must convince the world that your drink order is worthy of consideration, doesn't need to be altered to better suit the tastes of the master coffee maker, and in fact was voiced clearly to their previously donned persona minutes ago.
author: Chris M.

description: Have gone past this spot several times and always liked the look of it from the outside. Sidewalk tables and full of people. Can't say I was that impressed when I actually went there to eat lunch though. Service was pretty slow, and the menu was overpriced. The pizza sauce was really tasty, but $10 for a personal Margherita with barely any cheese and about 5 small pieces of basil sprinkled about just didn't seem worth it. Next time I'll go across the street to Just for You cafe.
author: jaja w.

description:
My SO and I practically live at Piccino. GREAT food: fresh. seasonal, local ingredients beautifully prepared. Wonderful soups--sometimes vegetarian, sometimes not--and luscious contorni. They always have pizzas but will also prepare other dishes on a seasonal basis. Check out their special food events, around which you can always count on some amazing grouping of dishes. The portions are not standard-American-"I just plowed the back forty"-restaurant sized, but nice and normal. Really, the flavor and presentation are so satisfying you feel nourished all kinds of ways. Anyway, it's nice to have space for dessert.

The staff and the whole general aesthetic is really great.
author: Claudia L.

description: regarding Piccino Cafe Bar (entrance on 22nd St) only: the Fig Newton is amazing. with the cold-brewed coffee on a lazy afternoon, it was the perfect pick-me-up snack. omg, that crumbly shortbread. have to have more!
author: A. M.

description: everything is delicious and fresh!  only criticism- they need better music in the restaurant.  but the food is otherwise great.
author: Laleh J.

description: Delicious coffee and sweets and a bright, little spot, albeit a bit slow on service.
author: M R.

description: I love the coffee and homemade pastries here.  I've also had their thin crust pizzas at lunchtime.  I like the unique topping combinations and the thin crust makes for a light lunch.
author: Julie D.

description: This place is a 5 star joint if you don't mind slow service, bite size paninis that cost $8.50 and have only 6 items on the menu to choose from.  Don't think I'll be coming back. There are plenty of other places around the area, don't get suckered in by their "cute" decor.
author: Brian H.

description:
I have never posted a review here, though I have lurked around and found yelp quite helpful from time to time. I am posting this review as a public service - my way of saying thanks to all the other reviewers here whose information I have found so useful.

I have been waiting for this pizza/cafe joint to open since I first heard about it coming to my 'hood. I consider myself the worst kind of pizza snob (yes from new york) and while I was quite excited about piccino opening its doors, I was also terribly afraid that, well, it would suck. New restaurants don't open very often in the sleepy dogpatch, and if it wasn't any good, I would be stuck with pizza mediocrity for years. So it was with a bit of trepidation, and much anticipation, that I went to piccino today (they just opened this week), and ordered myself a margherita pizza (tomato sauce, basil, cheese). 

The place is small, no more than 12 chairs inside and has the feel of a small, relaxed lunch cafe. there are a few small tables outside also, but its a bit chilly this time of year to be eating outside. The decor is nice, and the service was relaxed and extremely friendly. To be honest, I cared not at all about the decor and service - but perhaps you do.

The pizza. This is the only thing that matters (they serve other stuff like sandwiches and espresso and blah blah - it all looked quite good actually, but I care not). First, it is NOT an nyc/brooklyn greasy slice. It doesn't exist here in SF, (Arinell is close but not quite - the sauce is off) likewise you can't find a good burrito in the east village. These are just the cruel vagaries of life - get over it (even though I can''t). But back to my pizza. The pizza is a single pie (they had three or four different pies, but you always judge a pizza place based on the basics), no slices for sale here. It is thin, exceptionally thin. If you don't like thin pizza, you are a.) weird b.) unwelcome here. The crust has a satisfying crispiness (no you won't be folding these wafer thin slices), and tastes like great bread. Then there is the sauce. this is clearly the highlight of the pizza. I have tried almost every pizza in the bay area (from extreme pizza to chez panisse) and not one has had a sauce this good. It is appropriately fresh tasting, it is just sweet enough and sour enough, with a perfect amount of saltiness to stand up to the crust and the cheese. And the cheese/sauce ratio is perfect. Yes, the mere fact that I could see the sauce was a good sign, but most importantly the taste combination was spot on. 

This pizza is definitely a 'gourmet  pizza', but in its most simplistic form. I find it superior to Delfina, Pizzetta 211, Arizmendi, and even the venerable Cheeseboard. My standards for pizza are very, very high, and although it is not the best pizza I have ever had (Joe's Pizza, 7 Carmine St. NYC - hands down, bar none, best slice in the world, even more so at 3am) it is, in its own category, a sublime delight. My only sadness is that it is so small - i foresee some very long waits in my future. I almost decided not to post this review, and maybe I'll get lucky and it will never find the light of day, but as I said at the top, this is my public service to yelpers, and I'm not sure when, if ever, I will feel compelled to write in again.
author: Sterling S.

description: Best cappuccino in the city by day. Pizzas, small plates for supper. The food feels virtuous and lovingly crafted.
author: chris o.

description: Oh my god this place is freaking amazing. It is such a hidden gem in Dogpatch. Totally reasonable and the greatest breakfast I've had in a long time. The toast with the creme freche and berries is to die for and the breakfast pizza hurt it was so good. Not to mention there's nothing better than fresh french pressed coffee. The people there were totally nice too, I can't believe it was so empty!
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
I should give this place 1 star because I don't want it to get too popular, but it really does deserve a good rating. 

Tasty food at reasonable prices and just a very nice, comfortable ambiance.  I'm a fan.
author: n s.

description: That was a damned good espresso.  Served in a super cute demitasse.  Seriously one hell of a tasty shot.
author: Tom B.

description: awesome cappucinos in a very well decorated garage, no wifi and only 2 tables so usually just grab a drink and run
author: Nadia E.

description: I would give it 5 stars but I reserve that for super special food ; ) This place is GREAT!!! The food is fresh, tasty and a little bit unique. I had something last night called Contorno (a vegetable dish) and it was so delicious. Oh and a white bean, arthichoke soup...YUM!!! The place is small so not a good place for a large party. Enjoy!!!
author: Rob F.

description:
Well, let me tell you that this is the worst place to go eat if you are actually hungry. Like the worst. For a 20 dollar cup of coffee and a snack, the place is right up the alley of alleys.
  I have been trying to go and eat at some high class joints. My friends have been teasing me about the "foodie" thing for some time. I like to eat and I like to try new things. Striking out smarts, though. And this place did.
  Have you ever seen any media teasing the idiocy of fine dining? You know, the kinds that show people paying a shitload of money for a shred of salad and a cooked pigeon foot on the center of a massive plate, all topped off by rude service from some snotty prick? Piccino comes a little close to that.
  The first time I was in there, I got the "we don't serve crap here go somewhere else because we don't even know what crap is, " crap from them. I was on my way to work in the Point and needed coffee and breakfast. There is NOTHING in the way of decent breakfast in the Point, so I stopped in the Dogpatch on my way out there. I wanted a cup of coffee and a bagel. Piccino was the only thing open. Inside, I got a "we don't serve bagels, but you can buy this crappy artisan bread for $35 and then put some of our crappy artisan butter on it for $29 extra. By the way, we are annoying posers." They also acted completely lost when I asked them if they knew of anything around there that sold a simple bagel. They also acted insulted when I didn't want to pay an arm for their stuff.
  If I wanted high end breakfast, I wouldn't have asked for a bagel.         They did have Blue Bottle, which saved their asses, believe me. If you don't know what Blue Bottle is by now, go the fuck back to your mom's house and that big red can of Sanka.
  Well, I left. Flash forward to a few days ago. I wanted to go and eat with my girlfriend. She suggested something tried and true, but I wanted a change. Expansion of the knowledge I already got. I got on this trusty site and typed in Dogpatch and italian. I got Piccino.
  We drove out and parked. The second I walked up to the place, I felt a sinking in my empty stomach. But I wanted to try something new, and if we turned around, my girlfriend would have given me shit for the rest of the night. She likes to do that. 
  We took a seat next to the door. It is a small place(REALLYSMALL), with only five tables. The kitchen takes up most of the place, and there are tables outside. If the weather is cold out and the doors are open, then you get to shiver while you eat. (Note to restaurant owners who are to cheap to install heaters.)
  I was hungry and  quick to forgive. The menu looked good, and they had some good shit under cork behind the counter, so we got a few drinks and ordered some food.
  The sight of it arriving is what got me. I ordered gnocchi. I got 10 gnocchi. 10. And they weren't fist sized, either. 10 gnocchi.
My girlfriend got a pizza that didn't hold a finger to the Baron. It was thin crust, really thin crust.
  Don't get me wrong. The food was delicious. Hand made and everthing, but when you need food, you need food. We paid the $50(10 gnocchi) check and drove to In and Out in Daly City. Huh.
author: Jeremiah M.

description:
this is a great little neighborhood restaurant. 

a long time fan of pizetta, the drive to the avenues is sometimes just too much. piccino is the answer. they don't even get mad and tell you they are outta dough when they are about to close.

i've eaten here maybe a half dozen times. with blue bottle and pizetta alums at the helm its a given the pizza and coffee are solid and they continue to bring it with salads, sandwiches and desserts. della fattoria toast, goat cheese, arugula, shitake mushrooms, hazelnuts and tangerines ... apple cake ... pink wine? yes please.

in response to naysayers, it is a tiny place. they take meticulous care choosing ingredients and in fact with everything. if you'd rather eat in an a big place, with huge plates of sloppy food, piccino is not for you. i think there's a red lobster on the peninsula.
author: Kenya l.

description:
Had to find a place in my new neighborhood that would please my mother's need for excellent lattes.  After many days and different shops, I'm taking her here when she visits.
Only downside is the lack of seating, there is sort of a little bench thing outside and inside, but that's about it as far as I could see.
author: T B.

description: You're tiny, cute and adorable!  Your food is clean, honest and delicious.  Your coffee makes even a non-coffee drinker get down on her knees and weep.  I want to hold you in my arms and stroke your silky hair.  Thank you for being you.
author: Tati K.

description: I've been to Piccino several times for dinner and the food is delicious!  I appreciate the friendly service and lively atmosphere as well.  The easy neighborhood parking is also a huge plus.  We will continue coming back for the frequently revised menu options.
author: Kelsey A.

description: First they were very nice people..... But they completely forgot my order in a restaurant with at total of five tables. They also offered me a complementary coffee for the extra wait and then completely forgot to make that as well. And after my forty five minute wait I wasn't overly impressed with my 10 dollar pizza.
author: andrew h.

description:
Are you guys kidding me?  this place is silly -- too precious and dull.  the pizza is tasty, but come on!

I do have to say they serve wonderful coffee, but this place is not what the neighborhood needed.
author: melissa W.

description: I don't drink coffee, but I love this place.  Great homemade yogurt and granola, awesome muffins, friendly staff, lots of cool neighbors hanging out.
author: Lesley G.

description: I loved the pizza!  Unfortunately that is the only thing they served besides RABBIT the nite I went.  Go for excellent pizza.  Doesn't really offer anything else.
author: Gran A.

description: I will not go back even though it's spitting distance from my house.  I went in the morning to get a yogurt and granola cup to go and was tossed back and forth between the main place on the corner and the to-go coffee place half a block down the way.  I know it's not as bad as actually having bad food (their food and coffee are quite good).  But having incompetent (and borderline rude) wait staff is unforgivable.
author: Natasha M.

description: 2 words - sausage pizza.  first time there, we had to increase our party size.  absolutely the most accomodating staff i have ever encountered.  second time there, we sat at the bar.  We watched whistfully as the pastry chef whipped out some ah-mazing looking cinnamon rolls (only served at the coffee bar) and the meyer lemon torte (restaurant).  Both times, we were thrilled with the simplicity of the food, yet complex flavours (i sound so pretentious).  lovely wines by the glass.  all in all, a GREAT time.  can't wait to go back.
author: Sonia C.

description: This is a new place in the Potrero Hill area.  Has the potential to be a four or five star with a few improvements.  The ingredients are fresh and tasty but a panini has to have two slices of bread otherwise there isn't much separating the dish from getting as full  as eating cheese and crackers. A side salad or potatoes along with a panini sandwich would go a long way.  Until then, have a panini as an appetizer, the ingredients are fresh and good, but stop by Just for You Cafe or Hard Knox around the corner for the entree.
author: Josh K.

description: Adorable, bright, tiny place with outside tables too.  Super friendly staff.  Tasty, uber-simple, super fresh pizzas like cheese, green garlic & egg. (They're small...I could eat two.)  Awesome tasty salumi and cheese panini with the best texture panini bread.  Served with nice pickled baby carrots and olives.  Soups smelled amazing too.  Cute neighborhood hangout.
author: Melanie C.

description: It didn't totally live up to the hype but I really liked the space and the food.  Definitely worth sharing with your table.  I was least impressed with the service-- snobby and acted as if we were lucky to get a table.  Regardless of how popular a place is, it is always worth considering the dining guests as special and worth satisfying.
author: Shannon T.

description:
This is the WORST restaurant in the city. Don't eat here! Ever!

(Sigh) 

OK...If everyone finds out how great Piccino is, we won't be able to get a table at our favorite place in town! This place is the bomb, with wonderful food, fresh and inventive, and great service too. 

So whatever you do, DON'T eat here!
author: tess s.

description: Yay for blue bottle coffee! I'm a huge fan of blue bottle and if I can't get to the embarcadero ferry building or on linden street then piccino will do! This coffee bar is located in the dogpatch neighborhood and serves up delicious blue bottle coffee. I usually like to order a drip is super aromatic and the taste is unbeatable to any coffee shops out there. Piccino also sells blue bottle 8oz bags for $8 so I had to snatch up three bags of their fine espresso beans, and they even grind the beans for you!
author: Janet T.

description: Well let's see. This is kind of an unusual place. The quality of every dish in flavor and presentation is a 5. The portion size doesn't need to be huge but after appetizer soup and a pasta main course I was still a tad hungry. The deserts were the weak point of the meal. The staff was attentive but the wait was a bit long. I can see how dime see the staff as having attitude.
author: Walter J.

description: Everything about this place is wonderful-- from the Funghi pizza to the desserts to the friendly, honest staff and cozy interior. Worth a trip to Dogpatch for sure.
author: Brandi S.

description:
Merf, they're pretty nice here. Today they were frazzled because lo & behold they're the ONLY Dogpatch restaurant that isn't closed from 12/26-1/2! 
I'm an East Coast/Midwest girl, and while I have lived in SF for over 15 years I still hold some things sacred. Pizza is one of them. I will eat the cornmeal crust pizza, I've learned to love deep dish (thank you Little Star) and occasionally I will let you convince me that figs or artichoke hearts are acceptable toppings. Sorry Piccino, your pie doesn't do it for me - too dry, the sauce is too much like a paste and not enough cheese for this dairy freak. It wasn't a bad combination of flavors, it just isn't something I'd go for again.
The salad on the other hand was pretty damn good. I'm a sucker for the beet salad, and while this one was a little pricey for what you get, it was perfectly balanced. Crisp lettuce mix, little bites of tangerines, bitty yellow beets and shavings of delightful cheese to top it all off. Very nice.
author: Colleen B.

description: I love the idea of this place -  the food, the ambiance, the intent to create a place that is about food, beauty, and community. Unfortunately, Piccino is far from being a place "welcoming as the home of a close friend." The food is impeccable, the space has the warmth, sensuality and 'wabi sabi' of a modern Japanese eatery. The hosts are downright snobby. The wait staff is aloof. (downgraded 1 star for poor service) I so wanted this to be my go-to neighborhood spot but have been utterly put off by the disdainful welcome at the door. A solo diner, walking in mid-week before 6pm to sit at the counter shouldn't have to wait 5 minutes to be acknowledged or told to wait maybe 20+ minutes for a seat at the counter. Its great that they have been so successful but would be so nice if they did something for to acknowledge local neighbors- neighbor night or something. I'd sworn off this place but l last Sunday, a dear friend begged me to go here for dinner. After being only somewhat neglected at the door (at 5:30pm) by the host, another person at the desk seated us at the counter. I have to admit I had the nicest, most attentive waitress ever in my experience there. I might just come back if she's working.
author: Sirima S.

description: Hands down the best coffee I've ever had! Staff is super cool and friendly... try the savory bread pudding. It's the bomb!
author: Donna V.

description: I mean, i guess this place is good..... if you live over here. There are so many other italian places in san francisco, though. there is NOTHING around this area. we got a margherita pizza and it was $9.50 for a personal size. it was alright, nothing great. the service was very good though, the people were very nice.
author: Tim M.

description: Came here on a rush to get some pizza before playing a show nearby. The pizza was really good, and they were really nice about getting our orders through fast because we were in a rush. Would like to come back here another time and exactly entire some more time there.
author: Angus M.

description: My husband and I had a late lunch here last weekend. It's a beautiful space and the staff are friendly and helpful. The restaurant was busy though not full when we arrived. We ordered the pickled vegetables which were delicious, though a rather spartan offering for $6.00. My husband ordered a chicken panini sandwich and I had the mushroom and stracchino pizza. We waited no less than 45 minutes for it to arrive. We had a lemonade and a San Bitter soda. Lunch was $50.00. It took forever. It was good, however, to us, not a place we'll rush back to.
author: Leanne S.

description: This place gets 4 stars solely because they serve Blue Bottle coffee. Very good move. Tiny place, friendly atmosphere and the lunch options look quite yummy and healthy. Will be back for those later.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Brian is San Francisco's  espresso slinging  Guru.  Coming up in Seattle made me a coffee snob early on. Fine espresso is god's gift to attention deficit, seasonally affected depressives like me. 
Hands down no one comes close. This is the best barista in town. Don't take my word for it. Get in line, and tip well! 
He'll even gives private lessons, if you ask nice.
author: magdalena w.

description:
piccino, i wish you were bigger but do understand why you need to be a small restaurant.  

i came to piccino on a wednesday night with a friend, and we immediately got a table - which surprised me since all tables were full, but we just lucked out on timing.  i wonder how long the wait is during the weekend.

we ordered a baby gem lettuce salad, a margherita pizza, a sausage pizza, and an inexpensive bottle of wine.  i also noticed there was a pork belly entree on the menu too.  oh dear, if i were hungrier or had a larger party, i would have also ordered the 2 special pizzas (one red, one white) and the entree!

anyhow - the pizza's super thin, served casually on a piece of wood and parchment paper.  we liked the margherita pizza so much that we almost burnt ourselves eating it.  the server even indulged us w/ extra-extra sauce, and she comped us the salad when she forgot to bring it out before our pizzas arrived.

i would definitely come back to piccino.  the size of the place, the casual (but attentive and accomodating) servers, and homey-ness of the kitchen make me want to open up my own restaurant.  piccino totally feels homegrown, but the decor reminds you that there are some serious restaurateurs there.  

i will be back on a warm day (ahem, outdoor seating!) or on a weeknight!
author: kim n.

description: The salsiccia and meatballs beat delfina (and anyone else) any day of the week. Add in the beautiful ambiance and this place is my favorite in the city. You guys rock!
author: Leeroy B.

description: I love this little place. The pizzas were very nicely done, and they had some pretty interesting apps and reasonably-priced wines by the glass. Our server was totally cool and friendly. A diamond in the Dog Patch.
author: Andrew S.

description: A couple of friends came here and liked it, so I had to check it out for myself.  This is a cute little place - cozy, yet uncrowded.  Service was gracious, the food fresh, and interesting specials.   My friend and I had the apple-yam soup and shared a white pizza - just right for any appetite.  I'd come back, for more pizza as well as brunch.
author: Julie C.

description: Ate lunch there today. Mixed green salad: salty. Pizza was ok: nothing special. Service a little slow. Staff was friendly, nice looking restaurant, prices high. Crowd typical new potrero hill fru fru.
author: J B.

description: This is a great neighborhood restaurant! The pizzas and salads are amazing, and I love the ambiance. It's a great place to sit outside and have a glass of wine and a snack on a nice day. If you don't live in Dogpatch, it's worth the trip.
author: Lindsay B.

description: What a perfect little neighborhood gem.  Small, but warm & welcoming, friendly, easy parking.  Oh, and fantastic food!  Delicious & creative nightly specials, and regular lineup (the oft-referenced funghi) to die for.  I think they take something like ~3 reservations a night, so call ahead and check.  My only complaints are that I wish they were a little bigger, and stayed open a little later -- it's not too hard to get a table now, but once word gets out...
author: Adam G.

description:
hidden gem, so sad it won't be for long!

best pizza in town, a16 might be their only competition.  

all of the other items are also fantastic: salt cod, pork sausage bread pudding, etc to name a few

great wine list too, if i remember correctly everything was under 30

yum yum yum
author: Marie U.

description:
Blue bottle coffee is awesome 
They get busy and the line can get a  llittle long sometime, but the staff seems to have a photgraphic memeory and remember the order the customers show up ... how do they do that???
An awesome addition to Dogpatch !
author: super u.

description: For me, this is a more convenient, easier to park next to, not quite as good, Pizzetta 211. With better coffee.
author: Mister X.

description: This is a delightful place full of potential. However, after 2 visits, I'm convinced service is in need of an overhaul. Piccino is not cheap - lunch was about $40/person and that comes with expectations. On both visits, food exceeded expectations. Veggies are farm fresh and the pizza is delicious. The wine list is extensive and contains something for every taste and budget. The dining room is comfortable and pleasant to look at. Where Piccino fails its customers is in how its staff members fail to work as a team. There's no bus staff to assist the waitstaff and the waitstaff needs constant prodding to do the right thing. After asking for a few extra minutes to decide on an order, we are abandoned by our waitress who is replaced eventually by a waiter. Said waitress returns later in the mail to present a check with a $9.50 error - a charge for a 2nd wine glass I never ordered or received. We are not offered dessert until after we request the check which is 30 minutes after we finish our entrees. I also can't recall an Italian restaurant that does not provide bread to its patrons. I hope Piccino gets it right. It would be a shame to get this close and not meet its maximum potential.
author: Keith R.

description:
tiny, tasty, friendly, fast, blue bottle-brewin' coffee...chop.

and conveniently located 2 blocks from the 22nd street caltrain station, for all of us commuting caff-fiends.
author: Paula T.

description: Fabulous lunch spot.  Thin crust pizzas are to die for!  Always get the ones marked today's special.  Allot at least 2 hours to dine here as the service is leisurely.  Too bad the outdoor seating isn't on the sunny side of the street!
author: Bibby G.

description: Great service, Great Coffee, Awesome Location. This is my morning ritual for Monday, and there's nothing like Blue Bottle coffee made by Piccino. This is a must see/taste for any coffee lover. I normally get a mocha which runs 4.50. You would think the price is high, but for the quality and care behind the magic... it's so worth every second and penny spent. I see alot of people getting the drip, so if your a raw kinda person...this would be your choice....
author: David C.

description: I drink decaf exclusively and am always on the hunt for decaffeinated coffee with flavor.  This iced decaf latte was as good as Spike's, my usual fave.  Delicious!  Thanks, Mike, for sending us here.
author: Thelma Lee G.

description:
Maybe it was the mood I was in, but Piccino completely hit the spot for dinner.  True, I felt like I was a part of the intimate conversation of every other party in the restaurant, but it was cozy and genuine.  

There wasn't a wait on a Thursday night at 7pm, and they do have outdoor tables with heat lamps for additional seating.  It's fun to watch them make the pizza since you almost feel like you're IN the kitchen.  The plates they serve them on are even more fun.

The salsiccia pizza we had was amazing: sweet onions, warm mozzarella, and sausage; not to mention the much-yelped about thin crust.  The food overall wasn't fancy, just fresh and delicious.
author: Dian C.

description:
adorable!
this wonderfully teeny place in dogpatch is perfect!
stop by in the morning for a latte, blue bottle coffee and warm, fresh from the oven scone.  it is the best way to start a morning.
squeeze on in for dinner -- small pizzas, salumi, cheese plates and wonderful wines! 
can't wait to spend more mornings and evenings relaxing at piccino!
author: Lija H.

description:
This is becoming my regular neighborhood restaurant.
They have a fairly small menu that's substituted by daily specials. I several times went for their wonderful Pizza with eggs which is surprisingly good. Once you had a pizza with yolk running over it, there is no way back! However, today my yolk wasn't runny )-:
They always have very fresh and inspired specials. Once they had an organic chicken that turned out to be one of the best chickens I ever had. Today I also tried their winter vegetable soup with roasted duck which was perfect as well.

The place has the perfect atmosphere you want from your San Francisco neighborhood restaurant. The staff is super sweet and you immediately feel like you are a regular here.
author: Alexander M.

description:
warm. cozy. simple.
fungi pizza, no regrets.
adds to neighborhood.
author: yutai l.

description: I've lived in the Bay Area for 5 years, and as a great lover of pizza, I have tried nearly every pizza spot in town.  Piccino is my favorite, and I come here time and again!  I love the high quality ingredients they use and the tasty, thin crust on each pizza.  The ambiance is fun too.  Piccino is small so if its crowded it can be hard to secure a table if the place is crowded.
author: Lauren S.

description: When I first went to Piccino, I loved it so much I had to run double duty. First a tasty morning pastry (an outrageous flakey ginger scone) with my Blue Bottle Coffee, then back at lunch for a perfectly cooked pizza with delicious sausage and rabe. Oh and add to that the most tender, tangy and invigorating roasted beet salad I've had in ages. It's nice to taste how much they care.
author: Matthew R.

description: Tiny joint, well designed (especially the dishware) with a simple menu that will please everyone. I really loved their white pizza with pancetta and apple/onion marmalade, although the Margherita was way overwhelmed with sauce, with rare traces of spotted cheese. Big points for the crust. Big points. Focaccia (a sweet one) was very unpleasant: dry, crumbly, bitter.....a mess. Also, they don't have lager beers, just stout and IPA....good ones, nothing to say, but they don't match at all a real pizza experience. Coffee is just good, nothing fancy. Why 4 stars? Because I forgot I was in San Francisco! I completely felt the atmosphere of a bar in Italy during spring time with seatings outside and big windows...somehow I made a leap overseas. And finally, shame on me for being a pizza-snob, it was just a great brunch ! Final remarks...reasonably priced.
author: Dario B.

description: Bright, fresh salads. My panzanella salad was so good with artichokes, radish, arugula and tuna confit, yum. Thats my idea of a salad. The pizza was very good and even better than Delfina- gasp!  This place is tiny and if its chilly outside you might have to wait for a table, but we loved our lunch and will be back soon.
author: James S.

description: Piccino is everything a simple neighborhood restaurant should be: intimate setting, locally-source food, simple menu and a host of entrees under $15. After a fabulous day listening to music outside, my girlfriend and I searched for simple dinner and Piccino fit the bill. The only thing I would change: at least one "bargain" on the wine list.
author: Cameron K.

description:
yum, yum, yum! 

i have been waiting for months for this place to open. and all of my expectations have been fulfilled. the pizza here is excellent, dare I say, better then Delfina Pizzeria. I enjoyed the pannini's and the salads as well, the beet salad was delish.

And they serve blue bottle coffee, my dreams have come true, just three short blocks from my house. They have fresh made pastries as well, they berry turnover was light, flaky and, did I say yum? yum yum yum
author: Kai H.

description: THE best coffee ever!  About the only one I drink, am not a huge coffee drinker as caffeine doesn't tend to agree with my body.  However, my boyfriend is a coffee addict and loves his espressos proper italian style, and even he loves this place ;)
author: Karin A.

description: I just moved into the neighborhood and I've eaten here a couple of times.  The staff are very friendly here and the food has been consistently good.  This place is well worth checking out.
author: Robert H.

description:
Went here for lunch with my girlfriend since its close to her work.

The Good:

1. Cozy, homemade kitchen atmosphere.
2. The margherita pizza had a sweet creamy sauce.
3. The bathroom was clean (although painted in blood red)

The Bad:

1. The red special pizza had so little sauce and toppings that it was like eating dry breadsticks.
2. Service was abysmal. The waitstaff never checked in with us once. The waiter forgot to bring our drink (and since he never came by again we couldn't ask for it). The credit card bill arrived with no pen. Ten minutes after ordering, the owner came by and asked if we wanted to order. The to-go box was torn and had marinara thumbprints smudged all over it.
3. The seating (as others have mentioned) is terrible. We were squeezed on the end of a bench such that our neighbors perpendicular to us were staring right at us.
author: Mac G.

description: I have been here 3x's. Dinner and lunch. I've eaten across the menu and still can't figure out my favorite- tho the squash or broccoli rabine and pizzas are so tasty. The space just feels so...modern, charming and breezy. Eclectic local dogpatch crowd across the age spectrum. Literally an inspiring treat in an otherwise somewhat expected new restaurant mecca.
author: kelli p.

description: Still loving this place even though I don't live nearby anymore.  Lovely setting for a glass of wine and a yummy pizza (fungi is fabulous).  Blue bottle coffee and okay desserts.
author: Poppy C.

description: omg pizza is to die for.  Soooo good.  Beautiful chill relaxing layout with an earthy feel.  The Gnocchi was a bit disappointing - more like polenta cakes.  But would definitely come back for the pizza :)  OFTEN
author: Mima G.

description: Nice little restaurant just a bit off 3rd Street in the Dogpatch.  I had the baked rigatoni and it was fantastic!  Service was great, the atmosphere was perfect, and the food was good...
author: Mark D.

description: Yay Piccino!  Worth the wait.  Have been twice since they opened.  Somehow, despite the crowds and their recent opening, they manage to feel like they totally know what they're doing.  Service has been great -- very nice and knowledgeable both times, and good humored with all of the crowding and questions.  The pizza rocks -- have had the sardine and mushroom.  The crust is perfect even after it sits on the table for a bit.  The meatballs are totally delish.  The space is beautiful and I'm jonesing for the MAC jacket that's been in the window both times.  Don't forget to byob until they get their liquor license :)
author: lisa b.

description: I am starting with a 3 star review but I will give them a second chance so that maybe I can up them to 4 stars after having a better experience.  We went on a night when they weren't serving pizza because it was too hot out (something about the yeast and the dough being messed up).  Which sucks because I really wanted pizza.  But it gave us the chance to try some other dishes that were quite tasty - little gem salad (awesome dressing) and the antipasti platter.  The wine was eh and the waiter, well he was confused.  Maybe you could blame that on the heat like they did for the pizza?  He was scattered and then lingered a bit too long at our table.  The outdoor seating is nice and they let our dog chill next to our table.  I will go back and hopefully try their pizza so stay tuned!
author: Piper B.

description: I want to love this place, its really cool and cute and friendly, has blue bottle coffee, great seats and copper-tin-type tables.  It's fun and i'll come back sometime probably, but its kind of disorganized, not a good flow for ordering, paying, waiting for food.  Frustrating.  Plus the scone was a little undercooked.  Granola with yogurt and fruit (strawberries) was super good, though :))).  Cool plates and dishes and silverware, too.  Yet, missing some solid basics, or something like that... get the feeling it's mostly charm appeal (which you pay for), a little shallow/lazy beneath the surface i felt.  Lost respect.  Still have a little crush on it though.
author: Today Y.

description: Really great experience from beginning to end. Beautiful space (not too loud, and just-right lighting), excellent and friendly service, and--most important--delicious food. Had the summer bean salad, mushroom pizza, and torta (with apples) for dessert. Pizza is very subjective, of course, but I loved their crust (thin but not too thin), it was generously sized. Also, this place is a very good value--our total bill for two was very reasonable for such a great place. This is a restaurant that's clearly in the "neighborhood-place-but-worth-the-drive" category. Will definitely come back.
author: Fred S.

description: As with other Blue Bottle places, the regular coffee is made fresh single serving style and while this definitely adds to its deliciousness, it also makes service a little slow, and a little nerve wrecking when I'm going to catch Caltrain, but still very very worth while. I would give myself an extra 10-15 minutes buffer time if I'm in any kind of hurry. Most importantly - Blue Bottle has developed the Piccino Roast, which is served here of course, and is by far the best coffee I have ever had.
author: Midori G.

description: I've eaten here countless times for breakfast and lunch, never waited for a table despite it's tiny size. The pizzas are what I would call "designer" pizzas, not for the Extreme Pizza fans or the unadventurous eater. I would never dream of  combining sausage and figs on a pizza but oh boy, what a delicious combo. I actually crave the taste now. Today I tried the white pizza with nettles and egg. It was delicioso. Now I know why Eyore was always munching on nettles at Pooh Corner. God bless creative chefs. The bread pudding with bacon was too good to share but I love my boyfriend so I did, although I was muttering profanities inside. And their desserts are heavenly. All this goodness is very reasonably priced as well...Okay, I'm hungry now...
author: Brittany A.

description: A few weeks ago my husband & I went to check this place out.  WOW! This is how a restaurant should be. Light, airy, & be able to talk! And the service was excellent. The place was packed, but we were able to sit at the bar (we took the last 2 seats in the house). Servers came right away & did a very nice set-up. The server recommened a lovely wine which was perfect.  We ordered the meatballs - very simple topped w/chopped tomatoes & basil. Then we ordered the pizza. Forget about the other places you read about. Ordered the roasted mushroom & herb pizza.  Very thin crust, nicely browned at edges. Then you have a surprise of a few very, very thin garlic slices that kicks it up - Best pizza we ever ate! For dessert we had the apricot tart - so good, nice & buttery crust; & the affagado.  Behind us at the bar, we can see into the clothing store M.A.C. - Beautiful stuff. We will have to go back.
author: Pam R.

description: I would definitely return for the pizza. I had rabbit which was very salty; too bad the flavors were masked by the salt. Had Brussels sprouts as an appetizer, again too salty. Soup was terrific.
author: Sylvia J.

description: Was very happy to find the cafe had opened next door to Piccino. Always worth stopping by for a Gibraltar and maybe an indulgent treat.
author: Mariangela S.

description: I love this place - beautiful space, the vibe is mellow and relaxed, food always so fresh and seasonal.
author: chloe w.

description:
wow!  what an awesome surprise.  last minute choice for dinner with a friend, was awesome:

* great antipasti
* near amazing white pizza - i am not usually a fan but rapini + meyer lemon blew my mind
* great short ribs - only non-pizza dish on the menu, often that means it's a throw-away item, but this was really delicious
* great service
* and they let us buy a bag of blue bottle from the coffee shop next door on the way out

so great!

things to work on
* get an espresso machine for the restaurant
* more wines by the glass.

totally worth the trip to dogpatch
author: James R.

description:
Went here this past week on Tuesday. I'd read about this 'joint' for a while from there humble beginnings around the corner to their new digs.Had  a really good meal and a great time. Let me digress a second.
We had to wait as they were expecting a large party.The Hostess put our name in as we were resolved to sticking it out. Rain inhibited our eating at one of outside tables. We visited Yield Wine Bar around the corner and hung out there , then headed back.
We returned to a mere 5  minute wait. They were all so friendly, helpful and informative.Wine list and the menu were not only easy to navigate, but difficult to make a choice , it sounded so good.
Two salads and one (peperonata) pizza later, oh yeah and a half litre of nebbiolo had us sated. All that we tasted was prepared fresh simple and important to me no muddled flavors. I could have used a bit more salt but...What we consumed  was simply prepared and delicious.  
The conversation/patter between us and staff was beyond friendly and most definitely added to the experience. Sit at the counter, unless you are on a romantic rendezvous.
Oh yeah, the space itself is really beautiful and woody.Ask one of the staff and the story will unfold as to the history of the restaurant and the build out. It as well is interesting as the experience.
author: Lou S.

description:
The food here was tasty, fresh, and not overly rich, which is great for a lunch spot.  That being said, none of the flavors necessarily struck me as super-inventive, and the seating is a tad awkwardly arranged.  That being said, it's still miles ahead of most lunch spots in the city.  

At least in it's cafe/lunch capacity, Piccino does exactly like it's supposed to, and provides a solid, affordable midday meal.
author: Patrick P.

description: Very good pizza.  Not as good as pizzeria delfina, better than a16.  Great desserts and coffee.  Easy parking.  SUPER cute little place.  We walked right in and sat down on a thursday night - I will go again!
author: Emily d.

description: Delicious Blue Bottle coffee, fabulous and friendly baristas, really great focaccia sandwiches from Piccino (oh god, I've been thinking about the brie and persimon sandwich for months), sometimes cute art, no lines, cheerful neighbors with their big ass dogs drinking cappuccinos outside--what more could you want in a neighborhood coffee bar? This place makes me so happy. Glad I moved into its hood.
author: Emily F.

description:
Rarely do I give 5 stars.  Was pretty easy here.  

Great atmosphere - quaint little neighborhood spot gets dark as you're eating.  

Awesome service - just a few tables, so you would expect that.

Very tasty food - had 2 salads - both were great especially a duck confit salad.  Great summer vegetable pizza with squash.  

Couple of drinks + a dessert + another app (risotto cake - pretty good, not as good as the other dishes) = around $60.  Pretty good value.
author: Chris A.

description:
i came here for lunch with my friend.  she ordered a pizza, and i ordered a panini (i really like sandwiches).  The veterinarian (eggplant) panini was good.

I remember that my friend's pizza was tasty too, though i remember thinking it was somewhat small for the cost.

nice outdoor seating.  the place is next to a hair salon, and this lady tied her dog to the tree next to us.  the dog was really cute!
author: H. L.

description: We came for Hog Island Oyster Day and had a blast sitting in the sun, slurping up the kumamotos and the sweetwaters and sampling the magnificent Piccino pizzas!  What treats!
author: Pelle Y.

description: They take their foam decorations seriously. I respect that. Good pizzas and soups, too. Gotta love changing menus and quality ingredients.
author: Jessica W.

description: Wow! I was becoming desperate for good pizza on the days that I am working out on the SouthEast end of San Francisco, when I stumbled into this wonderfully little pizza place.  Great margherita (tomatoes, cheese, basil only) pizza, nicely polite service, moves you in and out of there on time during lunch; only one drawback, from a lunch point of view---parking can be a drag.  But I recommend it! In San Francisco, only Delfina Pizzeria on 18th Street is more highly thought of by me...
author: Roger W.

description: Some of the food was okay but I was disappointed in the service.  We had a waitress that did not seem to have acquired the skill to describe food to a dining patron (sort of basic you would think!).  I had to request the host come over to our table to help decipher the menu.  He was great and really helped us pick out some entrees.  But both entrees were a bit on the salty side (one was gnudi and the other was a fish of the day).   For dessert, we had the lemon verbena affogato, which was done poorly.  It seems one would have to try hard to fail on such a simple dish (ice cream, espresso and whip cream).  But there was no whip cream, just a scoop of ice cream swimming in a bowl of expresso.  Had they included whip cream (traditionally a key ingredient) that may have married the lemon verbena (a bit flowery) flavor with the espresso but without it the contrast was off, and a waste of money.  This place is a bit pretentious and trying too hard to be hip.  The service is very slow.  I would not return.
author: Mary B.

description:
My girlfriend and I live a few doors down from their old location, so just around the block from their new location. The first time we tried to visit the new place, it was packed to the rafters, but tonight we got in and sat immediately at the bar.  Yes, they are serving beer and wine again -- I had a lovely Magnolia Blue Bell Bitter. The spicy mustard greens salad was perfect. The gnocchi were large, pillowy, and delicious. The waiter somehow marked the mushroom pizza instead of the house-made sausage, but whisked it away and offered us house-made crackers or a bowl of fancy olives.  Olives eaten, the salciccia pizza arrived. It was about 14", and served on a very thin crust. The flavor and texture were perfect and light. The crust: crisp but not cracker-like. It was worth the extra wait. Finally, we had a strawberry crostada for dessert that had the nicest strawberries I've ever had in a restaurant.

At the bar, we watched a chef prepare the salad, olives, and crostada. Everything was carefully balanced and presented. We drank three or four carafes of water and never waited for a full carafe. Aside from the mistaken pizza order, the waitstaff was attentive and generally perfect (although our main server looked like Anthony Perkins, which was a little creepy, but also fun, so, there you go).

So, a salad, three large gnocchis, a bowl of olives, a small pizza, and a crostada were enough to share between the two of us despite being quite hungry on our way in.  Actually, maybe that sounds like a lot, but it was not that expensive.  We'll go back for sure, and maybe we'll take out a couple of pizzas occasionally since we're so close.

Oh, consider making a reservation if you'd like to eat there during busy times.
author: Jesse M.

description: Was there at lunch (11:30am) this past Sat and thought that it was very nice.  Decided to have dinner there this coming Sat evening and called on Mon to make the reservation at 9:40pm  GROAN!!!  After I got through all the "about precious us" I got a reservations voicemail box that was full.  Was not surprised because with all the information they require, one reservation message would fill the box.  How about, Press 1 for Reservations, Press 2 for Private Parties, Press 3 for Accounting ... get the drift. Ad nauseam and ad ego -- my preference for a table and then when I get there you will tell me I can't have it (and these are going the be the people in front of me when I arrive for my "normal reservation") GROAN!!  Pity!! Of course I may decide to come back when they get their act in gear, because the food was lovely and the ambiance was nice.
author: Macrooster M.

description:
its cute on the outside as well as the inside. you can see the chef spinning the pizza dough and preparing the toppings. and the pizza was really good. i recommend the salciccia pizza [sausage, mozzarella and cipolline onions]. 

i love you can just walk over and there's a little coffee bar, which i think was good. i love when the make pretty flower designs on my latte.

at both places, the service was great, and i'll be going back soon.
author: Natalie B.

description: I love this place. They have the best thin crust pizza in town. I'm there almost weekly getting orders for the whole office. Their coffee is also the best in town - by far. Highly recommended.
author: Marko G.

description: Came here for my birthday dinner... made reservations for 930, showed up at 800pm... waited for over 2 hours. We were starving! The sommelier lady was really great, very friendly, casual, and knew her wines. The host was way too high strung though- maybe there should have been two? The waitress was a bit too attentive (I like to pour my own water, especially when there is always a bottle on the table, and not have someone reaching over my shoulder every 2 minutes). Also, if someone doesn't eat much sugar and declines dessert, and then you bring them a birthday cake (cute), be OK with the fact that they said thank you and appreciated the gesture, but don't guilt-trip them into eating it (there were 5 others at the table to demolish it for me!). The gnocchi were good- but not gnocchi, they were polenta things... pretty interesting though (but not at all filling). The funghi pizza was tasty, but lacked character/spice/salt? A cute, romantic, up-scale place, but not amazing in the least, and not worth it if it's on your dime.
author: Amanda S.

description: We went for brunch last Sunday. Gorgeous space. Inviting. Light. Great wood. High ceilings. Too bad the food and service couldn't keep up. I did love their ortica pizza: wild nettles, ricotta, and nectarines. Unusual but very yummy. However, the gnocci abruptly woke us up from that dream. LD commented, "Soggy bread". We love pillow-y gnocci not soggy gnocci. Just order the pizza, stay away from the gnocci, and stay clear away from the rude and snobby waiter. You know who you are ...
author: Seymour S.

description:
what an epic battle i fought to get here. stupidly, coming from the mission, i thought i could bike over potrero and land in the dogpatch and all would be well. potrero beat me, beat me badly. the only happiness came when i turned back and zipped down the hill at dangerously fast speeds.

i circumnavigated the hill, going along 17th and riding down mississipi. when i finally arrived at piccino, i was famished and beat.

i sat at the bar and the bar tender was so friendly.. i think he smiled everytime i saw him. i don't remember what i ate, but i do remember reading my poetry book, getting teary eyed, and feeling completely comfortable in such a warm, homey place. i'd go there any day to just feel some joy, during the good and the bad.
author: omar k.

description: Good, consistently crunchy, thin crust pizza. Long wait for each pizza (we went around 1pm) and then they came out around 20 minutes apart. Thank god for the yummy coffee that tided us over. Liked the crust here more than Pizzeria Delfina.
author: Evelyn G.

description:
great hang out for small bites with a glass of wine. water carfe from old milk bottles and plates looking like they were made from a 5th grade art project.

yummy unique pizza - White: Pea shoots, lamb & green garlic 

finish the meal off with a piece of burnt caramel and huge mug of blue bottled coffee.
author: Katie K.

description:
too pretentious for me, but kick ass pizzetas, I love the bianca one.
been going there for over a year on and off.

Honestly was highly turned off when the owner or manager, or whoever it was with those fancy wooden sandals ($200-300 seen them at Gimme shoes) was talking mean to his gal staff and spraying AHEM! WD-40 on the door, trying to show her how to close the door, er properly etc.) while a bunch of us were still eating... hello manners...

BEANS: blue bottle (yay!)
author: ninja M.

description:
This is my favorite pizza, and I just got back from Italy.
Thin crust exactly as it should be. Tasty, crisp, but not dry. The topping can be weird (cod?) but always end up amazing. 

Desserts are wonderful, coffee is blue bottle....doesn't get any better.
Nothing else to say - try this place!
author: Robert F.

description: sad to drop my stars, but since Piccino has moved to a larger more high profile location, I have not been able to get a table....sad.
author: dude m.

description: My friend and I ate dinner at Piccino last night and had a wonderful time. First of all I was 20 minutes late due to traffic problems on the Embarcadero.  The staff very graciously seated my friend, who is in her 80's at the quieter table I had requested, and there was never any pressure to hurry things along to make up for lost time. The space itself has a very pleasant feeling,  vibrant energy , without being too noisy.    The food was very good, we both enjoyed everything from the corn chowder, through the gnocchi,  squash appetizer, and the pizza. The wine that our waiter suggested was delicious, and the service was excellent.  I would definitely go back to Piccino
author: helen g.

description: The Bianca pizza might not be the best pie on the menu but it got me intrigued to try another one. The thin crust was great, the ingredients were fresh, but the combo was bit boring. The overall experience at Piccino is a great: very cute interior, great salads with very fresh produce, and a friendly staff. I'll be back to try a different pizza very soon.
author: Abraham W.

description: This is a great new spot in an overlooked neighborhood. very casual and friendly. We sat outside in the sun. The special pizza was thin and tasty. the sandwich was a perfect size with apple slices and ham on this awesome hearty thinly sliced grain bread. Nice combo. Both items had more grease than I've consumed since the early 80's. Great flavors, but I will remember the grease.
author: Monster B.

description: Incredible  flatbread pizza!  I love their sausage pizzas the most especially the one with eggs.  It's almost impossible to find pizza that is not heavy and greasy but still tasty.  This is the place!
author: Jac C.

description:
This is really a 3.5 type of place.
So I went all the way down to the Dogpatch today to eat lunch with my boyfriend who works in Mission Bay. I was really looking forward to having some southern inspired food at either Hard Knox or Just for you. Unfortunately both restaurants were closed due to Holiday season. 
We happened upon Puccino and decided to try it. The small inside was packed due to the freezing weather, lucky we got there right before the lunch time rush. 
Ordered the white pizza with cameralized onions, fennel, and apple compote (or something similar) and nettle and rice soup. The soup was tasty and perfect for the weather. I spiced up the mild flavor with red pepper from the pizza. The pizza was very good and the flavors worked very well together. The service was a bit crazy and it took 20 minutes for us to get our cafe au laits. This is definitely a cute little cafe I would come back for breakfast when it was warmer and sit outside,
author: Courtney R.

description: It's tiny, as suggested by the name. So don't expect to show up with a group of six and get a table right away. In fact, I don't think they even have a table for six. They do have great food (tasty olives, thin crust pizza, flat bread), and decent table wines though. Which you can top off with a great espresso. All served by friendly people, in a cool part of town. And that's why I am a happy returning customer.
author: Michiel D.

description: I gave it five stars because my experience here has always been wonderful.  The Napoletana Pizza with tomato sauce, olives, and anchovies was a incredible find.  Finally a place that makes good Sicilian style pizza....cheeseless!  Bravo!  (No more "No Cheese?  But that won't taste good!  You have to have cheese!" or simple dirty look)  And, I find out that they brew Blue Bottle Coffee with their own special blend!  The only problem that I have is the size of the place.  It's so small that if we didn't go for late lunch, or if people sitting next to us were just about to leave when we sit down, we'll have a hard time hearing each other....I'm not sure if I'd bring my date there for dinner....maybe lunner?
author: Vivian H.

description: I remember long ago when Piccino first opened. That great guy with the crazy grey hair worked the espresso bar and the atmosphere was soft, casual, languid. I used to run around those nearby warehouses, free and a little crazy. I used to think of piccino simply as blue bottle in the dogpatch and that vision is imprinted on my brain. Food? I guess they have some there. Now piccino is more popular, more people, more frustrating to park (better to follow that T Line), but the outdoor tables with those shady trees make for a leisurely spent afternoon. Fresh pizzas combined with fresh coffee makes me happy.
author: Faye P.

description: You know you are living in San Francisco when you just paid $10 for 3 cups of coffee and a small cookie that you had to wait 10 minutes for.
author: Amy E.

description: I love this place. Maybe it's the fact that it's just a few blocks away from my house, or that it was the first place I ate at when I moved to San Francisco, or that the menu changes with the seasons - but Piccino is one of my favorite places to eat in the city.  This is the way I like pizza, too: super thin crust, fresh ingredients, interesting flavor combinations.   The pizza is so good that I was inspired to attempt to duplicate Piccino's pizza at home; I've since decided to leave this to the professionals!
author: Anne D.

description:
i loved the "old" piccino, and have been counting down the days until the new yellow building piccino opened.

coffee bar:  the coffee bar opened first, and it is fabulous!  i love the big open doorway, and the baked goods are as good as ever -- but there is more variety.  the coffee is perfection.

the cafe:  delightful.  we opted to sit outside rather than wait for a table inside.  we did not know that it was going to get so cold, although the navy blue blankets that were brought to us by our waiter really helped.  the menu has increased in size -- my husband had some pasta that was over the top delicious.  the space is beautiful!  i had my usual pizza, and it was as good as it always is.  i am so happy for the piccino owners, and i love the new yellow building.  i feel so lucky to live in this neighborhood!
author: Dawn J.

description:
name of place= very cute (pee-chee-no; means tiny); I love saying it.
latte at Piccino coffee bar= worth getting to the train station early
decor at Piccino= cool neo industrial elegant
wine list at Piccino= delicious (try the Verdicchio, it schools all other whites)
crab at Piccino= good, but hard to eat with just regular forks and tiny plates
pizza at Piccino= cheese & sausage was good, but the crust had no color and little taste; they're missing a few ingredients from their crust recipe, and until they figure that out, it won't really matter what goes on top.
sigh, sad to be disappointed; 
service was great, very friendly and just the right balance of attention; 
the whole place, soup to nuts, is "gentle." If you're into that sort of thing.
author: Renu C.

description: Yay to more and more thin-crust pizza places in the city! Piccino is where I go to pick up my veggie box every so often, so I know they get amazing produce. I've been here twice now and have been consistently impressed by their pizzas. This last time, three of us split their version of Caesar salad (with zest of Buddha's hand!), a braised lamb/arugula pizza, and pizza overflowing with pure mushroomy goodness. The next time I go back, I'd like to try some of their basic pizzas since I bet they make a pretty mean Magherita - but I'll probably fail because their special pizzas always look so so good.
author: Angi C.

description: Saw the restaurant review on the home page of SF Gate yesterday. Told my husband we gotta try this restaurant. We went there last night. We were lucky that we were able to get a tiny table. A half hour later, the restaurant was full.  I ordered the salad with strawberries and magherita (sp) pizza. My husband ordered the magherita (sp) pizza. The salad was yummy. Liked the strawberries. :) We admitted that we had to wait a bit longer for our pizzas. I would give a 4 star for my pizza because on the bottom, it was slighty black and burnt. Cheese was good. Wish they put little more fresh mozz cheese on my pizza. We would like to come back in future. If you want to bring your kids, they dont have big table. It would be best if you order the take out and your kids can eat pizza at home.
author: Melody S.

description: fabulous coffee!!! I believe Blue Bottle makes a special roast for them... anyway, the coffee is definitely Blue Bottle, and definitely wonderful!! I love this joint.
author: Aditya S.

description: My whole order was forgotten here from top to bottom.  I came with a large party (8 people).  We sat outside and were nice and comfy.  Everyone ordered drinks and apps.
