Everyone got theirs, but me.  I reminded the waitress about my wine and olives, and was served shortly after.  Then we all ordered pizza's.  Everyone else's came, but not mine.  I waited patiently, and then one of the guys in our party went inside to get the waitress, and my pizza finally came after everyone was already done eating.  The food was decent, but my pizza was made in a rush, and I'm not sure that it accurately reflects their product.  I was underwhelmed.  My wine was comped, but really, the pizza should have been as well.  I probably won't go back.
author: Lauren M.

description: another nice restaurant serving local sustainable organic cuisine.
author: Fzarond K.

description: Had delicious pizza and salad here while back. Looking forward to taking a friend there real soon.
author: Julie K.

description: My new fav pizza joint in town!   Really small and sometimes cramped, but worth it for the pizzas alone -- they are light, fresh, crispy and full of interesting toppings.  Thumbs up!
author: Anthony S.

description: This is a great little restaurant/coffee bar. If I'm craving pizza, this is my default thin crust restaurant. I also like their soups and salads. They change on a weekly basis, but I haven't had a salad I don't like from this place.
author: Melinda K.

description: Love this place!  Sad I'm not closer ;(  The lattes are made by skillful baristas that have the perfect foam, color, latte leaf shape in the foam...   Really warm fun barista and customers.  I would say it rivals coffee in Italy.  Now that's some damn good coffee!
author: Laura Y.

description:
yum. and by that i mean the baristas. oh, and the coffee is excellent too. 

i'm actually not a regular coffee drinker but on my days off i sometimes like to stroll down here to get a latte or a mocha. my big beef with a lot of coffee is that they tend be bitter or don't have much complexity but the coffee here is tasty and smooth. plus, they use good chocolate in their mochas; recchiuti, i think.

the service can be a little slow but i don't mind waiting since, like i said before, i usually just come here on my days off. the baristas, contrary to what some have said in their reviews for the restaurant, have always been friendly to me. the two that i see most often are brian and another guy whose name i have yet to learn but who looks like a younger, better-looking willem defoe.

yay piccino!
author: stykkisholmur t.

description: It's the best coffee in the city and the people who work there are really really nice. Highly recommended
author: alexandra t.

description: Great neighborhood place with friendly service and seasonal food. 2nd best pizza in the city!
author: Lily C.

description: Best pizza I have had in a long time - I had the Neopolata - tomato sauce, anchovies and black olives. The flavors balanced very nicely and the crust was crispy and thin. Yum...
author: Elizabeth P.

description: My boyfriend and I frickin' love this place.  I love the small, intimate atmosphere (I think the restaurant can maybe seat 15 people).  All the food is delicious, but I especially like one of their special pizzas with a fried egg on top.  I know, sounds weird, but it's really good.  The desserts are always a good time too.  I think last time we went we had an apple cake.  Yum!  They serve blue bottle coffee which is always a nice way to end a meal.
author: Tory Q.

description: I can't tell you how lucky I feel to have Piccino in the same neighborhood as my offices. In fact, it is only a short block away for me to go and enjoy one of the  best lattes in the city. Deliciously brewed Blue Bottle coffee convinces me again and again that yes...it is that good. Piccino is tiny and ridiculously charming and they back all of that up with their tasty food and perfect coffee. I am a big fan of the salads and pizzas and this morning I became a believer in their morning frittatas. It has definitely gotten me through some long days in the office and is a great standard for the newest and most favorite up and coming neighborhood in the city.
author: Sugey G.

description:
Any place that's one block away from the SF chapter of the Hell's Angels is okay in my book.  

They make great salads, nice pizzas, and have a great little wine list.  Kermit Lynch would approve.  Oh, and Blue Bottle Coffee made on a beautiful La Marzocco espresso machine (someone needs to teach the chick pulling my shot wtf is up, however).  Service?  Unbelievably friendly if a bit slow and forgetful.  The place is called Piccino after all ;)

Warm Sunday...ahem...I mean Saturday...and I'm there.

Amen!
author: daily r.

description: Great food and wonderful owner and staff. This place has a nice neighborhood feeling.
author: Dana C.

description: Superb coffee but WAY overpriced.  The pastries are too expensive, the coffee is too expensive.  I feel like I'm back in Paris spending 5 Euro for a cappuccino.  I'm sure there will be claims that it's premium coffee and premium pastry.  I say whatever.  I mean look at the Genevieve's review on 12/30.  2 coffees and 2 pastry for $15+.  Am I the only one that's outraged?
author: P C.

description: piccino is bomb. everything is made fresh in house every morning. except Mondays, they're not open. Home-made yogurt and granola, biscotti and pastries--  an over easy egg sitting on top of a pizza next to a Mimosa for brunch. ,and   for dinner duck confit and nettle soup.  yes blue bottle coffee is also available. its sooo good.  i eat here 5 days a week.   the menu changes all the time so by the time you read this its prolly changed.   eat more pizza. ok?
author: Brian D.

description: The best granola and yogurt in san francisco. hands down. for sure.
author: Ariel C.

description: Hope you are not in a hurry! I love this place- the food is excellent and simple. Portions are small, but the flavors are fresh and delicious. Service is slow and friendly. Make sure that you have time for a leisurely lunch because I have never been able to get out of there within an hour.
author: Rosie M.

description: Greatest thin pizza ever!  Perfect neighborhood experience.  Staff is so down to earth and knowledgeable.  Because everything is handmade though, sometimes wait can be a little longer than usual but maybe that's because I'm always starving and over anxious for my meal whenever I go.  Yummy blue bottle coffee too!
author: Amy D.

description:
I really like my neighborhood coffee bar. Excellent espresso and pastries.

My only suggestion would be to please make the espresso's a bit faster. I know... it's an art and you can't rush it but I know that it can be done quicker and still be awesome.

I've gotten to the point where I won't bother if there's more than two people in line in front of me.
author: Jeremiah M.

description: I am holding out 5 stars for the pizza I haven't run into yet.  The two closest to perfect pies that I have eaten are from Il Fornaio and Piccino.  They are quite similar with beautiful thin crusts and as simple as you like.  I.I. the Margherita.
author: rick l.

description: Great pizza and very relaxed service.  As others have mentioned it is a bit cramped inside, but you're not going to Piccino for a fine dining experience.  Highly recommend getting egg on your pizza. Bottom line is great pizza, great staff and you can get blue bottle coffee.
author: Nate H.

description:
this place is, simply put, brilliant. i have been here many times and is always the same. it's perfect in every way; food, freshness, variety, decor, ambiance, wine, coffee, sweets, service, location, value for money, personality, etc. the specials are psycho and there is nothing bad on this menu. period. everyone who works here is sweet, kind, and helpful.  

anyone who doesn't fully appreciate piccino doesn't know what the hell they're talking about.
author: Casey H.

description:
The coffee here is, in my opinion, great! All three of the baristas have been really friendly. But the best part is the little works of art that they make in the top of the latte foam. I've gotten hearts, flowers and trees. 

Coffee service can be slow here, but the company is friendly so it's worth the (usually short) wait. The coffee can also be not that hot so if you do like it hot, make sure to ask.

The pastries are excellent too, especially the coffee grounds and fig (or was it date) muffin and the ginger scone
author: Bill M.

description: Went here on a whim with friends who have 4 month old twins. They were VERY accommodating, and made sure the 6 of us had a nice corner table. Yes, the place is small and very busy, but the food was fantastic. The salad w/ Buddha's Hand Citron was quite lovely, and the pizza was some of the best thin crust I've had in a long time. No beer on tap, but the Steelhead Stout in a bottle was cool with me, and the Mrs. enjoyed the Prosecco. A Blue Bottle coffee and chocolate brownie made for a perfect dessert. Me thinks we shall return.
author: Raymond A.

description: Serving Piccino Blue Bottle Coffee! Now I can get coffee early in the morning. Open at 7a.m to 6ish?
author: Elle C.

description: Small portions with tiny shreds of meat. The staff ignored us so much that I had to ask for a plate four separate times. Restaurant was virtually empty when we were ignored. The food was of good quality but did not match the prices.
author: Derek B.

description:
I've been to Piccino three times since it opened, making the trek from Sunnyvale for this delectable, beautiful comfort food. The soups are thick, tasty, and subtly flavored. The salads are perfectly dressed. The pizzas are inventive, crisp, and leave you wanting to try every one. And the panini are to die for. 

Not only that, but the artful, heavenly Blue Bottle lattes made by master barrista Brian have turned me from a tea drinker into an espresso drinker -- but only at Piccino! 

Having said all this, some who know might say I'm slightly prejudiced, since Sher (co-owner with Margherita) is my sister-in-law, and that's probably the case. Every word about the food is true, though. And Sher is one little sweetie pie, and makes the Piccino experience just that much better. She and Margherita are the dynamic duo.
Go there -- often!
author: Jill D.

description:
My little Dog Patch neighborhood needs more places like this. The place has great pizza's; fresh, simple and delicious. The first time the hubs and I tried out the place was one of those nights where we didn't have a thing in the house to eat and it was sort of a last minute decision to finally try this place out rather than just ordering delivery, so we headed to this corner spot. When we first got there they were extremely busy, the place was packed. The place is small, very small. We were ignored for a bit and when someone finally greeted us she told us it would only be a few minutes (which I found strange, because it didn't appear as anyone was going to be leaving anytime soon). It was also a cold night so sitting outside was not an option. And then another couple came in after us and got the next table? Well, apparently they called ahead of time, whatever. 20 min later we were seated. So unfortunately, things did not start off all that good, but when we did get seated our waitress apologized and she was very friendly. The hubs and I split everything and we ended up having a great salad, fresh and oh so good gnocchi (I can't remember the exact details of them, but they where little pieces of heaven) a pizza, and a piece of olive oil cake. We also ordered a couple of glasses in wine. All very good! We have been back to sample some more of pizza's and they have all been great. I have also ordered the pizza's to go. I haven't tried many of the coffee drinks, one latte and it was good. Also the menu appears to change, always fun to see what they will be serving next.

As noted the place is small and I think they are still trying to figure things out. Last time I was there they still didn't except credit cards, so the couple times I have been back I have been prepared with cash. Hopefully, they take credit cards now. 

Great having you in the neighborhood. Thanks Piccino!
author: Angela B.

description: Went for dinner for the first time. We had a great time. Place is tiny and the seating was cramped. I would sit outside next time. The panzella salad w. Tuna was excellent. We had the sausage pizza which was also good and finished with a olive oil cake. That was the first time I have ever had an olive oil cake and I would definitely order it again. We will be back for sure. Get there early if you don't want to wait.
author: Phill and Molly O.

description: Good coffee, decent service.  Too expensive keeps it from being 4 stars.
author: The P.

description:
coffee doesn't like me, so it puts me to sleep every time i try it.  but DAMN is this coffee good. well, the magic is in the Blue Bottle beans. 

now i think of it, i don't like chocolate either. i should hate this little place.  but their little chocolate madelines are insane!! its dense, moist, not too sweet...don't know how they do it but its like they combined bread with chocolate. man its some good stuff
author: Alex C.

description:
i have avoided writing a yelp review until now. the experience i had at piccino pushed me over the edge to the point of finally making this a necessity. 

went for the first time a few weeks ago. looked super cute. looks are not everything my friends. like others have mentioned, the staff was earnest, but completely inefficient. after being seated, we waited for 45 minutes just for our appetizers. my friends got their pizzas another half hour after the appetizers, but the salad i ordered... never came. 15 minutes through everyones pizzas i kindly (sort of) told the waitress that i had ordered a salad, but not to mother anymore. at this point we had been there for 2 hours. they at least had the sense to comp our wine as an appology for the poor service.

my boyfriend and i made the mistake of of going back because it was convenient, and the first time the people i was with KIND OF enjoyed their pizzas. awful awful decision.

we went for the outdoor seating. i ordered a spinach salad with nectarines and blue cheese. he ordered the red pizza with broccoli, shaved pecorino, olives, and capers.

the salad was a disappointment. in a season when lovely ripe nectarines are practically falling off the tree, just DONT put completely hard flavorless nectarines on your allegedly gourmet salad. if you inexplicably cant pull through on a ripe nectarine, TAKE IT OFF THE DAMN MENU. 

my bfs pizzas was an utter disgrace. it was tomato paste shlorped atop some bread with yellow broccoli. a couple tiny slivers of cheese, a few capers, no olives. he took 2 bites and had it sent back. he told me he wouldve more enjoyed putting some cheap cheddar on a tortilla and slapping it in the microwave.

when we left, we heard the waitress appologizing to another group of people and offering substitutions. i felt bad for her.

also, the menu is simply not good.

the only star-worthy aspect of the experience was the whole outdoor wine sipping thing. 

go to pizetta 211 for the experience that piccino is wishing to provide.
or go down the street to serpentine for a good meal in the area.
author: annie d.

description: The perfect way to start each day.  An amazing mocha and wonderfully friendly baristas (especially Brian).  Couldn't be better.
author: Tamara H.

description: I haven't even had the pizza yet, and this postage stamp of a restaurant is my new favorite in the Dogpatch/Potrero Hill metro area.  I've walked past many times and salivated over their vibrant salads and delicate-looking pies.  I recently had a chance to stop in.  I'm generally a sucker for the small, food-geek format of restaurant.  And Piccino delivers.  I always consider it a good sign when I'm impressed by salad (in this case, a spinach salad with shaved sunchokes, parmesan, truffled gremolata, and a perfect walnut vinaigrette).  We also had the pork & beef polpette, a wonderful white bean soup, and the daily entree, which was a milk-braised pork tender enough to eat with a spoon.  I would say that the seasoning tends to be on the restrained side, presumably to highlight the outstanding ingredients.  Anyone who would call this "overpriced" is either not paying attention, or nuts.  Highly recommended.
author: Ben R.

description: I am not a fancy-portion (re: way too small for the money) diner. That's the type of eatery this is. So, if you've got an appetite, don't bother. You'll leave hungry or be hungry again faster than if you ate Chinese food. Plus, I can't say anything good about the service because it was virtually non-existent. It took over an hour to be in and out for lunch. My friend and I split a pizza, which was good, but took forever, and a "sandwich." This word is in quotes because I am only familiar with the traditional two pieces of bread with stuff in between sort of sandwich. What passes for a sandwich here is two small as hell pieces of sourdough bread toasted too crisp with a very meager portion of stuff. And it was served open-faced, but not because it had too much stuff on each piece to close it into a proper sandwich. I suspect that they believe the "sandwich" looks bigger served this way. I freelance a block away from here and would have given it a second chance if I didn't mind overpaying for ambience and leaving hungry.
author: K H.

description: When food is this good, I find most other things forgivable. I have not had the pizza yet, but we did pop in for a Sunday morning breakfast. Every single thing we ate was more delicious than the next. Homemade yogurt with honey and marmelade, foccacia, frittata, grapefruit avocado salad. But, what is still a lasting impression on my brain, is that I have not had a cappucino that tasted this good since I was sitting in a cafe' in Italy. Truly, they have mastered it and I didn't think it was possible (btw, I NEVER order cappucinos in the US). They just opened, give them a break if the service is not yet impeccable. I found it priced right. Cannot wait to go back...
author: Stephanie P.

description: Awesome brunch/lunch place! Went with the girls on Sunday and we loved it. There were 5 of us around noon and we had no trouble getting a table, which was nice, since so many brunch places on the weekend have a massive wait. Service is spotty - we had to send back a coffee because it was cold, and then a soup because it was cold, and we ended up grabbing the small plates we'd requested, as well as sugar cubes for our coffees. But somehow I liked it anyway. They have Blue Bottle Coffee which was delish of course. We shared a few salads and a couple of pizzas. The salads were perfect, one had goat cheese and beets, and the other had ricotta and a lemony dressing. Both tasted really fresh and really refreshing. We got 2 of the beets salad and it was a major hit. We also liked our pizzas a lot. We got the Salciccia (sausage, mozzarella & cipolline onions) and a special of the day, which was a white pizza with asparagus and egg. One thing though, if you have anyone with special food needs, like that doesn't do gluten, that kind of thing, this one could be tough, since it's a pretty small menu. Otherwise - super good! Highly recommended!
author: Sarah R.

description: I feel sort of like a cad only giving this place three stars. I wanted to love it.  The staff was super friendly. The atmosphere was warm and welcoming.  The outside tables and carafes of wine give it a european cafe feel.  But frankly our pizzas were pretty mediocre.  I would definitely give it another try . . .
author: Fallon C.

description: sorry to say this, but after reading the yelp reviews and the review in the chron, i think this place is overrated - the pizzas were decent but nothing spectacular - you know you can make your own with 99 cent pizza dough from trader joe's and a $20 pizza stone from bed bath and beyond?
author: Lisa M.

description: My first time experience in Dogpatch was very positive because of the great lunch I had at Piccino. The caprese salad was served with fresh heirloom tomatoes. The pepperone pizza was tasty - very thin crust and wonderful sauce. I also liked that they included a pitcher of water on the table. Service was great - responsive and friendly. Can't wait to go back and try their coffee!
author: Mat J.

description: This is a pleasant little cafe with nice thin crust pizza.  The crust itself is excellent but the toppings seemed a little dull to me.  This is a nice neighborhood place but I don't think the pizzas rank with Delfina or Berreta.  I will give them props for have a nice (though short) selection of wine available by the glass and 1/2 litre.
author: Peter H.

description: Great atmosphere; efficient friendly service. The pepperoni pizza was fantastic. The sauce wan't too sweet and had a nice tomato flavor. The poached pears with a ginger bundt cake for dessert was oustanding. Dense cake, perfectly textured pears - light and tasty. I'll be back...it's a great find.
author: J P S.

description: one of my favorite brunch destinations, especially on a lazy sunday when you want honest, soulful, rustic food, coffee, and pastries. charming neighborhood vibe, excellent pizzas, and some non-pizza menu items that have never disappointed. small and cozy. whomever is the mastermind behind the pizza oven is incredibly talented.
author: jennifer y.

description: Yes, the coffee is great.  But do they have to be so snobby about it?  I went in to get a double espresso to go, because I wanted to make coffee ice cream.  But they refused to pour the espresso into a to-go cup, because they "don't like the way it tastes."  I appreciate that they have a discerning palate, but I don't like being dictated to about how to take my coffee.  I just wanted to make some ice cream, can you work with me people?
author: K S.

description: A little gem.  The Pizza is Great.  Just a gem.  Had the soup and a pizza, glass of wine, Done.  Just what you expect from a little whole in the wall.  Granted went on a weekday after lunch...almost no one in there, but it was just what the doctor ordered.  WIll be back, when I can.
author: Paul M.

description: This is my favorite little neighborhood place.  I really don't want more people to know about it because its so small and I love not having to wait for a place to sit whenever I feel like coming.  The vibe is great.  The waitstaff are terrific.  The food is fresh and local and a lot of care is put into the quality of how its made.  The changing wine list is always perfect.  The plates are creative and locally made.  I live local so whenever I have guests visit from out of town I always take them here because this is and example of everything I love about San Francisco - delicious, original, laid back and proud of it.  If you want a quiet romantic place for two that's off the beaten path this is the place to go.
author: Natalie B.

description:
next door to the couch i surfed after coming back to the USA from Europe was Piccino, a tiny italian-style restaurant serving up orgasmic ristrettos dusted with crumbly ginger-peach shortbread scones. the supple, chocolatey hot popsicle of a blue bottle ristretto: there is nothing like it in my narrow book of experience.

 the changes in knowing are documented as follows:

1. chocolate one-two kick of something that teases emotions out of me that have no place being present at seven thirty in the morning. who has sexy time with chocolate so early?!? well, i guess, me!
2. pushhhh, pull pushhhh, slap slap roll, ding! tiny cakes and lumpy plum scones; ca-runchhhh spat slap slice, the savory-sweet focaccia served up sultry on a smashed-down clay tray designed by the restaurant owner's partner. succulent saltiness does not stand a chance for anything else you might find at a streetside cafe for breakfast.
3. sitting. waiting. talking. knowing. forgetting. staring. moments lost in reverie to the accosting of chocolate powerhouse only one inch tall. and to spend forty-five minutes between small talk and sugar crystals, what have i been staring at for the last ten minutes? why does the clock disappear from that wall? i turn around and you are gone. where did you go, clock? why, suddenly, are you the bathroom, or the glass case? is that person afraid of themselves and what they might have exposed to my staring eyes?

there is no longer such thing as a "coffee to go."

i tried going to starbucks and asking for a ristretto.

he gave me a latte.

when i said, "uh... um... a ristretto is a short espresso shot" he gave me some hot brown soup in a cup and sent me on my way.

shee-it.

all right. if by now you do not go to piccino in the morning and tell them that molly sent you, you are apparently not interested in early-morning orgasms. which is fine! personally, i prefer my sex with chocolate, but hey, to each his own.
author: Molly A.

description: Didn't I already write a nice review about this lovely place?  I could swear it did.  do they drop off after like 500 reviews?
author: Troy B.

description: 5 stars?  yes 5 stars fellow yelpers...and if you're wondering if you should give piccino a shot well what the hell have you got to lose? you can start   small and then GO LARGE.  i promise you can't go wrong with the pizzas and other specialties they provide...don't forget to try the coffee though....blue bottle rips and so does their main barista BRIAN.
author: Jaclyn L.

description: Loved the salad, soup, and pizza!  We had an early dinner with our one year old & everything was wonderful!
author: Amy F.

description: My fiance chose this place to have dinner when his parents were meeting my parents for the first time, which was last night.  Today?  Everybody is still alive, and thinks everyone else is great.  This is no small feat, and I'd like to thank Piccino from distracting us from any possibly sticky conversations with delicious pizza.  Also, when, we called them to make a reservation we told them about the situation and they sent around a prosecco toast for us.   Very cute.  Also, the place is small and intimate enough to actually hear one another talk, which was nice.
author: lesley b.

description: exquisite, well made food, friendly served.  thanks for the recommend, hil!  the only time i will dine without you there, promise!
author: tim y.

description: i believe the former owner/partner of pizzetta 211 opened this place, which would explain why the pizza dough is the same as pizzetta's.  both are very good, but sooooo thin that it's reminding me more and more of a really good saltine cracker.  the red sauce might be different, not sure, but it is delicious.  great baby gem lettuce salad.  ridiculously tiny place.  friendly owner runs the whole show, ie. takes orders, clears tables, makes the pizzas, etc...crazy, y'all.
author: Betsy K.

description: 3.5 Stars - Rounding up as the weather was perfect. An intimate place to eat that has a quaint atmosphere & nice servers. Overall, I'll be honest, I wasn't as impressed by the pizzas as I have been at other places. I did like the mushroom pizza (special). Yum! Nevertheless, still a neighborhood gem.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
i was initially gonna give it 3 stars and i don't think that's really a bad rating.  doesn't that mean it's "good" when taking into account the highest mark, denoting flawless perfection, is 5 friggin' stars?  you can't just be doling them 5 stars out wantonly now, can you?  the pizzas are good - really good sauce which sometimes seems like an afterthought at some places - but they're not always as filling as you'd like them to be.  the rest of the menu is good if not somewhat limited.  i think what threw me off was that i had really high expectations and altho the experience didn't live up to them, i'm remebering the margherita pizza w/spicy sausage which was so very tasty, the addictive crispy bread crackers that came w/my super fresh (and not at all greasy) minestrone soup, the AMAZING savory corn bread pudding, and the perfect little slice of plum and apricot tart.  oh yeah, and bluebottle coffee, it's so terrific and wonderful blahblahblahblah (it IS pretty damn good i'll admit).  good selection of beer and wine too.

...and one more thing, it was a fairly slow saturday when we went but there were enough people there to keep the ONE barista/server/cashier person really busy, but she was such a trouper and was always really pleasant and managed to get all our drink and food orders right.  

so there you have it.  4 stars.  i play nice!
author: Bird B.

description: I love this place, even more now that they have opened up a separate coffee bar a few doors down.  First, it's on my side of Po' Hill, making it perfect for that Sunday morning stumble to get Blue Bottle Coffee (aka nectar of the gods).  Second, the folks who run the joint are so nice; very refreshing after the 'tude you get at Farley's and most other coffee joints.  I'd give 5 stars, but the scones are crazy price-y (although they are really good).
author: M D.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee. Yummy as a hand prepared drip or grab an espresso. On par with Ritual.
author: Cynthia s.

description: i would give this place more stars if the food would actually fill me up. . . and i'm a chick! deeelicious thin crust pizzas, great seasonal salads, and amazing savory bread puddings. the cookies are ok. . . i love to bake and i would have to say my cookies are contenders! small portions so i end up spending twice as much as i would to get my fill. . . and you should see my bf--he's 6'4, 240!
author: mary c.

description: Love this place.  Pizza is deliciously simple.  Staff super friendly, Latte's are some of the best in the city, pastries in the morning are outstanding.    One downside is they don't have a highchair for my toddler who loves their pizza, so I bring my portable  one and sit outside.  One of my favorite places in dogpatch.
author: PHill Resident G.

description: piccino is a very quaint and delicious italian restaurant/cafe. what first allured me was the blue bottle coffee counter inside, and the dogpatch location is convenient for me, but perhaps not for most.  what sold me was the amazing food- thin and light pizzas, many "white" or without sauce (which is how i prefer them) with toppings like roasted fennel and goat cheese or lemon and broccoli rabe. they are also beautiful to look at. I had a lamb pizza here once that was perhaps the best pizza i've ever had. and spectacular paninis made perfectly simple with ingredients like cabot cheddar. for dinner they carry other entrees like duck confit. the salads are always really great as well and they have an excellent lemon tart. piccino also supports local organic food so their menu changes frequently reflecting thriving vegetables of the season. and everything is served on these charming artful but very raw-looking ceramic dishes crafted by one of the owner's husband. i always enjoy examining every new one i get and admiring their semi-comical honesty. if you've ever torn slabs in ceramics, you'll know what i'm talking about. piccino is small but the wait is never very long (you can catch a drink at the wine bar around the corner) and the outside seating is plentiful- and who wouldn't rather eat outside? i would imagine the acquisition of their new heat lamps will better facilitate more outdoor seating throughout the less desirable temperature periods.
author: little gem z.

description: Good thin crust Euro pizza.  Lemon tart and cookie plate was good too.
author: Rob P.

description: Delicious pizzas and perfect coffee drinks make this place a San Francisco gem.  You can enjoy it all at one of the outdoor tables on the sidewalk too.  Go now.  You'll like it.
author: Adam P.

description: I love this place! The pizzas are deelish and creative (the cauliflower, lemon, and anchovy is great....really!), the folks are super friendly, and the whole vibe is very community oriented---which I love since I can walk there. It's the perfect place to order up a smattering of different things for lunch with a group, get a bottle of wine mid-day, and pretend you have all the time in the world.
author: Kathleen D.

description: Trendy looking, weak pizza. Crust was the good part, super thin and crisp. On top of that was thin canned sauce, almost like catsup. On the margherita pizza there were little slices of mozzerella and (gasp!) dried basil. For a $10 pie, I say boo!
author: evan a.

description: I will only give 2 stars because the coffee is good. The portions are tiny, and way over priced. I was still hungry after a pizza and salad. Everything tasted okay, but it was like only 2 bites! I will only go back for the coffee.
author: NIcole N.

description: I love the food -- wild nettle pizza for dinner with a salad of arugula and the first strawberries of the season. Even just a quick breakfast -- ginger scones and the perfect cup of coffee -- starts the day on a good note. But even more than the food I love the welcome here. It's a rare restaurant that makes you feel at home (even sitting at a cafe table on the sidewalk), but Piccino is so cozy, intimate and warm that it's a pleasure just to walk up to the front door. I love how the waitstaff brings you thick blankets when the fog begins to roll up from the water.
author: Ann S.

description: The blue bottle espresso here is the best I've had in the whole damed city!  The espresso is so complex, not bitter at all. Wow!  It redefines what espresso can be!
author: Benny B.

description: This place has absolutely delicious thin-crust pizza!  Our party of three enjoyed them so much we ordered a fourth!    Friendly team service and good value wine list.  Remarkable little neighborhood spot that's worth a cross-town visit.  Only drawback: very limited seating space.
author: David M.
